editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Myles Couerdale vnto the Chri≈øtian Reader, mo≈øte hartelye wy≈øheth the continuall encrea≈øe of heauenlye ta≈øte and ≈øpirituall ≈øwetne≈ø≈øe, in the ≈øame a≈ø≈øured ≈øaluation which commeth onely through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.
div.p: THe more nigh that mens wordes & workes approch vnto ye mo≈øt whole≈øome ≈øayinges & fruitful doings of ye old auncient Saincts & cho≈øeÃÑ childreÃÑ of god (which loued not only to heare his word, but al≈øo to liue therafter) the more worthy are they to be e≈øtemed, embraced, & followed. And therfore as we heare & read of many godly, both meÃÑ & wemen, who≈øe coÃÑuer≈øatioÃÑ in old time was beautifyed wt ≈øyngular giftes of ye holy gho≈øt (according as ye Apo≈øtle de≈øcribeth theÃÑ in the .xi. chap. to ye Hebrues) ≈øo haue we iu≈øt cau≈øe to reioyce, that we haue bene familiar & acquainted wt ≈øome of tho≈øe, which walked in ye trade of their fote≈øteppes. For ye which cau≈øe, it doth vs good to read and heare, not the lying legendes of fayned, fal≈øe, counterfayted, and popi≈øh canonized ≈øaincts, neither ye triflyng toyes & forged fables of corrupted writers: but ≈øuch true, holy, & approued hi≈øtories, monuments, orations, epi≈øtles & letters, as do ≈øet forth vnto vs ye ble≈ø≈øed behauiour of gods deare ≈øeruauÃÑtes. It doth vs good (I ≈øay) by ≈øuch comfortable remeÃÑbraunce, conceaued by their notable writinges, to be conuer≈øaunt with them, at the lea≈øt in ≈øpirite.

S. Hierome, writing to one Nitia, and hauyng occa≈øion to ≈øpeake of letters or epy≈øtles, maketh mention of a certayne Authour named Turpilius, who≈øe woordes,
(≈øayeth he) are the≈øe: a letter or epi≈øtle, is the thyng alone yt maketh men pre≈øent which are ab≈øent. For among tho≈øe that are ab≈øent, what is ≈øo pre≈øente, as to heare and talke with tho≈øe whom thou loue≈øt? Al≈øo, that noble Clarke Era≈ømus Roterodame, coÃÑmendyng the booke of the Epi≈øtles or letters which S. Augu≈øtine dyd write, ≈øayeth thus: by ≈øome of Augu≈øtines bokes we may perceaue, what maner of man he was being an infant in Chri≈øt. By other ≈øome, we may knowe what maner a one he was being a young man, and what he was being an olde man. But by thys onely booke (meaning the booke of the Epi≈øtles or letters) thou ≈øhalt knowe whole Augu≈øtyne altogether. And why doth S. Hierome or Era≈ømus ≈øaye thus? No doubt, euen becau≈øe that in ≈øuch writynges, as in a cleare gla≈ø≈øe, we maye ≈øee and beholde, not onely what plentifull furniture and ≈øtore of heauenly grace, wi≈øedome, knowledge, vnder≈øtanding, fayth, loue, hope, zeale, pacience, mekenes, obedience, with the worthy fruites thereof, almighty god had be≈øtowed vpon the ≈øame his mo≈øt deare children: but al≈øo what a fatherlye care he euer hadde vnto them: how his mightye hand defended them: howe hys prouidence kept watch and warde ouer them: howe hys louyng eye loked vnto them: howe hys gracious eare heard their prayers: how he was alwaye myndfull of them, neuer forgat them, neither fayled them, nor for≈øoke them: how the armes of his mercye were ≈øtreytched oute to embrace them, when ≈øoeuer they faythfullye tourned vnto hym: howe valiaunte al≈øo and ≈øtronge in ≈øpirite, howe ioyfull vnder the cro≈ø≈øe, howe quyet and cheerefull in trouble he made them: what victorye of their enemyes, what deliueraunce oute of bondes and captiuitie, what health from ≈øicknes, what recouerye from plagues, what plentye from ≈øcarcene≈ø≈øe: to bee ≈øhorte, what helpe at all nede and nece≈ø≈øity he gaue and be≈øtowed vpon them.

By ≈øuch lyke mounmentes al≈øo and writynges, it is manife≈øt and playne, how the ≈øame deare children of God in their time behaued them≈øelues, a≈øwel towards hym, as al≈øo towardes their frendes and foes: yea what the verye thoughts of their hartes were, when they prayed (as their maner was ince≈ø≈øantlye to doe) when they confe≈ø≈øed their ≈øinnes, & complained vnto god: when they gaue thankes: when they were per≈øecuted and troubled: when they were by the hand of god vi≈øited: when they felte, not onelye the horrour of death, the griefe of ≈øynne, & the burthen of gods di≈øplea≈øure by rea≈øon of the ≈øame: but al≈øo the ≈øwete ta≈øt of hys great mercy & eternal comfort through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, in theyr con≈øcience. Of the which thinges, lyke as we may euidently perceiue rich and plentiful experience in the heaueÃÑly trea≈øurie of that mo≈øt excelleÃÑt boke which we coÃÑmonly cal Dauids P≈øalter: ≈øo hath not god nowe in our days, left hym≈øelfe without witne≈ø≈øes: yea no more, then he dyd in other ages before vs: but of his aboundante goodnes, euen when the late per≈øecutioÃÑ was mo≈øt cruel, and the enemies rage mo≈øt extreme, he hath rai≈øed vp ≈øuch zelous men & women as (by the wonderful operation of hys holy ≈øpirit) of weake were made ≈øo valeant & ≈øtrong in him (a≈øwel again≈øt all idolatry, ≈øuper≈øtitioÃÑ, fal≈øe doctrine and corrupted religion, as again≈øt their own old blemi≈øhes & ≈øinnes) that they haue turned to flight, and coÃÑfounded the whole rable of ≈øuche malicious papi≈øts, as were the per≈øecutors and murtherers of them.

Wherby they that li≈øt not ≈øtil to be blind, may plainlye behold and ≈øee, not onely the terrible iudgementes of God ouer & again≈øt the wicked, but al≈øo his wonderful doinges mixt wit mercy in and towardes hys cho≈øen: vnto whom, as vnto them that loue him, he cau≈øeth al things to worke for the be≈øt. So that with him, by the heaueÃÑly light of ≈øtedfa≈øt faith, they ≈øee lyfe euen in death: wt him, euen in heauines
& ≈øorrow, they faile not of ioy & comfort: wyth hym euen in pouerty, affliction and trouble, they neither peri≈øh nor are for≈øaken. How els could they be ≈øo patieÃÑt, ≈øo quiet of minde, ≈øo cherefull and merye in aduer≈øitie and ≈øtraite captiuitie: ≈øome beyng throwne into dungeons, vg≈øome holes, darke, lothe≈øome and ≈øtinking corners: other ≈øome lying in fetters and chaynes, and loaded wyth ≈øo many irons that they could ≈øcarcely ≈øtyrre: ≈øome tied in the ≈øtocks wyth their heeles vpwarde: ≈øome hauyng their legges in the ≈øtockes & their neckes chayned to the walle wyth gorgets of iron: ≈øome both handes and legges in the ≈øtockes at once: ≈øometimes both hands in, and both legges out: ≈øometimes ye right hand with the left leg, or the left hand with the right legge fa≈øtened in the ≈øtockes wyth manicles and fetters, hauyng neither ≈øtoole nor ≈øtone to ≈øitte on, to ea≈øe their wofull bodies withall:The≈øe engines are called Skeuingtons giues, the forme & maner wherof you ≈øhall ≈øee in the boke of Martyrs. Fol. 1651. ≈øome ≈øtanding in mo≈øt painful engines of iron with their bodies doubled: ≈øome whypped & ≈øcourged, beateÃÑ with roddes, & buffeted with fi≈øtes: ≈øome hauing their handes burned with a caÃÑdel to trie their patience, or force theÃÑ to relente: ≈øome hunger pyned & mo≈øt mi≈øerably fami≈øhed. Al the≈øe torments & many moe, eueÃÑ ≈øuch as cruel Phalaris could not deui≈øe wor≈øe,If the≈øe vnmerciful mon≈øters had the reward of their tiranny that Phalarts had, yet ≈øhuld they not haue ≈øo muche as they haue iu≈øtly de≈øerued. wer practi≈øed by the papi≈øts, the ≈øtout ≈øturdy ≈øouldiours of Satan, thus delityng in variety of tiranny and torments, vpon ye Saints of god, as it is ful wel & too well knowen, & as many can te≈øtify which are yet aliue, and haue felte ≈øome ≈ømart therof. Yea & furthermore, ≈øo extremely were the≈øe deare ≈øeruantes of god delt withal, that although they were mo≈øte de≈øirous by their pen and writing, to edify their brethren, other poore lambes of Chri≈øt, & one to comfort an other in him, yet were they ≈øo narowly watched and ≈øtraitly kepte from al nece≈ø≈øary helpes, as paper, inke, bokes & ≈øuch lyke, that great maruail it is how they could be able to write any one of the≈øe or other ≈øo excellent & worthy letters. For
≈øo hardly were they v≈øed (as I ≈øaid afore) for ye mo≈øt part yt they could not end their letters begon:Notwith≈øtandyng al this cruel dealyng, they wrote verye manye worthy and fruitfull letters moe: wherof ≈øundry are mentioned in this boke which ≈øhall God willing, be publi≈øhed hereafter, if they in who≈øe handes they remaine, wil bring them to light. ≈øometime for lacke of ea≈øe, being ≈øo fettered with chaines, & otherwi≈øe handled as you haue heard: ≈øometime for lacke of light, when they could neither ≈øee to write wel, nor to reade their letters again: & ≈øomtyme through ye ha≈øty coÃÑming in of ye kepers or officers, who left no corner nor bed≈øtraw vn≈øearched: yea ≈øomtime they were put to ≈øo hard ≈øhiftes, that lyke as for lacke of pennes they were fayne to write with ye lead of ye windowes: ≈øo for want of inke they toke their own blood, (as yet it remaineth to be ≈øene) and yet ≈øomtime they were faine to teare & rent what they had writteÃÑ at the ha≈øty coÃÑ ming in of ye officers.

Thus, thus vnkindly, thus churli≈øhly, thus cruelly & vnnaturally were eueÃÑ they entreated & handled, who≈øe mo≈øt notable & godly writings are here ≈øet forth in thys booke. For ye which, & ≈øuch other monumeÃÑts, great cau≈øe haue we to prai≈øe god: which he him≈øelf hath pre≈øerued & broughte to light, no dout by his ≈øiÃÑguler great prouideÃÑce, yt herby we beiÃÑg taught to haue his mighty mercy & merciful working ye more in reuereÃÑt & thaÃÑkful regard, might not onely con≈øider what heaueÃÑly ≈øtreÃÑgth & rich po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øioÃÑ of coÃÑ≈øtant faythe, of ardent zeale, of quiet patience, of peace & ioy in the holy gho≈øt, he v≈øeth to arme theÃÑ, yt can find in their harts to abhor al vngodlines both of doctrine & life: but al≈øo to ioine wt theÃÑ our ≈øelues in ≈øuch ≈øort, that loking to Ie≈øus our captain, abiding ye cro≈ø≈øe & de≈øpi≈øing ye ≈øhame, as they did for ye ioy yt was ≈øet before theÃÑ, may wt much quietnes of a good con≈øcieÃÑce, end this our ≈øhort cour≈øe, to his glory, to ye edifyeng of his church, to ye coÃÑfu≈øion of Satan, to ye hinderaunce of al fal≈øe doctrine, & to our own eternal coÃÑfort in the ≈øame our lord & alone Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. To whoÃÑ wyth the father and ye holy gho≈øt be all honour, al glory, al thankes and all prai≈øe, world without ende. Amen.

Certayne godly and fruitfull letters of D. Cranmer late Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, who fir≈øt being impri≈øoned in the Tower of London, and afterward in Oxford, was there cruelly burnt for the true te≈øtimony of Chri≈øtes go≈øpel, in the yeare of our Lorde, 1556. the 16. daye of Februarye.
Thomas Cranmer Archbi≈øhop of Caunterbury to Quene Mary.
div.p:
MO≈øt lamentably mourning & moning him≈øelf vnto your highnes Thomas CraÃÑ mer, although vnworthy either to write or ≈øpeake vnto your highnes, yet hauing no per≈øoÃÑ that I know, to be mediatour for me, and knowing your pitifull eares ready to heare al pitiful complaintes, and ≈øeing ≈øo many before to haue felte your aboundaunt clemency in like ca≈øe:He de≈øired to be relea≈øed of his offence for con≈øentyng vnto kyng Edwardes wyll and ≈øo he was, but after was accu≈øed of here≈øy, which he be≈øt liked for then he knewe hys cau≈øe was chri≈øtes. am now con≈øtrained mo≈øt lamentably and with mo≈øt penitent and ≈øorowfull heart, to a≈øke mercy and pardon for my haynous folly and offence, in con≈øenting and folowyng the Te≈øtameÃÑt and la≈øt will of our late ≈øoueraigne Lord king Edward the ≈øyxt your graces brother, which will god knoweth, God he knoweth I neuer liked, nor neuer any thing greued me ≈øo much that your graces brother did, and if by any meanes it had bene in me to haue letted the makyng of that will, I would haue done it, and what I ≈øaid therin, as well to his coun≈øell, as to him≈øelfe, diuers of your Maie≈øties coun≈øell can report, but none ≈øo wel as the Marques of NorthhaÃÑpton,
and the Lord Darcy then Lord Chamberlayne to the kynges Maie≈øty, which two were pre≈øent at the communication betwene the Kynges Maie≈øtye and me. I de≈øired to talke with the kings maie≈øty alone, but I could not be ≈øuffered, and ≈øo I fayled of my purpo≈øe, for yf I might haue commoned with the king alone, & at good lea≈øure, my tru≈øt was that I ≈øhuld haue altered hym from that purpo≈øe, but they being pre≈øent, my labour was in vayne. Then when I could not di≈ø≈øwade him from the ≈øaid wyll, and both he and his priuy coun≈øell al≈øo enformed me that the Iudges & his learned coun≈øell ≈øayde, that the acte of entayling the crowne made by his Father, coulde not be preiudiciall to him, but that he being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øioÃÑ of the crowne, might make his wil therof, this ≈øemed very ≈øtraung vnto me, but being the ≈øentence of the Iudges and other his learned coun≈øell in the lawes of this realme (as both he and his Coun≈øel informed me) me thoughte it became not me beyng vnlearned in the law, to ≈øtaÃÑd again≈øt my prince therin, & ≈øo at leÃÑgth I was required by the kinges maie≈øty him ≈øelf to ≈øet to my haÃÑd to his wil, ≈øaying yt he tru≈øted yt I alone would not be more repugnaÃÑt to his wil, thaÃÑ the re≈øt of the couÃÑ≈øel were (which words ≈øurely greued my harte very ≈øore) and ≈øo I graunted him to ≈øub≈øcribe his will, and to follow the ≈øame, whiche when I had ≈øet my hande vnto, I did it vnfainedly and withoute di≈ø≈øimulation. For the which I ≈øubmit my ≈øelfe mo≈øt humbly vnto your maie≈øty, acknowledging mine offence wyth mo≈øt greuous and ≈øorowfull hart, and be≈øeching your mercy and pardon, which my hart geueth me, ≈øhall not be denied vnto me, being grauÃÑted before to ≈øo many which trauailed not ≈øo much to di≈ø≈øwade both the King and his coun≈øell as I did. And where as it is contayned in two acts of parliament (as I vnder≈øtand,) that I wyth the Duke of Northumberland ≈øhould deui≈øe and compa≈ø≈øe the depriuation of your Maie≈øty from your royal crowne, ≈øurely it is vntrue, for the Duke neuer opened his mouth to me, to moue me anye ≈øuche matter, nor I hym, nor his heart was not ≈øuche towardes me, ≈øeekyng long tyme my de≈øtruction, that he woulde eyther tru≈øte me in ≈øuche a matter, or thinke that I would bee per≈øwaded by him. It was other of the Coun≈øel that moued me, and the Kynge hym≈øelfe, the Duke of NorthumberlaÃÑd not beyng pre≈øent. Neither before, neyther after,
had I euer any priuy communication wyth the duke of that matter, ≈øauyng that openly at the couÃÑ≈øel table the duke ≈øaid vnto me, that it became not me to ≈øay to the king as I dyd, when I went about to di≈ø≈øwade hym froÃÑ the ≈øayd will.

Nowe, as concernyng the e≈øtate of religion as it is v≈øed in thys Realme of England at this pre≈øente, if it plea≈øe youre highne≈ø≈øe to licence me, I woulde gladly write my minde vnto your maie≈øtye. I will neuer, God willyng, be author of ≈øedition, to moue ≈øubiectes from the obedience of their heades and rulers, whiche is an offence mo≈øte dete≈øtable. div.p:
I Wi≈øh you grace in god and loue of the truth without the which truely ≈øtabli≈øhed in mens hartes, by the mighty haÃÑd of almighty god, it is no more po≈ø≈øible to ≈øtand by the truth in Chri≈øt in time of trouble, then it is for the waxe to abide the heat of the fyre. I am per≈øuaded chri≈øts wor ‚Ä¢ es to be true: who≈øoeuer ≈øhall confe≈ø≈øe me before men, him wil I confe≈ø≈øe al≈øo before my father which is in heauen, and I beleue that no earthly creature ≈øhall be ≈øaued, whom the redemer and ≈øauiour of the world ≈øhal before his father deny. It is a goodly wi≈øh that you wi≈øh me depely to con≈øider thynges pertaynyng vnto gods glorye: but if you had wi≈øhed al≈øo ye neither feare of death, nor hope of worldly pro≈øperity ≈øhould let me to maintain gods word and his truth, which is his glory and true honour, it would haue liked me well. In dede ≈øyr, now it is tyme ≈øo to doe, for ≈øo farre as I can perceiue, it ≈øtandeth me vpon no le≈ø≈øe daunger, then of the lo≈ø≈øe both of body and ≈øoule, and I trowe then it is time for a man to awake, if any thyng will awake him. He that will not feare him that threatneth to ca≈øt both body & ≈øoule into euerla≈øting fier, Luk. 12. whom will he feare? With this feare, O Lord, fa≈øten thou together oure fraile fle≈øhe, that we neuer ≈øwarue from thy lawes. You ≈øay you haue made much ≈øuite for me. Sir God graunt that you haue not in ≈øauyng for my worldly deliueraunce, empayred and hindered the furtheraunce of Gods worde and his truthe. You haue knowen me long in dede, in the which tyme it hathe chaunced me (as you ≈øay) to mi≈ølyke ≈øome thynges. It is true, I graunt: for ≈øodayne chaunges wythout ≈øub≈øtantial and nece≈ø≈øary cau≈øe, and the heady ≈øetting forth of extremities, I did neuer loue. euen at this day. My doctrine and my preaching, you ≈øaye you haue heard often, & after your iudgement haue thought it godly, ≈øauyng onely for the Sacrament, whiche thyng although it was of me reuerently handled and a greate deale better then of ye re≈øt (as you ≈øay) yet in the margeÃÑt you write warely, and in this world wi≈øely: and yet me thoughte all ≈øounded not well. Syr, but that I ≈øee ≈øo many chaunges in thys worlde and ≈øo much alteration, els at this your ≈øaying I would not a lyttle maruayle. I haue taken you for my frend, and a man whom I fan≈øied for plaine≈ø≈øe and faith fulnes as much (I a≈ø≈øure you) as for your learnyng: and haue you kept this ≈øo clo≈øe in your hart from me vnto this day? Sir, I con≈øider mo thinges then one, and will not ≈øay al that I thynke. But what nede you to care what I think, for any thing that I ≈øhal be able to do vnto you, either good or harme? Truely ≈øir, I herein lyke your coun≈øel very wel, and by Gods grace I entend to follow it vnto my liues ende.

To write vnto tho≈øe whom you name, I cannot ≈øee what it wyll auayle me. For this I would haue you know, that I e≈øteme nothyng auailable for me, which al≈øo wil not further the glory of God. And now, becau≈øe I perceiue you haue an entire zeale and de≈øyre of my deliueraunce out of this captiuitie and worldly mi≈øery, if I ≈øhoulde not beare you a good heart in god agayne, me thynke I were to blame. Sir how nighe the daye of my di≈ø≈øolution and departure oute of thys world is at hand, I can not tel: the Lords wyll be fulfilled how ≈øoone ≈øoeuer it ≈øhall come. I know the Lordes wordes mu≈øt be verified on me, that I ≈øhall appeare before the incorrupt iudge, and be countable to him of al my former life. And although the hope of his mercye is my ≈øhooteanker of eternall ≈øaluation, yet am I per≈øwaded, that who≈øoeuer wittingly neglecteth and regardeth not to cleare his con≈øcience, he caÃÑnot haue peace with God nor a liuely fayth in his mercye. Con≈øcience therefore moueth me, con≈øideryng you were one of my familye and one of my hou≈øeholde, of whom then I thynke I had a ≈øpeciall cure, and of all them which were within my hou≈øe, whiche in dede ought to haue bene an example of godline≈ø≈øe to al the re≈øt of my cure, not only of good
lyfe, but al≈øo in promotyng of gods word to the vttermo≈øt of their power: but (alas) now when the tryal doth ≈øeparate the chaffe from the corne, how ≈ømall a deale it is, god knoweth, which the wynd doth not blowe awaye: this con≈øcience I ≈øay doth moue me to feare lea≈øt the lightnes of my family ≈øhal be layd to my charge for lack of more earne≈øt & diligent in≈øtruction which ≈øhould haue ben done. But ble≈ø≈øed be god which hath geuen me grace to ≈øee this my default and to lament it from the bottome of my heart before my departyng hence. This con≈øcience doth moue me al≈øo now to requyre both you and my frend Doctour Haruy, to remember your promi≈øes made to me in times pa≈øt, of the pure ≈øetting forth & preachyng of gods word & hys truth. The≈øe promi≈øes, although you ≈øhal not nede to fear to be charged with them of me hereafter before the world, yet loke for none other (I exhort you as my freÃÑdes) but to be charged with them at gods hand. This con≈øcience and the loue that I beare vnto you, biddeth me now ≈øay vnto you both in gods name, feare god and loue not the world: for god is able to ca≈øt both body and ≈øoule into hel fire. P≈øa. 2. When hys wrath ≈øhal ≈øodenly be kindled, ble≈ø≈øed are al they that put their tru≈øt in him. And the ≈øaieng of S. Iohn is true: Iohn. 2. al yt is in the world, as ye lu≈øt of ye fle≈øh, ye lu≈øt of the eies and the pryde of life, is not of the father, but of the world, & the world pa≈ø≈øeth away and the lu≈øt thereof, but he that doth the wyl of god abideth for euer. If this gift of grace, which vndoubtedly is nece≈ø≈øarily required vnto eternall ≈øaluation, were truely and vnfainedly graffed and firmely ≈øtabli≈øhed in mens harts, they would not be ≈øo light, ≈øo ≈øodainly to ≈øhrinke from the mainteynaunce and confe≈ø≈øion of the truth, as is now (alas) ≈øene ≈øo manife≈øtly of ≈øo many in the≈øe days. But here peradueÃÑture you would know of me what is ye truth. Syr, gods word is the truth, as ≈ø. Iohn ≈øaith, Iohn. 17. Eccl. 27 and that euen the ≈øame that was heretofore. For albeit man doth vary and chaunge as the moone, yet Gods word is ≈øtable & abideth one for euermore: and of Chri≈øt it is truly ≈øaid, Chri≈øt ye≈øterday and to day, the ≈øame is al≈øo for euer.

Heb. 13When I was in office, all that were e≈øtemed learned in gods word, agreed this to be a truth in gods word written, that the common praier of the Church ≈øhould be had in the common tongue. You know I haue conferred with manye,
& I en≈øure you I neuer found man (≈øo far as I do remember) neyther olde nor newe, Go≈øpeller nor Papi≈øt, of what iudgement ≈øo euer he was, in this thyng to be of a contrary opinion. If then it were a truth of gods worde, thinke you that the alteration of the world canne make it an vntruthe‚ñ™ If it cannot, why then doe ≈øo manye men ≈øhrinke from the confe≈ø≈øion and maintenaunce of thys truthe receyued once of vs all? For what is it I pray you els to confe≈ø≈øe or deny Chri≈øt in this world, but to maintayne the truth taught in gods word, or for any worldly re≈øpecte to ≈øhrynke from the ≈øame? For he that wil for≈øake wittingly, either for feare or gayne of the world, any one open truthe of gods word, if he be con≈øtrained, he wil a≈ø≈øuredly for≈øake god and all his truth, rather then he will endaunger him≈øelfe to lo≈øe or to leaue that he loueth better in deede then he dothe God and the truth of his word. I like very wel your playn ≈øpeaking, wherin you ≈øaye: I mu≈øt either agree or dye, and I thynke that you meane of the bodily deathe whiche is commoÃÑ both to good & bad. And bycau≈øe (I dare ≈øay) you wrote of frend≈øhip vnto me this ≈øhorte earne≈øt aduerti≈øement, and I thinke verelye wi≈øhyng me to lyue and not to die, therfore bearing you in my hearte no le≈ø≈øe loue in god than you do me in the world, Apo≈øtata was he which fled from hys captaine to the enemy. div.head: ¬∂ To my mo≈øt deare brother, and reuerend fellow Elder in Chri≈øte, Iohn Hoper, grace and peace.
div.p:
MY dearely beloued brother and fellow Elder, whoÃÑ I reuerence in the lord, pardon me I be≈øech you, that hitherto ≈øince your captiuitie and myne, I haue not ≈øaluted you by my letters: wheras, I do in deede confe≈ø≈øe, I haue receiued from you (≈øuche was your gentlenes) two letters at ≈øuÃÑdry tymes, but yet at ≈øuch times as I could not be ≈øuffred to write vnto you againe, or yf I might
haue writeÃÑ, yet was I greatly in dout, le≈øt my letters ≈øhuld not ≈øafely come vnto your haÃÑds. But now my dere brother, for as much as I vnder≈øtaÃÑd by your workes, which I haue yet but ≈øuperficially ≈øene, that we throughly agree & wholy con≈øent together in tho≈øe thynges which are the groundes, & ≈øub≈øtaÃÑtial points of our religioÃÑ, again≈øt the which ye world ≈øo furiou≈øly rageth in the≈øe our dais, how≈øoeuer in time pa≈øt in ≈ømaller matters & circuÃÑ≈øtaÃÑces of religion, your wi≈ødom & my ≈øimplicity (I coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe) I haue in ≈øom points varied: Now (I ≈øay) be you a≈ø≈øured, that euen with my whole heart (God is my witnes) in the bowels of Chri≈øt, I loue you & in truth for the truthes ≈øake, which abideth in vs, and (as I am per≈øwaded) ≈øhall by the grace of God, abyde with vs for euermore. And becau≈øe the world, as I perceiue brother, cea≈øeth not to play his pageant, 1. Cor x. & bu≈øely con≈øpireth again≈øt Chri≈øt our ≈øauior, with all po≈ø≈øible force and power, exaltyng high thinges again≈øt the knowledge of god: let vs ioyne handes together in Chri≈øt, and if we cannot ouerthrowe, yet to our power and as much as in vs lieth, let vs ≈øhake tho≈øe hyghe thinges, not with carnal but wt ≈øpiritual weapoÃÑs: & withall brother, let vs prepare our ≈øelues to ye day of our di≈ø≈øolution, wherby after the ≈øhorte time of this bodely affliction, by the grace of our lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, we ≈øhall triumphe together with him in eternall glory.

I pray you brother ≈øalute in my name that reuerend father,Of this good fathers godly ende and con≈øtant coÃÑ fe≈ø≈øion of the truth, you ≈øhall read in the next editioÃÑ of the boke of martyrs your fellow pri≈øoner Doctor Crome, by whom ≈øince the fir≈øt day, yt I heard of his mo≈øt godly & fatherly con≈øtancy in confe≈ø≈øing ye truth of the go≈øpel, I haue conceiued great con≈øolation and ioy in the lord. For the integritie and vprightnes, the grauitie & innoceÃÑcy of that maÃÑ, al EnglaÃÑd I think, hath knowen long ago. Ble≈ø≈øed be God therfore, whiche in ≈øuch abundance of iniquity, & decay of all godline≈ø≈øe, hath geuen vnto vs in this reuerend old age, ≈øuch a witnes for the truth of his go≈øpel. Mi≈øerable & hard harted is he, whoÃÑ the godlines & con≈øtant confe≈ø≈øion of ≈øo worthy, ≈øo graue, & innocent a maÃÑ, wil not moue to acknowledge & coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe the truth of god. I doe not nowe brother require you to write anye thing to me againe, for I ≈øtaÃÑd much in feare le≈øt your letters ≈øhould be intercepted before they can come to my hands. Neuertheles know you, that it ≈øhalbe to me great ioy to heare
of your con≈øtancie and fortitude in the lords quarel. And albeit I haue not hitherto writen vnto you, yet haue I twi≈øe as I could, ≈øeÃÑt vnto you my mind touching ye matter which in your letters you required to know, neither can I yet brother be otherwi≈øe per≈øuaded, I ≈øee me thinkes ≈øo many perils wherby I am earne≈øtly moued to couÃÑ≈øel you not to ha≈øteÃÑ the publi≈øhyng of your workes, e≈øpecially vnder the title of your own name. For I feare greatly lea≈øt by this occa≈øion, both your mouth ≈øhould be ≈øtopped hereafter, & al things taken awaye from the re≈øte of the pri≈øoners whereby otherwi≈øe, if it ≈øo plea≈øe god, they may bee able to doe good to many. Farewell in the lord my mo≈øt deare brother, and if there be any more in pri≈øon with you for Chri≈øtes cau≈øe, I be≈øech you as you may, ≈øalute them in my name: to who≈øe praiers, I do mo≈øt humbly and hartely commeÃÑd my ≈øelfe and my fellow pri≈øoners concaptiues in the lord, and yet o ‚Ä¢ ce againe and for euer in Chri≈øt, my mo≈øt deare brother, Farewell.

div.head: ‚òû A letter of M. Edmunde Grindal, then being in exile for the te≈øtimony of the truth, and now bi≈øhop of London, to D. Ridley pri≈øoner in Oxforde, whiche we thoughte good here to place, for that the letter followyng is an aun≈øwer therof.
div.p:
GRatiam & con≈øolationem a Domino & ≈øeruatore nostro Ie≈øu christo. Syr I haue often bene de≈øirous to haue written to you and to haue heard from you, but the iniquity of the tymes haue hitherto always put me forth of all hope and comfort. Now at thys pre≈øent god ≈øemeth to offer ≈øome likelyhode, that the≈øe might come to your handes, which I thought to v≈øe, referring the rest to Gods di≈øpo≈øitioÃÑ. Your pre≈øent ≈øtate, not I only (who of all other am most bouÃÑd) but al≈øo all other our brethreÃÑ here, do most hartely lament, as ioyned with the mo≈øt mi≈øerable captiuitie that euer anye church, of Chri≈øt hath ≈øuffred. Notwith≈øtanding we geue god mo≈øt humble thankes, for that he hath ≈øo ≈øtrengthened you and others your concaptiues, to profe≈ø≈øe a good profe≈øsioÃÑ before ≈øo many witne≈ø≈øes. And
I doubt nothyng, but he that hath called you and them not onely to beleue vpon hym, but al≈øo to ≈øuffer for hym, dothe not leaue you destitute of that vn≈øpeakable comfort which he v≈øeth to mini≈øter abundantly to his in the ≈øchole of the cro≈ø≈øe. He graunte that his name may be glorified in you, whether it he by life or death, as may be most to his honour, and your euerlasting con≈øolation.

Syr I thought it good to aduerti≈øe you partelye of our ≈øtate in the≈øe parties. We be here di≈øper≈øed in diuers and ≈øeuerall places. Certayne be at Tigurye good ≈øtudents of either vniuer≈øity a number, very well entreated of maister Bullinger, of the other miny≈øters and of the whole citye. An other number of vs remayne at Argentine, and take the commodity of mai≈øter Martyrs le≈øsons, who is a very notable father. Maister Scory and certayne other with hym be in Fri≈øland, and haue an engli≈øhe church there, but not very frequent. The greate≈øt number is at Frankeforde where I was at this pre≈øeÃÑt by occa≈øioÃÑ, a very fayre city, the magistrates fauourable to our people, with ≈øo many other coÃÑmodities as exiles caÃÑ well loke for. Here is al≈øo a church, and now (god be thanked) well quieted by the prudency of maister Coxe and other whiche mette here for that purpo≈øe. So that now we tru≈øt god hathe prouided for ≈øuch as will flye forth of Babilon, a restyng place where they may truly ≈øerue hym and heare the voice of their true pa≈øtour. I ≈øuppo≈øe in one place and other di≈øper≈øed, there be wel nigh an hundreth ≈øtudentes and ministers on this ≈øide the ≈øeas. Such a lord is god to work dyuer≈øly in his, accordyng to his vn≈øercheable wi≈ødom, who knoweth best what is in man.Cyprianus de lap≈øis. Primus e≈øt victoriae titulus gentilium manibus apprehen≈øum, dominum confiteri. Secundus ad gloriam gradus e≈øt, cauta ≈øece≈øsione ≈øubtractum domino re≈øeruari. Illa publica, haec priuata confe≈øsio e≈øt. Ille iudiceÃÑ ≈øeculi vincit, hic contentus deo ≈øuo iudice, con≈øcientiaÃÑ pu ‚Ä¢ aÃÑ cordis integritate cu≈øtodit. I≈øthic fortitudo promptior, hic ≈øolicitudo ≈øecurior. Ille appropinquante hora ≈øua iam maturus inuentus e≈øt, hic forta≈ø≈øe dilatus e≈øt, qui patrimonio derelicto idcirco ≈øece≈øsit, quia non erat negaturus, confiteretur vti
que ≈øi fui≈ø≈øet & ip≈øe detentus. We haue al≈øo here certayn copies of your
an≈øweres in the di≈øputatioÃÑ. IteÃÑ Antoniana obiecta cum re≈øpon≈øione. The treati≈øe in engli≈øh against tran≈øubstantiatioÃÑ, whych in tyme ≈øhalbe tran≈ølated into Latine. It hath bene thought best not to printe them till we ≈øee what god will do with you, bothe for incen≈øyng of their malicious fury, and al≈øo for re≈øtraining you and others from writing hereafter, which ≈øhould be a greater lo≈øse to the church of Christ, than forbearing of the≈øe for a tyme. If I ≈øhal know your wil to be otherwi≈øe in it, the ≈øame ≈øhalbe folowed. Thus much I thought good to let you vnder≈øtaÃÑd coÃÑcerning the≈øe matters and coÃÑ cerning the poore ≈øtate of men here: who most earnestly and ince≈ø≈øantly do cry vnto god for the deliuery of his churche, to behold the cau≈øes of the afflicted, and to heare the grones of hys impri≈øoned, knowyng that you, who in this ≈øtate haue more familiar acce≈ø≈øe vnto god, do not forget vs. God comfort you, ayde you, and a≈øsi≈øt you with his ≈øpirit and grace, to coÃÑtinue his vnto thend, to the glory of his name, the edification of his church, and the ≈øubuer≈øion of Antichri≈øtes kyngdome. Amen.

div.head: ¬∂The aun≈øwer of D. Rydley to the former letter.
div.p: BLe≈ø≈øed be god our heauenly father which enclined your hart to haue ≈øuch a de≈øyre to write vnto me, & ble≈ø≈øed be he againe which hath heard your reque≈øt and hath brought your letters ≈øafe vnto my haÃÑds: and ouer al this I ble≈ø≈øe him through our lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, for the great coÃÑfort I haue receiued by the ≈øame, of the knowledge of your ≈øtate and of other our dearly beloued brethren and couÃÑtrey men in tho≈øe parties beyonde the ≈øea.

Dearly beloued brother Grindall I ≈øay to you & all the re≈øt of our brethren in Chri≈øt with you, reioyce in the lord, & as ye loue me and the other my reuerend fathers and concaptiues (which vndoubtedly are gloria Chri≈øti) lamente not our ≈øtate, but I be≈øeche you and them all to geue vnto our heauenly father for his endles mercies and vn≈øpeakable benefites euen in the myddes of all our troubles geuen vnto
vs, mo≈øt harty thankes. For know ye that as the weight of his cro≈ø≈øe hathe increa≈øed vppon vs, ≈øo he hathe not nor doth not cea≈øe to multiply his mercies to ≈øtrengtheÃÑ vs, & I tru≈øt, yea by his grace I dout nothing, but he will ≈øo do for Chri≈øt our ma≈øters ≈øake eueÃÑ to thend. To heare yt you & our other brethreÃÑ do find in your exile fauour & grace wt the mage≈øtrates, mini≈øters and citizens at Tigury, at Frankforte and other where, it doth greatly comfort (I dare ≈øay) al here that do in dede loue Chri≈øt and his true word. I en≈øure you it warmed my hart to here you by chaunce to name ≈øome, as Scory and Coxe &c. Oh that it had come in your mynde to haue ≈øaid ≈øomwhat al≈øo of Cheeke, of Turner, of Leauer, of Samp≈øoÃÑ, of Chambers, but I tru≈øt to god they be all well. And ≈øyr, ≈øeing you ≈øaye that there bee in tho≈øe parties with you of ≈øtudents and mini≈øters ≈øo good a number, now therfore care you not for vs, otherwy≈øe then to wi≈øhe that gods glory may be ≈øet forth by vs. For when≈øoeuer god ≈øhall call vs home (as we loke daily for none other, but when it ≈øhall plea≈øe god to ≈øaye, Come) ye, ble≈ø≈øed be God, are enoughe through his aid, to light and ≈øet vp again the lanterne of his word in England. As coÃÑcernyng the copies ye ≈øay ye haue with you, I wonder how euer they did wander and coulde fynd the way to come to you.This di≈øputatioÃÑ of his owne penning is in the boke of Martyrs. My di≈øputation, excepte you haue that which I gathered my ≈øelf after ye di≈øputatioÃÑ done, I can not thynke ye haue it truely. If ye haue that, then ye haue there withall the whole maner after the which I was v≈øed in the di≈øputation.

As for the treati≈øe in engli≈øh contra tran≈øubstantiationeÃÑ, vix po≈øsuÃÑ adduci vt credam operoepretiuÃÑ fore vt in latinuÃÑ traÃÑ≈øferatur. CaeteruÃÑ quicquid ≈øit, nullo modo velim vt quicquaÃÑ quocun
que modo meo nomine ederetur, donec quid de nobis dnÃÑs coÃÑstituerit fieri, vobis prius certo coÃÑstiterit: & thus much vnto your letters. Now although I ≈øuppo≈øe ye knowe a good part of our ≈øtate here (for we are forth coÃÑming, eueÃÑ as wheÃÑ ye departed. &c) you ≈øhal vnder≈øtaÃÑd yt I was in ye tower about the ≈øpace of ij. monethes clo≈øe pri≈øoner, & after yt had graunted to me without my labour, the liberty of ye tower, & ≈øo continued about half a yeare, and then bicau≈øe I refu≈øed to allowe the ma≈ø≈øe with my pre≈øence, I was ≈øhutte vppe in clo≈øe pry≈øon agayne.

The la≈øt Lent ≈øaue one, it chaunced by rea≈øon of the tumult
≈øtirred vp in Kente, there was ≈øo manye pri≈øoners in the Tower, that my L. of Canterb. M. Lacimer, M. Bradforde and I were put altogether in one pri≈øon, where we remained ≈øtill almo≈øt to the next ea≈øter, and then we three, Caunterb. Latymer and I, were ≈øodainly ≈øent a little before Gato Oxford, and were ≈øuffred to haue nothyng with vs, but that we caried vpon vs. About the Whit≈øontide folowyng was our di≈øputations at Oxford, after the which was al taken from vs, as penne and ynke, &c. our owne ≈øeruauntes were taken from vs before, and euery one had put to him a ≈øtraunge man, and we eche one appointed to be kept in ≈øeuerall places, as we are vnto this day.

Ble≈ø≈øed be god we three at the writyng hereof, were in good health and (in god) of good cheare. We haue loked long ago to haue bene di≈øpatched, for we were all three on one daye within a day or two of our di≈øputations, of D. We≈øt your old companion & ≈øometime mine officer (alas) hath relented (as I haue heard) but the lord hath ≈øhortned
hys daies,This We≈øt wheÃÑ he had relented & ≈øayd ma≈ø≈øe again≈øt his con≈øcience, ≈øhortly after pined away and died for ≈øorow. for anone he died and is gone. My brother Ship ≈øyde that hath maryed my ≈øy≈øter, hathe bene almo≈øte halfe a yere in pry≈øon for deliueryng (as he was accu≈øed) of certain thynges, I weene, from me: but now, thankes be to god, he is at liberty agayne, but ≈øo that the bi≈øhop hath taken from hym hys parke.

Of al vs three coÃÑcaptiues at Oxford I am kept mo≈øt ≈øtrait, and with lea≈øt libertie, vel quia viro in cuius edibus, ego custodior, vxordominatur (licet modo ≈øit prefectus ciuitatis) mulier vetula, moro≈øa, & ≈øuperstitio≈øi≈øs: quae etiaÃÑ hoc ≈øibi laudi ducit quod me dicatur arcti≈øsime & cauti≈øsime custodire, vir autem ip≈øe Iri≈øchius nomine, mitis ≈øatis est omnibus, vxori vero plu≈øquam ob≈øequenti≈øs. Licet vxorem (vti nosti) nunquam habuerim, tamen ex hac quotidiana con≈øuetudine quam cum istis coniugibus habeo, videor mihi non nihil po≈øse intelligere qu√†m graue malum & intollerabile iugum ≈øit cum mala mulierein coniugio colligari. Recte ergo ≈øapiens dixit, vxor bona donum Dei: & iterum, mulieris bonae beatus vir. Vel haec inquam cau≈øa e≈øt, vel quia a magnis magi≈øtratibus (ne≈øcio quas ob cau≈øas) illud e≈øt vt ita fieret, ip≈øis maÃÑdatum: id quod illi ≈øi quando de meanimia ≈øeruitute apud eos conqueror, ≈øedulo ≈øoepe rur≈øus mihi inculcant.

At Cambridge (as I heare ≈øay) Omnes ≈øtudioruÃÑ & ≈øtatutoruÃÑ reformationes nuper factae, nunc ≈øunt denuo deformatae & deletae, & omnia ≈øunt in pri≈øtinum chaos & in antiquum papi≈ømum reducta: omnes collegiorum prefecti qui ≈øynceritati euaÃÑgelij fauebaÃÑt, vel qui coniugati eraÃÑt, loco moti ≈øunt, & alij papi≈øticae factionis in eorum loca ≈øurrogati, quod & de ≈øocijs collegiorum qui noluerunt flectere genu Baall factuÃÑ e≈øse audio. Nec miruÃÑ, naÃÑ & i≈øtud pa≈øsim factuÃÑ e≈øt in vniuer≈øo regno angliae, in omnibus Archiepi≈øcopis, Epi≈øcopis, Decanis, prebeÃÑdarijs, Sacerdotibus eccle≈øiarum & in toto clero: and to tel you much naughty matter in a few wordes, Papi≈ømus apud nos vbique in pleno fuo antiquo robore regnat.
The Lord be merciful and for Chri≈øtes ≈øake pardon vs our olde vnkindne≈ø≈øe and vnthankefulne≈ø≈øe: for when he powred vppon vs the giftes of hys manifolde graces, and fauour (alas) we dyd not ≈øerue him nor rendered vnto hym thankes according to the ≈øame. We pa≈øtors many of vs wer to cold and bare to much (alas) with the wycked world, our magi≈øtrates did abu≈øe to theyr owne worldlye gayne bothe gods Go≈øpell and the mini≈øters of the ≈øame, the people in many places was waywarde and vnkynd. My brother as yet, becau≈øe they nether ≈øhewed any comi≈ø≈øioÃÑ or authority wherbye they did examine him nor al≈øo anye thynge of his letters (although they ≈øaid they had them) as yet I ≈øay my brother hath confe≈ø≈øed nothing. Bicau≈øe in the booke of N. R. and H. L. it is ≈øaide in the ende that. div.head: To mai≈øter Bradford pri≈øoner in the kinges Bench.
div.p:
WElbeloued in Chri≈øt our ≈øauiour, we all with one hart wi≈øh you, with all tho≈øe that loue god in dede and truth, grace and healthe, and ≈øpecially to oure dearely beloued companions which are in Chri≈øts cau≈øe and the cau≈øe both of theyr brethren and of theyr own ≈øaluation, readye and willing to put theyr necke vnder the yoke of Chri≈øts cro≈ø≈øe. How ioyful it was to vs to heare the reporte of D. Taylor & of his godly confe≈ø≈øion &c: I en≈øure you, it is hard for me to expre≈ø≈øe. Ble≈ø≈øed be God which was and is the geuer of that and all godly ≈øtrength and ≈øtomacke in the time of aduer≈øity. As for the rumors that haue or doe go abroade either of our relenting or ma≈ø≈øing, we tru≈øt that they which know god and theyr dutye towardes theyr brethren in Chri≈øt, wil not be to lyght of credit to beleue them. It is not the ≈øclaunderers euell tounge but a mans owne euell deede, that can with God defile a man, and therfore by gods grace, you ≈øhal neuer haue cau≈øe to doe otherwi≈øe then you ≈øay you do, that is not to doubt but that we will continue, &c. Like rumor as you haue hearde of oure comminge to London hathe beene here ≈øpreade of the comminge of certayne learned men pri≈øoners hether from London: but as yet we knowe no certeyntye whether of the≈øe rumors is or ≈øhalbe more true. Know you yt we haue you in our dayly remembrance, and wi≈øh you and all the re≈øt of our fore≈øayde companions, well in Chri≈øt. It ≈øhould do vs much comfort if we might haue knowledge of the ≈øtate of ye re≈øt of our mo≈øt dearely beloued, which in this trouble≈øome time doe ≈øtande in Chri≈øtes cau≈øe, and in the defence of the truth therof. We are in good health thankes be to God, & yet the manner of our entreting doth chaung as ≈øoure ale doth in ≈øoÃÑmer. It is reported to vs of our kepers, that the vniuer≈øity beareth vs heauely. A cole chaunced to fal in the night out of the chimney & burnt a hole in the floore, & no more harme was done, the balifes ≈øeruants ≈øitting by the fyer. An other night there chaunced a drunken fellow to multiply wordes, and for the ≈øame he was ≈øet in Bocardo. Vpon the≈øe thinges as is reported, there is ri≈øeÃÑ a rumor in the towne & countrey about,
that we would haue brokeÃÑ the pri≈øoÃÑ wt ≈øuch violeÃÑce, as if the balifes had not plaid the prety men, we ≈øhould haue made a ≈øcape. We had out of our pri≈øoÃÑ a wal that we might haue walked vpon, and our ≈øeruants had liberty to go abroad in the towne or fieldes: but now both they and we are re≈øtrayned of both. The bi≈øhop of Worceter pa≈ø≈øed by vs through Oxford, but he did not vi≈øit vs. The ≈øame day beganne our re≈øtraint to be more, and the boke of the communion was taken from vs by the balifes at the Mayors commaundemeÃÑt. No man is licenced to come vnto vs: afore they might that woulde, ≈øee vs vpon the wal, but that is ≈øo grudgod at and ≈øo euel reported, that we are now re≈øtrayned &c. Sir ble≈ø≈øed be God, with all oure euell reportes, grudginges and re≈øtrayntes, we are mery in God, and all our eare is and ≈øhalbe by gods grace, to plea≈øe & ≈øerue him, of whome we loke and hope after this temporall and momentany mi≈øeries, to haue eternall ioy and perpetuall felicity, with Abraham, I≈øaac and Iacob, Peter and Paule and al the ble≈ø≈øed company of the aungels in heauen, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our lord. As yet there was neuer lerned man or any ≈øcholer or other yt vi≈øited vs ≈øince we came into Bocardo,Bocardo is a ≈øtinking and filthy pri≈øon for drunkards whores and harlottes and the vile≈øt ≈øort of people. which now in Oxford may be called a colledge of quondaÃÑs: for as you know we be no fewer here theÃÑ thre, and I dare ≈øay, euery one well contented with his portion, whiche I doe recken to be our heauenly fathers gracious & fatherly good gift. Thus fare you wel. We ≈øhal with gods grace one day mete together & be mery: the daye a≈ø≈øuredly approcheth apace, ye lord grauÃÑt yt it may ≈øhortly come, for before yt day come I feare me the world wyl waxe wor≈øe & wor≈øe: but theÃÑ al our enemies ≈øhal be ouerthrown & troden vnder foote, righteou≈ønes, & truth then ≈øhall haue the victory and beare the bell away, wherof the lord graunte vs to be partners & all that ≈øincerely loue the truth. We al pray you, as you can to cau≈øe al our commeÃÑ dations to be made to all ≈øuch as you know did vi≈øit vs & you when we were in the tower with theyr frendly remeÃÑ brances & benefites. Mi≈øtres Wilkin≈øon & mi≈øtres Warcup haue not forgotteÃÑ vs, but euen ≈øince we came into Bocardo wt theyr charitable & freÃÑdly beneuolence, haue coÃÑforted vs:
Not that els we lacke, (for god be ble≈ø≈øed which euer hetherto hath prouided ≈øufficiently for vs) but it is a great coÃÑfort & an occa≈øion for vs to ble≈ø≈øe god when we ≈øe that he maketh them ≈øo frendly to tender vs, whom ≈øome of vs were neuer familierly acquaynted withall.

div.head: To mai≈øter Bradford.
div.p: DEarely beloued, I wy≈øh you grace mercy & peace. According to your mind I haue run ouer all your papers, and what I haue done (which is but ≈ømal) therin may appeare. Sir what ≈øhall be≈øte be done with the≈øe thinges,This was a treati≈øe of the communioÃÑ with other thinges which M. Bradforde ≈øent to hym to peru≈øe & to geue his iudgement therof. now you mu≈øt con≈øider: for if they come in ≈øight at this time, vndoubtedly they mu≈øt to the fier with theyr father, and as for any ≈øafegarde that your cu≈øtody can be vnto them, I am ≈øure you loke not for it: for as you haue bene partner of the worke, ≈øo I am ≈øure, you loke for none other, but to haue and receaue like wages and to drinke of the ≈øame cuppe. Ble≈ø≈øed be god that hath geuen you libertye in the meane cea≈øon, yt you may v≈øe your pen to his glory, & to the comfort (as I heare ≈øay) of manye. I ble≈ø≈øe god dayly in you and all your whole companye, to whome I be≈øeche you to commend me hartly. Now I loue my countreyman in deede and in truth, I meane. D. Taylor, not now for my earthly countreis ≈øake, but for oure heauenly fathers ≈øake, whome I heard ≈øay, he did ≈øo ≈øtoutly in time of perill confe≈ø≈øe: and yet al≈øo now for our countreis ≈øake and for all our mothers ≈øake, but I meane of the kingdome of heauen and of heauenly hieru≈øalem, and bicau≈øe of the ≈øprite which bringeth in hym, in you, and in your coÃÑpany ≈øuch ble≈ø≈øed fruites of boldnes in the lords cau≈øe, of pacience, and con≈øtaÃÑcy. The Lord which hath begon this worke in you al, performe and perfite this his own dede, vntill his own day come. Amen.

As yet, I perceiue you haue not beene baited & the cau≈øe therof God knoweth, which wil let them do no more to his then is his plea≈øed will and good plea≈øure to ≈øuffer them to do for his own glory and to the profit of them which be trulye his, for the father whiche dothe guide theÃÑ that be chri≈øts to Chri≈øte is more mighty than all they, and no man is able to pulle theÃÑ out of the fathers hands: except, (I ≈øay) it plea≈øe
our father, it plea≈øe our mai≈øter Chri≈øte to ≈øuffer them, they ≈øhal not be able to ≈øturre one heare of your heades. My brother. P. the bearer hereof, would that we ≈øhoulde ≈øay what we thynke good concerninge your mynde: that is, not for to aun≈øwere excepte ye myghte haue ≈øomewhat indifferent iudges. We are (as ye know) ≈øeparated, & one of vs can not in any thing con≈øult with an other, and muche ≈øtraite watching of the baylifes is about vs that there be no priuy conference amonge≈øt vs. And yet (as we heare) the ≈øcholers beare vs more heauelye then the town≈øemen. A wonderful thing, among ≈øo many, neuer yet ≈øcholer offred to any of vs (≈øo farre as I know) any manner of fauor either for or in Chri≈øtes cau≈øe. Now as concerning your demaunde of our coun≈øell, for my part I do not mi≈ølike that which I perceiue ye are minded to do: for I loke for none other, but if ye aun≈øwere before the ≈øame commi≈ø≈øioners that we did, ye ≈øhalbe ≈øerued & handled as we were, though ye were as wel lerned as euer was either Peter or Paule. And yet further I think that occa≈øion afterward may be geuen you, and the con≈øideration of the profite of your auditory may perchauÃÑce moue you to doe otherwi≈øe. Finallye, determinately to ≈øaye what ≈øhalbe be≈øte, I am not able: but I tru≈øte he, who≈øe cau≈øe ye haue in hand, ≈øhal put you in minde to do that which ≈øhalbe mo≈øt for hys glory, the profite of his flocke, and your owne ≈øaluation. This letter mu≈øt be common to you & M. Hoper, in whome and in hys pri≈øon fellowe good father Crome, I ble≈ø≈øe god euen from the bottome of my harte: for I doubte not but they both doe to our may≈øter Chri≈øte, true, acceptable and honorable ≈øeruice and profitable to his flocke, the one with hys penne and the other wyth hys fatherlye example of patience and con≈øtancye and all manner of true godlynes. But what ≈øhall I nede to ≈øay to you, let this be common amonge your brethren? among whome (I dare ≈øay) it is with you as it is with vs, to whome all thinges here are common: meate, money, and what ≈øoeuer one of vs hath that can or may doe an other good. Althoughe I ≈øayde the baylifes & our ho≈øtes ≈øtraitly watch vs that we haue no conference or intelligence of any thynge abroade, yet hath God prouided for euery one of vs in ye ≈øtede of our ≈øeruants faythful fellowes which wilbe content to heare and ≈øee, and to do for vs what ≈øo euer they can: it is Gods worke ≈øurely,
ble≈ø≈øed be God for his vn≈øpeakeable goodnes. The grace of our Lorde Ie≈øus Chri≈øte and the loue of God, and the communion of the holy go≈øte be with you all, Amen, Amen. As farre as London is from Oxford, yet thence we haue receaued of late both meate, money, and ≈øhyrtes, not onlye from ≈øuch as are of our acquayntance, but of ≈øome whom this bearer can tell, with whome I had neuer to my knowledge any acquaintance. I knowe for who≈øe ≈øake they do it: to hym therfore be all honoure glorye and due thankes, And yet I pray you do ≈øo much as to ≈øhew them that we haue receiued theyr beneuolence, and (god be ble≈ø≈øed) haue plentye of all ≈øuch things. This I de≈øire you to do, for I know they be of mai≈øter Hopers and your familier acquayntaunce. May≈øter Latimer was cra≈øed, but I heare nowe thankes be to God that he amendeth agayne.

div.head: To mai≈øter Bradford.
div.p:
BRother Bradford I wi≈øh you and your companye in Chri≈øt, yea & al the holy brotherhode that nowe wyth you in diuer≈øe pri≈øonnes ≈øuffreth and beareth paciently Chri≈øts cro≈ø≈øe for the mayntenance of his go≈øpell: grace, mercy and peace from god the father and froÃÑ our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øte. Syr, con≈øideringe the ≈øtate of this chiualrie and warfare, wherein I doubte not but we be ≈øet to fight vnder Chri≈øtes banner and his cro≈ø≈øe again≈øt oure go≈øtly enemy the deuill and the old ≈øerpent SataÃÑ, me think I perceaue two thinges to be his mo≈øt perilous and mo≈øte daungerous engines which he hath to impugne chri≈øts verity, his go≈øpel, his faith: and ye ≈øame two al≈øo to be the mo≈øt ma≈ø≈øye po≈øtes and mo≈øt mighty pillers, wherby he mainteyneth and vpholdeth his Satanical ≈øinagoge. The≈øe two ≈øir, are they in my iudgement: the one his fal≈øe doctrine and idolatry call v≈øe of the Lords ≈øupper, and the other, the wicked and abhominable v≈øurpation of the primacye of the ≈øea of Rome. By the≈øe two Satan ≈øemeth to me principally to manteine and vphold his kingdom: by the≈øe two, he driueth down mightely (alas) I feare me, Apo. 8. the third part of the ≈øtarrs
in heauen. The≈øe two poy≈øonfull rotten po≈øtes he hathe ≈øo painted ouer with ≈øuch a pretence and colour of religion, of vnitye in Chri≈øtes church, of the catholike fayth and ≈øuche like, yt the wily ≈øerpeÃÑt is hable to deceaue (if it were po≈ø≈øible) euen the elect of god. Wherfore Iohn ≈øayd not wtout great cau≈øe,Apoc. ij. if any know not Satans ≈øubtilties and the doungeons thereof, I will wi≈øhe him no other burden to be laden withal. Sir, becau≈øe the≈øe be his principal and maine po≈øtes whervppon ≈øtandeth all his fal≈øhode, craft, and trecherye, therfore according to the pore power that God hath giuen me, I haue bended mine artillary to ≈øhoote at the ≈øame. I know it to be but little (God knoweth) that I can do, and of my ≈øhote I know they pa≈ø≈øe not. Yet wyll I not (God willing) cea≈øe to do the be≈øt that I can, to ≈øhake tho≈øe cankered and rotten po≈øtes. The Lord graunt me good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, to the glory of hys name and the furtheraunce of Chri≈øtes go≈øpell. I haue now alredy (I thanke god) for this pre≈øent time ≈øpent a good part of my powder in the≈øe ≈øcryblyngs, wherof thys bearer ≈øhall geue you knowledge. Good brother Bradforde, let the wicked ≈øurmi≈øe and ≈øaye what they li≈øte, know you for a certeynty by gods grace, without al doubt, that in Chri≈øtes go≈øpelles cau≈øe, again≈øt and vpon the fore≈øayd gods enemyes, I am fully determined to liue and die. Fare well deare brother, and I be≈øeche you and all the re≈øte of our brethern, to haue good remembraÃÑce of the condemned heretikes (as they call them) of Oxforde in your prayers. The bearer ≈øhall certifye you of our ≈øtate. Fare well in the Lorde.

div.head: To mai≈øter Bradford
div.p: DEarelye beloued brother, ble≈ø≈øed be God oure heauenlye father for hys manifolde and innumerable mercies towardes vs, and ble≈ø≈øed mighte he be that hath ≈øpared vs thus long together, that eche one of vs maye ble≈ø≈øe his mercye and clemencye in other vnto this daye aboue the expectation and hope of any worldlye appearance.

Where as you wryte of he outragious rule that Sathan our go≈øtly enemy beareth abrode in the worlde, wherbye he ≈øtirreth and ray≈øeth ≈øo pe≈øtilente and heynous here≈øies, as ≈øome to deny the ble≈ø≈øed trinity, ≈øome the diuinity of our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt, ≈øome the diuinity of the holy go≈øt, ≈øome the bapti≈øme of infants, ≈øome original ≈øinne, and to be infected with the errors of the pelagiaÃÑs, & to rebapti≈øe tho≈øe that haue ben bapti≈øed with Chri≈øtes bapti≈øme alredy: alas ≈øyr this doth declare this time and the≈øe dayes to be wicked in dede. But what can we looke for els of Sathan here and of his mini≈øters but to do the wor≈øte that they can ≈øo farre forth as god ≈øhal or wil ≈øuffer them. And now me thincke he is le≈ø≈øe to be merueled at at this tyme if he be≈øtirre him by al manner of meanes, yt the truth in deede doe take no place. div.head: ¬∂To mai≈øter Bradford.

For when the ≈øtate of religion was once altered, and per≈øecution beganne to waxe whote, no man douted but Cranmer, Latymer, and Rydley, ≈øhoulde haue beene the fyr≈øte to haue beene called to the ≈øtake. div.head: ¬∂To mai≈øter Bradford.
div.p: BRother Bradford, I wi≈øhe you in Chri≈øt our Sauiour, grace, mercy, and peace, and to al theÃÑ which are with you or any where els captiues in Chri≈øt, and to heare that ye be al in good health and ≈øtand con≈øtaÃÑtly in the confe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtes go≈øpell, it dothe hartely reioyce vs. Knowe you lykewy≈øe that we all here bee (thankes be to god) in good health and comforte, watchyng wyth our lampes lyght (I tru≈øt in god) when it ≈øhall plea≈øe our mai≈øter the brydegrome, Math. 25. to call vs to wayte vpon hym vnto the mariage. div.head: ¬∂To mai≈øter Bradford.
div.p:

div.p:
BRother Augu≈øtine, I ble≈ø≈øe god with all my harte in hys manyfold mercifull giftes giuen vnto our deare brethreÃÑ in Chri≈øt, e≈øpecially to our brother Rogers whome it plea≈øed to ≈øetforth fir≈øt, no doubt but of his gratious goodnes &
fatherly fauor towardes hym. And likewi≈øe ble≈ø≈øed be God in the re≈øt, as Hoper Saunders, and Taylor, whome it hath plea≈øed the Lord likewi≈øe to ≈øet in the forefrount of the battayle, again≈øt his aduer≈øaries, and hath endewed them al (≈øo far as I can here) to ≈øtand in the confe≈ø≈øion of his truth and to be content in his cau≈øe & for his go≈øpels ≈øake to lo≈øe their life. And euermore and without end ble≈ø≈øed be eueÃÑ the ≈øame our heauenly father for our deare and entierly beloued brother Bradford, whome now the Lorde (I perceiue) calleth for: for I wene he wil no longer vouch≈øafe him to abide amonge the adulterous and wycked generation of thys world. I do not doubt but that he (for tho≈øe giftes of grace which the Lord hath be≈øtowed on him plenteou≈øly) hath holpen tho≈øe which are gone before in their iorney, that is, hath animated and encouraged them to kepe the high way, & ≈øic currere vti tandem acciperent premium. The Lord be his comfort, wherof I doe not doubte, and I thanke God hartely that euer I was acquaynted wyth hym, and that euer I had ≈øuche a one in my hou≈øe. Protomartyr is the fir≈øt Martyr: whome he ≈øo called, becau≈øe he was the fir≈øt that ≈øuffred here in tho≈øe bloudy dayes. And yet agayne I ble≈ø≈øe God in our deare brother and of thys tyme protomartyr Rogers, that he was al≈øo one of my callinge to be a prebendarye preacher of London. And nowe becau≈øe Grindall is gone (The Lord I doubt not hath and koweth wherein he will be≈øtowe him) I tru≈øte to God it ≈øhall plea≈øe him of his goodnes to ≈øtrengthen me to make vp the trynytye out of Paules churche, to ≈øuffer for Chri≈øt, whome God the father hath annoynted, the holye ≈øpirite doth beare witnes vnto, Paule and al the Apo≈øtles preached. Thus fare you well. I had no paper, I was con≈øtrayned thus to write.

div.head: To Augu≈øtine Berneher.
div.p:
BRother Au≈øtine I thanke you for your manifolde kindene≈ø≈øe.This almes was ≈øent him by the Ladye Katherin Duches of Suffolk, to who he wrote againe a worthy letter, which is l ‚Ä¢ ≈øt and many other writen bot ‚Ä¢ to her & others. I haue receiued my Ladies graces almes, ≈øixe Royalles ≈øyxe ≈øhillinges and eyghte pence. I haue written a letter here vnto her grace, but I haue made no mention therof, wherfore I de≈øire you to render to her grace harty thankes. Ble≈ø≈øed be God, as for my ≈øelfe I wante nothyng, but my Ladies almes commeth happilye to relieue my poore brothers nece≈ø≈øity, whome you know they haue ca≈øt and kepe in pri≈øon
(as I ≈øuppo≈øe) you know the cau≈øe why. Farewell brother Au≈øtine, & take good heede I pray you, & let my brothers ca≈øe make your ye more wary. Read my letter to my ladies grace. I would mai≈øtres Wilkin≈øoÃÑ & may≈øtres Warcup had a copy of it: for althoughe ye letter is directed to my ladies grace alone, yet the mater therof pertaineth indiffereÃÑtly to her grace and to all good women, which loue God and his worde in deede and truth.

div.head: ¬∂ To Mai≈øtres Glouer, a woman zelous and harty in the cau≈øe and furtherance of Gods go≈øpell.
div.p:
MAi≈øtres glouer, I wy≈øh you grace & peace, and although I am not acquainted wt you, yet neuertheles, hearing that your hu≈øbaÃÑd ma≈øter Glouer is in pri≈øon for gods wordes ≈øake, and al≈øo that you are a womaÃÑ harty in gods cau≈øe, and thirdly that old father Latimer is your vncle or nere co≈øin, whoÃÑ I do thinke ye lord hath placed to be his ≈øtanderd bearer in our age and country agayn≈øt his mortal foe Antichri≈øt: I was thus bold to write vnto you in goddes behalf, to do accordinge to the report which I here of you: that is, that you be hartye in Goddes cau≈øe, and hartye to youre may≈øter Chri≈øt, in furdering of hys cau≈øe and ≈øettinge fourth his ≈øouldiours to hys warres to the vttermo≈øt of your power. Let no carnality nor worldly regard of any thinge ≈øet you to declare your trew hart, which you are ≈øaid to beare to your may≈øter chri≈øt aboue all other thinges. Be harty nowe al≈øo to your hu≈øbande, and declare your ≈øelfe to loue him in God as the true faythfull chri≈øtiaÃÑ womaÃÑ vnto her hu≈øbaÃÑd is bound to do. Now ≈øeing your hu≈øbaÃÑd which is ≈øet by gods ordinaÃÑce to be your head, is redy to ≈øuffer & abide in aduer≈øity by his ma≈øters cau≈øe, & to cleaue to his head chri≈øt: ≈øee like wi≈øe that you do your dutye accordyngly, and cleaue vnto him your hed: ≈øuffre with him yt you maye furder his cau≈øe. His cau≈øe nowe I vnder≈øtande to be Chry≈øtes cau≈øe, and
therefore beware good ≈øy≈øter in Chry≈øte, that in no wy≈øe ye hynder it. Loue ≈øo hys bodye and the ca≈øe and wealthe thereof, as youre loue maye further hym to the wynnynge bothe of bodye and ≈øoule vnto euerla≈øtynge lyfe. And thys loue ≈øhall bothe God allowe, your hu≈øbande ≈øhall haue iu≈øte cau≈øe to reioyce thereof, and all the godlye to commend you therefore, and to number you for the ≈øame, amonge the godlye and holye women of God. To youre hu≈øbande I haue written more: And thus fare you well nowe good deare Si≈øter in our ≈øauioure Chri≈øt. I was the bolder to write vnto you, for that I vnder≈øtoode my dearely beloued brother Au≈øtyne, whome I call Fau≈øtus, ≈øhouldbe the carier, a manne whome I thynke God hathe appoynted to doe much plea≈øure for hys pre≈øte ≈øeruauntes to hys warres.

div.head: To a frend that came to vi≈øite hym in pri≈øon but could not ≈øpeake wyth hym.
div.p: WElbeloued I thancke you hartelye for youre manyfolde kyndnes, but the Lorde ≈øhal, (I tru≈øt) acquite you youre meede. Thoughe Sathan rage, the Lorde is ≈øtronge inough to brydle hym, and to put an iron chayne ouer hys no≈øe when it ≈øhal plea≈øe hym. In the meane tyme they that are the Lordes, wyll flee vnto hym, & a≈ø≈øuredly he wyl not for≈øake them that ≈øeke vnto hym, in verye deede and in truthe. Thys bearer my manne is tru≈øtye, you maye ≈øende your token by hym. Let Nycolas keepe ≈øtyll the ≈øhyrtes. The Lorde rewarde that Ladye VViatte, whyche for hys ≈øake hathe thus remembred me: I doe not knowe her per≈øonne. What canne I rendre to may≈øtres Wylkyn≈øon for all her benefytes? Nothyng ≈øurelye but to de≈øyre the Lorde to acquite her with hys heauenlye grace. If you tarye I ≈øhall haue more to ≈øaye to you peraduenture hereafter. Nowe Vale in Domino chari≈øsime.

div.head: ¬∂ The manner of D. Ridleyes handlinge in the Scholes at Oxford, and of the impudent, ≈øpite full, & cruel dealing of the papi≈øtes: which he ≈øet before his di≈øputation by way of a preface, and is not vnfitte here to be placed among the letters, tran≈ølated out of his lattin copy into engly≈øh.
div.p: I Neuer yet in all my life ≈øawe or hearde anye thing done or handled more vaynelye or tumultuou≈øly, then the di≈øputation which was had with me of late in the ≈øcholes at Oxford. And ≈øurelye I coulde neuer haue thoughte, that it had bene po≈ø≈øible to haue found anye within this realme, beyng of any knowlege, learning and auncient degree of ≈øchole, ≈øo bra≈øen faced and ≈øo ≈øhameles, as to behaue them≈øelues ≈øo vainly and ≈øo like ≈øtage plaiers, as they did in that di≈øputation.

The Sorbonical clamours which at Paris when popery mo≈øt reigned, I in times pa≈øte haue ≈øene, might be worthely thought, in compari≈øon of this Thra≈øonicall and glorious o≈øtentation, to haue had muche mode≈øty. Howbeit, it was not to be wondred at, for that they which ≈øhould there haue bene Moderatoures, and rulers of others, and whiche ≈øhould haue geuen a good example in woorde grauitye &c.1. Tim. 4. as Paule teacheth, gaue wor≈øt example of all, and did, as it were, blowe the trompet to other, to rayle, rage, roare, and cry out. By rea≈øon wherof good chri≈øtian reader, it is manife≈øt that they neuer ≈øought for any truth, but only for the glorye of the world, and a bragginge victorye. But be≈øides the innumerable raylinges, rebukes, and taunts wherwith I was bayted on euery ≈øide, lea≈øt our cau≈øe, which in deede is gods cau≈øe, and his churches, ≈øhould al≈øo by the fal≈øe exaÃÑ ples of our di≈øputations, be euel ≈øpoken of & ≈ølaundered to the world, & ≈øo ye verity ≈øu≈øtayne hurt & hinderaÃÑce therby: I haue thought good to wryte my aun≈øweres my ≈øelfe, that who≈øoeuer is de≈øirous to know them and the truth withall, maye thereby perceyue tho≈øe thinges, whiche were chiefly obiected again≈øt me, and al≈øo in effect, what was aun≈øwered of me to euerye of them. Howebeit good Reader,
I coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe this to be mo≈øt true, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øet forth either al yt was (God knoweth) tumultuou≈øly ≈øpoken, & like as of mad men obiected of ≈øo many, whiche ≈øpake ofteÃÑtimes hudle, ≈øo that one could not well heare an other: eyther all that was aun≈øwered of me briefly to ≈øuch and ≈øo diuer≈øe opponentes. Moreouer, a great part of the time appointed for the di≈øputations, was vaynly ≈øpente in mo≈øt contumelious tauntes, hy≈ø≈øinges, clapping of handes and triumphes more then tolerable euen in ≈øtage playes, and that in the engli≈øh tounge to get the peoples fauor withall. All which thinges, when I with godly griefe did ≈øuffer, and therwithall did openly bewayle and witnes, that that companye of learned men, and ≈øcholes which were appoynted to graue men and to graue matters, were contaminate and defiled by ≈øuch foli≈øh and Robinhode pa≈øtimes, and that they which were the doers of ≈øuch things, did but therby openly ≈øhew theyr vanity: I was ≈øo far by my ≈øuch humble complaynt from doinge good, or helping any thing at al, that I was enforced, what wyth hi≈ø≈øing & ≈øhowting, and what with authority, to heare ≈øuch great reproches and ≈ølaunders vttered agayn≈øte me, as no graue man without blu≈øhing, could abide the herynge of the ≈øame ≈øpokeÃÑ of a mo≈øt vile knaue again≈øt a mo≈øt wretched ruffiane. At the beginning of the di≈øputatioÃÑ, when I ≈øhould haue confirmed mine an≈øwer to the fyr≈øt propo≈øition in few woordes, and that after the maner of diputations, before I could make an ende of my probation, whiche was not verye longe, euen the doctours them ≈øelues cried oute, he ≈øpeaketh bla≈øphemies, bla≈øphemies, bla≈øphemies. And wheÃÑ I on my knees mo≈øt humbly & hartly be≈øought theÃÑ, that they would vouch≈øafe to heare me to ye end, wherat ye Prolocutor ≈øomething moued (as it ≈øeemed) cried out let him reade it, let him read it: Yet wheÃÑ I again began to read it, there was by & by ≈øuch a cry and noy≈øe bla≈øphemies, bla≈øphemies, as I (to my remembrance) neuer heard or redde the like, except it be one which was in the actes of the Apo≈øtles ≈øtirred vp of Demetrius the ≈øiluer ≈ømith and others of his occupation cryenge out agayn≈øt Paule, greate is Diana of the Ephe≈øians, great is Diana of the Ephe≈øians: and excepte it were a certayne di≈øputation which the Arrians had again≈øt the Orthodoxes & ≈øuch as were of godly iudgment in Affricke, where it is ≈øaid
that ≈øuch as ye pre≈øidents & rulers of ye di≈øputatioÃÑ were, ≈øuch was al≈øo yt end of ye di≈øputatioÃÑ. Al was done in hurly burly, and the ≈ølaunders of the Arrians wer ≈øo outragious, that nothyng coulde quietly be hearde. So wryteth Victor in the ≈øebooke of his hi≈øtorye. And thus the cryes and tumultes of the≈øe men agayn≈øte me, nowe ≈øo preuayled, that whether I woulde or no, I was inforced to leaue of the readinge of my probations although they were but ≈øhort. And of the truthe herof, I haue al tho≈øe that were pre≈øent beyng of any di≈øcretion or hone≈øtye to be my witne≈ø≈øes. But hereof wil I cea≈øe to complayne any further. &c.

div.head: ¬∂ To Doctor We≈øton, requiring performaunce of certaine promi≈øes made vnto him, but neuer fulfilled, according to thaccu≈øtomed wily & vnfaythful dealyng of the papi≈øtes.
div.p: MAy≈øter Prolocutor, ye remember I am ≈øure how you promi≈øed me openlye in the Scholes after my prote≈øtation, that I ≈øhould ≈øee how my aun≈øweres were there taken and written of the notaries, whome you appoynted (Me fateor neminem recu≈øante) to write what ≈øhould be ≈øayd, and to haue had licence for to haue added vnto them, or for to haue altered them, as vpon more deliberation ≈øhoulde haue ≈øeemed me bea≈øte. Ye graunted me al≈øo, at the deliuerye of myne aun≈øwere vnto your fyr≈øte propo≈øition, a copye of the ≈øame.What promi≈øes he made openly in the ≈øcholes that were neuer performed, reade in the booke of Martyrs Folio. 958. The≈øe promy≈øes be not performed. If your ≈øuddeyne departure be any part of the cau≈øe therof, yet I pray you remeÃÑber that they maye be performed, for performance of promy≈øes is to be looked for at a righteou≈øe iudges handes.

Now I ≈øend you here myne aun≈øwers in writynge to your ≈øeconde and thyrde propo≈øitions, and doe de≈øire and require earne≈øtlye a copye of the ≈øame, and I ≈øhall by Gods grace, procure the paynes of the writer to be payde for and ≈øati≈øfyed accordinglye. When I woulde haue confyrmed my ≈øayenges with authorities or rea≈øons, you ≈øayde there openlye that I ≈øhoulde haue hadde time and place to ≈øaye and brynge what ≈øo euer I could an other time. And the ≈øame your ≈øayenge
was then there confyrmed of other of the Commi≈ø≈øioners: Yea and I dare ≈øay the audience al≈øo thought then that I ≈øhoulde haue had another daye to haue broughte and ≈øayd what I could ≈øaye, for the declaration and confyrmation of mine a≈ø≈øertions. Now that this was not done, but ≈øo ≈øodeÃÑly ≈øentence geuen before the cau≈øe was peefectlye heard, I can not but merueil at all, and the due reformation of all things which are ami≈ø≈øe, I commit vnto almighty god my heauenly father, which by hys deare ≈øon our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt (whome he hath made the vniuer≈øall iudge of all fle≈øh) ≈øhall truely & rightuou≈øly iudge both you and me,

May≈øter Proloquutor I de≈øire you, and in Gods name require you, that you truly bring forth and ≈øhow al my thre aun≈øwers writen & ≈øub≈øcribed with mine own hand, vnto ye higher hou≈øe of the coÃÑuocatioÃÑ, & ≈øpecially vnto my lord chauncelor, my Lordes of Dure≈øme, Elie, Norwich, Worcetor, & Chiche≈øter, and al≈øo to ≈øhow and exhibite this my writynge vnto them, which in the≈øe few lines I write herevnto you. And that I do make this reque≈øt vnto you by this my writyng, know you yt I dyd take witnes of theÃÑ, by whom I did ≈øend you this writing, & of tho≈øe which were then with theÃÑ pre≈øent, that is of the baylifes of Oxford, and of Mai≈øter Iri≈øh Alderman than there called to be a witnes.

div.head: To a Co≈øin of hys.
div.p:
GOds holye ≈øpyrite be with you nowe and euer, Amen. When I cal to remeÃÑbrabnce (beloued co≈øine) the ≈øtate of tho≈øe yt for fear of trouble, either for lo≈ø≈øe of goods, wil do in the ≈øight of the world, tho≈øe thinges that they know and be a≈ø≈øured are contrary to the will of God, I can do no le≈ø≈øe but lament theyr ca≈øe, beyng a≈ø≈øured that the ende therof wyll be ≈øo pitifull, withoute ≈øpedye repentaunce, that I tremble and feare to haue it in remembraunce. I woulde to God it lay vpon ≈øome earthly burden, ≈øo that fredome of con≈øcience mighte begenen vnto them. I write, as god knoweth, not of pre≈øumption but onlye lamentinge theyre ≈øtate whome I thought nowe in thys daungerous time, ≈øhould haue geuen bothe you and me comfortable in≈øtructions.
But alas, in ≈øtede therof, we haue per≈øwa≈øions to follow (I lament me to rehear≈øe it) ≈øuper≈øtitions idolatrye, yea & that wor≈øte of all is, they will ≈øeeke to proue it by the ≈øcripture. The Lord for his mercy turne theyr hartes. Amen.

div.head: A letter which he wrote as his la≈øt farewell, to al his true and faythefull frendes in God a little before he ≈øuffred: with a ≈øharpe admoniton by by the way, to the papi≈øts the enemies of the truth.
div.p: AT the name of Ie≈øus let euery kne bow, both of thyngs in heauen, and things in earth, and thinges vnder the earth, and let euerye tonge confe≈ø≈øe that Ie≈øus Chri≈øt is the lord vnto the glory of God the father. Amen.

As a man minding to take a farre iourney and to depart from his familiar frendes, commenly and naturally hath a de≈øire to byd his frendes farewell before hys departure: ≈øo likewi≈øe now I loking dayly when I ≈øhoulde be called for to departe hence from you (O al ye my dearely beloued brethren and ≈øi≈øters in oure Sauioure Chri≈øte, that dwel here in this world) hauing a like mind towardes you all, & al≈øo ble≈ø≈øed be God of this ≈øuch time & lea≈øure, whereof I right hartely thank his heauenly goodnes: do byd you all my deare brethren and ≈øi≈øters (I ≈øay) in Chri≈øt, that dwel vp on the earth, after ≈øuch manner as I can, Farewell.

Farewel my deare Brother George Shyp≈øide, whome I haue euer found faythfull, tru≈øty, and louinge in all ≈øtate and condicions, and now in the time of my cro≈ø≈øe, ouer all other to me mo≈øt frendly, and ≈øteadfa≈øt, & that which liked me be≈øt, ouer all other thinges, in Gods cau≈øe euer harty.

Farewell my deare ≈øi≈øter Alice his wyfe: I am gladde to beare of thee that thou doe≈øt take Chri≈øtes cro≈ø≈øe, whiche is layed now (ble≈ø≈øed be God) both on thy backe and mine, in good parte. Thanke thou GOD that hathe geuen thee a godly, and a louing hu≈øband: ≈øe thou honor him, and obey hym, according to Gods lawe. Honour thy mother in lawe his mother, and loue al tho≈øe that perteyne vnto hym, being ready to do them good as it ≈øhall lye in thy power. As for
thy chyldren, I doubte not of thy hu≈øbande, but that he whyche hathe geuen hym a hearte to loue and feare God, and in God them that pertayne vnto hym, ≈øhall al≈øo make hym frendely and benefyciall vnto thy children, euen as yf they had bene gotten of hys owne body.

Farewell my welbeloued brother Iohn Rydley of the Waltowne, and you my gentle and louyng Sy≈øter Elizabeth, whome be≈øydes the naturall league of amitye, your tender loue whiche you were ≈øayde euer to beare towardes me aboue the re≈øte of youre brethren, dothe bynde me to loue. My mynde was to haue acknowledged this youre louyng affection, and to haue acquyted it wyth dedes, and not wyth woordes alone. Youre daughter Elizabeth I byd farewell, whom I loue for the meeke and gentle Spiryte that God hath geuen her, which is a precious thyng in the ≈øyght of God.

Farewell my beloued Sy≈øter of Vnthancke, wyth all youre chyldren my nephewes and nices. Synce the departure of my Brother Hughe, my mynde was to haue beene vnto them in the ≈øteade of theyr father: but the Lorde god mu≈øt and will be theyr father, if they wil loue hym and feare him, and lyue in the trade of hys law.

Farewell my welbeloued and wor≈øhipfull Co≈øyns mai≈øter Nicholas Ridley of Wyllimount≈øwick and your wife, and I thanke you for all youre kyndne≈ø≈øe ≈øhewed bothe to me, and al≈øo to all youre owne kyn≈øefolke and myne. Good Co≈øyn, as GOD hath ≈øette you in that oure ≈øtocke and kyndred, not for anye re≈øpecte of youre per≈øonne, but of hys aboundaunte grace and goodne≈ø≈øe to bee as it were the Belweather to order and conducte the rea≈øte, and hathe al≈øo endued you wyth his manyfold gyftes of grace bothe heauenlye and worldlye aboue others: ≈øo I praye you good Co≈øin (as my tru≈øte and hope is in you) continue and increa≈øe in the mayntenaunce of truthe, hone≈øtye, rightuou≈øne≈ø≈øe and all true godlyne≈ø≈øe, and to the vttermo≈øt of your power, to wyth≈øtande fal≈øehode, vntruthe, vnryghteou≈øne≈ø≈øe and all vngodlyne≈ø≈øe, whych is forbid and condempned by the word and lawes of God.

Farewel my yong Co≈øin Rafe Whitfield. Oh your tyme
was verye ≈øhorte wyth me: my mynde was to haue done you good, and yet you caughte in that little tyme a lo≈ø≈øe, but I tru≈øte it ≈øhall bee recompenced as it ≈øhall plea≈øe almighty god.

Farewell al my whole kyndred and countreymen, farewell in Chri≈øt altogether. Therefore, ≈øeyng we haue ≈øo muche occa≈øion to ≈øuffer and to take afflictions for Chri≈øtes names ≈øake pacientlye, ≈øo many commodities thereby, ≈øo waightye cau≈øes, ≈øo manye good examples, ≈øo greate nece≈ø≈øitye, ≈øo ≈øure promi≈øes of eternall life and heauenlye ioyes, of hym that cannot lie: Let vs throwe away what≈øoeuer might let vs, all burden of ≈øynne, and all kynde of carnalitie, and patiently and con≈øtantly let vs ronne for the be≈øte game in thys race that is ≈øet before vs, euer hauyng our eyes vpon Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the ryngleader, Heb. 12. capitain, and perfiter of our fayth, which for the ioy that was ≈øet before him, endured the cro≈ø≈øe, not pa≈ø≈øyng vpon the ignomy & ≈øhame therof, and is ≈øet now at the right hand of the throne of god. not the correction of the Lord, nor fall not from hym, when thou art rebuked of hym, for whom the Lorde loueth hym doth he correcte, and ≈øcourgeth euery childe whome he receyueth: what chylde is he whome the father doth not cha≈øten? Al cha≈øti≈øement for the pre≈øent tyme, appeareth not plea≈øaunt but payneful: but afterward it rendreth the fruit of ryghtuou≈ønes on them, whiche are exerci≈øed in it. Wherfore let vs be of good chere (good brethren) and let vs pluck vp our feble members that were fallen, or began to fainte, harte, handes, knees, and all the re≈øt, and let vs walke vprighte and ≈øtraighte, that no lymping nor haultyng bryng vs out of the way.
