Why ≈øhoulde we chri≈øtians ferre death? Can death depryue vs of Chri≈øt, which is all our comforte, our ioye, and our lyfe? Nay for≈øothe. But contrary, deathe ≈øhall delyuer vs from thys mortall bodye, whyche lodeth and beareth downe the Spirite,2. Cor 5. that it can not ≈øo well perceyue heauenly thinges: in the whiche ≈øo long as we dwell, we are ab≈øent from God.

Wherfore, vnder≈øtandyng oure ≈øtate in that we be chri≈øtians, that yf our mortall bodye, whiche is oure earthlye hou≈øe, were de≈øtroyed, we haue a building,2. Cor. 5 a hou≈øe not made wyth handes, but euerla≈øtyng in heauen &c: therefore we are of good cheare, and knowe that when we are in the bodye, we are ab≈øente from God, for we walke by faythe and not by cleare ≈øyghte. And who that hath true faith in our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt, whereby he knoweth ≈øomewhat truly what Chri≈øt our Sauiour is, that he is the eternal ≈øonne of God, lyfe, lyght, the wi≈ødome of the father, all goodnes, al rightuou≈øne≈ø≈øe and what≈øoeuer is good that hart can de≈øire, yea infinite pleÃÑty of al the≈øe, aboue that that mans hart can eyther conceyue or thynke, (for in him dwelleth the fulne≈ø≈øe of the godhead corporally) and al≈øo that he is geuen vs of the father, and made of God to be our wi≈ødome,1. Cor. 1. our rightuou≈ønes, our holines, and our redemptioÃÑ: who (I ≈øay) is he that beleueth this in dede, that would not gladly be with his mai≈øter Chri≈øt? Phili. 1. To dye in the defence of Chri≈øtes go≈øpell, it is oure bounded duety to Chri≈øt, and al≈øo to our neyghbor. To Chri≈øt, Rom. 9 1. Iohn. 3. for he died for vs, & ro≈øe again ye he might be lord ouer all. And ≈øeyng he dyed for vs, we al≈øo (≈øaieth S. Iohn) ≈øhoulde ieopard, yea geue our lyfe for our bretherne. Ble≈ø≈øed are they therfore that die in the lorde, and if they die in the Lordes cau≈øe, they are mo≈øt happy of all. div.p: KNow (gentle Reader) that mai≈øter Prollocutour dyd promy≈øe me in the di≈øputations publikely, that I ≈øhould ≈øee myne aun≈øwers how they were collected and gathered of the Notaries, and that I ≈øhould haue licence to adde or dimini≈øhe, to alter or chaunge afterwarde, as I ≈øhould thynke be≈øt would make for me to the aun≈øweryng of the propo≈øitions. And now, for that is le≈øte for vs to do, let vs pray that God would haue mercy on his churche of Englande, that yet once, when it ≈øhall be hys good plea≈øure, it may clearely ≈øee and gredely embrace, in the face of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the wyl of the heauenly father, and that of hys infinite mercye, he would eyther turne to hym the ragyng and rauening wolues, and mo≈øt ≈øubtyll ≈øeducers of his people, whiche are by them altogether ≈øpoyled and bewitched, eyther that of hys mo≈øt rightuous iudgement, he would dryue the≈øe faythle≈ø≈øe feeders from hys flocke, that they may no more bee able to trouble and ≈øcatter abroad Chri≈øtes ≈øhepe from their ≈øhepeherd, and that ≈øpedely: Amen, Amen. And let euery one that hath the ≈øpirite (as S. Iohn ≈øayeth) ≈øay Amen. Yet further know thou, that when Mai≈øter Prolocutour did put forth three propo≈øitions, he dyd commaund vs to an≈øwer particularly to them all. After our an≈øwers, neyther he nor hys fellowes did euer enter into any di≈øputation of any one of theÃÑ ≈øauyng only of the fyr≈øt. Yea, when that he had a≈øked vs after di≈øputations of the fyr≈øt (as ye haue heard for my part) whether we would ≈øub≈øcribe to the whole, in ≈øuch ≈øort, forme, and words as there are ≈øet forth, withoute further di≈øputation,

But thanks be to God that gaue me to write thys before the v≈øe of ≈øuche thinges were vtterly taken awaye. Almyghty God whyche beholdeth the cau≈øes of the afflicted, & is wonted to lo≈øe & loke mercifully on the bonds & gronings of the captiues, he vouch ≈øafe now to looke vpoÃÑ the cau≈øes of hys pore church in EnglaÃÑd, & of his great wi≈ødome & vn≈øpeakable mercy, wyth ≈øpeede to make an end of our mi≈øery, Amen, Amen, Amen,

div.head: ‚ùßLetters of may≈øter Iohn Hoper late By≈øhoppe of Gloce≈øter: wher, after his long and cruel impri≈øonmente in the flete, he was burnte wyth mo≈øt terrible kindes of tormentes (as you may reade in the boke of martyrs fol. 1062.) for the defeÃÑce of the ≈øyncere truth of the go≈øpell, the 9. day, of Ianuary, in the yeare of our Lord. 1555.
¬∂A letter which he wrote to certayn godly per≈øons, profe≈ø≈øours and louers of the truth, in≈øtructing them howe they ≈øhoulde behaue them ≈øelues at the beginnynge of the chaunge of religion.
div.p:
THe grace, mercy, and peace of God the father throughe our Lorde Ie≈øus Chry≈øte, be wyth you my deare brethren and wyth al tho≈øe that vnfaynedly loue and embrace his holye go≈øpell, Amen. It is tolde me that the wycked Idole the ma≈ø≈øe is ≈øtably≈øhed agayne by a law, & pa≈ø≈øed in the Parleament hou≈øe. Lerne the truth of it I pray you, & what penalty is appointed in the act, to ≈øuch as ≈øpeake agayn≈øt it. Al≈øo whether there be any coÃÑpul≈øion to con≈øtraine men to be at it. The ≈øtatute throughlye knowne, ≈øuch as be abroade & at liberty, maye prouide for them ≈øelues and auoyd the daunger the better. Doubtles there hath not bene ≈øene before our tyme, ≈øuch a parleament as thys is, that as many as were ≈øu≈øpected to be fauourers of gods worde, ≈øhoulde be bany≈øhed out of both hou≈øes. But we mu≈øt geue god thankes for that truth he hathe opened in the time of hys ble≈ø≈øed ≈øeruaunte kynge Edwarde the ≈øyxte, and praye vnto hym that we denye it not, nor dy≈øhoner it with idolatrye
but that we maye haue ≈øtrength and patience rather to dye tenne tymes, then to deny him once. Ble≈ø≈øed ≈øhall we be if euer god make vs worthye of that honoure, to ≈øhede oure bloode for hys names ≈øake. And ble≈ø≈øed then ≈øhall we thinke the parentes whiche broughte vs into thys worlde, that we ≈øhoulde from thys mortalitye be caried into immortalitye. If we followe the commaundemente of Saynte Paule that ≈øayth, if ye be ri≈øen agayne wyth Chry≈øte, Col. 3. ≈øeeke the thynges that be aboue where Chry≈øte ≈øytteth at the righte hande of God: we ≈øhall neyther departe from the vayne tran≈øitorye goodes of thys worlde, nor from thys wretched and mortall lyfe, wyth ≈øo greate paynes as other doe. Let vs praye to our heauenlye father that we maye knowe and loue hys ble≈ø≈øed wyll, and the gloryous ioye prepared for vs in time to come, and that we maye knowe and hate all thynges contrarye to hys ble≈ø≈øed wyll and al≈øo the payne prepared for the wicked men in the world to come. There is no better waye to be v≈øed in thys trouble≈øome tyme for your con≈øolation, then many tymes to haue a≈ø≈øemblies to gether of ≈øuche menne and women as be of your religion in Chry≈øte, and there to talke and renewe amonge your ≈øelues the truth of youre religion, to ≈øee what ye be by the woord of God and to remembre what yee were before yee came to the knowledge thereof, to waygh and conferre the dreames and fal≈øe lyes of the preachers that nowe preache, wyth the woorde of God that retayneth all truth, and by ≈øuche talke and familiar re≈øortinge together, ye ≈øhall the better fynde out all their lyes that nowe goe aboute to deceyue you, and al≈øo both knowe and loue the truth that God hath opened to vs. It is muche requi≈øite that the members of Chry≈øte, comforte one an other, make prayers together, conferre one with another: ≈øo ≈øhall ye be the ≈øtronger, and Gods ≈øpirite ≈øhall not be ab≈øent from you but in the myds of you to teach you, to comfort you, to make you wi≈øe in al godly thyngs, patiente in aduer≈øity and ≈øtrong in per≈øecution. Ye ≈øe how the congregatioÃÑ of the wicked by helping one an other, make their wicked religion & them≈øelues ≈øtrong again≈øt Gods truth & hys peple. It ye may haue ≈øome lerned maÃÑ that can, out of ye ≈øcriptures ≈øpeak vnto you of faith & true honoryng of God, al≈øo
that can ≈øhew you the de≈øcente of Chri≈øtes church from the begynning of it vntyll thys daye, that ye maye perceaue by the lyfe of your forefathers the≈øe two thynges: the one that Chry≈øtes woorde, whych ≈øayde that al hys mu≈øt ≈øuffer per≈øecutioÃÑ and trouble in the world, be true: the other that none of all hys before our time, e≈øcaped trouble: then ≈øhall ye perceiue that it is but a folly for one that profe≈ø≈øeth Chri≈øte trulye, to looke for the loue of the worlde. Thus ≈øhall ye learne to beare trouble and to exerci≈øe youre religion and feele in deede that Chry≈øtes woordes be true: in the worlde, ye ≈øhall ≈øuffer per≈øecution. Iohn. 16 And when ye feele your religion in deede, ≈øaye yee be no better then youre forefathers, but be gladde that ye maye be counted worthye ≈øouldioures for thys warre, and praye to God when ye come together, that he wyll v≈øe and order you and youre doyinges to the≈øe thre endes, whyche ye mu≈øte take heede of: the fyr≈øte that ye gloryfye God, the nexte that ye edifye the churche and congregation, the thyrde that ye profyte your owne ≈øoules. In all youre doynges beware ye be not deceaued. For although thys tyme be not yet bloodye and tyrannous as the time of oure forfathers that coulde not beare the name of Chri≈øte wythout daunger of lyfe and goodes: yet is oure tyme more perellous both for bodye and ≈øoule. Therefore of vs Chry≈øt ≈øayde: Luke. 18. thinke ye when the ≈øonne of manne commeth, he ≈øhall fynde anye fayth vpon earth? He ≈øayde not, thynke ye he ≈øhal fynde anye man or woman chry≈øtened and in name a chri≈øtian: but he ≈øpake of the faythe that ≈øaueth the chri≈øtian man in Chry≈øt, and doubtles the ≈øcar≈øitye of faith is now more (and wyll I feare increa≈øe) then it was in the time of the greate≈øt Tyrannes that euer were: and no maruell whye. Reade yee the ≈øyxte chapter of Saynte Iohns Reuelation and ye ≈øhall perceyue amonges other thynges, that at the opening of the fourthe ≈øeale, came out a pale hor≈øe, and he that ≈øatte vppon hym was called deathe, and hell followed hym. Thys hor≈øe is the time wherein hypocrites and di≈ø≈øemblers entred into the Churche vnder the precente of true religion, as monkers, Friers Nonnes, ma≈ø≈øynge prie≈øtes, wyth ≈øuche other, that haue killed moe ≈øoules wythe here≈øyes and ≈øuper≈øty≈øtitioÃÑ,
theÃÑ al the TyraÃÑnes that euer were, killed bodies with fyre, ≈øword, or bani≈øhement, as it appereth by hys name that ≈øitteth vpon the hor≈øe, who is called death: for all ≈øoules that leaue Chri≈øt and tru≈øt to the≈øe hipocrytes, lyue to the diuil in euerla≈øting payne, as is declared by him that followeth the pale hor≈øe which is hel. The≈øe preteÃÑ≈øed and pale hypocrites, haue ≈øtirred the earthquakes, that is to witte, the princes of the world, agayn≈øt Chri≈øtes church, and haue al≈øo darkned the ≈øonne, and made the moone bloody, and haue cau≈øed the ≈øtarres to fall from heauen, that is to ≈øaye, haue darkned wyth mi≈øtes and daylye doe darken, as ye heare by theyre ≈øermons, the cleare ≈øonne of Gods mo≈øte pure woorde: the moone, whiche be Gods true preachers, whiche fetche onelye lyghte at the ≈øonne of Gods woorde, are turned into blood, pri≈øons, and chaines, that theyr light can not ≈øhine vnto the world as they would: WherupoÃÑ it coÃÑmeth to pa≈ø≈øe that the ≈øtars, that is to ≈øay Chri≈øtian people, fal froÃÑ heauen that is to witte, from Gods mo≈øte true word, to hypocri≈øye, mo≈øt deuely≈øhe ≈øuper≈øtition and idolatrye. Let ≈øome learned man ≈øhew you al the articles of your belief and monuments of Chri≈øtian fayth, from the time of Chri≈øte hetherto, and ye ≈øhall perceiue that there was neuer mention of ≈øuch articles as the≈øe hypocrites teache. God ble≈ø≈øe you, and praye for me as I do for you.

I haue receaued from you (dearelye beloued in our ≈øauioure Ie≈øus Chri≈øte) by the hands of my ≈øeruant william Downton, your liberality, for the which I do mo≈øt hartly thank you, and I pray≈øe god hyghly in you and for you, who hathe moued youre heartes to ≈øhowe this kindnes towardes me, prayinge hym to pre≈øerue you from all famyne, ≈øcarcity, and lacke of the truth of hys word, which is the liuely foode of your ≈øoules, as you pre≈øerue my body from hunger and other nece≈ø≈øities, which ≈øhould happeÃÑ vnto me, were it not cared for by the beneuolence and charity of godly people.
Suche as haue taken all worldlye gooddes and landes from me, and ≈øpoyled me of all that I had, haue empri≈øoned my bodye and appoynted no one halfepeny to feede or to relieue me wythall. But I doe forgeue them and praye for them daylye in my poore prayer vnto God, and from my hearte I wy≈øhe their ≈øaluation, and quietlye and pacientlye beare theyr iniuries, wy≈øhyng no farther extremity to bee v≈øed towardes vs. Yet yf it ≈øeeme contrary be≈øte vnto oure heauenlye father, I haue made my reckenyng, and fullye re≈øolued my ≈øelfe to ≈øuffer the vttermo≈øt that they are able to do again≈øt me, yea death it ≈øelfe, by the ayde of Chri≈øt Ie≈øu, who dyed the mo≈øte vyle deathe of the cro≈ø≈øe for vs wretches and my≈øerable ≈øynners. But of thys I am a≈ø≈øured, that the wycked world with all his force and power, ≈øhall not touche one of the heares of our heades wythout leaue ad lycence of oure heauenly father, who≈øe wyll be done in al thynges. If he wyll lyfe, lyfe bee it: if he wyll deathe, deathe be it. Onelye we praye, that oure wylles maye bee ≈øubiecte vnto hys wyll, and then althoughe bothe we and all the worlde ≈øee none other thynge but deathe, yet yf he thynke lyfe be≈øt, we ≈øhall not dye, no althoughe the ≈øword be drawen oute ouer oure heades: as Abraham thoughte to kyll his ≈øonne I≈øaac, yet when god perceaued that Abraham had ≈øurrendred hys wyll to Gods wyll, and was contente to kill hys ≈øonne, god then ≈øaued hys ≈øonne. Dearely beloued, if we be contented to obeye gods wyll, and for hys commaundementes ≈øake, to ≈øurrender oure goodes and our ≈øelues to be at his plea≈øure, it maketh no mater whether we kepe goods and lyfe, or loo≈øe them. Nothing can hurte vs that is taken from vs for Gods cau≈øe, nor nothyng can at length doe vs good, that is pre≈øerued contrary vnto Gods commaundemente. Lette vs wholye ≈øuffer God to v≈øe vs and ours after hys holye wy≈øedome, and beware we neyther v≈øe nor gouerne oure ≈øelues contrarye to hys wyll by oure owne wi≈øedome, for yf we doe, oure wi≈ødome wyll at lengthe proue foli≈øhnes. It is kept to no good purpo≈øe that we kepe contrarye vnto his commaundementes. It can by no meanes be takeÃÑ from vs that he would ≈øhould tary with vs. He is no good chri≈øtian that ruleth hym ≈øelfe and his, as worldlye meanes ≈øerueth: for he that ≈øo doth ≈øhall haue as
many chaunges as chaunceth in the world. To daye, wyth the worlde he ≈øhall lyke and pray≈øe the truthe of GOD, to morowe as the worlde wyll, ≈øo wyll he lyke and pray≈øe the fal≈øhode of manne: to daye wyth Chry≈øte, and to morowe wyth Antichri≈øte. Wherefore deare brethren, as touchynge youre behauoure towardes God, v≈øe both youre inwarde ≈øpirytes and youre outewarde bodyes, youre inwarde and youre outwarde man (I ≈øaye) not after the meanes of menne, but after the infallible woorde of God. Refrayne from euyll in bothe, and glorify your heauenlye father in both. For yf ye thynke ye can inwardly in the hart ≈øerue hym, and yet outwardlye ≈øerue wyth the worlde in externall ≈øeruyce, the thyng that is not GOD, ye deceaue youre ≈øelues, for bothe the bodye and the ≈øoule mu≈øte together concurre in the honoure of God, as Saynte Paule playnlye teacheth. 1. Cor 6. For if an hone≈øte wife be bounde to geue both hart and body to fayth and ≈øeruice in mariage, and if an hone≈øt wiues fayth in the hart, cannot ≈øtande with an whory≈øh or defiled body outwardlye: muche le≈ø≈øe can the true faythe of a chri≈øtian in the ≈øeruice of chri≈øtianitye, ≈øtande with the bodely ≈øeruice of externall idolatry: for the my≈øtery of mariage is not ≈øo honorable betwene man and wyfe, as it is betwene Chry≈øte and euery Chri≈øtian man, as Saynte Paule ≈øayeth. Therfore deare brethren, praye to the heauenlye father, that as he ≈øpared not the ≈øoule nor the bodye of hys dearelye beloued ≈øonne, but applyed bothe of them with extreame payne, to worke our ≈øaluation both of bodye and ≈øoule: ≈øo he wyll gyue vs all grace to applye our bodies and ≈øoules to be ≈øeruantes vnto him, for doubtles he requyreth a≈øwell the one as the other, and cannot be mi≈øcontented with one, and well plea≈øed with the other. Let not vs therefore good brethren, deuide our ≈øelues, and ≈øaye oure ≈øoules ≈øerue hym what≈øoeuer our bodies do to the contrarye, for ciuile order and pollicie. But (alas) I knowe by my ≈øelf what troubleth you, that is, the great daunger of the world that wil reuenge (ye thinke) youre ≈øeruice to God, wythe ≈øwoorde and fyre, wythe lo≈ø≈øe of goodes and landes, But deare bretherne waye
of the other ≈øyde, that your enemies and Gods enemies ≈øhal not do a≈ømuch as they would, but a≈ømuch as God ≈øhal ≈øuffer them, who can trappe them in their owne coun≈øels, and de≈øtroye them in the middes of theyr furies. Remember ye bee the workmen of the Lord, and called into his vineyard, there to labour till euening tyde, that ye may receyue youre peny, Math. 20. which is more worth then all the kinges of the earth. But he that calleth vs into hys vyneyard, hath not tolde vs how ≈øore or how feruently the ≈øonne ≈øhall trouble vs in our labour: but hath bidde vs laboure and committe the bytterne≈ø≈øe therof vnto hym, who can and will ≈øo moderate all afflictions, that no man ≈øhall haue more layd vpon hym, then in Chri≈øt he ≈øhalbe able to beare: vnto who≈øe mercifull tuitioÃÑ and defence, I commend both your ≈øoules and your bodeis. 2. September. 1554.

div.p: THe grace of God be with you, Amen. I perceaued by youre letter, howe that vppon new yeares daye at nyghte, there were taken a godlye companye of Chri≈øtians, while≈øt they were praying. So doth the worde of God commaunde all men to pray charitablye for tho≈øe that hate them, and not to reuile any maie≈øtrate with words, or to meane him euyll by force and violence. They al≈øo maye reioyce that in well doynge they were taken to the pri≈øoÃÑ. Wherfore I haue thought it good to ≈øend them this little wrytyng of co≈øolation, prayng god to ≈øend them patience, charity, and con≈øtancye in the truth of hys mo≈øt holy word. div.head: ¬∂To the godly and faithfull company of pri≈øoners in both the Counters, which were taken together at prayer in a hou≈øe in Bowchurchyard.

Dearely deloued in the Lord, euer ≈øythens your impri≈øonment, I haue ben maruelou≈øly moued with great affections and pa≈ø≈øioÃÑs, as wel of mirth and gladnes, as of heauines and ≈øorow. Of gladnes in this, that I perceiued how ye be bent and geuen to prayer and inuocation of gods helpe, in the≈øe darke and wicked procedings of men again≈øt gods glory. I haue bene ≈øory, to perceiue the malice and wickednes of meÃÑ to be ≈øo cruell, diueli≈øh, and tyrannical, to per≈øecute the people of god, for ≈øeruyng of god, for ≈øaying and hearyng of the holy p≈øalmes and the word of eternall life. The≈øe cruell doings do declare, that the papi≈øts church is more bloody and tyrannical, then euer was the ≈øword of the Ethnickes & gentiles. When I heard of your takyng, and what ye were doing, wherfore, and by whome ye were taken: I remembred how the chri≈øtians in the primitiue church were v≈øed by the cruelty of vnchri≈øtened heathens in the tyme of Traiane the emperour, about 77 yeres after Chri≈øtes a≈øcen≈øion into heauen. The chri≈øtians were per≈øecuted very ≈øore, as thoughe they had bene traitors & mouers of ≈øedition. Wherupon the gentile emperour Traiane required to know the true, cau≈øe of chri≈øtian mens trouble. When Traiane the emperour vnder≈øtode it was for nothyng but for con≈øcince and religion: he cau≈øed by his coÃÑmaundements euery wher, that no man ≈øhould be per≈øecuted for ≈øeruyng of god. Lo, a gentile and heathen man would not haue ≈øuch as were of a contrary religion, puni≈øhed for ≈øeruing of god. But the pope and his church haue ca≈øt you into pri≈øon, beyng taken euen in doyng the worke of god, and one of the mo≈øte excellente workes that is required of chri≈øtian men, that is to witte, whiles ye were in prayer, & not in ≈øuch wicked and ≈øuper≈øtitious

prayer, as the papi≈øtes v≈øe: but in the ≈øame prayer that Chri≈øt hath taught you to pray, and in his name onely ye gaue god thankes for that ye haue receaued, and for hys ≈øake ye a≈øked for ≈øuch things, as ye want. O glad maye ye be that euer ye were born, Math. 5 to be appreheÃÑded while≈øt ye were ≈øo vertuou≈øly occupied. Ble≈ø≈øed be they that ≈øuffer for righteou≈ønes ≈øake. For if god had ≈øuffred them that toke your bodies, then to haue takeÃÑ your life al≈øo: now had ye ben folowing the laÃÑbe in perpetual ioyes away from the coÃÑpany & a≈ø≈øeÃÑble of wicked men. But the lord woulde not haue you ≈øodainly ≈øo to depart, but re≈øerueth you gloriou≈øly to ≈øpeake & maintain his truth to the world. Be ye not careful what ye ≈øhal ≈øay, for god wil go out & in with you, & wil be pre≈øeÃÑt in your harts & in your mouthes to ≈øpeak his wi≈ødoÃÑ, althogh it ≈øeme foli≈øhnes to ye worlde. He that hath begon this good work in you, confirme, ≈øtrengthen, & continue you in ye ≈øame vnto the end, and pray vnto him, that ye may fear him only, that hath power to kil both body and ≈øoule, & to ca≈øt theÃÑ into hel fire. Be of good comfort, al the hears of your heads be numbred, Math. 10. and there is not one of them canne peri≈øhe, except youre heauenlye father ≈øuffer it to pery≈øhe. Nowe ye bee eueÃÑ in the field, and placed in the forefront of Chri≈øtes battaile. Doubtles it is a ≈øinguler fauour of God, and a ≈øpecial loue of hym towardes you, to geue you this foreward and preeminence, and a ≈øigne that he tru≈øteth you before others of hys people. Wherfore (deare brethreÃÑ and ≈øi≈øters) continually fyght thys fyght of the Lorde. Your cau≈øe is mo≈øt iu≈øte and godly, ye ≈øtand for the true Chri≈øt, who is after the fle≈øh in heauen, and for hys true religion and honour, whiche is amplye, fully, ≈øufficiently and aboundantly conteined in the holy Te≈øtament ≈øealed wyth chri≈øts own blood. Be not afeard of your aduer≈øaries,i. Iobn. 4. for he that is in you, is ≈øtronger then he that is them. Shrynke not although it be payne to you. Your paynes be not now ≈øo greate as hereafter

Reade the ≈øecond chapter of S. Lukes go≈øpell, and there ye ≈øhall ≈øee, howe the ≈øhepheardes that watched vpon their ≈øhepe all night, as ≈øoone as they heard that Chri≈øte was borne at Bethlem, by and by they went to ≈øee hym. So let vs do now, wheÃÑ we be called, and commit all other thynges vnto hym that calleth vs. He wyll take heede that all thinges ≈øhal be wel: he wyll helpe the hu≈øband, he will comfort the wyfe, he wil guide the ≈øeruaunts, he wyll kepe the hou≈øe, he wil pre≈øerue the goods, yea rather then it ≈øhould be vndone,i. div.head: ¬∂To certaine of hys beloued frendes in god, exhortyng them to ≈øticke con≈øtantlye to the profe≈ø≈øed truth of the go≈øpell in tho≈øe days of tryall, and not to ≈øhrynke for any trouble.
div.p:
THe grace of God be with you, Amen. I did write vnto you of late, & told you what extremitye the parliamente had concluded vppon concernyng religion, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øyng the true, and ≈øettyng forthe the vntrue, entendyng to cau≈øe
all men by extremity to for≈øweare them≈øelues and to take agayne for the head of the church, him that is neyther heade nor member of it, but a very enemy, as the word of god and all auncient writers do record: and for lacke of law and authority they wyll v≈øe force and extremity, which haue bene the arguments to defend the Pope and popery ≈øith his wicked authority began fyr≈øte in the worlde. But nowe is the tyme of tryall, to ≈øee whether we feare more God or man. It was an ea≈øy thing to hold with Chri≈øt, whiles the prince and world held with hym: but now the worlde hateth hym, is the true tryall who be hys. Wherfore in the name and in the vertue, ≈øtrength, and power of his holy ≈øpiryte, prepare youre ≈øelues in any ca≈øe to aduer≈øitye and con≈øtancie. Lette vs not runne away when it is mo≈øt tyme to fyght. Remember that none ≈øhalbe crowned but ≈øuch as fyghte manfully, and he that endureth vnto the ende, ≈øhalbe ≈øaued. Ye mu≈øte now turne all your cogitations from the peryll ye ≈øee, and marke by fayth what foloweth the peryl: either victorye in this worlde of your enemies, or els a ≈øurrender of this life, to inherite the euerla≈øtyng kyngdome. Beware of beholdyng to much the felicity or the my≈øerye of this worlde: for the con≈øideration and earne≈øt loue or feare of eyther of theÃÑ, draweth from god. Wherfore thynke wyth youre ≈øelues as touchyng the felicity of the worlde, it is good, but yet none otherwy≈øe then it ≈øtaÃÑdeth with the fauoure of god: it is to be kept, but yet ≈øo farre forthe as by kepyng of it, we loo≈øe not god. It is good to abyde and tary ≈øtyll among our frendes here, but yet ≈øo that we tary not therwithall in gods di≈øplea≈øure, and hereafter to dwell in hell with the deuils in fyre euerla≈øtyng. There is nothyng vnder god by may be kept, ≈øo that god beyng aboue all thynges we haue, be not lo≈øte. Of aduer≈øity iudge the ≈øame. Impri≈øonment is paynefull: but yet liberty vpon euil conditions is more payneful. The pri≈øons ≈øtincke, but yet not ≈øo much as ≈øwete hou≈øes, where as the feare and true honor of god lacketh. I mu≈øt be alone and ≈øolitary, it is better ≈øo to be and haue god with me, thou to be in company with the wicked. Lo≈ø≈øe of goods is great, but lo≈ø≈øe of gods grace and fauour is greater. Wherefore there is neither felicitye nor aduer≈øitie of this world, that can appeare to be greate, if it be wayed with the ioyes or paynes in the worlde to come. I can doe no more but praye for you: doe the ≈øame for me for Gods ≈øake. For my parte I thanke the heauenly father, I haue made myne accouÃÑptes & appointed my ≈øelfe vnto the wil of the heauenly father: as he will, ≈øo I will by his grace. For gods ≈øake, as ≈øoone as ye can, ≈øende my poore wyfe and chyldren ≈øome letter from you, and my letter al≈øo whiche I ≈øente of late to Downton. As it is tolde me, ≈øhe had neuer letter from me, ≈øith the comming of ma≈øter S vnto her: the more to blame the me≈ø≈øengers, for I haue written diuers times. She is a godly and wi≈øe womaÃÑ, & if my meanynges had bene accompli≈øhed ≈øhe ≈øhould haue had nece≈ø≈øary thinges: but that I meant god can performe, to whome I commend both her and you all. I am a precious iewell now and deintely kepte, neuer ≈øo deintely: for neither mine own maÃÑ nor any of the ≈øeruaunts of the hou≈øe may come at me, but my keper alone, a ≈øimple rude maÃÑ god knoweth. div.head: An other letter to certaine godly par≈øons wrytten to the ≈øame effecte.
div.p:
THe grace of god be with you, Amen. I doe geue our heauenly father thankes, that moueth you to remeÃÑber your afflicted brethern, and I do (as I am bound) pray for you, that wyth your remembraunce of me, ye prouide helpe, & ≈øuccour me with ≈øuch goods, as god doth endue you withall. Doubtle≈ø≈øe yf euer wretch & vyle

Seyng he is ≈øo mercifull and carefull for my ≈øynful body, I doubt not but he hath more care of my wretched ≈øoule, ≈øo that in bothe I may ≈øerue his maie≈øty, and be a liuely and profitalbe meÃÑber of hys poore afflicted church. I do not care what extremity this world ≈øhal worke or deui≈øe, praying you in the bowels of hym that ≈øhedde his precious bloode for you, to remember and folow the knowlege ye haue learned of his truthe. Be not a≈øhamed nor afrayde to follow hym, beware of this ≈øentence, that it take no place in you: Luke. 9 no man (≈øayeth Chri≈øt) that putteth hys hand to the ploughe and looketh backewarde, is meete for the kyngdome of God. Remember that Chry≈øte wylled hym that would builde a Tower, to ≈øytte downe fyr≈øt and loke whether he were able to performe it, lea≈øte he ≈øhould begin and leaue of in the mydde≈øt and ≈øo be mocked of hys neyghbors and lo≈øe therwythall a≈ømuche as he be≈øtowed. Luke. 14 Chri≈øte tolde ≈øuche as woulde builde in hym eternall lyfe, what the price thereof was, euen at the begynnyng of hys doctryne, and ≈øayde they ≈øhoulde be per≈øecuted. Math. 10. Al≈øo they ≈øhoulde ≈øometyme paye and be≈øtowe both goodes and landes, before the Tower of ≈øaluation woulde be builded. Seyng the pryce of truthe in religion hathe bene alwayes the di≈øplea≈øure and per≈øecution of the worlde, let vs beare it, and Chri≈øt wil recompence the charges aboundantly. Yt is no lo≈ø≈øe to lacke the loue of the worlde, and to fynde the loue of God, nor no harme to ≈øuffer the lo≈ø≈øe of worldly thinges and fynde eternall lyfe. div.p:

Leaue the outward ≈øhew, & ≈øee by the word of god what truth is, & accept truth & di≈ølike her not though man call her fal≈øhode. As it is now, ≈øo hath it ben heretofore, the truth reiected & fal≈øhod receiued. Suche as haue profe≈ø≈øed truthe, for truthe haue ≈ømarted, and the frendes of fal≈øehode laughed them to ≈øcorne. Wherfore dere brother a≈øke & demauÃÑd of your boke, the te≈øtameÃÑt of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt in the≈øe woful & wretched dais, what you ≈øhold

The dayes be daungerous and ful of perill, not only for the world and worldly thinges, but for heauen and heauenly thinges. I woulde wryte more often vnto you, but I do perceyue you be at ≈øo much charges with me that I feare you would thinke wheÃÑ I write, I craue. Send me nothyng tyll I ≈øend to you for it, and ≈øo tell the good men your partners, and wheÃÑ I nede I will be bold of you .3. Decem. 1554.

div.head: A report of hys mi≈øerable impri≈øonment and mo≈øt cruell handlyng by Babington, that enemye of god and of hys truthe, then Warden of the Fleete.
div.p: THe fyr≈øt of Semptember. 1553. I was committed vnto the Flete from Richmont, to haue the liberty of the pri≈øon, and within vi. dais after, I payed for my liberty fyue poundes ≈øterling to the Warden for fees, who immediatly vpon the paymente therof, complained vnto Steven Gardiner, bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, and ≈øo was I committed to clo≈øe pry≈øon one quarter of a yeare, in the Tower chaÃÑber of ye Fleete, & v≈øed very extremely. Then by the meanes of a good gentlewoman, I had libertye to come downe to dinner and ≈øupper, and not to ≈øpeake wyth any of my frendes: but as ≈øoone as dinner and ≈øupper was done, to repayre to my chamber againe. Notwith≈øtanding, whiles I came downe thus to dinner and ≈øupper, the Warden and hys wyfe pyked quarels with me, and complained vntruly of me to their great frend, the bi≈øhop of winche≈øter.

After one quarter of a yeare, and ≈øomewhat more, the Warden and hys wyfe fell out with me, for the wicked ma≈ø≈øe
and thereupon, the warden re≈øorted to the by≈øhop of Winche≈øter, & obteined to put me into the wardes, where I haue continued a long time, hauing nothing appoynted to me for my bedde, but a little pad of ≈øtraw, a rotten couerynge, with a tike and a few fethers therin, the chamber beyng vile and ≈øtynckynge, vntill by Gods meanes, good people ≈øente me bedding to lye in: of the one ≈øide of which pri≈øon, is the ≈øynke & filth of all the hou≈øe, & on the other ≈øyde, the towne ditch: ≈øo that the ≈øtinche of the hou≈øe hath infected me wythe ≈øundrye di≈øea≈øes. During which tyme, I haue bene ≈øicke, & the dores, barres, ha≈øpes and chaynes beinge all clo≈øed, and made fa≈øte vpon me, I haue mourned, called and cryed for helpe. But the warden, when he hath knowen me many tymes redy to dye, and when the poore men of the wardes haue called to helpe me, hath commaunded the doores to be kepte fa≈øt, and charged that none of hys men ≈øhould come at me, ≈øayenge: lette hym alone, it were a good riddaunce of hym. I payd alwayes like a Baron to the ≈øayd warden, a≈øwell in fees as for my boord, whych was xx. ≈øhyllinges a weke, be≈øides my mans table, vntil I was wrongfullye depriued of my bi≈øhoprycke. And ≈øithens that time, I haue payde hym, as the be≈øte gentleman doth in hys hou≈øe? yet hath he v≈øed me wor≈øe and more vylye, then the verie≈øt ≈ølaue that euer came to the hall commons. The ≈øayde warden hath al≈øo empri≈øoned my man, Wylliam Downton, and ≈øtrypped him out of his clothes to ≈øearch for letters, and could finde none, but onelye a little remembraunce of good people names, that gaue me theyr almes to relieue me in pri≈øonne. And to vndoe them al≈øo, the Warden deliuered the ≈øame bill vnto the ≈øayd Steuen Gardiner, Gods enemy and myne.

I haue ≈øuffred empri≈øonmente almo≈øt eighten monethes, my goods, lyuyng, frendes, and comfort taken from me, the Quene owyng me by iu≈øte accompte foure ≈øcore poundes or more. div.head: ¬∂A letter concerning the vayne and fal≈øe reportes whiche were ≈øpreade abrode of him, that he had recanted and abiured that doctrine whiche he before had preached.

And thys talke ri≈øeth of this, that the by≈øhoppe of London and his chapleines re≈øort vnto me. Doubtles if our brethren were as godly as I could wi≈øh them to be, thei would think, that in ca≈øe I did refu≈øe to talke wyth them, they might haue iu≈øt occa≈øioÃÑ to ≈øay that I were vnlerned, & di≈ødained to ≈øpeak with them. Therfore to auoyd iu≈øt ≈øu≈øpition of both, I haue and doe daylye ≈øpeake wythe them when they come, not doubtinge but they will reporte that I am neyther proude nor vnlearned. And I would wy≈øh all men to do as I doe in thys poynte, for I feare not theyr argumentes, neyther is death terrible vnto me. wherfore I pray you to make true export of the ≈øame as occa≈øioÃÑ ≈øhal ≈øerue, & al≈øo that I am more confyrmed in the truthe that heretofore I haue preached, by theyr coÃÑmunication: and ye that may, ≈øend to the weake bretherne abroad, prayinge theÃÑ yt they trouble me not with ≈øuch

For I haue hetherto left all thinges of this world, & ≈øuffred great paynes & long impri≈øonment, & I thanke God I am ready, euen as gladly to ≈øuffer deathe for the truthe I haue preached, as a mortall man may be. It were better for them to pray for vs, rather then to credite or rei≈øe rumours that bee vntrue, vnle≈ø≈øe they were more certaine thereof, then euer they ≈øhall be able to proue: we haue enemies enough of ≈øuch as knowe not God. I haue taught this truth wyth my tounge and penne heretofore, and hereafter ≈øhortly will confyrme (by Gods grace) the ≈øame wyth my bloode. Pray for me gentle brethern & haue no mi≈øtru≈øt.

div.head: To my dearely beloued Sy≈øter in the Lord mai≈øtres. A. W.
div.p:
THe grace of god be with you, AmeÃÑ. I thank you for your louing token. I pray you burden not your ≈øelf to much, it were mete for me rather to beare a payn, then to be a hinderance to many. But as Ieru≈øalem ≈øtode in the way, & was an impedimentte to the≈øe wi≈øe menne: ≈øo doth the ≈øinagoge of Antichry≈øte that beareth the name of Ieru≈øalem, whiche

And to ≈øtay them in dede, they take away the ≈øtarre of light which is Gods word that it can not be ≈øene, as as ye maye ≈øee howe the cele≈øtiall ≈øtarre was hyd froÃÑ the wy≈øe men, wheÃÑ they a≈øked of the Phare≈øeis at Hieru≈øaleÃÑ wher Chri≈øt was borne. Ye may ≈øee what great daungers happened vnto the≈øe wi≈øe men, whyles they were a learning of liers where Chri≈øt was. Fyr≈øt they were oute of theyr way, and next they lo≈øt their guide and conductour, the heauenly ≈øtarre. Chri≈øt is mounted from vs into heauen and there we ≈øeke hym, as we ≈øay let vs therfore go the the ‚Ä¢
ward by the ≈øtarre of hys worde, and beware we happen not to come into Hieru≈øalem the church of men & a≈øke for him. If we do, we go out of the way & lo≈øe al≈øo our conductor & guide that only leadeth vs ≈øtrayght thether. The Poetes write in fables, that Ia≈øon wheÃÑ he fought with the dragoÃÑ in the Ile of Colchis was pre≈øerued by the medicines of Medea, and ≈øo wan the golden flee≈øe. And they write al≈øo that Titan, whom they fayne to be ≈øonne and heyre of the highe God Iubiter, woulde neades vpon a day haue the conducting of the Sun round about the world, but as they fayne, he mi≈ø≈øed of the accu≈øtomed cour≈øe, wherupon when he went to hygh, he burned heauen, & wheÃÑ he went to low, he burned the earth & the water. The≈øe prophane hi≈øtories do ≈øhame vs that he chri≈øtiaÃÑ men. Ia≈øon agayn≈øt the poi≈øon of the dragon, v≈øed onlye the medicine of Medea. What a ≈øhame is it for a Chri≈øtian man agayn≈øte the poy≈øon of the deuyl, here≈øye, and ≈øynne, to v≈øe any other remedye, then Chri≈øt and hys woorde? You ≈øhal meete with ≈ølauÃÑder & conteÃÑpt of the world and be accoÃÑpted vngracious & vngodlye: you ≈øhal heare & mete with cruell tyranny to doe you al extremities: you ≈øhal now & theÃÑ ≈øee the troubles of your own con≈øcieÃÑce, & fele your own weaknes: you ≈øhal heare that you be cur≈øed by the ≈øentence of the catholike church, wit ≈øuche like terrours: but praye to God, & followe the ≈øtarre of hys word, & you ≈øhall ariue at the port of eternall ≈øaluacioÃÑ by the merites only of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, to whome I commende you and all yours mo≈øt hartely.

div.head: To may≈øter Ferrar by≈øhop of S. Dauids. D. Taylor, mai≈øter Bradford and may≈øter Philpot, pri≈øoners in the kinges Bench in South warke.
div.p:
THe grace of God be wyth you, Amen. Wherfore deare brethren, I do aduerty≈øe you of the thing before for diuer≈øe cau≈øes. For many of them know already the truth, manye of them erre rather of zeale then malice, and the others that be iudurate ≈øhould be aun≈øweared fully to theyr ≈øhame (I doubt not) although to our ≈ømarte and blood≈øheedyng. For of thys I am a≈ø≈øured, that the commi≈ø≈øioners appointed to hear vs & iudge vs, meane nothyng le≈ø≈øe then to heare the cau≈øe indifferentlye, for they be enemies vnto vs & vnto our cau≈øe, and be at a poynt alredy to geue ≈øentence agayn≈øt vs: ≈øo that if it were po≈ø≈øible wyth Saynte Stephen to ≈øpeake ≈øo that they could not re≈øy≈øt vs, or to v≈øe ≈øuch ≈øylence & pacience as Chri≈øt did, they wil procede to reuenging. Wherfore my deare brethren in the mercye of Ie≈øus Chry≈øte, I would be gladde to know your aduy≈øe thys daye or to morrowe, for ≈øhortlye we ≈øhall be gone, and I verelye ≈øuppo≈øe that we ≈øhall not companye together, but be kepte abroade one from the other. But the≈øe things (my godly wife) requyre rather cogitation, meditation and prayer, then wordes or talke. They be ea≈øy to be ≈øpoken of but not ≈øo ea≈øy to be v≈øed and practi≈øed. Is it then any meruayle if ≈øuch chri≈øtians as god delighteth in, be ≈øo maÃÑgled and defaced in this world, which is the kitchyn and myll to boyle and grynde the fle≈øhe of Godes people in, tyll they acheaue their perfection in the

And as man looketh for the nutrimente of his meate when it is full dige≈øted, and not before: ≈øo mu≈øt he looke for his ≈øaluation when he hathe pa≈ø≈øed this troublous world, and not before. And to iudge thynges indifferently (my godlye wyfe) the troubles be not yet generally as they were in our good fathers times, ≈øoone after the death and re≈øurrection of our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt Ie≈øu, Math. 24. whereof he ≈øpake in S. div.head: ‚òûA letter ≈øente to the Chri≈øtian congregation, wherin he proueth that true faith cannot be kepte ≈øecrete in the heart without confe≈ø≈øion therof openly to the world when occa≈øion ≈øerueth.
div.p:
SAint Paule in ye .10. chap. to the Rom. annexeth the faythe of Chri≈øt in the hart, wyth the confe≈ø≈øion of the mouth, ≈øo that the one (it ≈øemeth by him) can be no more without the other, then fire can bee without heate, ≈øaying the≈øe wordes: with the hart man beleueth vnto righteou≈ønes, & with the mouth he confe≈ø≈øeth vnto ≈øaluation, Wherein he declareth, that euen as the cau≈øe of our acceptation through Chri≈øt, is the confidence and faithe of the hart in the promi≈øes of god: ≈øo is the confe≈ø≈øion outwardlye of the ≈øame fayth by the mouthe, the fruite that all chri≈øtian faythfull hartes brynge forthe throughe the ≈øame gyfte of GOD. And where as thys effecte of confe≈ø≈øion of faythe is not, there wanteth al≈øo the cau≈øe of confe≈ø≈øion, whiche is true faythe: for as the tree is knowen by her fruites, ≈øo is faythe by her effectes. And as the wante of fruite is a demon≈øtration that the tree is vnprofitable: ≈øo the wante of true confe≈ø≈øion of faythe, is a token that the faith is dead. The ende of the vnprofitable tree,Math. x. 1. Pet. 3. is cuttyng down and ca≈øtynge into the fyre: the ende of the fruitles faythe is death and ca≈øtyng to eternall dampnation. Wherefore Saincte Peter requyreth vs to make aun≈øwere to euerye man that demauÃÑdeth of vs, of ≈øuch hope as is in vs, with gentlenes &
reuerence, which is a very te≈øtimony that we ≈øanctify god in our hartes, as it is before expre≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame chapter. For the greate≈øt honour that man can geue to god, is to confe≈ø≈øe in the tyme of trouble, truly and faithfully hys holy worde and fayth. Wherfore it is the duty of euery chri≈øtian, to pray & ≈øtudy to haue a through knowledge of his faith in Chri≈øt, and as the glory of god ≈øhall requyre, & the cau≈øe of his religion, to bee readye to make aun≈øwere for the ≈øame (howe ≈øoeuer the world, feare, di≈øplea≈øure, frend≈øhip, or other lettes ≈øhall moue vs to the contrary) vppon payne, ≈øaieth Chri≈øte in the x,Math. x. of Mathew, that I will deny hym before my father which is in heauen. But how harde a thyng it is to confe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øte in the dayes of trouble, not onely the ≈øcripture, but al≈øo daily experieÃÑce in good men and women doth declare. True confe≈ø≈øion is warded on euery ≈øide, with many daungers, on the righte hande and on the lefte hande, now with fayre meanes, then wyth foule threatnynges, fearefull and daungerous: as it is ≈øayde by Chri≈øte our Sauioure, they ≈øhall betray you to the iudges, and of them ye ≈øhall be beaten and iudged to deathe. Of the other ≈øyde ≈øhall pull vs backe the loue of wyfe, childreÃÑ, brother, Sy≈øter, kin, frends, and the loue vnto our ≈øelues. But he that is ouercommen by any of the≈øe meanes, hath his iudgemeÃÑt: he is not meete for me ≈øayth Chri≈øt.

The≈øe thynges be impo≈ø≈øible vnto men, yet to chri≈øtian men, in Chri≈øt po≈ø≈øible, and ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary, that chri≈øtianity and true religion cannot bee in hym, that is a fearde to confe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt and his go≈øpell in the tyme of per≈øecution. The wi≈ødome of the world doth ≈øay, although I accompli≈øhe the de≈øyre of my frendes, and to the ≈øight of the worlde am pre≈øent at the ma≈ø≈øe, and with my body do as other men do, or as I may do: yet my hart is clean contrary to their belief, & I do dete≈øt ≈øuch Idolatry & beleue yt the thing that I am pre≈øent at, is mere idolatry, and abhominatioÃÑ. Here be fayre words for an euill purpo≈øe, and pretenced excu≈øe, for a iu≈øt condemnation before God. For if it be true that ye know the thing which ye re≈øort vnto, to be the di≈øhonor of god, why doe ye honour it with your pre≈øence? If ye know it to be euil, why refrayne ye not from it? If your con≈øcience ≈øaye it is Idolatry, why ≈øerueth your body ≈øuch things as your fayth abhorreth? If in your hart you know but one God, why with
your exterior pre≈øence, ≈øerue ye the thing that ye knowe is not God? If your fayth ≈øee idolatrye, why doth your ≈øilence coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe and allow the ≈øame? Two meÃÑ in one, god loueth not. If the inwarde man knowe the truth, why doth the outward man confe≈ø≈øe a fal≈øehode? If your ≈øpirite be per≈øwaded that the ma≈ø≈øe is idolatry, why do ye with your bodely pre≈øence, v≈øe it as a God and geue godly honoure to it? Do ye not perceaue that it is written E≈øay. 25. Math. 15. the≈øe people honor me with theyr mouth, but their harts be farre froÃÑ me? The cau≈øe why God was offended with the≈øe people, was that outwardly they confe≈ø≈øed him & ≈øerued him, but their hartes were farre froÃÑ him inwardly. Wherfore ye may ≈øee what it is to beare two faces in one hoode, outwardly to ≈øerue God, and inwardly to ≈øerue the deuil. Now marke of thys place, if it be ≈øo horrible & damnable a thing to be fal≈øe in the hart, which none knoweth but God, and is worthy al≈øo of damnatioÃÑ: what is to be iudged of the outward and manife≈øt v≈øe of idolatry, which not only God, but al≈øo euery good man knoweth and abhorreth? There is no coulor, nor cloked hipocri≈øie, that God caÃÑ away with. If the hart thinke not as the tong ≈øpeaketh, or els ye tong ≈øpeake otherwi≈øe theÃÑ the hart thinketh, both be abhominable before God.2. Cor. 6. Read ye the .3. and the .6. Chapters of the fyr≈øt Epi≈øtle of S. Paul to the Corinth, where as S. Paule ≈øayth: know ye not that your bodie is the temple of the holy gho≈øt? If your body be the temple of ye holy gho≈øt, what agrement hath it with idolatry? Can one body at one time, bee the temple of the holy gho≈øt, and be pre≈øent at ≈øuch idolatry as god abhorreth and dete≈øteth? Can a maÃÑ ≈øerue two ma≈øters? If he do, he loueth (as Chri≈øt ≈øaith) the one and hateth the other. Math. 6. As god requireth of a faithful man, a pure hart: euen ≈øo requyreth he that his external profe≈ø≈øion in al thinges be according therunto, for both body and ≈øoule be detters vnto god, & he redemed them both. The woorde of God ≈øayth vnto vs,1. Cor. 6. glorifye and beare God in your bodies. If we be pre≈øent at ≈øuch idolatry as God forbiddeth, and our own knowledge in con≈øcience is a≈ø≈øured to be euill, do we glorifye God in our bodies? No doutle≈ø≈øe we di≈øhonour him, and make our bodyes the ≈øeruauntes of idolatry, not only to Gods di≈øhonoure, but al≈øo to the great daunger both of body and ≈øoule. For this is a
true ≈øaying of S. Augu≈øtine, he that doth again≈øt his con≈øcience, buildeth to hell fyre.

It is not enough for a Chri≈øtian man to ≈øay, I know the ma≈ø≈øe is nought, but to obey ciuill lawes and orders I wil do outwardly as other men do, yet in my hart abhorre it & neuer thinke it to be good. Doutle≈ø≈øe the≈øe two mindes, the ≈øpirite to thinke wel & the body to do euil, in this re≈øpect be both naught, & god wil ≈øpue yt whole maÃÑ out of his mouth, as he did ye mini≈øter of ye coÃÑgregatioÃÑ of Laodicia. Apo. 3. The 8. chap. & the .10 of the fyr≈øt to ye Corinthians in thys matter & in this time, be places very muche expedient to lead & gouerne the iudgement of euery Chri≈øtian maÃÑ: where we may ≈øee that the Corinthians in dede had knowlege & perceaued right well that neither the idoles amonge≈øt them, neyther the meate dedicated vnto the idoles were any thing, & pa≈ø≈øed as light of both, as of thinges of nothing, & vppon that knowledge v≈øed to be pre≈øent and al≈øo to eate at the fea≈øt, & of the meate dedicated vnto Idoles. Wherewithall Paule was ≈øo ≈øore offended, that he gaue this ≈øentence: if a man ≈øee thee which ha≈øt knowledge,1. Cor. 8 ≈øit at table in the Idoles teÃÑ ple, ≈øhal not the con≈øcience of him which is weake, be boldened to eate tho≈øe things which are ≈øacrificed to Idoles? and through thy knowledge ≈øhall the weake brother peri≈øh, for whoÃÑ Chri≈øt died. Now when ye ≈øinne ≈øo again≈øt ye brethren, and wound their weake con≈øcience, ye ≈øinne again≈øt Chri≈øt. This iudgement of Paul is more to be followed, theÃÑ al our own fayned and wre≈øted defences, which would fayne ≈øeme to do wel, wheÃÑ we halt on both ≈øides, which god abhorreth. Paule hath a profounde & depe con≈øideration of that mans fault that hath knowledge, & perceaueth his di≈ø≈øimulation to be dauÃÑgerous & perilous to al per≈øons which he dwelleth with al. Fir≈øt ≈øuch as be of a right and ≈øtayed iudgement and will not pro≈øtrate their bodies to an Idole, do condemne, & nedes mu≈øt, ≈øuch di≈ø≈øimulation. The very Idolaters them≈øelues, haue a defence of their abhomination, by the pre≈øence of him yt the Chri≈øtiaÃÑ congregatioÃÑ knoweth to haue knowledge. The weaker ≈øort yt would gladly take the be≈øt way, by a di≈ø≈øemblers halting & playing of both handes, embraceth both in body and in ≈øoule, the euil that he abhorreth in hys
hart, and though he haue knowledge, yet with his pre≈øence he e≈øtemeth it as other do which haue no knowledge. If S Paule ≈øayd yt the weake brother doth peri≈øh for whoÃÑ Chri≈øt died, by him that abu≈øed knowledge in meates and drinkes that of them≈øelues be indifferent: how muche more by the knowledge of him that v≈øeth manife≈øte Idolatry forbidden of God as a thing not indifferent? Take hede what ≈ø. Paule meaneth, and what he would proue again≈øt this man which had knowledge that neither the Idoles neither ye meates dedicated to Idoles were any thing. For≈øooth this would he proue: that a poore man that wanteth knowledge, by the example of him that hath knowledge, doth there aduenture to do euil, which he would not do in ca≈øe he ≈øawe not tho≈øe that he hath good opinion of, to go before him as authors of the euill. And in dede the ignoraunte people, or tho≈øe that be halfe per≈øwaded in a truth, yea or els throughly per≈øwaded what is euill, when they haue any notable men or women for an example to follow, they thinke in following of them, they be excu≈øed, yea although peraduenture they do it again≈øt their con≈øciences: as ye may ≈øee how many good men by the example of Peter began to di≈ø≈øemble, yea Barnabas hym≈øelfe the Apo≈øtle of the Gentiles. Gala. 2 But how great offence this is before god, ≈øo to make a doubtful coÃÑ≈øcience or ≈øtriuig again≈øt knowledge to do any thing that is not godly, let the iudgement of men pa≈ø≈øe, and mea≈øure it from gods word. Chri≈øt ≈øayth, Math. 18 it were better a mil≈øtone were hanged about ≈øuch an offenders necke, & ca≈øt into the ≈øea. And doutle≈ø≈øe the payne mu≈øt be the greater, bycau≈øe we geue offence willingly, and agayn≈øt our owne con≈øciences: and thys before God is a wicked knowledge that cau≈øeth an other to peri≈øhe. Woe be vnto hym that is learned to bring his brother to de≈øtruction. Doth a Chri≈øtian man know the truth to bring his brother to a lye? For tho≈øe weaklinges that we make to ≈øtomble, Chri≈øt died, as S. Paul ≈øayth. God defend we ≈øhould confyrme any mans con≈øeience in euil. Let euery maÃÑ of god waye with him≈øelfe the doctrine of S. Paul that coÃÑmaundeth vs to flye Idolatrye.1. Cor. 10 And marke what ≈ø. Paul in that place calleth Idolatrye. It is to be ≈øene plainly yt he

To that I aun≈øwered that I dyd not remember any ≈øuche lawe of Iu≈øtinian: but I am ≈øure that Iu≈øtinian writeth in Titulo de indicta viduitate, in cod. that if one would bequeath to his wife in his te≈øtament al ‚Ä¢ egacie vnder a condition that ≈øhe ≈øhould neuer marye agayne, and take an othe of her for the accomply≈øhyng of the ≈øame, yet ≈øhe ≈øhall marye againe if he dye, notwith≈øtandyng the afore≈øayd condition and othe taken and made agayn≈øt mariage: and an othe is an other manner of obligation to God, then is a papi≈øticall vowe. Then my lorde Chauncellour ≈øaid thou lye≈øt of Chri≈øo≈øtome, but thou doe≈øt as all thy companions do, belye euer without al ≈øhame, both the ≈øcriptures & the doctors. I an≈øwered, we reade in the decrees, that the fower generall coun≈øels, Nicene, Con≈øtantinopolitane, Ephe≈øme and Calcedon, haue the ≈øame autoritye that the foure Euangeli≈øtes haue. div.head: The copy of a writing that D. Taylour ≈øent to a frende of hys concerning the cau≈øes vvherfore he vvas condemned.
div.p:
IT is here≈øie to defend any doctrine again≈øt the holy ≈øcripture: therfore the Lord Chauncelor and by≈øhops con≈øenting to his ≈øentence again≈øt me, be heretikes, for they haue geueÃÑ ≈øentence again≈øt the mariage of prie≈øts, knowing that S. Paules coun≈øel and lawful, but gods coÃÑmaundemeÃÑt al≈øo to marry, for ≈øuch as can not other wi≈øe liue cha≈øt, neither auoyde fornicatioÃÑ.1. Cor. 7 Gene. 2. They know that ≈øuch as do marry, do not ≈øinne. They know that god, before ≈øinne was, ordained matrimony, and ye in paradi≈øe betwene
two of his principal creatures, MaÃÑ & Woman. They know what ≈øpirite they haue, whiche ≈øay it is euil to marrye, ≈øeing God ≈øayd: Gene. 2. it is not good for maÃÑ to be alone without a wife, hauing no ≈øpeciall gift contrary to the generall coÃÑmaundement and ordinaunce diuer≈øe times repeted in the booke of Gene≈øis, Gene. 1. which is to encrea≈øe & multiply. Paule geueth a great pray≈øe to matrimony, calling it honourable, and that not to & among many, but to and among al men without exception, who≈øoeuer haue nede of that Gods remedy for mans and womaÃÑs infirmitie. They know that if there were any ≈øinne in matrimony, it were chiefly to be thought to be in the bedcompanye: but S. Paule ≈øayth that the bed company is vndefyled. Gene. 18. Exod. 18. Gene≈ø. 25. Gene. 31. 2. Reg. 7. Math 1. They know that the hauing of a wife was not an impediment for Abraham, Moy≈øes, I≈øaac, Iacob, Dauid, &c. to talke with God, neither to the Leuites; bi≈øhops & prie≈øtes office in the tyme of the olde Te≈øtamente or the newe. They know that Chri≈øt would not be conceaued or borne of the ble≈ø≈øed mother the Virgine Mary, before ≈øhe was e≈øpou≈øed in mariage his own ordinance. They know by S. Ciprian, and S. Au≈øtine, that a vowe is not an impediment ≈øufficient to let matrimony, or to diuorce the ≈øame. They knowe that S. Chri≈øo≈øtome ≈øayth: it is here≈øie to affyrme that a By≈øhop may not haue a wife. They know that S. Ambro≈øe wil haue no coÃÑmaundement but coun≈øell only to be geuen, touchyng the ob≈øeruing of virginitie. They know that Chri≈øt with his ble≈ø≈øed mother and Apo≈øtles were at a mariage, Iohn. 2. & beautifyed & honoured the ≈øame with his pre≈øence and fyr≈øt miracle. To be ≈øhort, they know yt al that I haue here written touching ye mariage of prie≈øtes, is true, and they know yt the papi≈øtes theÃÑ≈øelues do not ob≈øerue touching yt matter, theyr own lawes & canons, and yet they continue marked in con≈øcieÃÑce wt an hote iron as dete≈øtable heretikes in this behalf. My ≈øecond cau≈øe why I was coÃÑdemned as an heretike, is yt I denied ye tran≈øub≈øtantiation & concomitation, two iugling words of the papi≈øtes, by the which they do beleue and wil coÃÑpel al other to beleue yt Chri≈øts natural body is made of bread, & that the godheade by & by is ioyned therunto: ≈øo that immediatly after the words called the wordes of con≈øecration, there is no more bread and wine in the ≈øacrameÃÑt, but the ≈øub≈øtance only of the body and bloud of Chri≈øt together wt his godhead: ≈øo that the ≈øame being now Chri≈øt both god & man, ought to be wor≈øhipped with godly honour, & to be offred to god, both for the quicke and the dead, as a ≈øacrifice propitiatory and ≈øati≈øfactory for the ≈øame. This matter was not long debated in words, but bycau≈øe I denyed the fore≈øaid papi≈øtical doctrine, yea rather plainly mo≈øt wicked Idolatry, bla≈øphemy and here≈øye, I was iudged an heretike. I dyd al≈øo affyrme the pope to be Antichri≈øt, & poperye Antichri≈øtianitie: and I coÃÑfe≈ø≈øed the doctrine of the Bible to be a ≈øufficieÃÑt doctrine touching al & ≈øingular matters of Chri≈øtian religion and of ≈øaluation. I al≈øo alledged that the othe again≈øt the Supremacy of ye by≈øhop of Rome, was a lawful othe, and ≈øo was the othe made by vs all touchyng ye kings or Queenes preeminence. I de≈øired the Bi≈øhops to repent for bringing the Realme froÃÑ Chri≈øt to Antichri≈øt, froÃÑ light to darkenes, from verity to vanitie. Thus you know a ≈øuÃÑme of my la≈øt examination & condemnation. Pray for me, & I wil pray for you.

God be pray≈øed, ≈øince my condemnation I was neuer affraid to die: Gods wil be done. If I ≈øhrinke froÃÑ gods truth, I am ≈øure of an other maÃÑner of death theÃÑ had iudge Hales. But God be pray≈øed, euen froÃÑ the bottome of my heart, I am vnmoueably ≈øetled vpoÃÑ the rocke, nothing douting, but that my dere god wil performe and fini≈øh the worke, that he hath begon in me & other. div.p: I Say to my wife, & to my children, the Lord gaue you vnto me, & the Lord hath taken me from you, and you froÃÑ me: ble≈ø≈øed be the name of the Lord. We heretofore haue had ye fruitioÃÑ of you by bodily pre≈øence to our inexplicable benefite (pray≈øed be that our gracious God therfore) and now in ≈øpirit we haue the experience of vn≈øpeakeable coÃÑfort by your reuerend fatherhodes, Math. 5. for that in this ≈øo glorious ≈øort, ye become a towne ≈øet vpon a hill, a candle vpon a Candle≈øticke,1. Paule, that the thyngs which happeÃÑ vnto vs, do chauÃÑce vnto the great furtherance of the Go≈øpel: ≈øo that our bondes in Chri≈øt are manife≈øt, not only throughout al the iudgement hal, but in all whole Europa, in ≈øo much that many of the brethren in ye Lord being encouraged through our bondes, dare more boldlye ≈øpeake the woord without feare. And herein as you haue with S. Paule greatly to reioyce: ≈øo we do reioyce with you, & we do in dede with you geue thankes for this excellent worthy fauour of our God towards you, that Chri≈øt is thus magnifyed in you, yea and hereafter ≈øhal be magnifyed in your bodyes, whether it be through life or death. Of whiche thing truely we are a≈ø≈øured in our prayers for you, and mini≈øtring of the ≈øpirite. And although for your owne partes Chri≈øt is vnto you life, and death aduantage, and that your de≈øire is (as in dede it were better for you) to be loo≈øed, Phil. 1. and to be with Chri≈øt, yet for the church of Chri≈øt were it muche more nece≈ø≈øary, that ye ≈øhould abide in the fle≈øh: Yea yt merciful god euen for his Chri≈øts ≈øake, grauÃÑt that ye may abide & continue for the furtheraunce of the churche & reioy≈øyng of fayth, that the reioycing thereof may be the more aboundauÃÑt through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt by your re≈øtoring again, Amen, Amen. But if it ≈øeme better otherwi≈øe vnto the diuine wi≈øedome, that by ≈øpedy death he hath appoynted you to gloryfye him, the Lordes wil be done. Yea euen as we do reioyce both on your behalfes, & al≈øo on our own, that god is magnifyed by lyfe, & ≈øhould be more aboundauntlye glad for the
continuaunce therof: ≈øo we ≈øhall no le≈ø≈øe reioyce to haue the ≈øame wrought by death. We ≈øhall geue thankes for thys honour geueÃÑ vnto you, phi. 1. reioycing that ye are accompted worthy to ≈øuffer for ye name of Chri≈øt, & that it is geuen to you of god not only yt ye ≈øhould beleue in him, but al≈øo yt ye ≈øhould ≈øuffer for his ≈øake. And herein we ≈øhal haue to reioyce in ye be halfe of ye church of Chri≈øt, who≈øe fayth may be ye fa≈øter fixed vpoÃÑ gods veritie, being coÃÑfyrmed wt three ≈øuch worthy witne≈ø≈øes. Oh thanks be to god for thys hys vn≈øpeakeable gift.

And now mo≈øte reuerend fathers, that ye may vnder≈øtande the truth of vs and oure e≈øtate how we ≈øtand in the Lorde, I doe a≈ø≈øure your reuerences, partlye by that I perceaue by ≈øuche of oure brethren as bee here in bondes with me, partly by that I heare of them which be in other places, and partly by that inward experience which I mo≈øt vnworthy wretch haue of Gods good comfort, more abundaunce wherof I know there is in others: ye may be a≈ø≈øured I ≈øay (by gods grace) that ye ≈øhall not bee fru≈øtrate of your hope of our coÃÑ≈øtant continuaunce in the chereful confe≈ø≈øion of Gods euerla≈øting veritie.Ephe. i. For euen as we haue receaued the word of truth, euen the Go≈øpell of our ≈øaluation, wherin we beleuing, are ≈øealed with the holy ≈øpirite of promy≈øe, which is the earne≈øt of our enheritaunce, Rom. 8 the whiche ≈øpirite certifyeth our ≈øpirit that we are the children of God, and therefore God hath ≈øent the ≈øpirite of his Sonne into oure heartes crying, Abba father: Gal. 4. ≈øo after ≈øuche portion as God mea≈øureth vnto vs, we with the whole churche of Chri≈øt, and with you reuerend Fathers, receauing the ≈øame ≈øpirit of fayth, according as it is written, I beleued & therefore I haue ≈øpoken, we al≈øo beleue, and therfore ≈øpeake.2. Cor. 4. P≈øa. 116. For the which we in this daungerous bondage and other afflictions, hauing euen ≈øuch a fyght as we haue ≈øene in you and haue heard of you, phil. 1. we are in no wy≈øe affrayde of our aduer≈øaryes. And fora≈ømuch as we haue ≈øuch an offyce, euen as God hath had mercy on vs, we go not out of kinde, but eueÃÑ with you, after our litle power, we labour to mainteyne the faith of ye go≈øpel, knowing mo≈øt certainly,2. Cor. 4. yt though we haue this trea≈øure in eartheÃÑ ve≈ø≈øels, yt the excellency of the power might be gods & not ours, yet ≈øhal we not be da≈øhed in peeces, for ye lord wil put his haÃÑd vnder vs. When we are troubled on euery ≈øide, yet are we not wtout ≈øhift: when we are
in pouerty, we are not vtterly without ≈øomthing: when we ≈øuffer per≈øecution, we are not for≈øaken therin: when we are ca≈øt down, yet we ≈øhal not peri≈øh: but to communicate with our ≈øwete Sauiour Chri≈øt in bearing ye cro≈ø≈øe, it is appointed vnto vs, that euen with him al≈øo we ≈øhall bee glorifyed. For it is a true ≈øaying:2. Timo. 2 If we be dead with him, we ≈øhall al≈øo liue with him: If we be patient, we ≈øhal al≈øo reygne with him:2. Cor. 4. If we deny him, he ≈øhall al≈øo denye vs. Wherefore we be of good cheere alwayes, bearyng about in our bodye the dying of the Lord Ie≈øus, yt the life of Ie≈øus myght appeare al≈øo in our body. For we know that he which ray≈øed vp the Lord Ie≈øus, ≈øhall ray≈øe vp vs al≈øo by the meanes of Ie≈øus, and ≈øhall ioyne vs to him≈øelf together with you. Wherfore we are not weryed, but though our outward man pery≈øhe, yet the inward man is renued day by day. For our tribulation, which is momentane and light, prepareth an exceding & an eternal weight of glory vnto vs, whiles we loke not on the things which are ≈øene, but on the thinges which are not ≈øene. For the things which are ≈øene, are temporall: but things which are not ≈øene, are eternal. We te≈øtifie vnto you reuerend fathers, E≈øay. 12. that we drawe the≈øe waters with ioy out of the welles of the Sauiour. And I tru≈øt we ≈øhall continually with you ble≈ø≈øe the Lord, & geue thanks to the lord, out of the≈øe welles of I≈øraell: Apoca. 19. we tru≈øt to be merye together at the great Supper of the Lambe, who≈øe Spou≈øe we are by fayth, and there to ≈øing that ≈øong of euerla≈øting Haleluyah. Amen. Yea come Lord Ie≈øu. The grace of our Lorde Ie≈øu Chri≈øt be with you. Amen.

div.head: ¬∂To the profe≈ø≈øours of the Go≈øpell and true doctrine of our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, in the towne of Litchefelde
div.p: GRace and peace with continuance in vnfayned fayth and a good con≈øcience, be vnto you in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu. Amen.

At what time it plea≈øed that gracious god of Abraham, I≈øaac, and Iacob, wonderfullye to woorke the deliueraunce of their of≈øpring the I≈øraelites, euen as he broughte to pa≈ø≈øe
the ≈øame by hys mighty arme: ≈øo dyd he thereunto admitte mans mini≈øtery as his ordinary in≈øtrumente, and therfore in≈øtructed fyr≈øte Mo≈øes that faythefull ≈øeruaunte of hys, what was to be done, as al≈øo with what chereful courage he ≈øhould do the ≈øame. The≈øe people by the hand of this Moy≈øes, were brought by no ≈ømal perils, Deut. 34. the mydde way toward their promi≈øed patrimonye, when as it plea≈øed God to take vnto hym ≈øelfe hys ≈øeruaunte Moy≈øes from this my≈øerable vale. In who≈øe place he appoynted Io≈øua that worthy leader of the Lordes people, who not alonely for his parte dydde boldelye take in hande ≈øo daungerous an enterpri≈øe, Io≈øua. 1. but al≈øo wyth earne≈øt ≈øtudye ≈øtyrred vppe hys ≈øayde people wyth lu≈øty courage to goe forwarde in the appoynted pa≈ø≈øage of theyr ieoperdous iourney. Yea he was hable abouÃÑdantly to coÃÑfort theÃÑ with ≈øuch coÃÑfortes as he him≈øelf receaued of his god, who at ≈øundry tymes a≈ø≈øured him therof, ≈øaying vnto hym thus: euen as I was with Mo≈øes, ≈øo wil I be with thee, I wil not for≈øake thee, neither leaue thee, be thou therfore of good courage and ≈øtronge: feare not, neyther be di≈ømayde, for I am with thee in all that thou take≈øt in hande. What ≈øoeuer thinges be written are written for our doctrine &c.

Dearely beloued, albeit that in the≈øe dais it may be ≈øayd truelye that ye haue very fewe ≈øuche captaynes to be compared wyth Moy≈øes or Io≈øua gods ≈øynguler iewelles, yet that ≈øame lord which is no chaungelyng, but euen the ≈øame mercifull and almightye defendour of all his people at all tymes: doth and ≈øhall in ≈øome degree directe you his cho≈øen children in the highe way toward your heauenly inheritaÃÑce by the hand of a Mo≈øes, in ≈øome parte re≈øembling the≈øe two principal paternes. For though we your brethreÃÑ, who heretofore by our vocation haue ≈øit in the chayre of Mo≈øes, and be go≈øtly captaines as Mo≈øes and Io≈øua vnto you: though I ≈øay we well know and acknowledge how little we haue to boa≈øt of, as of oure ≈øelues, yet this we haue to reioyce of in the lord our god, that as we haue bene of hym appointed vnto ≈øuch a place and function: ≈øo we do not altogether degenerate. For fir≈øt vnto our owne ≈øtrengthning, euen that gratious god whiche byddeth vs to be ≈øtrong by the operation of his ≈øpirit, performeth ye ≈øame in ≈øome part in vs, al glory
be vnto hym therfore. Al≈øo in the word of the lord we te≈øtify vnto you, to be ≈øtronge in the lorde, and ≈øhrynke not backe becau≈øe of the ≈øundrye temptations a≈ø≈øaultynge you in the pa≈ø≈øage vnto your countrey through the wildernes of thys world. Be content to be proued as tho≈øe people were. Doe not addict your ≈øelues vnto the fanta≈øing of the fle≈øh pottes of Egypte, Exo. 16. mo≈øt vnthankfully relinqui≈øhyng the promi≈øed po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. We geue you to know what warranti≈øe we haue of pro≈øperous ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in ≈øuche our procedinges: no le≈ø≈øe (be ye a≈ø≈øured) then tho≈øe former captaynes Moy≈øes and Io≈øua had. For be≈øydes that all the ≈øame mo≈øt comfortable promi≈øes which made them & their people to be bold to procede in their enterpri≈øe, do beloÃÑg vnto vs: we haue to reioyce in our god for his vnmea≈øurable mercies more plentifully powred vpoÃÑ vs by that abouÃÑdaÃÑt grace in hys deare ≈øonne our chri≈øt, in whome he offreth vs al fulnes of fauour and beneuoleÃÑce, all readines of deliueraunce, appoyntyng all credite wythout care to be geuen vnto ≈øuch a gouernour. Yea and that ≈øame hys Chri≈øt, who is made of hym our annointed ≈øauiour, is now become our graunde captayne, yea what is he not vnto vs to do vs good? He is our ≈øhepeheard, we be his people and the ≈øhepe of hys pa≈øture: he is our hu≈øband, we be hys ≈øpou≈øe. Iohn. 10 Math. 28. He hathe promy≈øed to keepe hys ≈øheepe that none ≈øhall ≈ønatch them out of hys handes. He hath promy≈øed to be wyth hys church alwayes, yea and that effectually to be wyth it, euen as the heade to geue lyfe vnto the members and parts of the body, euen as the vyne ≈øtocke to quicken the vyne braunches, and euen as the mo≈øt louyng hu≈øband to tender, cheri≈øh, defende, and keepe hys welbeloued ≈øpou≈øe. Let vs be bold to committe our ≈øelues vnto ≈øuche a ≈øafe conductor, ca≈øtyng oure care vpon hym: for were it not that he many tymes more careth for vs, then we can for our ≈øelues, it would not be well wyth vs. Full little dyd Peter perceaue any cau≈øe of greuance for that perillous fal which after befell. Luke. 24. But that ≈øuffraigne ≈øhepeheard before hand e≈øpied the ≈øpyteful de≈øire of that wolui≈øh Sathan to ≈øyft his Peter that ≈øely poore ≈øhepe: and therfore prayed vnto hys father that Peters fayth myght not faynt. Such a ≈øhepehard ≈øhall he be alway vnto his people, huÃÑbly complaining vnto
him in extreme daungers. And great cau≈øe haue we ≈øo to do, con≈øideryng not only the greedy de≈øyre of this Satan mo≈øt tyrannou≈øly ragyng lyke a roaryng Lyon ≈øeeking whome he maye deuoure: but al≈øo the imbecillitye in our ≈øelues,1. Pet. 5. beyng ≈øuche as is not hable to with≈øtande the lea≈øte of hys a≈ø≈øaultes: but on the contrarye beynge ouerwhelmed wyth the waues whiche be ≈øtyrred vp by the≈øe tempe≈øtes of hys temptations, Math. 8. we are compelled to crye wyth the≈øe Dy≈øciples, who in theyr extremitye cryed, ≈øaue vs Lorde or elles we pery≈øhe.

The tymes be perylous: we mu≈øte therfore be circum≈øpect & not ≈øolace our ≈øelues in carnall ≈øecurity, but beyng coÃÑtent to enter into the ≈øheepe of Chri≈øtes cro≈ø≈øe and obiecting our ≈øelues to al ieoperdous pa≈ø≈øages in the adueÃÑturous iorneying to our heauenly countrey, let vs for thys pre≈øent v≈øage accompte it comfort enough to haue the fellow≈øhip of ≈øuche a fellow venterer. He once beyng in the Shyppe wyth hys Di≈øciples, dyd wyth hys worde a≈øwage the ≈øwellyng of the Sea ≈øo daungerous. He hath not lefte vs alone in the Ship of thys frayle fle≈øhe, but ioyneth wyth vs in thys daungerous iorney, a≈øwel by hys once beyng ≈øubiecte vnto all bodely infirmities as we be (≈øynne only except) as al≈øo by his a≈ø≈øuryng vs of his gratious a≈ø≈øi≈øtaÃÑce, now that he is becom before hys heauenly father our Prynce, our Prie≈øt, and our Prophet, alwayes pre≈øt and ready to helpe by hys power, propitiation, and in≈øpiration of hys holy ≈øpirite. And what though he for a ≈øea≈øon do ≈ølepe and do ≈øo ≈øuffer vs (vnto our ≈øeemynges) to ≈øynke? He wyll bee awaked beyng pulled by prayer: and therfore doth he delay our ≈øpedy deliueraunce, euen to fortifye our faithe by importune prayer. Lette vs then wyth in≈øtance apply this bu≈øines, and the rather in re≈øpect of the dangerous do ‚Ä¢ ing of this old age of the world. For it is with the men of this latter age of the worlde as it is with a very aged man, who for impotency of the powers both of ye mind & the body, is brought to much imbecillitye. Then do the wittes by weakenes wander out of the waye. The bodye by feablenes and defaulte of the former ≈øtrength doth ≈øtagger & full weakely doth any lymme or part of that wretched body execute the function vnto it belongyng. In
lyke maner is it with the churche of Chri≈øte in this do ‚Ä¢ yng old age of the world. There is nothyng ≈øuch fulnes in gods graces as heretofore hath bene in the primatiue church and the tymes immediatly en≈øuyng. There is le≈ø≈øe perfection in the fayth, feare, and loue towardes god, & charity towardes the brethren. There is le≈ø≈øe zeale to confe≈ø≈øe god, and le≈ø≈øe con≈øtancy to continue in gods truth, then was heretofore. And this is not ≈øtraunge vnto them which do ob≈øerue the fore-≈øpeakings of the ≈øcriptures, a≈øwel of the prophets of our ≈øauior Chri≈øte, as al≈øo of his apo≈øtles, by whome it hath ben ≈øignified before hand what daungerous dayes ≈øhould come in the latter times, as Math. 24, 2. The≈øs. 2. 1. Timoth. 2. Timo. 3.2. Peter. 2.

Wherfore let vs which are come into the≈øe latter daungerous tymes, fir≈øt con≈øider how that the holy gho≈øt hath geuen vs warnyng therof, and al≈øo that we by proofe haue experience of the verifying of the ≈øame: let vs now (I ≈øay) the more earne≈øtly apply our humble petition vnto that mercyful father and hys ≈øonne our ≈øwete ≈øauiour, who is the head of hys churche, euen this his body (weake though it be) that he wyll vouch≈øafe not ≈øo muche to ob≈øerue the backe≈ølidyng and ≈øhrinkyng of thys hys feble body: as to re≈øpect the for≈øpeakynges of the≈øe perilous tymes, and let vs wyth and in the name of the whole church, remember often the prayer of Dauid P≈øal. 71. Lord ca≈øt me not away in ye tyme of mine olde age when my ≈øtrength doth decay. That tyme of the church is euen now pre≈øente: and truly if we be in≈øtance in prayer, we be not without warranti≈øe of gods promi≈øes to obtayne that we pray for. P≈øal. 40. Math. 24. 1. Cor. 10 Yea call vpon me (≈øayth he) in the day of thy trouble and I wyll delyuer thee. For the electes ≈øake it is ≈øayd the daungerous dayes ≈øhalbe ≈øhortned. Yea faythfull is he that wyll not ≈øuffer vs to be tempted aboue that we be able to abyde. We may be bold to put our gracious god in remembraunce of hys olde mercies, P≈øal. 44. & with Deuid ≈øay, oh god we haue hearde wyth our eares and our fathers haue declared vnto vs the noble workes that thou dydde≈øt in theyr dayes and in the olde tyme before theÃÑ. The te≈øtimonies of hys word do teach vs how he hath from the begynnyng alway gathered vnto him≈øelf a congregation & church, vnto the which hys cho≈øeÃÑ church he hath bound him
≈øelfe by his couenaunt of mercy to be their god and ≈øauiour, and be≈øydes that hath powred vppon them his ≈øundry ble≈ø≈øinges and benefits. But agayne it is to be ≈øene in the ≈øcriptures, how that euen the≈øe peculier gods people, did at ≈øundry tymes fall from that theyr heauenly profe≈ø≈øion, a≈øwell to Idolatrye and fal≈øe Gods ≈øeruice, as al≈øo vnto di≈ø≈øolute liuyng, therby prouokyng gods wrathfull plagues and puni≈øhmentes, the which in dede ofteÃÑtimes, as they were ofteÃÑ de≈øerued, ≈øo they fel vpoÃÑ them. But euen as ye god of I≈ørael did vi≈øite the offences of hys people wyth his rodde of cha≈øti≈øement: ≈øo did he not at any tyme take away hys mercies from them, P≈øal. 89. and that for that couenaunt of mercy made vnto them in Abraham, I≈øaac, and Iacob their forefathers. And therfore when at any tyme throughe hys grace they dyd by repentaunce turne vnto hym, he mo≈øt fatherly embraced theÃÑ with the armes of his mercy.

The≈øe thyngs be written for vs, that we in ≈øemblable wy≈øe ≈øhould con≈øider fyr≈øt the dignitye whereunto we haue bene called, that is euen to be hys church and people. Yea in comparyng our profe≈ø≈øion wt either the heatheni≈øh Turkes & infidels, or vnto the people which are profe≈ø≈øed vnto this hypotriticall papi≈øtrye: we haue to aduaunce our ≈øelues as the true childreÃÑ of Chri≈øt, for that we beare the ryght badges of gods true people, and that is the earne≈øt de≈øyre towards the propagation of gods mo≈øt holy word, and the right v≈øe of the ≈øacraments agreable to the ≈øame, hauyng ioyned ther with a readines of hart and mynde to ≈øuffer affliction & per≈øecution for the confe≈ø≈øion of our fayth, or at the lea≈øt rather then we wyll deny or put away faith and a good con≈øcience. And be≈øydes the≈øe outward notes and tokens declaryng ye we be the true church there is a nearer token in gods elect, which is the inward te≈øtimony of gods ≈øpirite, whiche beareth wytne≈ø≈øe vnto our ≈øpirit that we be gods children, Rom. 8 cau≈øyng vs to crye Abba father, and beyng in dede the earne≈øte peny of our ≈øaluation.

But notwith≈øtandyng that we be thus promoted by our god, and dignifyed by his graces, yet mu≈øt we con≈øider how vnworthely we haue v≈øed in ≈øundry wi≈øe, the≈øe gods graces & ble≈ø≈øyngs: yea ≈øo vnthankfully we haue receyued theÃÑ, that no le≈ø≈øe plagues by gods iu≈øt iudgemente, belong vnto vs,
then was at that tyme due vnto tho≈øe his people. Wherfore let vs faythfully confe≈ø≈øe that we haue offended wyth oure forefathers. The which beyng done in our conuer≈øion vnto the Lord our God wyth our whole heart, P≈øal. 89. let vs a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues that euen as he hath and doth vi≈øite our ≈øynnes with this captiuity of body and coÃÑ≈øcience and ≈øuch other plagues beyng his rodde of cha≈øti≈øement, ≈øo hath he not taken away his mercy from vs: but wyll plentifully vi≈øite vs wyth the ≈øame, euen for that couenaunt of mercy made vnto vs, not in Abraham, I≈øaac, and Dauid, but in that promy≈øed ≈øede of Abraham, in that ≈øpiritual Dauid eueÃÑ Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who is that peaceable Salomon, makyng peace betwen vs and his Father by the offeryng of hys bodye and ≈øheedyng of hys bloude, by who≈øe meanes we mu≈øt looke for the gilt of our ≈øynnes to bee forgeuen and the plagues thereby purcha≈øed to be taken away. And now (dearly beloued) we be taught by that heauenly ≈øpirit which our god hath geuen vnto vs, to ≈øeke comfort in the≈øe tymes of affliction, not in hope of rebellion or fulfillyng vnprofitable, yea pe≈øtilent wel≈øhe prophecies, but in the mo≈øt comfortable & glad tidings of ye heauenly promi≈øes a≈ø≈øured in his deare Chri≈øt.

And touchyng this mo≈øt mi≈øerable e≈øtate of the gho≈øtly captiuity of con≈øcience and bodely bondage, wherin for our ≈øynnes pre≈øently we be holden: let vs fyr≈øt mo≈øt obediently ky≈ø≈øe this rodde of our father by obedience ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, to abide al extremity that man may do vnto vs, rather then to forgoe faythe and a good con≈øcience. Lette vs al≈øo be≈øeche our heauenly father for his chri≈øtes ≈øake, to leaue of beating vs and to take awaye the rodde, eyther by conuertyng the hartes of tho≈øe whiche afflicte & per≈øecute vs (for ≈øo dyd he ≈øomtyme take away the rodde, as namely by conuertyng of Nabuchodonozer, & Mana≈ø≈øes) or els if ≈øuch wycked ≈øcourges be not to be coÃÑuerted, but be reprobates, ve≈ø≈øels of gods wrath, chyldren of perdition, ≈øuche vpon whome it plea≈øeth god to ≈øhewe hys iudgementees, and in whom he will ≈øhew hys power: If I ≈øaye they be ≈øuche, let vs wy≈øhe mo≈øt earne≈øtly that our God wyll ≈øpedely ary≈øe that hys and our enemies may ≈øhortelye be ≈øcattered. Yea he knoweth what the≈øe execrable erecters of the Romy≈øhe religion are. They
be the proude builders of the Babilonicall Tower. They wyll clyme vppe into Gods kyngdome by theyr owne attempts, not expectyng & waiting for Gods helpe. Yea that lord be iudge betwixt them & vs. He knoweth that as theyr buildinges tende vnto the de≈øtruction of that true & onelye foundation Chri≈øt: ≈øo our buildyng by Gods woorde hathe and dothe tende to the ≈øub≈øtantiall laying of that only foundation, and to the e≈øtably≈øhyng of Chri≈øtes cho≈øen church vpon that ≈øame rocke, wyth an vnfayned fayth and pure con≈øcience, & al≈øo vnto the building vpon the ≈øame faith al fruitfull workes of the Spirite, to ≈øerue GOD in holines and ryghteou≈ønes, &c. Tit. 2. Yea that euer lyuyng Lord knoweth the earne≈øte de≈øyre of our hartes, is euen the greedy expectation of the glorious commyng of that greate iudge, vnto who≈øe iudgemente, (loe heauen and earthe bee witnes and ye Gods Saynctes) we doe appeale: in the meane ≈øea≈øon abidyng our Gods good plea≈øure to doe wyth vs that may mo≈øte redounde vnto hys glorye whether to lyue or dye, nothyng doubtyng in hym to be ≈øtrengthened merely, and chearefully to make a ≈øacrifyce and burnte offeryng for the confirmation of thys infallible veritye taughte by vs, and once receiued of you. And ioyne wt vs deare fellowe heires as we ioyne with you in humble prayer, that euen as all we be by ≈øaithe handfa≈øted vnto our hu≈øband and knytte vnto our heade Ie≈øu Chri≈øte, and al≈øo be kyndled by loue one to an other, as mutual members in this my≈øticall body: ≈øo we may per≈øeuere and continue vnto the ende, and that by and in our Chri≈øt we may encrea≈øe more and abound in the ≈øpirite of grace and prayer, wherby to fetche all heauenly influence from that our heade Chri≈øte one for an other, euen as in the bodye one member myni≈øtreth vnto an other, Amen, Amen.
