div.head: ¬∂To may≈øtres Lucye Harryngton a godly gentlewoman, and frendly in hys trouble to hym and his.
div.p:
YOur mo≈øt gentle commendations, wherof this me≈ø≈øenger made remeÃÑbrance vnto me, was for two cau≈øes very coÃÑfortable. Fyr≈øt for that thereby I vnder≈øtoode of the ≈øtare of your health and bodely welfare, for the which I geue thankes vnto GOD, who graunte the long continuaÃÑce therof to his honour and fatherly good wil, wherunto I will daily ≈øaye, AmeÃÑ. And father I was refre≈øhed by the expre≈ø≈øing of your myndful frend≈øhip towards me far vnworthy therof. Wherin I take occa≈øion of muche reioy≈øing in oure ≈øo gratious a god and mercifull father, who as he hath in hys vnme≈øurable mercy by fayth handfa≈øted vs hys cho≈øen children vnto hys deare ≈øonne our Chri≈øt, as the ≈øpirituall ≈øpou≈øe of ≈øuche an heauenly hu≈øband: ≈øo he lynketh vs by loue one vnto another, beyng by that bonde compacte together with charitable readines to do good one vnto an other: ≈øo that fyr≈øte to the glory of our god and his chri≈øt, then to our owne ioying in the te≈øtimony of a good con≈øcience, and la≈øte of all to the ≈øtoppyng of the mouthes and confu≈øion of our aduer≈øaries, we beare the badge as the right ≈øpou≈øe of our Chri≈øt, which he hym≈øelfe noteth in this hys ≈øayeng: Iohn. 13. herein ≈øhall all men know that ye be my di≈øciples, if ye loue one an other. Then farther by thys bonde of mutual loue, is ≈øet forth the fatherly prouidence of god towardes vs his children: that though it be he which careth for vs, in whom we lyue, moue and be, who feedeth all fle≈øh with bodely ≈øu≈øtenaunce, yet hathe he apointed vs in the≈øe pre≈øent nece≈ø≈øities, to ≈øtand in his ≈øtede one vnto an other. Wherin is not only ≈øet forth our dignitye, but al≈øo that vn≈øpeakable accorde and vnity among vs the many members in thys my≈øticall body. And thoughe that eyther for lacke of hability, or els throughe di≈øtaunce of place, power and oportunitie of helpyng one another doe fayle: yet wonderfull is ye workyng of gods childreÃÑ through the ≈øpirite of prayer, as wherby they fetch all heauenly influence from Chri≈øte their cele≈øtiall heade by hys ≈øpirite, Iohn. 15 to be mea≈øured ≈øeuerally as may ≈øerue to the mayntenance of the whole body. Thus doth our faithful prayer which we make one for an other, di≈øtribute and ≈øcatter gods bountifull ble≈ø≈øynges both gho≈øtly and bodelye when ordinarye habilitye
lacketh, and when the arme may not reach ≈øuch gods riches. According hereunto I wel perceaue and vnder≈øtande your readyne≈ø≈øe to do good vnto all, and e≈øpecially I haue experience of your readye good will towards me in your hartie de≈øire to ≈øtretch out your helpyng hand to releue my lacke, and of your helpe to be extended to me in the other ≈øpirituall ≈øorte by your good prayer, I doubt not: as I al≈øo therein a≈ø≈øure you of my helpe, being al that I maye do, and yet the ≈øame not ≈øo much as I would do. My nede concerning bodely nece≈ø≈øaryes, is as yet furny≈øhed by Gods proui≈øion, ≈øo that I am not driuen to any extremity wherfore to be burdenous to you, as your gentle beneuolence prouoketh me, the Lorde reward you therfore. If god make me worthy to be his witnes at this pre≈øent in geuing this corruptible body to burne for the te≈øtimonye of his truth, it is enough for me to ≈øay vnto you that I haue a pore wife and childe whoÃÑ I loue in the Lord, and whom I know for my ≈øake you wil tender when I am departed hence. To be ≈øhort, I ≈øay vnto you as I ≈øay vnto my ≈øelfe, reioyce in the Lorde, ca≈øte your care on him, for he careth for vs &c. and accordynge to the tyme pre≈øent, let vs with our Chri≈øt and all hys deare Di≈øciples wepe, let vs with hym (I ≈øay) weepe a while that we may laugh with him euerla≈øtingly. Apoc. 7. Let vs con≈øider of what ≈øort of people they were whom Saincte Iohn by Reuelation dyd beholde in the heauenly bly≈ø≈øe and euerla≈øtyng ioy. The≈øe are they (≈øayde the Aungell vnto him) whiche came out of great tribulation and made their garmentes whyte in the blood of ye lambe, and therfore are they in the pre≈øence of the ≈øeate of God and ≈øerue hym daye and nyghte in hys temple, and he that ≈øitteth in the ≈øeate will dwell among them, they ≈øhal hunger no more, neyther thur≈øt, neyther ≈øhal the Sunne lyght on them, neyther any heate, for ye Lambe which is in the midde≈øt of the ≈øeate ≈øhall fede them and ≈øhall lead them vnto fountaynes of liuyng water, and God ≈øhal wype awaye all teares from theyr eyes. Though we ≈øowe in ≈øorrowe, we ≈øhall reape in great ioy, and for thys hopes ≈øake we ≈øeeke the thynges aboue and for≈øake the thynges pre≈øent. I be≈øech you geue mo≈øt hartie ≈øalutations vnto my good Ladye Fitzwilliams, vnto whom I wy≈øhe as to you

div.head: An other letter to Mai≈øtres Lucie Harrington.
div.p:
GRace & mercy &c. It happeneth oftentimes ye abundaunce of matter bringing with it muche vehemencie of frendly affection, maketh men dumme: & euen then chiefly wheÃÑ there is mo≈øt eger pupo≈øe of ≈øpeakyng, ≈øilence doth ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe, and cau≈øeth the partye ≈øo affected, vnperfectly to expre≈ø≈øe that he goeth about to vtter. Such impediment by muche matter myngled with feruencie of affection, feele I ≈øometymes in my ≈øelfe lettyng the vtteraunce eyther by toung or writing of the aboundaunce of the hart. The loue of oure mo≈øte gracious God and heauenly Father be≈øtowed vppon vs in the merites of hys Chri≈øt oure Sauiour, who maye by concepte of mynd comprehend, pa≈ø≈øing in deede all vnder≈øtandyng? muche le≈ø≈øe may the ≈øame by any meanes be expre≈ø≈øedly vttered. And as ≈øuch heauenly ble≈ø≈øynges whiche by fayth we fetch from aboue, be inexplicable: ≈øo is it hard to vtter, when the faithfull are ≈øet on fyre by loue, theyr readyne≈ø≈øe to reache forth and to geue by charitie, as by fayth they haue receaued. But (alas) we carye thys trea≈øure in earthen ve≈ø≈øelles: many tymes fayth is feeble and then loue lo≈øeth her feruour. Pray we therefore, Lorde encrea≈øe oure fayth, and loue forthwith will be on fyre. And immortall thankes be geuen vnto our God, who in our Chri≈øt hath be≈øtowed vppon vs the fyr≈øte fruites of hys ≈øpirite, who cryeth in oure hartes Abba Father. Rom. 8. And (as S. Paule ≈øayth) ≈øeing we haue the ≈øame ≈øpirit of fayth, accordyng as it is written I beleued and therefore haue I ≈øpoken: we al≈øo beleue and therefore we ≈øpeake: yea God knoweth this ≈øpirite putteth in vs a mynd to ≈øpeake,1. Cor. 4 but in attempting thereof, we are driuen with Moy≈øes to ≈øaye, O Lorde, I am ≈ølowe mouthed and of vncircumci≈øed lippes, and with Ieromye, O Lorde I can not ≈øpeake. Albeit that thys infancye re≈øtrayneth the openyng of ≈øuche aboundaunce of hart in my tender Chri≈øtian dutie to bee declared towardes you, yet I be≈øeche you let this be ≈øetled in
your vnder≈øtandyng, that as S. Paule expre≈ø≈øeth vnto his Corinthians that they were in hys hart eyther to liue or to dye, with many other ≈øuch ≈øayinges vttered vnto them and the Galathians, expre≈ø≈øing hys vehement affection towards them: ≈øo in ≈øome parte I woulde be lyke affected towardes all Gods children, and e≈øpecially towardes you whom I know in Chri≈øt, and to whom I will not ≈øay, how much I am indebted. I thanke you for your great frend≈øhip & tender good will towardes my wife: yea that good gracious God recompence you, which maye worthely with the more countreuaile the ≈øame & fulfill that which lacketh of thankfull dutye in vs. And bycau≈øe of that whiche heretofore I haue conceaued of you and of your loue more then naturall towardes me and myne: I make my ≈øelfe thus bolde to lay this burden vpon you, euen the care and charge of my ≈øayde poore wife, I meane, to be vnto her a mother and a my≈øtres to rule and directe her by your di≈øcrete Coun≈øell. I knowe ≈øhe conceaueth of you the ≈øame that I doe, and is thankeful vnto God with me for ≈øuche a frend, and therfore I be≈øech you euen for Chri≈øtes ≈øake, put neuer from you thys frendly charge ouer her whether I liue longer or ≈øhortly depart. But to charge you otherwy≈øe, thankes be to God, neyther I neyther ≈øhee haue any ≈øuche extreme neede: if we had, I would be as bolde with you as mine own mother. I be≈øech you geue my harty ≈øalutations vnto Mai≈øter Fitzwilliams and my good Ladie, with thankes al≈øo for my poore wife and childe, the Lord recompence them.

div.head: To hys godly and faythfull wyfe and to hys deare frendes Mai≈øter Robert Harrington and Mai≈øter Hurland.
div.p:
GRace and comforte &c. Deare wife reioyce in our gracious God and his oure Chri≈øte, and geue thankes mo≈øte humblye and hartely to him for thys dayes woorke, that in any part I mo≈øt vnworthy wretch ≈øhould be made worthy to beare witne≈ø≈øe vnto his euerla≈øting veritie, which Antichri≈øt
with his, by mayne force (I perceaue) & by mo≈øt impudent pryde and boa≈øting, will goe aboute to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe. Remember God alway my, deare wyfe, and ≈øo ≈øhal Gods ble≈ø≈øyng light vpon you and our Samuell. O remember alway my words for Chri≈øtes ≈øake: be mery & grudge not agayn≈øt God & pray, pray. We be al mery here thankes be vnto god who in hys Chri≈øt hath geuen vs great cau≈øe to be mery, by whoÃÑ he hath prepared for vs ≈øuch a kyngdome, & doth & wil geue vnto vs ≈øome litle ta≈øte therof euen in thys lyfe, & to al ≈øuch as are de≈øyrous to take it. Ble≈ø≈øed (≈øayth our Chri≈øt) be they which huÃÑger & thir≈øt after righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, for ≈øuch ≈øhal be ≈øati≈øfyed. Let vs go, yea let vs runne to ≈øeeke ≈øuch trea≈øure, and that with whole purpo≈øe of harte to cleaue vnto the Lord, to fynde ≈øuch ryches in hys heauenly worde through hys ≈øpirite obtayned by prayer. My deare frendes and brethren Mai≈øter Harrington and Mai≈øter Hurlande, Praye, pray. Math. 26. Spiritus quidem promptus e≈øt caro autem infirma. When I loke vpon my ≈øelf, quid ego ≈øtupidus & attonitus habeo quod dicam,
Luke. 5. P≈øa. 119. ni≈øi illud Petri, exi a me domine quia homo peccator ≈øum. But then fele I that ≈øwete comfort, lucerna pedibus meis verbum domini & lumen ≈øemitis meis, & hec mea e≈øt con≈øolatio in humilitate mea.
Iohn. 6. Then waxe I bolde with the ≈øame Peter to ≈øay, domine ad quem ibimus, verba vitae eternae habes. Thys comfort haue I when the geuer therof doth geue it. But I loke for battailes which the rote of vnfaithfulnes, the which I feele in me, will mo≈øte egerlye geue vnto my con≈øcience when we come once to the combate. We be (I weene) within the ≈øounde of the trompe of oure enemyes, playe ye that be abroade the part of Moy≈øes orantes in omni loco, ≈øu≈øtollentes puras manus, & Gods people ≈øhal preuayle, yea oure bloode ≈øhal be their perdition who doth mo≈øt triumphantly ≈øpil it, and we theÃÑ being in the handes of our god, Sapien. 5. ≈øhal ≈øhine in his kingdome & ≈øhal ≈øtand in greate ≈øtedfa≈øtnes agayn≈øte them which haue dealt extremely with vs. And wheÃÑ the≈øe our enemyes ≈øhal thus ≈øee vs, they ≈øhal be vexed wt horrible feare, & ≈øhal wonder at the ha≈øtines of ye ≈øodayne health, and ≈øhal ≈øay with theÃÑ≈øelues hauing inwarde ≈øorrow & mourning for very angui≈øh of mind: the≈øe are they whoÃÑ we ≈øometime had in deri≈øioÃÑ & ie≈øted vpon: we fooles thought their liues to be very
madne≈ø≈øe and theyr end to be without honour; but loe how they are accompted among the children of God. The ble≈ø≈øyng of God be wt you al. Salute I pray you my ≈øi≈øter B. S. with other our frendes in the ≈øame hou≈øe, gods grace keepe theÃÑ with al the rea≈øt of our godly acquaintance, louers of the truth & furtherers of the true confe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame: whoÃÑ al I bid mo≈øt hartely to be mery in the lord reioycing in hope, preparing them ≈øelues to be pacient in tribulation with coÃÑ tinuaunce in prayer. Let ≈øome bodye bye for me a pen≈øill of lead to write with al, for I ≈øhal hardly haue pen and Inke here ≈øith al libertye of writyng is taken away from vs.

div.head: An other letter to hys wyfe and to Mai≈øter Harrington and Mai≈øter Hurland.
div.p:
GRace and comfort, &c. Wyfe you ≈øhal do be≈øt not to come ofteÃÑ vnto the grate where the porter may ≈øee you. Put not your ≈øelf in daunger where it nedes not: you ≈øhal I thinke, ≈øhortly come farre enough into daunger by keping fayth and a good con≈øcience, which (deare wife) I tru≈øt you do not ≈ølacke to make rekoning & accompt vpon by exerci≈øing your inward man in meditation of Gods mo≈øt holy woorde, being the ≈øu≈øtenaunce of the ≈øoule, and al≈øo by geuing your ≈øelfe to humble prayer: for the≈øe two things be the very meanes how to bee made meÃÑ bers of our Chri≈øt mete to inherite his kyngdome. Do thys (deare wife) in earne≈øt, & not leauing of, and ≈øo we two ≈øhal with our Chri≈øt and all his cho≈øen children, enioy the mery world in ye euerla≈øting immortalitie, where as here wil nothing els be found but extreme mi≈øery, eueÃÑ of theÃÑ which mo≈øt greedely ≈øeke thys worldly wealth: and ≈øo, if we two continue Gods children graffed in our Chri≈øt, the ≈øame Gods ble≈ø≈øing which we receaue, ≈øhal al≈øo ≈øettle vpon our Samuell. Though we do ≈øhortly depart hence and leaue the poore Infant (to our ≈øeeming) at al aduentures, yet ≈øhal he haue our gracious God to be hys God, for ≈øo hath he ≈øayd and he can not lye: I will be thy God ≈øayeth he and the God of thy ≈øede. Yea if you leaue him in the wild wildernes de≈øtitute of
all helpe, being called of God to do hys wyll eyther to dye for the confe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, eyther any worke of obedyence: that God whiche heard the crye of the litle poore infante of Agar Saraes handmaiden and dyd ≈øuccour it, wil doe the like to the chylde of you or any other fearyng hym and putting your tru≈øte in hym. And if we lacke fayth, as we doe indeede many tymes, let vs call for it and we ≈øhall haue the encrea≈øe both of it and al≈øo of any other good grace nedefull for vs, and bee merye in GOD, in whom al≈øo I am very merye and ioyfull. O Lorde what greate cau≈øe of reioy≈øyng haue we, to thynke vppon that Kingdome which he voucheth ≈øafe for hys Chri≈øtes ≈øake, frelye to geue vs, for≈øakyng oure ≈øelues and following hym? Deare wyfe thys is truely to followe hym, euen to take vp our cro≈ø≈øe and follow hym, and then as we ≈øuffer with hym, ≈øo ≈øhall we reygne with hym euerla≈øtingly, Amen. Shortly, ≈øhortly. Amen.

My deare frendes Mai≈øter Harrington, and Mai≈øter Hurland, Praye praye, and bee merye in God, and I be≈øeche you as you maye, let the good brethren abroade be put in mynde of oure deare tryed brethren and ≈øi≈øters who haue (the Lorde be pray≈øed) made knowen theyr con≈øtancye in confe≈ø≈øyng the truth to the glorye of GOD and comforte (I doubt not) of hys Churche abroade. Thus haue they ≈øowen ≈øpirituall thynges confe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øt. I tru≈øt they wil not be forgetfull that they may reape of them whiche are of habilitie and at libertye theyr carnall thynges. Hereof I ≈øpeake now, bycau≈øe of my tender de≈øyre towardes the≈øe deare brethren here now in bondes and in other places, and al≈øo for that I doubte whether I maye haue wherewith to write hereafter. The keper ≈øayeth he mu≈øte needes ≈øee that we write not at al. The deuil roreth but be of good cheare, he will ≈øhortly be troden vnder foote and the rather by the bloude of Martyrs. Salute in my mo≈øt hartye manner good Mai≈øters Harrington and my good Ladye. F. I am theyrs as longe as I lyue and praye for them: de≈øyre them to do likewy≈øe for me and for al vs ≈øhepe appointed to the ≈ølaughter.

div.head: An aun≈øweare to a frende of hys who ≈øent to knowe what Doctor VVe≈øton dyd at the Mar≈øhal≈øe.
div.p: MAi≈øter We≈øton came to conferre with M. Grymbold & what he hath with hym concluded I know not: pray that it maye bee to Gods glory. Amen. Mai≈øter We≈øton of his gentlenes vi≈øited me & offred me frend≈øhip in hys worldlye wilye ≈øort &c. I had not ≈øo much maner to take it at his haÃÑds, ≈øaying that I was well enough and ready chearefully to abide the extremitie to kepe therby a good con≈øcieÃÑce. You be a ≈ølepe in ≈øynne ≈øayd he. I would awake (qoth I) & do not forget vigilate & orate, &. what church was there (qoth he) .xxx yeres pa≈øt? What church was there in Helias time quoth I &c. Ioane of Rente (quoth he) was of your Churche. No (qoth I) we did condeÃÑne her as an heritike. Who was of your church (quoth he) xxx. yeares pa≈øte? Such (quoth I) as that Romy≈øhe Antichri≈øt andhis rable had reputed and coÃÑ demned as heretikes. Wicliffe, Thorpe, old ca≈øtle (quoth he) &c. Yea (quoth I) wt many mo as ≈øtoryes do tel. The by≈øhop of Rome hath (quoth he) long time played aparte in your rayling ≈øermons, but now be ye ≈øure he mu≈øt playe an other manner of part. More pitie (quoth I) and yet ≈øome comfort it is to ≈øee how that the be≈øte learned, wi≈øe≈øt, and holye≈øt of you al, haue heretofore had hym to playe a parte likewy≈øe in your ≈øermons and writynges, thoughe nowe to plea≈øe the world, ye turne with the wethercocke. div.p:
TOuching the cau≈øe of myne impri≈øonment, I doubt whether I haue broken any law either proclamatioÃÑ. This proclamatioÃÑ was to inhibite the preaching of gods holy word. Actes. 24 ≈øic colo patriuÃÑ deuÃÑ, credens omnibus quae in lege et prophetis ≈øcripta ≈øunt, ≈øpem habeÃÑs in deuÃÑ, &c. And this my con≈øcience is not grounded vppon vayne fanta≈øye, but vppon the infallible veritye of Gods woorde, with the witne≈ø≈øyng of hys cho≈øen churche agreable vnto the ≈øame. It is an ea≈øye thynge for them whiche take Chri≈øte for their true pa≈øtour, to di≈øcerne the voyce of their true ≈øhepeheard, from the voyce of wolues, hirelynges and ≈øtraungers, fora≈ømuch as Chri≈øt ≈øaith: Iohn. 10 Oues meae vocem meam audiunt. Yea and therby they ≈øhall haue the gifte to know the ryght voyce of the true ≈øhepehard, and ≈øo to follow hym and to auoide the contrary, as he al≈øo ≈øayth: Oues pastorem ≈øequuntur quia nouerunt vocem eius: altenum vero non ≈øequuntur, ≈øed aufugiunt ab eo, quia non noueruut vocem alienorum. That is, the ≈øhepe follow the ≈øhepeheard, for they know hys voyce: a ≈øtraunger wyl they not follow but fly from him, for they know not the voyce of a ≈øtrauÃÑger. Such inward in≈øpiratioÃÑ doth the holy gho≈øt put into the children of God, beyng in deede taught of god, but otherwy≈øe vnhable to vnder≈øtaÃÑd the true way of theyr ≈øaluation. And albeit that the wolfe, as Chri≈øte ≈øayth, commeth in ≈øhepes clothyng, yet he ≈øayth, ex fructibus eorum cogno≈øcetis eos. That is, by their fruites ye ≈øhall know them. That the Romi≈øh religion is rauenyng and wolui≈øhe, it is apparant in three pryncipal pointes. Fyr≈øt it robbeth god of his due and only honour. Secondly it taketh away the true comfort of con≈øcieÃÑce in ob≈øcuring or rather burieng of Chri≈øt & his office of ≈øaluation. Thirdly it ≈øpoyleth god of hys true wor≈øhip & ≈øeruice in ≈øpirit & truth apointed in his pre≈øcript coÃÑmaundemeÃÑts, & dryueth men vnto ye incoÃÑuenience again≈øt the which Chri≈øt with the prophet E≈øay doth ≈øpeake ≈øharplye: Populus hic labijs me honorat, cor autem eorum longe a me e≈øt, ≈øed fru≈øtra me colunt docentes doctrinas & praecepta hominuÃÑ.
E≈øay. 26. Math. 25. That is, thys people honoureth me wyth theyr lyppes but theyr hart is farre from me: they wor≈øhyp me in vayne teachyng the doctryne and preceptes of men. That is, ye ca≈øt away the coÃÑ maundementes of god, to maynteyne your owne traditions Wherfore I in con≈øcience wayeng the Romy≈øhe religion, and by indifferent di≈øcu≈ø≈øyng therof, fyndyng the foundatioÃÑ vn≈øtedfa≈øt, and the buildyng therupon but vaine: and on the other ≈øyde hauyng my con≈øcience framed after the right and vncorrupt religion, ratified and fully e≈øtabli≈øhed by the worde of god and the con≈øent of his true church: neither may nor doe intend by gods gratious a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, to be pulled one iote froÃÑ the ≈øame, no though an aungell from heauen ≈øhould preach any other doctrine.Explicita fide ‚Ä¢ is called of the ≈øcholemen that faith wherof a rea≈øon may be geueÃÑ, and implicita fides is called that ≈øymple fayth whiche leaneth onely to the church althoughe there can no rea≈øon be geuen therof. div.head: ¬∂To hys wyfe and other of hys frendes after hys condemnation to rhe fyre and a litle before hys death.
div.p: GRace in Chri≈øt, with the con≈øolation of the holy gho≈øt, to the kepyng of faith and a good con≈øcience, confyrme and keepe you for euer ve≈ø≈øels to gods glory. Amen.

To ≈øtand to number the≈øe mercies in perticulars, were to number the droppes of the ≈øea, ye ≈øand on the ≈øhore, & the ≈øtarres in the ≈økie. Oh my dere wyfe and ye the re≈øt of my frendes that loue me in the lord, reioyce, reioyce with me, reioyce (I ≈øay) with thaÃÑkesgeuing for thys my pre≈øent promotion to be made worthy to magnify my god, not only in my lyfe by my ≈ølow mouth & vncircumci≈øed lippes to heare te≈øtimony vnto hys truth, but al≈øo by my bloode to ≈øeale the ≈øame to the glorye of GOD and confyrming of his church. And as yet, I te≈øtify vnto you the comfort in my ≈øwete chri≈øt doth driue from my phanta≈øy the feare of death. But if my deare hu≈øbaÃÑd do for my trial leaue me alone to my ≈øelfe, I know in what ca≈øe I ≈øhall then be: but if for proofe he do ≈øo, I am ≈øure he wyll not be farre froÃÑ me. He is ≈øo tender harted a Io≈øeph that though he ≈øpeake roughlye to his brethren and handle them hardly, yea and put his be≈øt beloued brother BeÃÑiamin in pri≈øon, yet can he not conteyne him≈øelfe from weepynge with vs and vpon vs, with clipping vs about the neck and
ky≈ø≈øing vs: ≈øuch a brother is our Chri≈øt vnto vs all. Wherfore ha≈øten to goe vnto hym as Iacob did and hys ≈øonnes and family, leauyng theyr own countrey and acquaintance. Yea this Io≈øeph of oures hath obtained for vs his brethreÃÑ, that Pharao the infidele ≈øhall mini≈øter vnto vs charetres wherin to be caried to come vnto hym: as we haue experience how our verye aduer≈øaries helpe vs vnto our euerla≈øtyng bli≈ø≈øe by their ≈øpeedy di≈øpatche, yea howe all thynges haue bene holpynges vnto vs ble≈ø≈øed be our God. And be not afraid of fray bugges by the way: feare rather the euerla≈øtyng fyre, feare the ≈øerpent that hath a ≈øtynge, and that is thys bodely death to them which are not graffed in Chri≈øte, beyng without fayth and a good con≈øcience, and ≈øo not acquainted wyth Chri≈øt the kyller of death. But (O my deare frendes and brethern) we we, whome God hath delyuered from the power of darkenes and hathe tran≈ølated in to the kyngdome of hys deare ≈øonne by puttyng of the olde man and by faithe puttyng on the newe, euen our Lorde Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, his wi≈ødome, holines, rightuou≈ønes and redemptioÃÑ: we I ≈øay haue to triumph again≈øt that terrible & ≈øpiteful ≈øerpent the deuil, ≈øinne, death, hell, & daÃÑnation, for Chri≈øte our bra≈øen ≈øerpent hath pulled awaye the ≈øtinge thereof,1 Cor. 15 ≈øo that now we may boldly in beholdyng the ≈øerpente this bodely death ≈øpoiled of her ≈øtinge, triumphe and with our Chri≈øte & all his elett ≈øay, O death where is thy ≈øting? O hel where where is thy victory? ThaÃÑkes be vnto god who hath geuen vs the victory through our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.

Wherfore be mery my deare frendes and bretherne, alwaies remember the Lord my fellow heyres of the euerla≈øting kyngdome: reioyce in hope, be patient in tribulation, continue in prayer, and for vs pray now already apointed to ye ≈ølaughter, yt we may be vnto our heauenly father a fat of ‚Ä¢ ring & an accepted ≈øacrifice. I may hardly wryte vnto you,To this his flocke he Wrote al≈øo a fruitfull lette ‚Ä¢ exhorting and chargyng theÃÑ to beware of the Romi≈øh religioÃÑ, which is not yet come to light wherfore let the≈øe few words be a witnes of coÃÑmendations to you & all theÃÑ which loue vs in the faith, and namely vnto my flock, emoÃÑgs whoÃÑ I am now re≈øideÃÑt by gods prouideÃÑce, but as a pri≈øoner. And although I am not emoÃÑges theÃÑ as I haue ben to preache to theÃÑ out of a pulpit, yet doth god now preach vnto theÃÑ by me & by this mine impri≈øoÃÑmeÃÑt & captiuity which now I ≈øuffer emoÃÑges theÃÑ for chri≈øtes go≈øpels ≈øake
byddyng them to beware of the Romi≈øh Antichri≈øtian religion and kyngdome, requiring and charging them to abide in the truth of Chri≈øt, which is ≈øhortlye to be ≈øealed with the blood of their pa≈øtour, who though he be vnworthy of ≈øuche a mini≈øtery, yet Chri≈øt theyr high pa≈øtour is to be regarded, who≈øe truth hath bene taught them by me, is witne≈ø≈øed by my chaines, and by hys power ≈øhalbe by my death al≈øo. Be not carefull good wyfe, ca≈øt your care on the Lord and commend me vnto hym in repentaunt prayer, as I do you and oure Samuell, whom euen at the ≈øtake I wyl offer, as my ≈øelfe vnto God. div.head: A letter written to a certayne backe≈ølyder from the truth of Gods woorde, whiche he had both profe≈ø≈øed and taught: the whiche, bicau≈øe it is thought of ≈øome, albeit not certaynly knowen, to be written by. M. Saunders, we haue here annexed vnto hys letters.
div.p:
IN mine own name and in the name of manye other your old familiars and acquaintance, I do write vnto you in heuines of hart, for that we haue heard of your fal. Oh how much better had it beene for you neuer to haue ≈øet your hand to the plough then negligently to looke backe, yea and foli≈øhly to follow that plough that tilleth not gods fielde, but turneth vp the rootes of that ≈øeede which in times pa≈øt you your ≈øelf haue ≈øoweÃÑ. Alas how foli≈øh a builder were you that woulde enterpry≈øe to builde vppon the rocke Chri≈øt, ≈øeing in your ≈øelfe not onely the lacke of tho≈øe thinges which be requyred to the fini≈øhyng of that worke, but al≈øo the lacke of a will to haue them, as appeareth by that that you goe aboute to ouerthrowe that little whiche you ≈øeemed to haue myghtely builded vppon that rocke. Howe foly≈øhe a virgine haue you declared your ≈øelfe to bee which haue gone forth to meete the bridegrome and taryed ≈øo long for hys comming not hauing oyle in ≈øtoore, Math. 25. but are nowe driuen when you heare the voyce of the forerunner, to ≈øeke at them that ≈øell? You bancketed with the children of the bridegrome ≈øo long as he was with vs, but now he is gone, you leaue vs alone to fa≈øte. You were contented to be
fedde at Chri≈øtes hand with fyue thou≈øand, but wheÃÑ he willeth you not to ≈øeeke the meate that pery≈øheth, you depart. The children of I≈øraell were muche to be blamed, for that they de≈øired to be in Egipt agayne, and yet was their lacke and laboure then more in de≈øerte then yours in London. Alas wretched man what hath cau≈øed thee thus to ca≈øte awaye thy ≈øelfe once knowing the truth, and to take in hande to be a mini≈øter in Antichri≈øtes Church? Arte thou ≈øo ≈øone wery of the heauenly Manna and ≈øo readye to returne to thy olde vomite agayne? we thought thou hadde≈øt beene ≈øo cleane e≈øcaped through the woorde of grace, that thou hadde≈øt bene a worthy man, to be a comforte to them that ≈øtand, a ≈øuccour to the weake, and an helpe to them that fall: and art thou now roled in thy filthye pudle agayn, and art become an helper to put other into the ≈øame? Oh more then damnable doings, the forgeuenes wherof farre pa≈ø≈øeth the hope of man. And were it not that things impo≈ø≈øible to man are po≈ø≈øible with God, we ≈øhoulde vtterly de≈øpayre of thy returne. But knowing that with God there is no impo≈ø≈øibilitie, we wil not only aduerty≈øe thee to remember froÃÑ whence thou arte fallen, that thou maye≈øt ≈øeeke to ry≈øe agayne, but we will al≈øo praye that he to whom thy returne is po≈ø≈øible, will vouch≈øafe of hys infinite mercyes to worke it in thee. Thou ha≈øte with Iudas ≈øolde thy mo≈øte louyng and gentle Mai≈øter: repente thee Peter and no doubte thou ≈øhalt fynde mercye. To fall is a thing annexed to the corrupte nature of man, but to lye ≈øtill in the filthye puddle of perdition, is to de≈øpi≈øe God the authour and fyr≈øt maker of nature. To fall into the darkenes of errour is a poynte of mans ignoraunce: but to walke on ≈øtil in darkenes, is to loue darkenes more then lyghte. To wyncke at the bryghtne≈ø≈øe of the Sunne, is a weakenes of the eyes, but to flye the light is to be of the nyght. To leaue the rough way that leadeth vnto lyfe, and walke in the plea≈øaunt waye that leadeth vnto perdition, is to loue thys lyfe: but not to leaue ye waye when we are warned, is to de≈øpi≈øe the lyfe to come. Breefely to leaue the good thyngs vndone that god commauÃÑdeth, and to doe that euell whiche he forbyddeth, is to de≈øerue euerla≈øtyng damnation at hys hande that rewardeth euerye
man according to hys workes: but not to repente of that euell when God calleth by hys meanes, is to kindle ye wrath of God again≈øt the impenitent and ob≈øtinate ≈øinner. Lea≈øte you therfore ≈øhoulde be found a de≈øpi≈øer of God the author of nature, a louer of darkenes more then lighte, not of the daye but altogether of the night, a louer of this life and an hater of ye life to come, & finally ≈øuch a one as would kindle the wrath of God again≈øte you: repent and come agayne to Chri≈øt. Remember what ioye there is in heauen among the Angels at the conuer≈øion of a ≈øinner. Forget not thy mercifull ≈øpou≈øe which would not ca≈øte of the adulterous I≈ørael when ≈øhe had committed whoredome with ≈øtockes & ≈øtones notwith≈øtanding that he had purged her froÃÑ her filth & maried her to him ≈øelf. Be mindfull of that louing Lord, which hath ≈øayd, I wil not the death of a ≈øinner, but rather that he conuert and liue, Ezechi. 18. and in what day ≈øo euer the ≈øinner doth repent hym of his ≈øinne from the bottome of his hart, I will remember his iniquitie no more.No weryne≈ø≈øe ≈øhould dy≈øcourage vs to beare the Lords armour or to fight vnder hys banner, nor lacke cau≈øe vs to ≈øhrinke from hym. What ≈øhoulde ≈øeperate vs from the loue of this Lord? What ≈øhould make vs to flye froÃÑ this our captaine? Should the weryne≈ø≈øe of an arme? ≈øhould the lacke of ≈øuch things as the phanta≈øie would haue? Better it were for vs to enter into life with werye armes and thynne chekes, then with louely countenaunces and lu≈øtye limmes to be ca≈øt into hell fyre. Make not proui≈øion for the fle≈øh with the lo≈ø≈øe of your ≈øoule. Beleue him that hath promi≈øed all thinges nece≈ø≈øary to them that ≈øeke the kingdome of God and the righteou≈ønes thereof. He hath not at any time deceaued you: why then ≈øhoulde you ≈øeke ≈øuch ≈øhamefull ≈øhiftes to make proui≈øion for the fle≈øhe? Haue not you your ≈øelfe had experience of the care that he taketh for them that put theyr tru≈øte in hym? And nowe whye are you fallen from hym for the bellyes ≈øake? Thys haue I written to call you backe agayne, if you bee not cleane gone oute of the waye, but and if you bee ≈øo geuen ouer to errour that you thynke lyghte to be darkenes and darkenes to bee lyghte, good to bee euill and euill to bee good, Chri≈øt to be Beliall and Beliall to bee Chri≈øt, the temple of God to be the Sinagoge of Sathan, and the Sinagoge of SathaÃÑ to be the temple of God: then haue I nothing to ≈øaye vnto
you, but the Lorde confounde both you and all ≈øuche. But with Gods grace we tru≈øte to heare better of you.

div.head: A letter ≈øente to Mai≈øter Farrer B. of S. Dauids. Doctor Taylour. M. Bradford, and. M. Philpot: which, albeit it was written before his condemnation, we thought good here to place as it came vnto our handes.

Good Fathers & deare brethren, be thankefull vnto our mo≈øt gracious God, which hath pre≈øerued vs, and ≈øhal (I doubt not) froÃÑ bla≈øphemyng his ble≈ø≈øed name: yea not only that, but al≈øo, ex ore infantium & lactentium perficiet laudem &c. The Donati≈øtes ≈øaye they, ≈øought for ≈øuch ≈øingularitie, but they were not mete to liue in a common wealth, no more be you, as you ≈øhal ≈øhortly vnder≈øtand. Death ≈øhal be welcome (≈øay I) as being loked for long ≈øince, and yet do iu≈øtice ye were be≈øt, for Abels blood cryed you wote what. The ≈øpirite of God be vpon you and God ≈øaue your honours. Thus departed I froÃÑ them. Pray pray. Ah, Ah, Puer ≈øum, ne≈øcio loqui. My brother P. ≈øhal ≈øhew you more herein. By hym ≈øend me woord what you haue done. Fare ye well and praye pray. div.head: An other letter written al≈øo before hys condemnation to Mai≈øtres Harrington: whiche, as it is here la≈øt in order, comming la≈øt vnto our hands, ≈øo it ≈øemeth to be the fyr≈øt he wrote vnto her.
div.p: GRace, mercy, and peace in Ie≈øu Chri≈øt, Amen.

Such is the knot wherwith true Chri≈øtiaÃÑs are compacte and ioyned together as members in the my≈øticall bodye of Chri≈øt, that no man can expre≈ø≈øe the commodityes ≈øo well as they whiche thereof haue experience, and yet neyther can they by words be able to vtter that which therin the con≈øcience conceaueth, pa≈ø≈øing (in deede) al vnder≈øtaÃÑ ding. And hereof caÃÑ I vnworthy wretch ≈øomewhat ≈øpeake of experience, for that by exercy≈øe of the inwarde man and practi≈øe of con≈øcience, I haue ≈øome acquaintaunce with my good God and hys ≈øwete Chri≈øt, and namely nowe in thys my pre≈øent e≈øtate it plea≈øeth that mercifull Lord to geue me ≈øome ta≈øte of hys mercyes by the a≈ø≈øuraunce and the ≈øealing vp of hys gracious promy≈øes in my con≈øcience by hys holye ≈øpirite, whereby I doe feele the incomparable benefite of his heauenly ble≈ø≈øing powred vpon vs his cho≈øen congregatioÃÑ. 2. Timot. 1. Iohn. 15 We be called in Chri≈øt with an holy vocation: we be graffed in hym as braunches in that ≈øo heauenlye a vyne: we be knit vnto him as the ≈øundrye members of that body wherof he onely is the head, in whom all the bodye is coupled together in euery ioynte, Ephe≈ø. 4. wherwith one mini≈øtreth vnto another according to the operation, as euery part hath his mea≈øure, and encrea≈øeth the body vnto the edifying of it ≈øelfe in loue, and we be handfa≈øted vnto hym as the ≈øpiritual ≈øpou≈øe of ≈øo heauenly an hu≈øband, Ephe. 5. euen fle≈øh of hys fle≈øhe, and bone of his bone: ≈øo that to the faythfull beleuer what can be lacking vnto perfect felicitie in ≈øuch a coÃÑmunion and precious pertaking wt Chri≈øt in all heauenly trea≈øures? For froÃÑ him we may fetche aboundaunt fulnes to ≈øupply our extreme emptines: we be quicke in him as liuely braunches in the vine≈øtocke: We be made a liue vnto god in him, as meÃÑ bers
of the body do liue by the head, and we bee by fayth in him accepted as his deare ≈øpou≈øe, and in thys matrimonial bond and couenaunt he hath made with vs a mo≈øt happye exchaunge. He hath taken vnto him what we brought, and geueth vs al that is his be it neuer ≈øo precious: ≈øo entierlye he loued vs. Thus be we made ryche in him, as many as thus know hym and thus do beleue hym to be ours. And ble≈ø≈øed be that heauenly father who hath hidde the≈øe thyngs from the wy≈øe and prudent, Luke. 10. and hath reueled the ≈øame vnto his cho≈øeÃÑ litle ones, Phillip. 3. who with holy Paul do count al things but lo≈ø≈øe, and do iudge theÃÑ but dong for the excellent knowledge of Chri≈øt Ie≈øu the Lord, to wynne him and to be fouÃÑd in hym not hauing righteou≈ønes of them≈øelues, but ye ryghteou≈ønes which commeth of God through fayth in Chri≈øt, in knowing hym and the vertue of his re≈øurrection and the fellow≈øhip of hys pa≈ø≈øions, to be coÃÑformable vnto his death wherby to attayne the re≈øurrection from death. This, thys, is that trea≈øure hid in the field, wherof is ≈øpoken Math. 13. Math. 13. the which a man findeth and hideth and for ioy therof goeth and ≈øelleth al that he hath and byeth that field. Now euen as the conceyuing of thys communion & fellow≈øhip which we haue with Chri≈øt, bringeth ≈øuch peace as pa≈ø≈øeth all vnder≈øtandyng: ≈øo (as I ≈øayde) the Chri≈øtian knittyng of faythful beleuers in thys Chri≈øtes mi≈øticall body, is vnto the vnder≈øtanders a ioyfull ioyning and enioying, and a profitable fruition one of an other: as in the bodye one member thereof mini≈øtreth vnto an other, thereby takyng comforte one in an other, Ephe. 4. whereof Saincte Paule mo≈øte liuelye and comfortablye ≈øpeaketh in the .4 Chapter to the Ephe≈ø. whiche woordes bee aboue mencioned. The bonde of this compactyng and knittyng of vs together, is loue. For euen as our head Chri≈øte by hys vnmea≈øurable mercye and vn≈øpeakeable loue towardes vs doth a≈ø≈øure hym ≈øelfe vnto vs to bee one with vs, we being in hym and he in vs: ≈øo thys loue is by hys ≈øpirite powred into oure hartes, whereby we bee taughte, that the faythfull beleuers as they are in number manye, ≈øo are they in Chri≈øte manye members makynge be
but one body. And hereof en≈øueth the carefull compa≈ø≈øion & chereful reioy≈øing of one for an other, as occa≈øion requireth. Hereof procedeth not onely a thankefulnes vnto God for hys graces receaued, but al≈øo a continuall per≈øeueraunce in praying one for an other, therby to purcha≈øe the mutual pertaking of hys manifold ble≈ø≈øings nedeful for vs. And finallie hereby is wrought in vs a liuely feling of a ≈øpiritual welfare, euen as in the body one meÃÑber is the better forthe welfare of the other: and thus much hereof. Which as I do not amplifie as an idle ≈øpeculatioÃÑ wtout ≈øome practy≈øe of ye ≈øame: ≈øo mu≈øt I confe≈ø≈øe that I am farre from that feling which I ought & al≈øo would haue therof. Notwith≈øtanding I yelde mo≈øt humble thankes vnto my God, who hath practi≈øed me in≈øome comfortable vnfayned experience of the ≈øame, and as I ≈øomewhat haue felt, ≈øo I ≈øomwhat haue ≈øpoken. And yet the rather do I reioyce to enlarge herein vnto you (my deare Chri≈øtian frend good Mai≈øtres Harrington) for that I doe well knowe,2. Cor. 4. that you haue dronke of the holy ≈øpirite with other, vnto whoÃÑ the knowledge hereof ≈øemeth not foly≈øhnes (as it doth vnto worlynges) but is in deede, ye wi≈ødome of God, and the hygh power of God to ≈øaue all them that beleue it. And for bycau≈øe I do e≈øteme you as one of the members belonging vnto that my≈øtical body, I do with no ≈ømal comfort many times remeÃÑber you, geuing god thanks for you, and dayly do I by name remeÃÑber you in my prayers, yea and al≈øo your familie, that you maye in the feare of god con≈øider your great charge, and that the rather by your abiding in the true reuerend feare of God, they whom you haue charge of, maye bee vertuou≈ølye tran≈øformed into the ≈øame, Amen, Amen.

I doubte not but yt you haue learned the lo≈ø≈øon of. ≈ø. Paul vnto hys Timothy:1. Timot. 1. haue fayth and a good con≈øcience, the which while ≈øome haue put froÃÑ them, they haue made ≈øhipwracke of their fayth. I knowe I ≈øhall not nede to bid you fly froÃÑ Idolatry, yea yt mo≈øt dete≈øtable idole of ye ma≈ø≈øe. him to be, and he wil be the helper at an extreme pinch. Oh how ≈øwete is he vnto them that wil be the ≈øimple ≈øhepe of his pa≈øture? div.p:
MY dearely beloued brother Careles, I haue receaued your louing letters ful of loue & coÃÑpa≈ø≈øioÃÑ, in ≈øo much yt they made my hard hart to wepe, to ≈øee you ≈øo careful for one that hath bene ≈øo vnprofitable a member as I haue bene & am in Chri≈øtes Church. And thys hath happened vnto me yt I might be hereafter an en≈øample of coÃÑfort, if the like happen vnto you or to any other of my deare brethreÃÑ with you in the≈øe cruel daies, in ye which the deuil ≈øo rageth at ye faithful flocke of Chri≈øt, but in vaine (I tru≈øt) again≈øte any of vs, who be per≈øuaded that neyther lyfe neither death is hable to ≈øeparate vs from the loue of Chri≈øtes Go≈øpell, which is gods high trea≈øure coÃÑmitted to our brittle ve≈ø≈øels to glorify vs by the ≈øame. God of his mercye make vs faythful ≈øtewardes to the end, & geue vs grace to feare nothing what≈øoeuer in his good plea≈øure we ≈øhall ≈øuffer for the ≈øame. That I haue not written vnto you er≈øte, the cau≈øe is our ≈øtraite keping & the want of light by night, for the day ≈øerueth vs but a while in our darke clo≈øet. This is the fir≈øt letter that I haue writen ≈øince I came to pri≈øon, be≈øides the report of mine examinatioÃÑs, & I am faine to ≈øcrible it out in ha≈øte. Comend me to al our faythful brethren & byd them with a good courage loke for their redeÃÑption and frame theÃÑ≈øelues to be harty ≈øouldiers in Chri≈øt. They haue taken his pre≈øt money a great while, & now let theÃÑ ≈øhew theÃÑ ≈øelues readye to ≈øerue him faythfully & not to flye out of the lords campe into ye world, as many do. Let them remember that in the Apocalips the feareful bee excluded ye kingdome. Let vs bee of good cheare for our lord ouercame the world, that we ≈øhould do the like. Ble≈ø≈øed is the ≈øeruant whoÃÑ when the Lord coÃÑmeth, he fyndeth watching. O let vs watch and pray earne≈øtly one for an other yt we be not led into temptation. Be ioyfull vnder the cro≈ø≈øe & pray≈øe the Lord continually, for this is the whole burnt ≈øacrifice which ye lord chiefly delyghteth in. CoÃÑmend me to my father Hunt & de≈øire him to loue & continue in ye vnitie of Chri≈øtes true church which he hath begon, & then ≈øhall he make me more & more to ioye vnder my cro≈ø≈øe with him. Tell my brother Clements that he hath comforted me muche by his louing token in ≈øignificatioÃÑ of an vnfayned vnitie with vs: let him encreace my ioye vnto the end perfectly. The Lord of peace be with you
all. Salute all my louing frendes, Mai≈øter Meryng, Mai≈øter Crooth, with the re≈øt, & ≈øpecially Mai≈øter Mar≈øhall and hys wyfe, with great thankes for hys kyndnes ≈øhewed vnto me. Fare well my deare Careles. I haue dalied with the deuill a while, but now I am ouer the ≈øhooes, God ≈øend me well out.

div.head: An other letter written to Iohn Careles out of the Colehou≈øe of darkenes, whereby he geueth lighte and heauenlye comforte to hys heauy and troubled mynde.
div.p: THe God of all comfort, and the father of oure Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, ≈øend vnto thee my deare brother Careles the inwarde con≈øolation of hys holy ≈øpirite, in al the malicious a≈ø≈øaultes and troublous temptations of our common aduer≈øarye the Deuill, Amen.

That god geueth you ≈øo contrite a harte for your ≈øinnes, I can not but reioyce to behold the liuely marke of the children of god, who≈øe propertye is to thinke more lowlye and vily of them≈øelues, then of any other, and often tymes doe ≈øet their ≈øinnes before them, that they myghte the more bee ≈øtyrred to bryng forth the fruites of repentaunce, and learne to mourne in thys worlde that in an other they myghte bee glad and reioyce. Such a broken heart is a plea≈øaunt ≈øacryfyce vnto God: O that I had the lyke contrite harte. God mollifye my ≈øtonye harte, which lamenteth not in ≈øuch wi≈øe my former dete≈øtable iniquities. Prai≈øed be god that he hath geuen you thys ≈øorrowful hart in re≈øpect of righteou≈ønes, & I praye you let me be pertaker of the≈øe Godly ≈øorrowes for ≈øinne, which be ye te≈øtimony of the pre≈øence of ye holy gho≈øte. Dyd not ye ≈øword of ≈øorrow pearce the harte of the elect and ble≈ø≈øed mother of our Lord? Did not Peter wepe bitterly for hys ≈øinnes which was ≈øo beloued of Chri≈øt? Dyd not Mary Magdalene was the feete of oure Sauiour with her teares, and receaued therwithall remi≈ø≈øion of her ≈øeuenfold ≈øinnes?
Be of good comfort therfore mine own deare heart, in thys thy ≈øorrowe, for it is the earne≈øt peny of eternall con≈øolatioÃÑ. In thy ≈øorrowe laughe, for the ≈øpirite of God is with thee. Ble≈ø≈øed be they (≈øayth Chri≈øt) that mourne: Math. 15. P≈øa. 125. p≈øal. 51 Luke. 7 for they ≈øhal bee comforted. They went forth and wepte, fayth the Prophet: ≈øuch ≈øhall come agayne hauing their gripes full of gladnes. And althoughe a ≈øorrowfull harte in con≈øideration of hys ≈øinne, be an acceptable ≈øacrifice before God, whereby we are ≈øtirred vp to more thankefulnes vnto God, knowing that much is forgeuen vs that we might loue the more: yet ye maÃÑ of god mu≈øte keepe a mea≈øure in the ≈øame, lea≈øte he bee ≈øwallowed vppe by to muche ≈øorrowe. Sainte Paule woulde not the The≈ø≈øalonians to be ≈øory as other men whiche haue no hope. Such a ≈øorow is not commendable,1. The≈øs. 4. 2. Cor. 7. but worketh damnation, and is farre from the children of God, who are continually ≈øorrowfull in god, when they loke vppon theyr own vnworthynes wt hope of forgeuenes. For God to thys end by his ≈øpirite ≈øetteth the ≈øinnes of hys electe ≈øtill before them, that where they perceaue ≈øinne to abounde, Rom. 5. there they myght be a≈ø≈øured that grace ≈øhall ≈øuperabounde, & bringeth them downe vnto hell, that he myght lift theÃÑ vp with greater ioy vnto heaueÃÑ. Wherfore myne own bowels in Chri≈øt, as long as you are not voyde altogether of hope, be not di≈ømayde throughe your pen≈øiue harte for your ≈øinnes howe huge ≈øo euer they haue beene, for God is hable to forgeue more then you are able to ≈øinne, yea, and he wil forgeue him which with hope is ≈øory for hys ≈øinnes.

But know brother, that as oft as we do go aboute by the helpe of Gods ≈øpirite, to do that is good, the euil ≈øpirit Sathan layeth hard wayte to turne the good vnto euill, & goeth about to mixe the dete≈øtable darnell of de≈øperation with the godly ≈øorrow of a pure penitent heart. You be not ignoraunt of hys malicious ≈øubtelty, and how that continually he a≈ø≈øaulteth that good which the grace of god planteth. I ≈øee the battel betwixt you & him, but ye victory is yours, yea & that daily. For you haue layd hold vpoÃÑ the anker of ≈øaluacioÃÑ, which is hope in Chri≈øt, the which will not ≈øuffer you to be made a≈øhamed. Be not di≈øcoÃÑforted yt you haue this coÃÑflict, but be glad that god hath geueÃÑ you ye ≈øame to try your faith, & that you might appeare daily worthy of the kingdome of God, for ye which you ≈øtriue. God beholdeth your ≈øtriuing
fayth agayn≈øt Sathan, & is plea≈øed with your mightye re≈øi≈øtaunce. The ≈øpirite which is in you is myghtyer theÃÑ al the aduer≈øaries power. Tempt he may, & lying awayte at your heeles, geue you a fal vnwares: but ouercome he ≈øhall not, yea he can not, for you are ≈øealed vp alreadye with a liuely fayth to be the child of God for euer, and whom God hath once ≈øealed for his own, him he neuer vtterly for≈øaketh. The iu≈øt falleth ≈øeueÃÑ times, but he ri≈øeth agayn. It is mans frailtie to fal, but it is the propertie of the deuils childe to lie ≈øtil. This ≈øtrife again≈øt ≈øinne is a ≈øufficieÃÑt te≈øtimony that you are the childe of god, for if you were not you ≈øhould fele no ≈øuch malice as he now troubleth you withal. Luke. 11 When thys ≈øtrong Goliah hath the hold, al things be in peace which he po≈ø≈øe≈øeth, and bicau≈øe he hath you not, he wil not ≈øuffer you vna≈ø≈øaulted. But ≈øtand fa≈øt, and hold out the buckler of faith, and with the ≈øweard of gods promi≈øes ≈ømite him on the ≈øcalpe that he may receaue a deadly wouÃÑd & neuer be able to ≈øtand again≈øt you any more. Iames. 4. S. Iames telleth you that he is but a coward, ≈øaying: re≈øi≈øt the deuil and he wil flye away. It is the wil of god that he ≈øhould thus long tempt you and not go away as yet, or els he had done with you long ere this. He knoweth alreadye that he ≈øhall receaue the foyle at your hands, and encrea≈øe the crowne of your glory, for he that ouercoÃÑmeth ≈øhall be trowned. Therfore glory in your temptations ≈øince they ≈øhal turne to your felicitie. Be not afrayd of your continual a≈ø≈øaultes, Ezechi. 33. which be occa≈øions of your daily victory. The word of god abideth for euer: in what houre ≈øoeuer a ≈øinner repenteth him of his ≈øinnes they be forgeueÃÑ. Who caÃÑ lay anything to ye charge of gods elect? Do you not perceaue the manife≈øt tokens of your electioÃÑ? Fir≈øt your vocation to the go≈øpel, & after your vocation ye manife≈øt giftes of the ≈øpirit of god geueÃÑ vnto you aboue many other of your condition, with godlines which beleueth and yeldeth to the authority of the ≈øcriptures, & is zelous for the ≈øame? Seing you are gods own dearling, who can hurt you? Be not of a deiect mind for the≈øe temptations, neyther make your vnfayned frendes to be more ≈øorrowful for you then nede doth require. Since God hath willed you at your Bapti≈øme in Chri≈øt to be Carles, why doe you make your ≈øelfe carefull? Ca≈øte all your care on him: ≈øet the Lord before your eyes alwayes,
for he is on your right ≈øide that you ≈øhal not be moued. Behold the goodnes of god toward me. I am careles, being fa≈øt clo≈øed in a paire of ≈øtockes, which pinch me for very ≈øtraitnes, & wil you be careful? I wil not haue ye vn≈øemely addition to your name. Be as your name pretendeth, for doubtles you haue none other cau≈øe but ≈øo to be. Pray I be≈øech you yt I may be ≈øtil careles in my carefull e≈øtate, as you haue cau≈øe to be careles in your ea≈øier coÃÑditioÃÑ. Be thankful & put away al care, & theÃÑ I ≈øhal be ioyful in my ≈øtrayt pre≈øeÃÑt care. CoÃÑmend me to al our brethreÃÑ, & de≈øire them to pray for me that I may ouercome my temptations, for the deuil rageth again≈øt me. I am put in the ≈øtockes in a place alone bicau≈øe I would not an≈øwere to ≈øuch articles, as they woulde charge me with al in a corner at the bi≈øhops appoyntment, & bycau≈øe I did not come to ma≈ø≈øe when the bi≈øhop ≈øent for me. I wil lie al the dayes of my lyfe in the ≈øtockes (by gods grace) rather then I wil con≈øent to the wicked generation. Pray ‚Ä¢ e god & be ioyful that it hath plea≈øed him to make vs worthy to ≈øuffer ≈øomewhat for his names ≈øake. The deuill mu≈øt rage for .x. dayes. ComeÃÑd me to mai≈øter Fokes & thank hym for his law bokes, but law neither equity wil take any place among the≈øe bloud thir≈øty. I would for your ≈øake their vniu≈øt dealing were noted vnto the Parliamente hou≈øe, if it myght auaile. God ≈øhorten the≈øe euil dayes. I haue an≈øwered ye bi≈øhop metely playne alredy, & I ≈øayd to him if he wil cal me in open iudgement, I will an≈øwer hym as playnlye as he wil require: otherwi≈øe I haue refu≈øed bicau≈øe I feare they wil condemne me in hugger mugger. The peace of god be with you my deare brother. I caÃÑ write no more for lacke of lyght, & that I haue written I can not read my ≈øelf, & god knoweth it is written farre vnea≈øely: I pray god you maye pytke out ≈øome vnder≈øtanding of my minde towards you. Written in a Colehou≈øe of darkenes out of a paire of paynful ≈øtockes by thine owne in Chri≈øt.

div.head: A letter of Iohn Careles writen to Maister Philpot, which we thought be≈øt here to place a part from hys other letters hereafter followyng, bicau≈øe it is an an≈øwere to the former letter.

q.p: A faythfull frende is a ≈øtrong defence, who ≈øo findeth ≈øuche a one, findeth a trea≈øure.
A faythfull frend hath no peere, the weight of golde and ≈øiluer is not to be compared to the goodnes of hys fayth.
A faythfull frend is a medicine of lyfe, and they that feare the Lorde ≈øhall finde him. Eccle≈øia≈øt. 6.

div.p: THe Father of mercye and God of all con≈øolation, comforte you with hys eternall ≈øpirite (my mo≈øte deare and faythfull louyng frend, good Mai≈øter Philpot) as you haue comforted me by the mighty operatioÃÑ of the ≈øame, the euerla≈øting God be pray≈øed therefore for euer, Amen.

Ah my deare hart, and mo≈øt louing brother, if I ≈øhoulde do nothyng elles day and nyght ≈øo long as the daies of heauen doe endure, but knele on my knees and reade p≈øalmes, I can neuer be able to render vnto God condigne thankes for hys great mercye, fatherly kindnes, & mo≈øt louing compa≈ø≈øion extended vnto me mo≈øte vile, ≈øinnefull, wicked and vnworthy wretch. Oh that the lord would open my mouth and geue me a thankefull hart, that from the bottome of the ≈øame might flowe his continual pray≈øe. Oh that my ≈øinneful fle≈øh (which is the cau≈øe of my ≈øorow) were cleane ≈øeparated from me, that I might ≈øing p≈øalmes of thanke≈øgeuing vnto the Lords name for euer: that with good Samuells mother I might continually record thys noble ver≈øe following, the which by good experience I haue found mo≈øte true, pray≈øed be my good god therfore.1 Reg 2 The Lord (≈øayth the good womaÃÑ) killeth and maketh aliue: he bringeth downe to hel and fetcheth vp agayne. Pray≈øed be that Lord for euer, yea, & pray≈øed be hys name, for that he hath geuen me true experience and liuely feling of the ≈øame. Ble≈ø≈øed be the lord god, who≈øe mercy endureth for euer, whiche hath not dealt with me according to my deepe de≈øertes, nor de≈øtroyed me in hys dy≈øplea≈øure, when I had iu≈øtly de≈øerued it. Oh what rewarde ≈øhal I geue agayne vnto the Lorde, for all the great benefites that he hath done for my ≈øoule? I will gladlye receyue
the cup of ≈øaluation at his hande, and will wor≈øhippe his name with prayer and with pray≈øe.

Ah my deare hart, yea mo≈øt deare vnto me in the lord, thynke not this ≈øodaine chaunge in me to be ≈øome fickle phaÃÑ ta≈øy of my foli≈øh head (as in dede ≈øome other would ≈øurelye ≈øu≈øpect it to be) for doutles it is the meruelous doynge of the Lord, mo≈øt mercifull vnto me hys vnworthye creature. God for his great mercy ≈øake geue me grace to be more than full vnto him then I heretofore haue ben, and kepe me that I neuer fall forth of hys fauour agayne. And now my deare brother & mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed me≈ø≈øenger of ye lord, who≈øe beautifull feete haue brought much glad tydings vnto my ≈øoule, what ≈øhall I do or ≈øay vnto you in the lea≈øte parte, to recompence your fatherly affection and godly care that you continually kepe for me. Oh that god would geue me the ≈øpirite of feruent prayer that I might yet that waye ≈øupplye ≈øome little part of my duty toward you. Ah my true louyng frend, how ≈øone did you lay a≈øide all other bu≈øines to make a ≈øwete plai≈øter for my wounded con≈øcience, yea and that out of a painfull payre of ≈øtockes, which place mu≈øt nedes be vnea≈øye to wryte in. But god hath brought you into a ≈øtrait place, that you might ≈øet my ≈øoule at libertye. Out of your pynchyng & payneful ≈øeat you haue plentifully powred vpon me your precious narde, the ≈øwete ≈øauour wherof hath greatly refre≈øhed my tired ≈øoule. The lord likewy≈øe refre≈øh you both bodye and ≈øoule by powring the oyle of his gratious Spirite into yours ≈øwete hart. Ah good Ieremy, Ieremy. 20 hath Pha≈øure put thee in the ≈øtockes? Why now thou ha≈øt the ryghte rewarde of a prophet. Thy glory neuer began to appeare vntil now. I dout not but ≈øhortly in ≈øtede of Ahikam the ≈øonne of Saphan, Ieremy. 26 Ie≈øus the ≈øonne of the liuyng god will come and deliuer thee forth of the hands of all thine enemies, & wil al≈øo make good again≈øt theÃÑ & the Antichri≈øtian Sinagoge, al the wordes that thou ha≈øt ≈øpoken in hys name.Ieremy. 1. The lord hath made thee this day a ≈øtrong defeÃÑded Tower, an iron pyller and a bra≈øen wall again≈øt the whole rable of Antichri≈øt, and though they fyghte again≈øt thee neuer ≈øo fiercely, Ieremy. 15. yet ≈øhall they not ouercome thee, for the Lord him≈øelfe is with thee to helpe and delyuer thee, and he will ridde thee out of the handes of the wycked, & wyll delyuer thee out of the hands
of ye tyraÃÑnes. And in that you are not bu≈øy in ca≈øting pearles before ≈øwine, Math. 7 nor in geuing holy things vnto dogs, you are much to be commended in my ≈øimple iudgement. And ≈øure I am that your circum≈øpect and mode≈øt behauiour hytherto hath bene as much to gods glory & confu≈øion of your enemies, as any mans doinges that are gone before you. Wherfore myne adui≈øe & mo≈øt earne≈øt de≈øyre is, wyth all other of your louyng frendes, that you ≈øtyll keepe that order with tho≈øe bloodthur≈øty by≈øhoppes that you haue begonne. For though in conclu≈øion they wyll ≈øurely haue your blood: yet ≈øhall they come by it wyth ≈øhame enough, and to their perpetuall infamy whiles the world doth indure. They would in dede condemne you in hugger mugger to darken gods glory if it might be: but Sathans thoughtes are not vnknowen to you and the depthe of hys ≈øubtiliy is by you wel fore≈øeene. Therfore let them do what≈øoeuer god ≈øhall ≈øuffer them to do, for I know al thynges ≈øhall turne to your be≈øt. Though you lye in the darke, ≈øtorryed wyth the bi≈øhoppes blacke cole du≈øt: yet ≈øhall you ≈øhortly be re≈øtored to the heauenly light, p≈øal. 68 and made as whyte as ≈ønowe in Salmon, and as the wyngs of a Doue that is couered wyth ≈øiluer wings and her fethers lyke golde. You knowe the ve≈ø≈øell, before it is made bright, is ≈øoyled wyth oyle and other thinges that it may ≈øcoure the better. Oh happy be you that you be nowe in the ≈øcouryng hou≈øe, for ≈øhortly you ≈øhall be ≈øet vpon the cele≈øtial ≈øhelfe as bryght as aungels.

Therefore my deare harte, I wyll nowe accordyng to your louyng reque≈øte, ca≈øte awaye all care, and reioy≈øe wyth you and pray≈øe GOD for you and praye for you day and nighte. Yea I will nowe with Gods grace, ≈øynge p≈øalmes of pray≈øe and thankesgeuyng with you, for nowe my ≈øoule is turned into her olde re≈øt agayne, and hath taken a ≈øwete nappe in Chri≈øtes lappe. I haue ca≈øt my care vpon the Lorde which careth for me, and wyll be Careles accordyng to my name in that re≈øpecte whiche you woulde haue me. I wyll leaue out my vn≈øemely addition as long as I lyue, for it can take no place where true faythe and hope is re≈øidente. So ≈øoone as I had red your mo≈øt godly and comfortable letter, my ≈øorrowes vani≈øhed away as ≈ømoke in the
wynde, my ≈øpirite reuiued, and comfort came agayne wherby I am ≈øure the ≈øpirite of god was author of it. Oh good mai≈øter Philpot, which art a pryncipall potte in dede, ≈øylled with mo≈øt precious lycour, as it apeareth by the prenceous powryng forthe of the fame: oh pot mo≈øt happy, of the high potter ordayned to honour, whiche doe≈øt contayne ≈øuch heauenlye trea≈øure in thy earthen ve≈ø≈øell: oh potte chry≈øe happy, in whom Chri≈øt hath wrought a great myracle, altering thy nature and turnyng water into wyne and that of the be≈øt, whereout the mai≈øter of the fea≈øt hath fylled my cup ≈øo full, that I am become dronken in ioy of the ≈øpirite through the ≈øame: when Martyrdome ≈øhall breake thee (O ve≈ø≈øell of honour) I knowe the fragraunce ≈øauoure of thy precious narde wyll much reioyce the heauy hartes of Chri≈øtes true members, although the Inda≈ø≈øes wyll grudge & murmure at the ≈øame, yea and bur≈øt out into wordes of ≈ølaunder, ≈øaping: it is but lo≈øt and wa≈øte. Be not offended deare harte, at my Metaphoricall ≈øpeache, for I am di≈øpo≈øed to bee merye and with Dauid to daunce before the Arke of the Lord, and though you play vpoÃÑ a payre of Organes not very comely or ea≈øy to the fle≈øh, yet the ≈øwete ≈øound yt came from the ≈øame cau≈øeth me thus to do. O that I were with you in body, as pre≈øently I am in ≈øpirite, that I might ≈øyng all care awaye in Chri≈øte, for now the tyme of comforte is come. I hope to be wyth you ≈øhortlye, if all thinges happen arighte, for my olde frendes of Couentrye haue put the Coun≈øell in remembraunce of me not ≈øixe dais ago, ≈øaying that I am more worthy to be burnt then any yt was burned yet. Gods ble≈ø≈øyng on their hartes for their good reporte, GOD make me worthye of that dignitie and ha≈øten the tyme that I might ≈øet forthe hys glorye. Praye for me deare harte I be≈øe ‚Ä¢ h you and will all your company to doe the ≈øame, and I wil pray GOD for you all ≈øo longe as I liue. And now farewell in Chri≈øte thou ble≈ø≈øed of gods owne mouthe, I wil for a time take my leaue, but not my la≈øt farewell. Ble≈ø≈øed be the tyme that euer I came into the kynges Benche to bee ioined in loue and fellow≈øhip with ≈øuch deare childreÃÑ of the lord. My good brother Bradford ≈øhal not be deade whyles you be alyue, for verelye the ≈øpirite of hym dothe te≈øte on you in
mo≈øt ample wy≈øe. Your letters of comforte vnto me in eche poynt do agree, as though the one were a copy of the other. He hath planted in me, and you doe water, the Lorde geue good increa≈øe. My deare brethreÃÑ and fellow pri≈øoners here, haue them humbly and hartely commended vnto you and your company, mournyng for your mi≈øerye, but yet reioy≈øing for your plenteous con≈øolation and comfort in Chri≈øt. We are all cherefull and mery vnder our cro≈ø≈øe, and do lack no nece≈ø≈øaries, prai≈øed be god for his prouidence, and great mercyes towardes vs for euermore. Amen.

div.head: ¬∂To certayne godly women for≈øakyng theyr owne countrey and goyng beyond the ≈øeas in the tyme of per≈øecution, for the te≈øtimony of the Go≈øpell.
div.p: THe ≈øpirite of truth reueled vnto you my derely beloued, by the go≈øpell of our ≈øauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, be continually abidyng with you, and augmented into a perfecte buildynge of you into the lyuely temple of God, throughe the mighty operation of his power, Amen.

Let your faythe ≈øhine in a ≈øtraunge countrey, as it hathe done in your owne, that your father which is in heauen may be glorified by you to the end, This farewell I ≈øend you, not as a thyng nedefull, which know alredy what your duety is, and be de≈øirous to performe the ≈øame, but as one that woulde haue you vnder≈øtand that he is myndefull of your godly conuer≈øation, whereof he hathe had good experience, and therefore wryteth this to bee as a perpetuall memoriall betwixt you and hym vntyll our metyng together before god, where we ≈øhall ioy that we haue here louyngly put one another in memory of our duetye to performe it. And yf you ≈øee any vntowardnes in you (as the fle≈øhe is continuallye repugnaunte to the wyll of GOD) a≈øke wyth faythfull prayer that the good ≈øpiryte of GOD maye leade youre ≈øynnefull fle≈øhe whether it woulde not, Iohn. 21 for yf we wyll dwell in the fle≈øh and follow the coun≈øel thereof, we ≈øhal neuer do the wyll of God, neyther worke that tendeth to our ≈øaluation. This was for the fyr≈øt fruits of his Archdeaconry, wherof al the tyme of his impri≈øonment he had no commodity, and yet his ≈øureties were compelled to pay the ≈øame.CoÃÑmend me to all theÃÑ that loue me in the Lord vnfaynedly. div.p:
MY dearely beloued brethren in our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt, althoughe the tyme I haue to lyue is very little (for hourely I looke when I ≈øhoulde be had hence to bee conueyed into Lanke≈øhyre there to bee burned, and to render my lyfe by the prouidence of God, where I fyr≈øt receyued it by the ≈øame prouidence) and althoughe the charge is great to kepe me from all thyngs wherby I might ≈øygnify any thyng to the world of my ≈øtate: yet hauyng as now I haue pen & ynke, through gods workyng, manger the head of Sathan and his ≈øouldiours, I thought good to write a ≈øhort coÃÑfe≈ø≈øion of my faith, and therto ioyne a little exhortation vnto you all, to lyue

In te≈øtimony of which fayth, I render and geue my life, beyng condemned as wel for not acknowledging the Antichri≈øt of Rome to be chri≈øts Vicar general and ≈øupreme head of hys catholike & vniuer≈øall church here and els where vpon earthe: as for denying the horrible and idolatrous doctrine of tran≈øub≈øtantiation and chri≈øtes real, corporall & carnal pre≈øence in his ≈øupper, vnder the formes and accidentes of bread and wyne. To beleue Chri≈øt our ≈øauiout to bee the heade of hys churche, and kinges in their realmes to be the ≈øupreme powers, to whome euerye ≈øoule oweth obedience, and to beleue that in the ≈øupper of Chri≈øte (which the ≈øacrament of the aultar as the papi≈øtes cal it and v≈øe it, dothe vtterlye ouerthrowe) is a true and a very pre≈øence of whole Chri≈øte god and man to the faythe of the receauer (but not to the ≈øtander by and loker vpon) as it is a true and a very pre≈øence of breade and wyne to the ≈øen≈øes of men: to beleue this (I ≈øay) wyl not ≈øerue, and therfore as an heretyke I am condemned & ≈øhall be burned, wherof I a≈øke god hartely mercy that I do no more reioyce then I do, hauing ≈øo great cau≈øe as to be an in≈øtrument wherein it maye plea≈øe my deare lorde and Sauiour to ≈øuffer. For albeit my manyfolde ≈øynnes, euen ≈øythen I came into pri≈øon, haue de≈øerued at the handes of God, not onelye this temporall but al≈øo eternall fyer in hell, much more then my former ≈øynful life, which the lord pardoÃÑ for his chri≈øts ≈øake, as I know he of his mercy hath done & neuer wil lay my iniquities to my
charge to condemnatioÃÑ, ≈øo great is his goodnes, prai≈øed therfore be his holy name: although (I ≈øay) my manyfold & greuous late ≈øinnes haue de≈øerued mo≈øt iu≈øtly all the tyranny yt man or deuil can do vnto me (and therfore I coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe that the lord is iu≈øt & that his iudgements be true & de≈øerued on my behalfe) yet the bi≈øhops and prelates do not per≈øecute them in me but Chri≈øt him≈øelf, his word, his truth and religion. And therfore I haue great cau≈øe yea mo≈øt great cau≈øe, to reioyce that euer I was borne & hetherto kept of the lord, that by my death, which is de≈øerued for my ≈øinnes, it plea≈øeth the heaueÃÑly father to glorify his name, to te≈øtify his truth, to coÃÑ firm his verity, to oppugne his aduer≈øaries. Oh good god & merciful father, forgeue me my great vnthaÃÑkfulnes, e≈øpecially herein. And you my derely beloued for ye lord Ie≈øu chri≈øts ≈øake, I humbly & hartely in his bowels & blood, do now for my la≈øt Yale & farewel in this pre≈øeÃÑt life, be≈øech you & euery of you, yt you wil coÃÑ≈øider this worke of the lord accordingly. Fir≈øt by me to be admoni≈øhed to beware of hypocri≈øie & carnal ≈øecurity. Profe≈ø≈øe not ye go≈øpel wt tong & lips only, but in hart & veritye: frame and fa≈øhioÃÑ your liues accordingly. Be ware gods name be not euil ≈øpokeÃÑ of, & the go≈øpel le≈ø≈øe regarded by your coÃÑuer≈øatioÃÑ. God forgeue me yt I haue not ≈øo hartely profe≈ø≈øed it as I ≈øhould haue done, but haue ≈øought much my ≈øelf therin, The go≈øpel is a new doctrine to the old man: it is new wine, & therfore cannot be put in old bottels, without greater hurt then good to the botlels. If we will talk wt the lord, we mu≈øt put of our ≈øhooes & carnal affectioÃÑs: if we wil heare ye voyce of the lord, we mu≈øt wa≈øh our garmeÃÑts & be holy: if we wil be chri≈øtes di≈øciples, we mu≈øt deny our ≈øelues, take vp our cro≈ø≈øe & folow chri≈øt. We caÃÑnot ≈øerue ij. ma≈øters: if we ≈øeke chri≈øtes kingdoÃÑ, we mu≈øt al≈øo ≈øeke for the righteou≈ønes therof. To the petition of, let thy kingdome come, we mu≈øte ioyne, thy wyll be done, done, done on earthe as it is in heauen. If we wil not be doers of ye word, but hearers of it, we ≈øore deceiue our ≈øelues. Yf we heare ye go≈øpel & loue it not, we declare our ≈øelues to be but fooles & builders vpoÃÑ ye ≈øand. The lordes ≈øpirit hateth faining: di≈øceitfulnes ye lord abhorteth. If we come to him, we mu≈øte beware we come not wt a double hart, for theÃÑ it may chaÃÑce yt god wil an≈øwer vs according to ye blocke which is in our harte, & ≈øo we ≈øhal deceiue our ≈øelues and others. To faithe ≈øee that we couple
a good con≈øcience, le≈øt we make a ≈øhipwracke. To the Lorde we mu≈øt come with feare and reuerence. If we will be go≈øpellers we mu≈øt be Chri≈øtes, if we be Chri≈øtes we mu≈øt crucify our fle≈øhe, wyth the lu≈øt and concupi≈øcences thereof. If we wyl be vnder grace, ≈øynne mu≈øt not beare rule in vs. We may not come to the lord and draw nigh to hym wyth our lippes, and leaue our hartes el≈øewhere, le≈øt the lords wrath waxe whotte, and he take from vs the good remaynyng: in no ca≈øe can the kyngdome of Chri≈øte approche to them that repente not.

Therfore my dearely beloued, let vs repente & be hartely ≈øory that we haue ≈øo carnally, ≈øo hypocritically, ≈øo couetou≈øly, ≈øo vayne gloriou≈øly profe≈ø≈øed the go≈øpel. For al the≈øe I confe≈ø≈øe of my ≈øelfe to the glorye of God and myne owne confu≈øion here, that he may couer myne offences in the day of iudgement. Let the anger and plagues of god mo≈øt iu≈øtly fallen vpoÃÑ vs, be applyed to euery one of our de≈øertes, that from the bottome of our harts, euery of vs may ≈øay: it is I Lord that haue ≈øinned again≈øt thee, it is mine hypocri≈øy, my vayn glory, my couetou≈ønes, vncleanes, carnality, ≈øecurity, idlenes, vnthankefulnes, ≈øelf loue and ≈øuch lyke, which haue de≈øerued the takyng away of our good kynge, of thy worde and true religion, of thy good mini≈øters by exile, pri≈øonmeÃÑt and death: it is my wickednes, that cau≈øeth ≈øucce≈ø≈øe and encrea≈øe of auctoritye and peace to thine enemyes. Oh be mercifull, be mercifull vnto vs. Turne to vs agayne, (oh lord of ho≈øtes) and turne vs vnto thee. Correcte vs, but not in thy furye, lea≈øte we bee con≈øumed. In thy wrathfull di≈øplea≈øure reproue vs not, but in the myddes of thine anger remember thy mercye: for if thou wylte marke what is done amy≈ø≈øe, who ≈øhall be able to abyde it? But with thee is mercifulnes, that thou mighte≈øt be wor≈øhypped: oh then be mercyfull vnto vs that we myghte truelye wor≈øhyppe thee. Helpe vs, for the glorye of thy name bee mercyfull vnto our ≈øinnes for they are greate: oh heale vs and helpe vs for thyne honoure, let not the wycked people ≈øay, where is theyr god. &c. On this ≈øorte my right dearely beloued, let vs hartely bewayle our ≈øynnes, repent vs of our former euyll lyfe, hartely and earne≈øtly purpo≈øe to amende our lyues in all thynges, continually watch in praier, diligently and reuerently
attend, heare, and read the holy ≈øcriptures, labour after our vocation to amend our brethren. Let vs reproue the workes of darkenes: let vs flye from all Idolatrye: let vs abhorre the Antichri≈øtian & romi≈øh rotten ≈øeruice, dete≈øt the popy≈øhe ma≈ø≈øe, for≈øake their Romi≈øh God, prepare oure ≈øelues to the cro≈ø≈øe, be obediente to all that be in authoritye in all thynges that be not agayn≈øt God and his woorde: for then aun≈øwere with the Apo≈øtles, it is more meete to obeye God then man. Howbeit, neuer for any thing re≈øi≈øte, or ry≈øe agayn≈øt the Magi≈øtrates: auenge not your ≈øelues, but committe your cau≈øe to the lord to whom vengeaunce pertayneth, and he in his time wil reward it. If ye feele in your ≈øelues an hope & tru≈øt in god, yt he will neuer tempte you aboue that he will make you able to beare, be a≈ø≈øured ye lorde wil be true to you, and ye ≈øhal bee able to beare al bruntes. But if ye want this hope, fly & get you hence, rather then by your tarying, gods name ≈øhould be di≈øhonoured. In ≈øuÃÑme, ca≈øt your care on the Lord, knowing for mo≈øt certayne that he is careful for you: with him are all yt heares of your head numbred, ≈øo yt not one of theÃÑ ≈øhall peri≈øh without his good plea≈øure & wil, much more then nothing ≈øhal happen to your bodies which ≈øhal not be profitable, how ≈øoeuer for a tyme it ≈øeme otherwi≈øe to your ≈øen≈øes. Hang on the prouidence of god, not only wheÃÑ you haue meanes to helpe you, but al≈øo wheÃÑ you haue no meanes, yea wheÃÑ al meanes be again≈øte you. Geue hym thys honour, which of all other thynges he mo≈øt chieflye requireth at your handes, namely beleue yt ye are his childreÃÑ through Chri≈øt: that he is your father & God through him: that he loueth you, pardoneth you al your offences: that he is with you in trouble, & wil be with you for euer. When ye fal he wil put vnder his hand, ye ≈øhall not lie ≈øtil. Before ye cal vppon him he heareth you: out of euill he wil finally bring you, and deliuer you to his eternal kingdome. Doubte not my dearely beloued hereof, doubte not I ≈øay: this wil god your father doe for you in re≈øpecte, not of your ≈øelues, but in re≈øpect of Chri≈øt your captaine, your pa≈øtour, your keper, out of who≈øe handes none ≈øhal be able to catch you. In him be quiet, and often con≈øider your dignity: namely how that ye bee gods children, the ≈øaintes of God, citizens of heauen, temples of the holy gho≈øt, the thrones of
God, members of Chri≈øt, and Lords ouer all.

Therfore be a≈øhamed to thinke, ≈øpeake, or doe any thyng that ≈øhould be vn≈øemely for Gods children, Gods ≈øaintes, Chri≈øtes member &c. Marueil not though the deuil and the world hate you: though ye be per≈øecuted here, for ye ≈øeruaunt is not aboue his mai≈øter. Couet not earthly riches, feare not the power of man, loue not this world nor things that be in this worlde: but long for the Lorde Ie≈øus his comming, at which time your bodies ≈øhall be made like vnto his glorious body. WheÃÑ he appeareth ye ≈øhal be like vnto him: when your life thus ≈øhal be reuealed, then ≈øhal ye appeare wt hym in glory: in the meane ≈øea≈øon liue in hope hereof. Let ye lyfe you lead be in the fayth of the ≈øonne of god, for yt iu≈øte doth liue by fayth, which faith flyeth froÃÑ all euill & followeth the word of god as a lanterne to her feete, & a light to her ≈øteps: her eyes be aboue where Chri≈øt is: ≈øhee beholdeth not the thinges pre≈øent, but rather thinges to come: ≈øhe glorieth in afflictions, ≈øhe knoweth that the afflictions of this life are not to be compared to the glory which god wil reueale to vs and in vs. Of this glory god graunt vs here a liuely ta≈øt: theÃÑ ≈øhall we runne after the ≈øent it ≈øendeth forth. It will make vs valiant meÃÑ to take to vs the kingdome of god: whether the lord of mercy bring vs in his good time through Chri≈øt our lord, to whom with the father and the holy gho≈øt, three per≈øons and one God, be al honour and glory world without end, Amen.

My dearly beloued, I would gladly haue geuen here my body to haue beene burned for the confirmation of the true doctrine I haue taught here vnto you, but that my countrey mu≈øt haue: therefore I pray you take in good part this ≈øignification of my good wil towards euery of you.
