div.head: To al that loue the lord Ie≈øus, and his true doctrine being in rhe vniuer≈øity and towne of Cambridge, Iohn Bradforde, a mo≈øt vnworthy ≈øeruaunt of the lord, novve not onely pri≈øoned but al≈øo condemned for the ≈øame true doctrine, vvy≈øheth grace, peace, and mercye vvith encrea≈øe of all godlines, from god the father of al mercy, through the bloody pa≈ø≈øion of our alonely Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, by the liuely workyng of the holy ≈øpirite, for euer, Amen.
div.p:
ALthoughe I looke hourely when I ≈øhould bee hadde to the ≈øtake (my righte dearelye beloued in the Lorde) and althoughe the charge ouer me is greate and ≈øtraite: yet hauyng by the prouidence of GOD ≈øecretlye penne and inke, I coulde not but ≈øomething ≈øignifye vnto you my ≈øolicitude which I haue for you and euery of you in the Lord, though not as I would, yet as I maye. Ye haue often and openly heard the truth (e≈øpecially in this matter wherin I am coÃÑ demned) di≈øputed and preached, that it is nedeles to do any more, but only to put you in remembraunce of the ≈øame: but hetherto ye haue not heard it confirmed, & (as it were) ≈øealed vp, as now ye do, & ≈øhal do here by me, that is, by my death and burning. For Albeit I haue de≈øerued (through my vncleannes, hipocri≈øie, auarice, vayneglory, idlenes, vnthankfulnes, and carnalitye, whereof I accu≈øe my ≈øelf to my confu≈øion before the world, that before God through Chri≈øt I mighte, as my a≈ø≈øured hope is I ≈øhal, finde mercy) eternal death & hel fire, much more then this affliction & fire prepared for me: yet my dearelye beloued, it is not the≈øe or any of the≈øe thynges, wherefore the Prelates do per≈øecute me, but gods veretye and truthe: yea euen Chri≈øte hym ≈øelfe is the onely cau≈øe and thynge wherefore I nowe am condemned, and ≈øhall bee burned as an heretyque, becau≈øe I wyll
not graunt the Anttchri≈øt of Rome to be Chri≈øts Vicar generall & ≈øupreame head of his church here, and euery where vpon earth, by gods ordinance, & bicau≈øe I will not graunt ≈øuch corporall, real, and carnall pre≈øence of Chri≈øtes body & blood in the ≈øacrament, as doth tran≈øub≈øtantiate ye ≈øub≈øtance of bread & wine, and is receaued of the wicked, yea of dogs and mice. Al≈øo I am excommunicated, and couÃÑted as a dead member of Chri≈øtes church, as a rotten braunch, & therfore ≈øhal be ca≈øt into ye fire. Therfore ye ought hartely to reioyce with me, & to geue thankes for me, that god the eternall father hath vouched ≈øafe our mother to bring vp any childe, in whom it would plea≈øe him to magnifye his holy name as he doth & I hope for his mercy and truthes ≈øake, wil do in me & by me. Oh what ≈øuch benefite vpoÃÑ earth caÃÑ there be, as that that which de≈øerued death by rea≈øoÃÑ of my ≈øinnes, ≈øhould be diuerted to a demon≈øtration, a te≈øtification, and confirmation of gods verity and truth.

Thou my mother the Vniuer≈øitye, ha≈øte not only had the truth of gods woorde playnly manife≈øted vnto thee by reading, di≈øputing, & preaching publikely & priuately, but now (to make thee altogether excu≈øeles and as it wer almo≈øt to ≈øinne again≈øt the holy gho≈øt, if thou put to thy helping hand wt the Romy≈øhe route to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the verity & ≈øet out the coÃÑ trary) yu ha≈øt my life and blood as a ≈øeale to confyrme thee if thou wilt be confirmed, or els to confound thee & beare witnes agayn≈øt thee, if thou wilt take parte with the prelates and clergye, which now fil vp the mea≈øure of their fathers, which flew the prophets and Apo≈øtles, yt al righteous blood from Abell to Bradford ≈øhed vpoÃÑ the earth may be required at their hands. Of this therfore I thoughte good before my death, as time & liberty wold ≈øuffer me, for ye loue and duty I beare vnto thee, to admoni≈øhe thee good mother, and my ≈øi≈øter the towne, that ye woulde cal to minde from whence ye are fallen, and ≈øtudy to do the fir≈øt woorkes. Ye knowe (if you will) the≈øe matters of the Romy≈øh ≈øupremacye, and the Antichri≈øtian tran≈øub≈øtantiation, wherby Chri≈øtes Supper is ouerthrowen, his prie≈øthoode euacuate, hys ≈øacrifyce fru≈øtrate, the mini≈øtery of his worde vnplaced, repentaunce repelled, fayth fainted, godlines extingui≈øhed, the ma≈ø≈øe maintayned, Idolatrye ≈øupported, and all impietye cheary≈øhed:
you know (I ≈øay) if you will, that the≈øe opinions are not only be≈øides Gods word, but euen directly again≈øte it, and therfore to take part with them, is to take part again≈øt god, agayn≈øt whom you can not preuayle.

Therfore for the tender mercye of Chri≈øt, in his bowells and blood I be≈øech you to take Chri≈øtes collyrium and eye ≈øalue to annoynte your eyes, that ye maye ≈øee what ye doe and haue done in admittinge (as I heare ye haue admitted, yea alas authori≈øed, and by con≈øent confirmed) the romy≈øhe rotten ragges, whiche once ye vtterly expelled. Oh be not canis reuer≈øus ad vomitum, be not ≈øus lota reuer≈øa ad volutabruÃÑ coeni. Beware lea≈øt old SathaÃÑ enter in with ≈øeuen other ≈øpirites, and ≈øo the la≈øte ≈øhall bee wor≈øe then the fir≈øte. It had bene better ye had neuer knoweÃÑ the truth, then after knowledge to runne from it. Ah woe to this world & the thyngs therin which hath now ≈øo wrought with you. Oh that euer this dirt of the deuill ≈øhould daube vp the eye of the realme: for thou (O mother) art as it were the eye of the realme. If thou be light and geue ≈øhine, al the body ≈øhalfare the better: but if thou the lyght be darkenes, alas, how great will the darkenes be? What is man who≈øe breath is in hys no≈øe-threls, that yu ≈øhoulde≈øt thus be affrayd of hym? Oh what is honour & life here but plain bubbels? What is glory in thys world but ≈øhame? Why arte thou affrayde to carye Chri≈øtes cco≈ø≈øe? Wilt thou come into his kingdome and not drinke of his cup? Do≈øt thou not knowe Rome to be Babilon? Do≈øte thou not know that as the old Babilon had the children of Iuda in captiuitye, ≈øo hath this, true Iuda, that is the confe≈ø≈øours of Chri≈øt? Do≈øt thou not know that as de≈øtruction happened vnto it, ≈øo ≈øhall it do vnto this? And trowe≈øt thou that God wil not deliuer his people now, when the tyme is come, as he did then? Hath not God commaunded hys people to come out from her, and wilt thou geue en≈øample to the whole realme to runne into her? Ha≈øt thou forgotteÃÑ the woe that Chri≈øt threatneth to offence geuers? Wilt thou not remember that it were beter a myl≈øtone were hanged about thy necke, and thou throwen into the ≈øea, then yt thou ≈øhoulde≈øt offend the litle ones? And alas, how ha≈øt thou offended? Yea how do≈øt thou ≈øtil offend? Wilt thou con≈øider things according to the outward ≈øhew? Was not the Sinagoge more ≈øeemely & like to the true churche, then the ≈øimple flocke of
Chri≈øtes Di≈øciples? Hath not the whore of Babilon more co≈øtly aray and riche apparel externally to ≈øet forth her ≈øelf, then the homely hou≈øewife of Chri≈øt? Where is the beautye of the Kinges doughter the Church of Chri≈øt? Withoute or within? Doth not Dauid ≈øay within? Oh remember that as they are happy which are not offended at Chri≈øt, ≈øo are they happy which are not offended at his poore church. Can the pope & his prelates meane hone≈øtly which make ≈øo much of the wife, and ≈øo litle of the hu≈øband? The churche they magnifie, but Chri≈øt they contemne. If this church were an hone≈øt womaÃÑ (that is Chri≈øtes wife) except they woulde make much of her hu≈øband Chri≈øt and hys word, ≈øhe would not be made much of, of theÃÑ. WheÃÑ Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles wer vpon earth, who was more like to be the true church? They, or the prelates, bi≈øhops and Sinagoge? If a man ≈øhoulde haue followed cu≈øtome, vnity, antiquitie or the more parte, ≈øhould not Chri≈øt and his company haue bene ca≈øt out of the dores? Therfore badde Chri≈øt: ≈øearch ye ≈øcriptures. And good Mother, ≈øhal the ≈øeruauÃÑt be aboue his mai≈øter? ≈øhal we loke for other intertainemente at the handes of the worlde, then Chri≈øt and his deare Di≈øciples founde? Who was taken in Noes time for the church? Poore Noe and his family, or others? Who was taken for gods church in Sodome? Lot, or others? And doth not Chri≈øt ≈øay: as it went then ≈øo ≈øhall it go now towardes the comming of the ≈øonne of man? What meaneth Chri≈øt when he ≈øaith, iniquitie ≈øhal haue the vpper hand, doth he not tel that charitie ≈øhal waxe colde? And who ≈øeeth not a wonderfull great lacke of charitie in tho≈øe which would now be taken for Chri≈øtes church? All that feare god in this Realme truly, can tel more of this, then I can write.

Therfore dere Mother, receaue ≈øome admonitioÃÑ of one of thy poore children now going to be burned for the te≈øtimony of Ie≈øus. Come agayne to Gods truth: come out of Babilon: confe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt and his true doctrine: repent yt whiche is pa≈øt: make amendes by declaring thy repentaunce by the fruites. Remember the readinges and preachings of Gods Prophet and true preacher Martyne Bucer. Call to mynde the threatninges of God, nowe ≈øome thynge ≈øeene by thy children Leauer, and others. Let the exile of Leauer, Pilkinton, Gryndall, Haddon, Horne, Scorye, Pouet &c,
≈øome thing awake thee. Let the impri≈øonmente of thy deare ≈øonnes, Cranmer, Ridley, and Latimer moue thee. Con≈øider the Martyrdome of thy Chickens, Rogers, Saunders, Taylour. And nowe ca≈øt not awaye the poore admonition of me going to be burned al≈øo, & to receaue the like crowne of glorye with my fellowes. Take to harte Gods callyng by vs. Be not as Pharao was, for then wil it happen vnto thee as it dyd vnto hym. What is that? Hardene≈ø≈øe of hart. And what then? De≈øtruction eternally both of bodye and ≈øoule. Ah therefore good Mother awake, awake, repente, repent, bu≈øtell thy ≈øelf and make ha≈øte to turne to the Lord, for elles it ≈øhal be more ea≈øye for Sodome and Gomorre in the day of iudgement, then for thee. Oh harden not your harts: Oh ≈øtop not your eares to day in hearing gods voice, though it be by me a mo≈øt vnworthye me≈ø≈øenger. Oh feare the Lord, for his anger is begonne to kindle. Euen now the are is layde to the roote of the tree. Ye know I prophecyed truely to you before the ≈øwet came, what woulde come if ye repented not you carnall go≈øpelling, and now I tel you before I depart hence, that the eares of meÃÑ wil tingle to heare of the vengeaunce of God that will fal vppon you all, both towne and vniuer≈øitie, if ye repente not, if ye leaue not your Idolatry, if ye tourne not ≈øpedely to the Lord, if ye ≈øtil be a≈øhamed of Chri≈øtes truth whiche ye knowe. Oh Perne repent, Oh Thom≈øon repente, Oh ye Doctors, Bachelors and Mai≈øters repent, Oh Maior Aldermen, & towne dwellers repente, repente, repente that ye maye e≈øcape the nere vengeaunce of the Lord. Rent your harts, and come apace calling on the Lord. Let vs al ≈øay, Peccauimus, we haue ≈øynned, we haue done wickedlye, we haue not harkened to thy voyce O Lord. Deale not with vs after our de≈øerts, but be merciful to our iniquities, for they are great. Oh pardon vs our offences: In thyne anger remember thy mercy. Turne vs vnto thee O Lorde God of ho≈øtes, for the glorye of thy names ≈øake: ≈øpare vs, and be mercifull vnto vs. Let not the wicked people ≈øay: wher is now their god? Oh for thine own ≈øake, for thy names ≈øake deale mercifully wt vs. Turne thy ≈øelf vnto vs, and vs vnto thee, and we ≈øhall pray≈øe thy name for euer.

If in thys ≈øort (my dearly beloued) in hart and mouth we come vnto oure father, and pro≈øtrate oure ≈øelues before
the throne of his grace, then ≈øurely ≈øurely we ≈øhal find mercye: then ≈øhal the Lord loke merely vpon vs for his mercye ≈øake in Chri≈øt: then ≈øhal we heare him ≈øpeake peace vnto his people, for he is gracious and mercifull, of greate pitye and compa≈ø≈øion: he caÃÑ not be chiding for euer, his anger can not la≈øt long to the penitent. Though we wepe in the morning, yet at night we ≈øhal haue our ≈øorow to cea≈øe, for he is exorable, & hath no plea≈øure in ye death of a ≈øinner: he rather wold our conuer≈øion and turning. Oh turne you nowe and conuert, yet once againe I humbly be≈øech you, & then the kingdome of heauen ≈øhall draw nygh. The eye hath not ≈øene, the eare hath not heard, nor the harte of maÃÑ is able to conceaue the ioyes prepared for vs if we repente, amende oure liues, and hartely turne to the Lord. But if ye repente not, but be as ye were, and goe on forwardes with the wicked, following the fa≈øhion of the world, the Lord will lead you on with wicked doers, ye ≈øhall pery≈øhe in your wickednes, youre blood will be vppon your owne heades, your part ≈øhall be with hipocrites, where ≈øhall be wepyng and gna≈øhyng of teeth, ye ≈øhall be ca≈øte from the face of the Lorde for euer and euer, eternall ≈øhame, ≈øorrow, woe, and mi≈øery ≈øhall be both in body and ≈øoule to you worlde without end. Oh therfore, ryght deare to me in the Lord, turne you, turne you, repent you, repent you, amend, amend your liues, departe from euill, do good, follow peace and pur≈øue it. Come out froÃÑ Babilon, ca≈øte of the woorkes of darkenes, put on Chri≈øt, confe≈ø≈øe hys truth, be not a≈øhamed of hys Go≈øpel, prepare your ≈øelues to the cro≈ø≈øe, drinke of Gods cuppe before it come to the dregges, and then ≈øhall I with you and for you, reioyce in the daye of iudgemente, whiche is at hand, and therfore prepare your ≈øelues therto I hartely be≈øech you. And thus I take my Vale in aeternum with you in thys pre≈øente lyfe, myne owne deare hartes in the Lorde. The Lorde of mercy bee with vs all, and geue vs a ioyfull, and ≈øure meetyng in his kingdome. Amen, Amen. Out of pri≈øon the .11. of February. Anno. 1555.

div.head: ¬∂To all tho≈øe that profe≈ø≈øe the name and true religion of our Sauioure Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, in Lanke≈øhyre and Che≈øshire, and ≈øpecially abyding in Manche≈øter and theraboutes, Iohn Bradford a mo≈øte vnworthy ≈øeruant of the Lord, now not only in bondes but al≈øo coÃÑdemned for the ≈øame true religion, wi≈øheth mercye and grace, peace and encrea≈øe of all godlines, froÃÑ god the father of all pietie, throughe the de≈øertes of our Lorde Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, by the workyng of the mo≈øt mighty and liuely ≈øpirite the comforter for euer. Amen.
div.p:
I Heare it reported credibly (my derely beloued in ye lord) that my heaueÃÑly father hath thought it good to prouyde that,The enemies had apointed to burne hym at MaÃÑche≈øter, but the lord altered their purpo≈øe. as I haue preached his true go≈øpel and doctrine amonges you by worde, ≈øo I ≈øhal te≈øtify and confyrme the ≈øame by deede: that is, I ≈øhall with you leaue my life, which by his prouidence I fir≈øte receaued there (for in Manche≈øter was I borne) for a ≈øeale to the doctrine I haue taught with you & emonges you: ≈øo that if from henceforth you wauer in the ≈øame you haue none excu≈øe at all. I know the enemies of Chri≈øt, which exerci≈øe this crueltye vpon me (I ≈øpeake it in re≈øpect of mine offence, which is none to theÃÑ wardes) thinke by killyng of me amongs you, to affray you and others le≈øt they ≈øhould attempt to teach Chri≈øt truly or beleeue hys doctryne hereafter: but I doubte not but that heauenly father will by my death more confyrme you in his truth for euer. And therfore I greatly reioyce to ≈øee SathaÃÑ and his ≈øouldiours ≈øupplanted in their own ≈øapience, which is playne foli≈øhnes emonges the wi≈øe in deede, that is, emonges ≈øuch as haue heard gods worde, and do followe it, for they onely are accompted wy≈øe of the wi≈øedome of God our ≈øauiour. In dede, if I ≈øhoulde ≈øimplye con≈øider my lyfe, wyth that which it ought to haue bene, and as God in hys lawe requireth, then could I not but crye as I do. Iustus es domine & omnia iudicia tua vera: Righteous art thou O lord and all thy iudgements are true. For I haue muche greued thee and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed thy holy precepts, not onely before my
profe≈ø≈øing the go≈øpel, but ≈øythen al≈øo, yea euen ≈øitheÃÑ my commyng into pri≈øon. I do not excu≈øe but accu≈øe my ≈øelfe before god and all his church, that I haue greuou≈ølye offended my Lorde god, I haue not lyued hys go≈øpell as I ≈øhoulde haue done. I haue ≈øought my ≈øelfe & not ≈øymply & onely his glory and my brethernes commodity, I haue ben to vnthaÃÑkful, ≈øecure, carnal, hypocritical, vayn glorious. &c. Al which my euils the lorde of mercy pardon me for his chri≈øtes ≈øake, as I hope & certainly beleue he hath done for hys great mercy in Chri≈øt our redemer. But wheÃÑ I con≈øider the cau≈øe of my coÃÑ demnation I can not but lameÃÑt ye I do no more reioyce theÃÑ I do, for it is gods verity and truth: ≈øo that the condeÃÑnation is not a condemnation of Bradford ≈øimply, but rather a condemnation of Chri≈øt and his truth: Bradford is nothing els but an in≈øtrument, in whom Chri≈øt and his doctrine is condemned. And therfore (my dearely beloued) reioyce, reioyce and geue thaÃÑkes with me & for me, that euer god did vouch≈øafe ≈øo great a benefit to our countrey, as to choo≈øe the mo≈øt vnworthy (I meane my ≈øelfe) to be one, in whom it woulde plea≈øe him to ≈øuffer any kynde of affliction, much more thys violent kynd of death which I perceiue is prepared for me emongs you for his ≈øake. Al glory & prai≈øe be geueÃÑ vnto god our father for hys excedynge greate mercye towardes me through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our lord.

But perchaunce ye wil ≈øay vnto me, what is the cau≈øe for the which you are coÃÑdemned? we heare ≈øay that you deny al prefeÃÑce of Chri≈øt in his holy ≈øupper, & ≈øo make it a bare ≈øigne & common bread & nothing els. My derely beloued, what is ≈øaid of me & wil be, I cannot tel. It is told me that M. Pendleton is gone down to preach wt you, not as he hath recaÃÑted (for ye al know how he hath preached contrary to yt he was wont to preach afore I came amongs you) but to recaÃÑt that which he hath recaÃÑted. How he wil ≈øpeake of me & report before I come, wheÃÑ I am come, & when I am burned, I much pa≈ø≈øe not: for he ye is ≈øo vncertain & wil ≈øpeake ≈øo ofteÃÑ again≈øt him ≈øelfe, I cannot thinke he wil ≈øpeake wel of me, except it make for his purpo≈øe & profit. But of this enough. In dede the chiefe thing which I am condemned for as an heretyke is, becau≈øe I deny the ≈øacrament of the altar (whiche is not chri≈øtes ≈øupper, but a plaine peruertyng of it, beyng v≈øed as
the papi≈øts now v≈øe it) to be a real, natural, & corporall pre≈øence of chri≈øtes body & blood vnder the formes & accidents of bread and wine: that is, becau≈øe I deny tran≈øub≈øtantiatioÃÑ, which is the derling of the deuil and doughter and heyre to Antichri≈øts religion, wherby the Ma≈ø≈øe is mainteyned, chri≈øtes ≈øupper peruerted, his ≈øacrifice & cro≈ø≈øe imperfected, hys prie≈øthode de≈øtroyed, the mini≈øtery taken away, repentance repelled, and al true godlines abandoned. In the ≈øupper of our lord or ≈øacrament of chri≈øtes body and blood, I confe≈ø≈øe & beleue, that there is a true & very pre≈øence of whole Chri≈øte god & man, to the faith of ye receauer (but not of the ≈øtaÃÑder by or loker on) as there is a very true pre≈øence of breade and wine to the ≈øen≈øes of him that is pertaker therof. This faith, this doctrine, which coÃÑfenteth with the word of god & with the true te≈øtimony of chri≈øtes Churche (whiche the popy≈øhe church doth per≈øecute) will I not for≈øake, and therefore am I coÃÑdemned as an heretike & ≈øhalbe burned. But my derely beloutd, this truth which I haue taught, ye haue receyued, I beleued & do beleue, and therin geue my life: I hope in god ≈øhall neuer be burned, bound, nor ouercome, but ≈øhal tryumphe, haue victory and be at liberty, manger the heade of all gods aduer≈øaries. For there is no coun≈øell again≈øt the lord, nor no deui≈øe of man can be hable to defeate the verity in any other, then in ≈øuch as be children of vnbeliefe, which haue no loue to the truth, and therefore are geuen vp to beleue lies. From which plague the lorde of mercies delyuer you and all this realme, my deare hartes in the Lorde, I humblye bee≈øeche hys mercye, Amen. And to the ende ye myght be delyuered from thys plague (ryght deare to me in the Lorde) I ≈øhall for my farewell wyth you for euer in thys pre≈øente lyfe, hartely de≈øyre you all in the bowels and bloode of oure mo≈øte mercifull Sauioure Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, to attende vnto the≈øe thynges, whiche nowe I ≈øhall ≈øhortlye wryte vnto you out of the Holy ≈øcriptures of the Lorde. Ye know an he ‚Ä¢ aye plague or (rather plagues) of God is fallen vpon vs, in takyng away our good kyng, gods true religion, Gods true prophetes and mini≈øters &c. and ≈øetting ouer vs ≈øuche as ≈øeeke not the Lorde after knowledge, who≈øe endeuoures GOD pro≈øpereth wonderfully ‚Ä¢ to the triall of manye, that hys people maye bothe better knowe
them≈øelues, and be knowen. Nowe the cau≈øe hereof is oure iniquities and greuous ≈øynnes. We did not know the tyme of our vi≈øitation, we were vnthankefull vnto god, we contemned the go≈øpell and carnally abu≈øed it to ≈øerue our hypocri≈øie, our vayne glory, our viciou≈ønes, auarice, ydlenes, ≈øecurity. &c. Longe did the lord lynger & tary to haue ≈øhewed mercye vppon vs, but we were euer the longer, the wor≈øe. Therfore mo≈øt iu≈øtly hathe God dealt with vs, and dealeth with vs. Yea, yet we may ≈øee, yt his iu≈øtice is tempered with much mercy: wherto let vs attribute that we are not vtterly con≈øumed: for if the lord ≈øhould deale with vs after oure de≈øerts (alas) how could we abide it? In his anger therfore, ≈øeyng he doth remember hys mercy vnde≈øerued, yea vnde≈øyred on our behalfe, let vs take occa≈øion the more ≈øpedelye to go out to mete him, not with force and armes, for we are not ≈øo able to with≈øtand hym, much le≈ø≈øe to preuaile again≈øt hym: but to be≈øeche hym to be mercifull vnto vs, and according to his waÃÑted mercy to deale with vs. Let vs ari≈øe with Dauyd and ≈øay: Ne intres in iudicium cum ≈øeruo tuo. &c. Enter not into iudgement (oh Lorde) with thy ≈øeruant, for in thy ≈øight no fle≈øh liuyng ≈øhall be iu≈øtifyed. Let vs ≈øend amba≈ø≈øadors wyth the Centurion and ≈øay, Lord we are not worthy to come our ≈øelues vnto thee, ≈øpeake the worde and we ≈øhal haue peace. Let vs peniteÃÑtly with the Publicane loke down on the earth, knocke our hard hartes to bur≈øt them, and cry out: oh god be merciful vnto vs wretched ≈øynners. Let vs with the lo≈øt ≈øonne returne and ≈øay, O father we haue ≈øynned again≈øt heauen and earth & before thee, we are vnworthy to be called thy children. Let vs (I ≈øay) do on this ≈øort, that is, hartely repente vs of our former euill lyfe and vnthankefull go≈øpelling pa≈øt, conuert & turne to god with our whole hartes, hopyng in hys great mercy through Chri≈øt, and hartelye calling vppon his holye name, and then vndoubtedly we ≈øhall fynde and feele otherwy≈øe then yet we fele, both inwardly and outwardly. Inwardly we ≈øhal fele peace of con≈øcience betwene god and vs, which peace pa≈ø≈øeth al vnder≈øtaÃÑdyng, & outwardly we ≈øhall feele much mitigation of the≈øe mi≈øeries, yf not an outward taking of theÃÑ away.

Therfore my derely beloued in the lorde, I your poore≈øt
brother now departyng to the Lord, for my vale in aeternum, for this pre≈øent lyfe, pray you, be≈øeche you, and euen from the very bottome of my hart, for al the mercies of god in Chri≈øt ≈øhewed vnto you, mo≈øt earne≈øtly begge and craue of you out of pri≈øon, as often out of your pulpittes I haue done, that ye will repente you, leaue your wycked and euil lyfe, be ≈øory for your offences and turne to the lorde, who≈øe armes are wyde open to receiue and embrace you, who≈øe ≈øtretched out hande to ≈øtrike to death, ≈øtayeth that he might ≈øhewe mercy vpon you: for he is the lord of mercy and god of all comfort, he wyll not the death of a ≈øynner, but rather that he ≈øhould returne, conuert and amend, he hath no plea≈øure in the de≈øtruction of men, hys long ≈øuffryng draweth to repentaunce before the tyme of vengeaunce and the daye of wrathe which is at hande, doth come. Now is the axe layed to the roote of the tree, vtterlye to de≈øtroye the impenitent. Now is the fyer gone out before the face of the Lorde, and who is able to quench it? Oh therefore repente you, repente you. It is enough to haue lyued as we haue done. It is enough to haue played the wanton go≈øpellers, the proud prote≈øtantes, hypocriticall & fal≈øe Chri≈øtians, as (alas) we haue done. Now the lorde ≈øpeaketh vnto vs in mercy and grace: oh turne before he ≈øpeake in wrath. Yet is there mercy with the lorde and plenteous redemption: yet hath he not forgotten to ≈øhew mercy to them that cal vpoÃÑ hym: oh then cal vpon him while he may be founde, for he is rich in mercy and plentiful to al them that cal vpon him: ≈øo that he that calleth vpon the name of the lord ≈øhalbe ≈øaued. If your ≈øinnes be as red as ≈økarlet, the Lord ≈øaith he wil make them as white as ≈ønow. He hath ≈øworne and neuer will repente hym thereof, that he wyll neuer remeÃÑber our iniquities, but as he is god faithfull and true: ≈øo will he be our God, and we ≈øhalbe his people. Hys law wyll he wryte in oure hartes, and engraft it in oure myndes, and neuer wyll he haue in mynde oure vnryghteou≈ønes.

Therfore my dere hartes in the Lord, turne you, turne you to the lorde your father, to the lorde your Sauiour, to the Lorde your comforter. Oh why do you ≈øtop your eares and harden your hartes to day, when you heare hys voyce by me your pore≈øt brother? Oh forget not how that the lord
hath ≈øhewed hym ≈øelfe true, & me hys true preacher by brynging to pa≈ø≈øe the≈øe plagues which at my mouth & by my preaching ye ofteÃÑ heard before they came: ≈øpecially wheÃÑ I entreated of Noes flood, and wheÃÑ I preached of the 23. chap. of. S. Math. go≈øpel on S. SteueÃÑs day the la≈øt yt I was with you. And now by me the ≈øame Lord ≈øendeth you word (dere cuntrey men) that if ye will goe on forewardes in your impenitencie, carnality, hypocri≈øy, idolatry, couetuou≈ønes, ≈øwearing, gluttony, dronkennes, whoredome, &c. wherewith (alas, alas) our countrey floweth: yf (I ≈øaye) ye wil not turne & leaue of, ≈øeyng me now burned emongs you, to a≈ø≈øure you on all ≈øydes how god ≈øeketh you and is ≈øory to do you hurt, to plague you, to de≈øtroy you, to take vengeance vpon you: oh your bloode wyll be vppon your owne heades. Ye haue bene warned & warned again, by me in preaching, by me in burnyng. As I ≈øaid therfore I ≈øay agayne (my deare hartes and derlinges in the Lord) turne you, turne you, repent you repent you, cea≈øe from doyng euill, ≈øtudy to do well, awaye with idolatry, flye the Romi≈øhe god & ≈øeruice, leaue of from ≈øwearing, cut of carnality, abandon auarice, driue away droÃÑ kennes, flye froÃÑ fornication & flattery, froÃÑ murther & malice, de≈øtroy di≈øceitfulnes & ca≈øt away al the workes of darknes, put on piety & godlines, ≈øerue god after his word & not after cu≈øtome, v≈øe your tonges to glorify god by praier, thankes geuing & confe≈ø≈øioÃÑ of his truth &c. Be ≈øpiritual, & by ye ≈øpirit mortify carnal affectioÃÑs, be ≈øober, holy, true, louing, gentle, merciful, & then ≈øhal the lords wrath cea≈øe, not for this your doyngs ≈øake, but for hys mercies ≈øake. Go to therfore (good cuntreymeÃÑ) take this couÃÑ≈øel of the lord by me now ≈øent vnto you, take it as ye lords couÃÑ≈øel (I ≈øay) & not as mine, yt in ye day of iudgemeÃÑt I may reioyce with you and for you: the which thing I hartely de≈øyre, and not to be a witnes again≈øt you. My blood wil cry for veÃÑgeance, as again≈øt the papi≈øts gods enemies (whom I be≈øech god if it be his good wil, hartelye to forgeue, yea euen them which put me to death and are the cau≈øers therof, for they know not what they doe) ≈øo wyl my blood cry for vengeance again≈øt you (my dearely beloued in the lord) if ye repent not, amend not, and turne not vnto the Lorde. Turne vnto the Lorde, yet once more I hertely be≈øeche thee, thou Manche≈øter, thou Bolton, Burye, Wigyn,
Lierpole, A≈øhton vnderlyne, Mottrine, Stepport, Win≈øley Eccles, Pre≈øte, Middleton, Radcliefe, and thou Citye of We≈øtche≈øter, where I haue truely taught and preached the worde of god. Turne I ≈øay vnto you all, and to al the inhabitauntes thereaboutes, vnto the Lord our god, and he wil turne vnto you. He wyll ≈øay vnto his aungel: it is enough, put vp thy ≈øword. The which thyng that he wyl do, I humbly be≈øech his goodnes for the precious bloodes ≈øake of his deare ≈øonne our ≈øauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Ah good brethreÃÑ, take in good part the≈øe my la≈øte wordes vnto euerye one of you. Pardon me mine offences and negligence in behauiour amonges you. The Lord of mercy pardon vs all our offeÃÑces for our ≈øauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øtes ≈øake, Amen.

div.head: ¬∂To the faythfull and ≈øuch as profe≈øse the true doctrine of our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, dwellyng at VValden and thereaboutes, Iohn Bradford a mo≈øt vnworthy ≈øeruant of the Lorde, nowe in bandes and condemned for the ≈øame true doctryne, wi≈øheth grace, mercye and peace, wyth the encrea≈øe of all godlines, in knowledge and lyuyng, from God the father of all comforte, through the de≈øertes of our alone and full redemer Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, by the mightye workyng of the mo≈øt holy ≈øpirite, the comforter for euer. Amen.
div.p:
WHen I remember how that by the prouideÃÑce and grace of god, I haue bene a man by whoÃÑ it hath plea≈øed hym, through my mini≈øtery to call you to repentaunce and amendement of lyfe ≈øomethyng effectually (as it ≈øeemed) & to ≈øo we emoÃÑgs you his true doctrine & religioÃÑ, left that by my affliction and the ≈øtormes now ry≈øen to trye the faythful, and to conforme them like to the Image of the ≈øonne of GOD, into who≈øe companye we are called, ye myghte be faynte harted: I coulde not but out of pri≈øon ≈øecretly
(for my kepers may not know that I haue penne and ynke) to write vnto you a ≈øignification of the de≈øyre I haue that you ≈øhould not only be more confirmed in the doctrine I haue taught emonges you, which I take on my death as I ≈øhall aun≈øwer at the daye of dome, I am per≈øwaded to be gods a≈ø≈øured, infallible and playne truth: but al≈øo ≈øhould after your vocation auouch the ≈øame by confe≈ø≈øion, profe≈ø≈øion, and lyuyng. I haue not taught you (my dearely beloued in the lord) fables, tales, or vntruth, but I haue taught you the verity, as now by my blood gladly (pray≈øed therefore be god) I ≈øhal ≈øeale vp the ≈øame. In dede to coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe the truth vnto you and to all the church of Chri≈øt, I do not thinke of my ≈øelfe but that I haue mo≈øte iu≈øtlye de≈øerued not onelye this kinde, but al≈øo all kyndes of deathe and that eternallye, for myne hypocri≈øye, vayne glory, vncleannes, ≈øelfe loue, couetou≈ønes, ydlenes, vnthankefulnes, and carnal profe≈ø≈øing of gods holy go≈øpell, lyuyng therein not ≈øo purely, louynglye, and painfully as I ≈øhoulde haue done: the lord of mercy for the blood of Chri≈øt pardon me as I hope, yea I certainelye beleue he hath done for his holy names ≈øake through chri≈øt. But my dearely beloued, ye and all the whole worlde maye ≈øee and ea≈øely perceiue, that the prelates per≈øecute in me another thing then mine iniquities: eueÃÑ chri≈øt him≈øelf, chri≈øtes verity and truthe, bicau≈øe I can not, dare not, nor wyll not confe≈ø≈øe tran≈øub≈øtantiation, and howe that wicked men, yea myce and dogges, eatyng the ≈øacrament (which they terme of the altare, therby ouerthrowyng chri≈øtes holy ≈øupper vtterly) do eate chri≈øtes naturall and reall bodye borne of the Virgine Mary. To beleue and confe≈ø≈øe as gods worde teacheth, the primatiue churche beleued, and al the catholyke & good holy fathers taught for 500. yeres at ye lea≈øt after chri≈øt, that in the ≈øupper of the Lorde (which the ma≈ø≈øe ouerthroweth, as it doth Chri≈øtes prie≈øthode, ≈øacrifyce, death and pa≈ø≈øion, the mini≈øtery of hys worde, true fayth, repentaunce and all godlines) whole Chri≈øt god and man is pre≈øent by grace to the fayth of the receyuers, but not of the ≈øtanders by and lokers on, as bread & wyne is to theyr ≈øen≈øes: wil not ≈øerue, and therfore I am condempned and ≈øhalbee burned out of hand as an heretyke. Wherfore I thanke my lord god hartely,
that wil & doth vouch me worthy to be an in≈øtrument, in whoÃÑ he him ≈øelf wold ≈øuffer. For ye ≈øee my affliction and death is not ≈øimplye bicau≈øe I haue de≈øerued no le≈ø≈øe, but much more at his handes and iu≈øtice: but rather becau≈øe I confe≈ø≈øe hys veritye and truth, and am not affrayd through his gifte, ≈øo to doe, that ye al≈øo mighte bee confirmed in his truth.

Therfore my dearely beloued, I hartely do praye you and ≈øo many as vnfaynedly loue me in god, to geue with me and for me mo≈øt hartye thankes to our heauenly father through our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, for this his exceding great mercy towards me & you al≈øo, yt your fayth ≈øhold not wauer froÃÑ the doctrine I haue taught and ye haue receaued. For what can ye de≈øire more to a≈ø≈øure your con≈øciences of the veritye taughte by your Preachers, then their owne liues? Goe to therfore (my deare harts in ye lord) wauer not in Chri≈øtes religioÃÑ truely taught you & ≈øet forth in King Edwards dayes. Neuer ≈øhal the enemyes be able to burne it, to pri≈øon it and kepe it in bonds. Vs they may pri≈øon, they maye bynde and burne, as they do and wil do ≈øo long as ≈øhal plea≈øe the lord, but our cau≈øe, religion and doctrine which we confe≈ø≈øe, they ≈øhall neuer be able to vanqui≈øhe and put away. Their Idolatry and popy≈øhe religion, ≈øhal neuer be builte in the con≈øciences of men that loue the truth. As for tho≈øe that loue not gods truth, that haue no plea≈øure to walke in ye wayes of the Lord, in tho≈øe (I ≈øay) the deuill ≈øhal preuayle, for god wil geue them ≈øtrong illu≈øioÃÑ, to beleue lies. Therfore (deare brethren and ≈øi≈øters in the Lord) I humbly be≈øech you and pray you in the bowells and blood of our Lord and Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, now going to the death for the te≈øtimony of Ie≈øus, as often times I haue done before thys pre≈øente out of the pulpit, that ye would loue the Lordes truth: loue it (I ≈øay) to liue it, and frame your liues thereafter. Alas ye knowe the cau≈øe of all the≈øe plagues fallen vpon vs, and of ye ≈øucce≈ø≈øe which Gods aduer≈øaryes haue dayly, is for our not liuing gods word ‚Ä¢ : ye know how that we are Go≈øpellers in lippes and not in life: we are carnall, full of concupi≈øcene, idle, vnthankefull, vncleane, couetous, a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gant, di≈ø≈øemblers, craftye, ≈øubtile, malicious, fal≈øe, backebiters &c.

And euen glutted with gods word, yea we lothed it, as dyd the I≈øraelites the Manna in the wildernes: and therefore as to them the Lords wrath waxed whotte, ≈øo doth it vnto vs: ≈øo that there is no remedye but that (for it is better late to turne then neuer to turne) we confe≈ø≈øe our faultes euen from the bottome of our harts, and with hartie repentance, (which god worke in vs al for hys mercyes ≈øake) we runne vnto the Lord our God, which is exorable, merciful and ≈øory for the euil poured out vpon vs, and cry out vnto him wt Daniell ≈øaying: we haue ≈øinned, we haue ≈øinned, greuou≈ølye (Oh lord god) again≈øt thy maie≈øty, we haue heaped iniquitie vpoÃÑ iniquitie, the mea≈øure of our tran≈øgre≈ø≈øioÃÑs floweth ouer, ≈øo yt iu≈øt is thy wrath & veÃÑgeance falleÃÑ vpoÃÑ vs: for we are very mi≈øerable, we haue coÃÑteÃÑpned thy long ≈øuffering, we haue not harkened to thy voyce when thou ha≈øte called vs by thy preaches, we hardened our hartes, and therefore now de≈øerue that thou ≈øende thy cur≈øe hereupon to harden our hartes al≈øo, that we ≈øhould henceforth haue eyes and ≈øee not, eares and heare not, hartes and vnder≈øtande not, le≈øte we ≈øhould be conuerted and ≈øaued. Oh be merciful vnto vs, ≈øpace vs good Lord and al thy people whoÃÑ thou ha≈øt dearely bought. Let not thine enemies triumphe altogether & alwaies again≈øt thee, for then wil they be puft vp. Loke down and behold the pitifull complaintes of the poore: let the ≈øorrowfull ≈øighinges of the ≈øimple come in thy ≈øight, and be not angry with vs for euer. Turne vs (Oh Lord god of ho≈øtes) vnto thee and turne thee vnto vs, that thou maye≈øt be iu≈øtified in thy ≈øwete ≈øeÃÑtences, and ouercome when yu art iudg ‚Ä¢ d, as now thou art of our aduer≈øaries: for they ≈øaye where is their god? Can God deliuer them now? Can their go≈øpell ≈øerue them? Oh Lord how long? For the glory of thy name, and for thy honours ≈øake, in the bowels and blood of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, we humbly be≈øech thee, come and helpe vs, for we ar very mi≈øerable. On this ≈øort, I ≈øay, dearelye beloued, let vs publikelye and priuately bewaile oure ≈øinnes: but ≈øo that hereto we ioyne cea≈øing from wilfulnes and ≈øinne of purpo≈øe, for ells the Lorde heareth not oure prayers, as Dauid ≈øayth. And o ‚Ä¢ Saint Iohn it is written, the impenitent ≈øynners
god heareth not. Now impenitent are they which purpo≈øe not to amend their liues: as for example, not only tho≈øe which folow ≈øtil theyr plea≈øures in couetou≈ønes, vncleanes, carnalitie: but tho≈øe al≈øo which for feare or fauour of man, do again≈øt their con≈øcience, con≈øent to the romi≈øh rags, and re≈øort to the rotten religion, communicating in ≈øeruice and ceremonyes with the papi≈øtes, thereby declaring them≈øelues to loue more the worlde then God, to feare more man then Chri≈øt, to dread more the lo≈ø≈øe of temporall thinges, then of eternal: in whom it is euident, the loue of God abideth not: for he that loueth the worlde, hath not Gods loue abidyng in him, ≈øayth the Euangeli≈øt.

Therfore (my deare harts, and deare agayne in the lord) remember what ye haue profe≈ø≈øed, Chri≈øtes religioÃÑ & name, and the renouncing of the deuil, ≈øinne and the worlde. Remember yt before ye learned A. B. C. your le≈ø≈øoÃÑ was Chri≈øts cro≈ø≈øe. Forget not that Chri≈øt wil haue no di≈øciples, but ≈øuch as wil promi≈øe to denie them ≈øelues, to take vp their cro≈ø≈øe (marke, they mu≈øt take it vp) & follow him, & not the multitude, cu≈øtome & v≈øe. CoÃÑ≈øider for gods ≈øake, yt if we gather not with Chri≈øt, we ≈øcatter abroade. What ≈øhould it profite a maÃÑ to winne the whole world, and lo≈øe his own ≈øoule? We mu≈øt not forget that this life is a wildernes and not a parady≈øe, here is not oure home, we are nowe in warfare: we mu≈øte nedes fight, or els be taken pri≈øoners. Of al things we haue in this life, we ≈øhal cary nothing wt vs. If Chri≈øt be our captain, we mu≈øt folow hiÃÑ as good ≈øouldiers. If we kepe coÃÑpany with him in afflittion, we ≈øhal be ≈øure of his ≈øocietie in glory. If we for≈øake not him, he wil neuer for ≈øake vs. If we coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe him he wil coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe vs: but if we deny him, he wil deny vs. If we be a≈øhamed of him, he wil be a≈øhamed of vs. Wherefore as he for≈øoke father, heauen, and al things to come to vs: ≈øo let vs for≈øake all thinges to come to him, being ≈øure & mo≈øte certayne yt we ≈øhal not lo≈øe therby. Your children ≈øhal finde & feele it double, yea treble, what ≈øoeuer ye lo≈øe for ye Lords ≈øake, and ye ≈øhal finde and fele peace of con≈øcience & frende≈øhip with god, which is more worth then al the goods of the world.

My dearly beloued, therfore for the Lordes ≈øake coÃÑ≈øider
the≈øe thynges, which I now write vnto you of loue, for my Vale and la≈øte farewell for euer in thys pre≈øent life. Turne to the Lorde, repente ye your euill and vnthankeful life, declare repentaunce by the fruites, take time whyles you haue it, come to the Lorde whiles he calleth you, runne into his lappe whiles his armes be opeÃÑ to embra≈øe you, ≈øeeke him whiles he may be found, cal vpon him whiles time is conueniente, for≈øake and flye from all euill both in religion and in the re≈øt of your life and conuer≈øation, let your lighte ≈øo ≈øhine before men, that they may ≈øee your good woorkes and pray≈øe god in the day of his vi≈øitation. Oh come again, come againe ye ≈øtraunge children & I wil receaue you, ≈øayth the Lord. Conuert and turne to me and I will turne vnto you. Why wil ye nedes peri≈øhe? As ≈øure as I liue (≈øwereth the Lord) I wil not your death, tourne therefore vnto me. Can a woman forget the child of her wombe? If ≈øhe ≈øhould, yet wil not I forget you, ≈øayth the lord your god. I am he, I am he which putteth awaye your ≈øinnes for mine owne ≈øake. Oh then (deare frends) turne, I ≈øay, vnto your deare≈øt father: Ca≈øt not the≈øe his ≈øweete and louing woordes to the grounde and at your tayle, for the Lorde watcheth on hys worde to performe it, which is in two ≈øortes: to them that lay it vp in their hartes and beleue it, will he pay all and eternall ioye and comforte. But to them that ca≈øte it at their backes and wilfully forget it, to them (I ≈øay) wil he poure out indignation and eternal ≈øhame. Wherfore I hartely yet once more be≈øech and pray you and euery of you, not to contemne this poore and ≈øimple exhortation which now out of pri≈øon I make vnto you, or rather the Lord by me. Loth would I be to be a witnes again≈øt you in the la≈øt day, as of truth I mu≈øt be if ye repent not, if ye loue not gods go≈øpel, yea if ye lyue it not. Therfore to conclude, repent, loue gods go≈øpell, lyue it in all your conuer≈øation: ≈øo ≈øhall gods name be pray≈øed, his plagues mitigated, his people comforted, & his enemies a≈øhamed. Graunt all thys thou gracious Lord god to euery of vs, for thy deare ≈øonnes ≈øake oure Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: To whom with thee and the holy gho≈øt be eternall glory for euer and euer, Amen. The 12. of Febr. 1555.

div.head: To the honourable lord Ru≈ø≈øell, nowe Earle of Bedford, being then in trouble for the veritye of gods Go≈øpell.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting and mo≈øt gracious god & father of our ≈øauioure Ie≈øu Chri≈øt, ble≈ø≈øe your good Lord≈øhip with al manner of heauenly ble≈ø≈øinges in the ≈øame Chri≈øt our onely comfort and hope, Amen.

Pray≈øed be god our father which hath vouched you worthy, as of fayth in his Chri≈øt, ≈øo of his cro≈ø≈øe for the ≈øame. Magnified be his holy name, who as he hath deliuered you from one cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øo he hath made you willinge (I tru≈øt) and ready to beare an other when he ≈øhal ≈øee his time to lay it vpon you: for the≈øe are the mo≈øt ≈øingular giftes of God geueÃÑ as to fewe, ≈øo to none els but to tho≈øe few which are mo≈øt deare in his ≈øight. Faith is reckened and worthely, among the greate≈øt giftes of god, yea it is the greate≈øt it ≈øelf yt we enioy, for by it, as we be iu≈øtifyed & made gods childreÃÑ, ≈øo are we temples & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øours of ye holy ≈øpirit, yea of Chri≈øt al≈øo, Eph. 4. and of the father him ≈øelf, Iohn. 14. By fayth we driue the deuil away. 1. Pet. 5. We ouercome ye world. 1. Ioh. and are already citizens of heauen and fellowes with gods deare ≈øaints. But who is able to recken the riches that thys fayth bringeth with her vnto the ≈øoule ≈øhee ≈øitteth vpoÃÑ? No man nor Angell. And therfore (as I ≈øayd) of al gods giftes, ≈øhe may be ≈øet in the toppe & haue the vppermo≈øt feare. The which thing if men con≈øidered (in that ≈øhe commeth alonely froÃÑ gods own mercy ≈øeate, by the hearing, not of Ma≈ø≈øe or Mattyns, Diriges or ≈øuch draffe, but of the word of God in ≈øuch a tong as we can and do vnder≈øtand) as they would be diligent and take great heede for doing or ≈øeing any thyng which might ca≈øte her down (for theÃÑ they fal al≈øo) ≈øo would they with no le≈ø≈øe care, read and heare Gods holy woorde, ioyning therto mo≈øte earne≈øt and often prayer, a≈øwel for the more and better vnder≈øtanding, as for the louyng, liuing & confe≈ø≈øing of the ≈øame, maugre the head of the deuil, ye world, our fle≈øh, rea≈øon, goods po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, carnall frendes, wyfe, children, and very life here, if they ≈øhoulde pulle vs barke to
harken to their voyce and coun≈øell, for more quiet, ≈øure, and longer v≈øe of them.

Now, notwith≈øtanding this excellency of fayth, in that we read the Apo≈øtle to match therewith, yea (as it were) to preferre ≈øuffering per≈øecution for Chri≈øtes ≈øake, Philip. 1. I trowe no man will be ≈øo fonde as to thinke otherwi≈øe, but that I and all gods children haue cau≈øe to glorifie & pray≈øe god, which hath vouched you worthy ≈øo great a ble≈ø≈øing. For though ye rea≈øon or wi≈øedome of the world thinke of ye cro≈ø≈øe according to their reach and according to their pre≈øent ≈øen≈øe, & therefore flyeth from it as from a mo≈øt great ignominie & ≈øhame: yet Gods ≈øcholers haue learned otherwi≈øe to thinke of the cro≈ø≈øe, that it is the frame hou≈øe in the which god frameth his children like to his ≈øonne Chri≈øte: the fornace that fyneth gods golde: the highe waye to heauen: the Sute and Liuerey that gods ≈øeruauÃÑtes are ≈øerued withal: the Earne≈øt and beginning of al con≈øolation & glory. For they (I meane gods ≈øcholers, as your Lord≈øhip is I tru≈øte) doe enter into gods Sanctuarie, P≈øal. 72 le≈øt their fete ≈ølip. They loke not as bea≈øts do, on things pre≈øent only but on thinges to come, & ≈øo haue they as pre≈øent to fayth, the iudgement & glorious coÃÑmyng of Chri≈øt, lyke as ye wicked haue now their worldlye welthe wherin they wallow & wil wallow til they tuÃÑble headlong into hel, where are torments too terrible and endles. Now they follow the Feende as the Beare doth ye trayne of honie and the Sowe the ≈øwillinges, till they be broughte into the ≈ølaughterhou≈øe, and then they knowe that their pro≈øperity hath brought them to perdition. Then crie they woe, woe, we went the wrong way: we counted the≈øe men (I meane ≈øuch as you be ye ≈øuffer for gods ≈øake lo≈ø≈øe of goods, frendes and life, whoÃÑ they ≈øhal ≈øee endued with rych robes of righteou≈ønes, crownes of mo≈øt pure precious golde, and palmes of conque≈øt in the goodly glorious palace of ye Lambe, where is eternalioye, felicitie &c.) we counted (will they then ≈øay) the≈øe men but fooles and madde men, we toke their conditions to be but curio≈øitie, &c. But then wil it be to late, then the time will be turned, laughing ≈øhall be turned into weeping, and weeping into reioycing. Read Sapien. 2. 3. 4. 5.

Therfore (as before I haue ≈øayd) greate cau≈øe haue I to thanke God which hath vouched you worthy of thys mo≈øt
bountifull ble≈ø≈øing: muche more then you haue cau≈øe (my good Lorde) ≈øo ≈øo bee, I meane thankefull. For loke vpon your vocation I praye you, and tell me howe many noble men, Earles ≈øonnes, Lordes, Knightes and men of e≈øtimation hath God in thys Realme of Englande dealte thus with all? I dare ≈øay you thinke not that you haue de≈øerued thys. Only Gods mercy in hys Chri≈øt hath wroughte thys on you, as he dyd in Ieremyes tyme on Abimeleche, in Achabs time on Abdias, in Chri≈øtes tyme on Io≈øeph of Arimathia, in the Apo≈øtles tyme on Sergius Paulus and the Queene of Candaces chamberleyne. Onely now be thankfull and continue, continue, continue (my good Lord) continue to confe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt. Be not a≈øhamed of hym before men, for then will not he be a≈øhamed of you. Nowe will he trye you: ≈øticke fa≈øte vnto hym and he will ≈øticke fa≈øte by you: he will be with you in trouble and deliuer you. But theÃÑ mu≈øt you cry vnto hym, for ≈øo it precedeth: P≈øa. 9 ‚Ä¢ . he cryed vnto me and I heard: I was with him in trouble &c. Remember Lothes wyfe which loked backe. Remember Fraunces Spira. RemeÃÑber that none is crowned but he that ≈øtriueth lawfullye. Remember that all you haue, is at Chri≈øtes commaundement. Remember he lo≈øt more for you then you can lo≈øe for him. Remember you lo≈øe not that which is lo≈øt for his ≈øake, for you ≈øhall fynde much more here and els where. Remember you ≈øhall dye, and when where, and howe, you can not tell. Remember the death of ≈øinners is mo≈øte terrible. Remember the death of Gods Saints is precious in his ≈øight. RemeÃÑber ye multitude goeth the wideway, which windeth to woe. RemeÃÑber yt the ≈øtraite gate which leadeth to glory hath but fewe trauellers. Remember Chri≈øt biddeth you ≈øtriue to enter in thereat. Remember he that tru≈øteth in the lord ≈øhall receaue ≈øtrength to ≈øtand agayn≈øt al the a≈ø≈øaultes of his enemies. Be certayne al the heares of your head are numbred. Be certayn your good father hath poynted boundes ouer the which ye deuil dare not loke. CoÃÑmitte your ≈øelf to him: he is, hath bene, & wil be your keper: ca≈øt your care on him & he wil care for you. Let Chri≈øt be your ≈øcope & marke to pricke at: let hiÃÑ be your patroÃÑ to worke by: let hiÃÑ be your en≈øaÃÑple to folow: geue hiÃÑ as your hart ≈øo your hand, as your mind ≈øo your touÃÑg, as your faith ≈øo your fete, & let his word be your candle
to go before you in al matters of religion. Ble≈ø≈øed is he that walketh not to the≈øe popy≈øh prayers, nor ≈øtaÃÑdeth at theÃÑ nor ≈øitteth at them: P≈øa. 1 2. Cor. 6. glorifye God in both ≈øoule & body. He that gathereth not with Chri≈øt ≈øcattereth abroade. V≈øe prayer, loke for gods helpe, which is at hand to them yt a≈øke & hope therafter a≈ø≈øuredly. In which prayer I hartelye de≈øire your Lord≈øhip to remember vs, who as we are going with you right gladly (God therfore be pray≈øed) ≈øo we loke to goe before you, hoping that you wil followe, if God ≈øo wil, accordinge to youre dailye prayer: thy wyll bee done on earth &c. The good ≈øpirite of God alwayes guide your Lord≈øhip vnto the end, Amen.

div.head: An other letter to the Lord Ru≈ø≈øell
div.p: THe eternal mercyes of God in his deare ≈øoÃÑne our ≈øauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, be more and more felte and hartely perceaued of you, my good Lord, to your endles ioye and comfort, AmeÃÑ.

Becau≈øe your Lord≈øhippe looketh not for thankes of me for Gods benefites mini≈øtred by you, and in fewe wordes I can not dulye declare that I woulde do, I will omitte the ≈øame, praying God our deare father in the day of his retribution to remember it, & in the meane ≈øea≈øon to a≈ø≈øi≈øt, coun≈øel, and comfort you as his child for euer in all thynges. I doubt not but that you haue that childly opinion. Yea per≈øua≈øion of his goodnes in Chri≈øt towards you: theÃÑ which ble≈ø≈øing (my good lord) none is greater geuen to man vpon earth. For a≈ø≈øuredly he that hath it, is the very childe of God, elect before al time in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu our lord, & therfore ≈øhal enioy euerla≈øting felicitie, although he be here afflicted and to≈ø≈øed in trouble and temptation to hys trial, that when he is found faythful he may receaue the crowne of glory. The onely thyng that di≈øcerneth the child of God from the wicked, is thys fayth, tru≈øt and hope in gods goodnes through Chri≈øt, the which I tru≈øt you haue, God encrea≈øe it in you & make you thankful. Certainly ≈øuch as enioye it be happy: if they be happye, and that happines is not where any thinge is to bee de≈øired, they can not but
for euer be mo≈øte a≈ø≈øured of per≈øeueraunce to ≈øaluation, for if they fall the lorde putteth vnder his hande that they ≈øhall not peri≈øh: they are beloued of Chri≈øt which loueth them to the very ende. God for his mercy ≈øake in Chri≈øte open more & more your eies to ≈øee this his ≈øwetenes in Chri≈øt, to make you ≈øecure in him, and awake the fle≈øhe from her ≈øecuritye, to be vigilant and heedeful how you may mo≈øt behaue your ≈øelfe in thankfull obedience to God and carefull helpe and ≈øeruice to his people, that all your whole lyfe may tende to this, how by example and otherwy≈øe you may doe good to others, and ≈øtill confirme his true ≈øeruyce and religion by your con≈øtancy. Wherin if you continue to the ende you ≈øhal receiue an incorruptible crowne of immmortal & vn≈øpeakable glory: but if for bicau≈øe of gods tarying, which is only to proue you, you relent (which god forbid) thinking it enough in hart to ≈øerue god, and in body to do as may make mo≈øt to your commodity temporally, as many do: then vndoubtedly your ≈øtaÃÑding hetherto (wherfore gods holy name be prai≈øed) ≈øhall make much more for the papi≈øticall kyngdome and glory thereof, then if you had neuer done as you haue done. Wherof (my good lord) be not wearye nor vnthankfull, for with the godly and in the church of god you are and ≈øhalbe had as a worthy meÃÑber of chri≈øt, worthy of double honour, becau≈øe god of his goodnes hath vouched you worthy with out your de≈øertes. In the one, that is for landes and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, you haue companions many: but in the other (my good lord) you are A per ≈øe A with vs to our comfort and ioye vn≈øpeakable, ≈øo long as you continue (as I tru≈øt you wil do to the ende) and to our mo≈øt heauy ≈øorrowe (which god forbid) if you ≈øhould relente in any pointe.

Therfore I be≈øech your lord≈øhippe in the bowels and blood of our ≈øauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, to per≈øeuer and continue to the ende. He that hathe not tempted you hetherto aboue your ≈øtrength, wil continue ≈øo to the ende. If for a tyme he hyde hys face from you, yet he doth it but for a momente to make you the more hartely to cry to hym, and ≈øurely he wil heare you, not onely when you are in cryeng, but al≈øo while≈øt you are in thynkyng how to cry: he is with you in trouble and wyll in deede delyuer you. The longer he taryeth,
the more plea≈øantly and comfortably will he appeare. As coÃÑcernyng the number and charges of vs heare (which this day I heard your lord≈øhip de≈øired to vnder≈øtande) this is ≈øo much as I know, that we are iiij. in number together, who≈øe names this bearer ≈øhall tell you. div.p: OVr deare & ≈øweete Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who≈øe pri≈øoner at this pre≈øent (pray≈øed bee his name therfore) I am, pre≈øerue and kepe you my good Mother, with my brothers and ≈øi≈øters, my father Iohn Traues, Thomas Sorrocolde, Laurence and Iames Brad≈øhaw with their wines & families &c. now and for euer, Amen.

I am at thys pre≈øent in pri≈øon ≈øure enough for ≈øtartyng, to confirme that I haue preached vnto you: as I am ready (I thanke God) with my life and blood to ≈øeale the ≈øame, if god vouch me worthy of that honoure. For good Mother and brethren, it is a mo≈øt ≈øpeciall benefite of god to ≈øuffer for hys names ≈øake and go≈øpel, as now I do: I hartely thanke hym for it,
‚Ä¢ . Timo. 2. and am ≈øure that with him I ≈øhall be partaker of his glory, as Paule ≈øayeth: if we ≈øuffer with him we ≈øhall reygne with him. Therfore be not faynt harted, but rather reioyce, at the lea≈øt for my ≈øake which now am in the ryght and high waye to heauen: for by many afflictions we mu≈øte enter into the kingdome of heauen. Ye all know there was neuer more knowledge of god & le≈ø≈øe godly liuing & true ≈øeruiÃÑg of god. It was counted a foli≈øhe thing to ≈øerue god truely, & earne≈øt praier

Malice, couetou≈ønes and vncleannes was coÃÑmon euery where, with ≈øwearing, dronkennes & idlenes. God therfore now is come as you haue heard me preach, and becau≈øe he will not daÃÑpne vs with the worlde, he beginneth to puny≈øhe vs: as me for my carnal liuing. For as for my preaching, I am mo≈øte certayne it is and was gods truth, and I tru≈øt to geue my life for it by gods grace, but becau≈øe I liued not the go≈øpel truly but outwardly, therefore doth he thus puny≈øhe me: naye rather in puni≈øhing ble≈ø≈øe me. And in dede I thanke hym more of this pri≈øon, then of any parler, yea then of any plea≈øure that euer I had: for in it I fynde God my mo≈øte ≈øweete good god alwayes. Perchaunce you are infirmed & weakened of that which I haue preached, becau≈øe god doth not defeÃÑd it (as you thinke) but ≈øuffereth the olde popi≈øhe doctrine to come agayne and preuaile: but you mu≈øte knowe good Mother, that God by this doth proue and trye his children and people whether they wil vnfainedly and ≈øimplie hang on him & his woord. So did he with the I≈øraelites, bringing them into a de≈øerte, after their comming out of Egipt, where (I meane the wildernes) was want of al things in compari≈øon of that which they had in Egipt. Chri≈øte when he came into thys worlde, brought no worldly wealth nor quietnes with him, but rather warre: the worlde (≈øayeth he) ≈øhall reioyce, Iohn. 16. but ye ≈øhall mourne & weepe, but your weping ≈øhal be tourned into ioy: and therfore happy are they that mourne and weepe, for they ≈øhal be comforted. They are marked then with gods marke in their foreheades and not with ye bea≈øtes marke, I meane the Popes ≈øhauen crowne, who now with his ≈øhauelinges reioyce, but woe vnto them, for they ≈øhall be ca≈øt down, they ≈øhall weepe and mourne. The riche Glutton had here hys ioy, and Lazarus ≈øorrow, but afterwards the time was chauÃÑ ged. The end of carnal ioy is ≈øorrowe. Wherefore feare God: ≈øticke to hys woorde though all the worlde woulde ≈øwarue from it. Dye you mu≈øte once, and when or howe, you can not tell. Dye therefore with Chri≈øte, ≈øuffer for ≈øeruing hym truly & after his word: for ≈øure may we be yt of al deathes it is mo≈øt to be de≈øired to dye for gods ≈øake. In peace wheÃÑ no per≈øecution was, then were you content and glad to heare me: then dyd you beleeue me, and wil you not do ≈øo now, ≈øeing I ≈øpeake that which I tru≈øt by gods grace if nede be, to verefye with my lyfe? Good Mother I write before God to you, as I haue preached before hym. It is gods truth I haue taughte: It is that ≈øame infallible word wherof he hath ≈øayd: heauen & earth ≈øhal pa≈ø≈øe, but my word ≈øhal not pa≈ø≈øe. The ma≈ø≈øe and ≈øuch baggage as the fal≈øe wor≈øhippers of god and enemies of Chri≈øtes cro≈ø≈øe (the papi≈øtes I ≈øay) haue brought in againe to poy≈øon the church of God withal, dy≈øplea≈øeth God highly and is abhominable in his ≈øyghte. Happye maye he bee whiche of con≈øcience ≈øuffereth lo≈ø≈øe of lyfe or goodes in di≈øalowing it. Come not at it. If God bee God followe hym: If the ma≈ø≈øe bee God, let them
that will ≈øee it, heare or be pre≈øent at it, go to the deuil with it. What is there as God ordayned? Hys ≈øupper was ordained to be receaued of vs in the memorial of his death, for the confyrmation of our fayth that his body was broken for vs & his blood≈øhed for pardon of oure ≈øynnes: but in the Ma≈ø≈øe there is no receauyng, but the prie≈øte keepeth all to hym ≈øelfe alone. Chri≈øte ≈øayeth, take eate: no ≈øayeth the Prie≈øte gape pepe. There is a ≈øacrificyng, yea killing of Chri≈øte agayne as muche as they maye. div.p: THe God of mercy and father of al comfort, at this pre≈øeÃÑt and for euer, engraffe in your hart the ≈øen≈øe of his mercy in Chri≈øt, and the continuance of his con≈øolatioÃÑ, which can not but enable you to cary wt ioy, what ≈øoeuer cro≈ø≈øe he ≈øhall lay vpon you, Amen.

Hetherto I coulde haue no ≈øuch libertie as to write vnto you, as I thinke you know: but now in that through gods prouidence I haue no ≈øuch re≈øtraint, I can not but ≈øomthing write, a≈øwell to purge me of the ≈øu≈øpition of vnthankfulnes towardes you, as all≈øo to ≈øignifie my carefulnes for you in the≈øe perilous dayes, lea≈øt you ≈øhould waxe colde in Gods cau≈øe (which god forbid) or ≈øuffer the light of the Lorde once kindled in your hart, to be quenched, and ≈øo become as you were before, after the example of the world and of many others, which would haue bene accompted otherwi≈øe in our daies, and yet ≈øtil beguile them ≈øelues, ≈øtill woulde be ≈øo accompted, althoughe by their outwarde life they declare the contrarye, in that they thinke it enough to keepe the harte pure, notwith≈øtanding that the outwarde man doth currye fauoure. Therfore I pray you call to mynde that there bee but two mai≈øters, two kyndes of people, two wayes, and two man≈øion places. Agayne: con≈øider that this worlde is the place of trial of gods people and the deuils ≈øeruauntes: for as the one will followe his mai≈øter what≈øoeuer cometh of it, ≈øo will the other. Stryue therfore good mai≈øter Doctor, nowe you haue founde it, to enter into it: and if you ≈øhould be called or pulled backe, looke not on this ≈øide or that ≈øide, or behynd you as Lothes wyfe dyd: but ≈øtrayght forewardes on the ende, which ≈øet before you (though it be to come) as euen now pre≈øent: lyke as you do and wyl your patientes to doe in purgations and other your mini≈øtrations, to con≈øyder the effecte that wil en≈øue, where through the bitternes and lothe≈øomnes of the purgatioÃÑ, is ≈øo ouercome, and the painfulnes in abydyng the workyng of that is myni≈øtred, is ≈øo ea≈øed, that it maketh the patient willyngly & ioyfully to receiue that is to be receiued, although it be neuer ≈øo vnplea≈øauÃÑt: ≈øo (I ≈øay) ≈øet before you the ende of this ≈øtraite way, and theÃÑ doutles, as Paule ≈øaith, aeternuÃÑ poÃÑdus gloriae pariet, whiles you loke not on the thyng ≈øene, for that is temporal, but on the thing which is not ≈øene which is eternall. So dothe the hu≈øbandman in plowing and tilling ≈øet before him the harue≈øt time: ≈øo doth the fi≈øher con≈øider the draught of his nette rather theÃÑ the ca≈øting in: ≈øo doth the merchaunt the returne of his merchauÃÑdi≈øe: and ≈øo ≈øhoulde we in the≈øe ≈øtormy daies ≈øet before vs not the lo≈ø≈øe of our goods, liberty, & very lyfe,
but the reaping time, the comming of our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt to iudgement, the fire yt ≈øhall burne the wicked & di≈øobedieÃÑt to gods go≈øpel, the bla≈øt of the Trumpe, the exceding glory prepared for vs in heauen eternally, ≈øuche as the eie hathe not ≈øene, the eare hath not heard, nor the harte of man can conceyue. The more we lo≈øe here, the greater ioye ≈øhall wee haue there. The more we ≈øuffer the greater tryumphe. For corruptible dro≈ø≈øe, we ≈øhall fynde incorruptible trea≈øures: for golde glorye: for ≈øyluer, ≈øolace without ende: for ryches, robes royall: for earthely hou≈øes, eternall Palaces, myrthe wythout mea≈øure, plea≈øure wythout payne, felicitye endeles: Summa, we ≈øhall haue God the father, the ≈øonne and the holy Gho≈øte. Reade Sapien 2.3.4.5. Reade Mathew. 25. Reade 1. Corrinthians. 15. 2. Corrinthians. 5. and by fayth (whiche GOD encrea≈øe in vs) con≈øyder the thinges there ≈øet forth. And for your comforte, reade Hebrewes. 11. to ≈øee what faythe hath done, alwayes con≈øyderyng the way to heauen to be by many tribulations, & that all they which wyll lyue godlye in Chri≈øte Ie≈øu, mu≈øt ≈øuffer per≈øecution. You know thys is oure Alphabet: he that wyll bee my Di≈øciple, ≈øayeth Chri≈øt, mu≈øt denye hym≈øelfe, and take vppe his cro≈ø≈øe and followe me: not thys Bi≈øhoppe, nor that Doctour, not thys Emperour, nor that Kynge, but me ≈øayeth Chri≈øte: for he that loueth father, mother, wyfe, chyldren, or verye lyfe better then me, is not worthye of me. Remember that the ≈øame Lorde ≈øayeth: Math. 8. he that wyll ≈øaue hys lyfe ≈øhall loo≈øe it. Comforte your ≈øelfe wyth thys, that as the Deuyls had no power ouer the Porkettes, or ouer Iobes goodes wythout Gods leaue, ≈øo ≈øhall they haue none ouer you. Remember al≈øo that all the heares of your head are numbred wyth GOD. The Deuyll maye make one beeleue he wyll drowne hym, as the Sea in hys ≈øurges threateneth to the lande: but as the Lorde hathe appoynted boundes for the one, ouer the whyche he cannot pa≈ø≈øe, ≈øo hathe he done for the other.

On god therfore ca≈øt your care, loue him, ≈øerue him after hys worde, feare him, tru≈øt in him, hope at his hande for all helpe, and alwayes praye, lookyng for the cro≈ø≈øe, and when ≈øoeuer it commeth, bee a≈ø≈øured the Lorde, as he is faythfull, ≈øo he will neuer tempte you further then he will make you able to beare, but in the mydde≈øt of the teÃÑptation, wil make ≈øuch an eua≈øion as ≈øhalbe mo≈øt to his glorye, and your eternall comfort. God for his mercy in Chri≈øte with his holye ≈øpirite endue you, comforte you, vnder the winges of hys mercy ≈øhadow you, and as his deare childe guide you for euermore. To who≈øe merciful tuition, as I doe wyth my hartye prayer committe you: ≈øo I doubte not but you praye for me al≈øo, and ≈øo I be≈øeche you to do ≈øtil. My brother. P. telleth me you would haue the la≈øt part of ≈øainct Hieromes workes, to haue the v≈øe thereof for a fortenighte. I cannot for the≈øe .iij. dais wel forbeare it, but yet on thur≈øday next I wil ≈øend it you if god let me not, & v≈øe me & that I haue as your owne. The lorde for his mercy in Chri≈øte directe oure wayes to his glory. Amen.

div.head: To May≈øtres M. H. a godly gentlewoman, comfortyng her in that common heauines and godly ≈øorrow, which the feeling and ≈øen≈øe of ≈øinne worketh in gods children.
div.p: I Humblye and hartelye praye the euerlyuyng good god and father of mercye, to ble≈ø≈øe and kepe your harte and mynd in the knowledge and loue of his truth, & of his Chri≈øt through the in≈øpiration and workyng of the holy ≈øpyryte, Amen.

Although I haue no doubte but that you pro≈øper and go forwardes daily in the way of godlines, more and more drawyng towardes perfection, and haue no neede of anyethyng yt I can wryte, yet becau≈øe my de≈øyre is yt you myghte be more feruent and per≈øeuer to the ende. I coulde not but wryte ≈øomethyng vnto you, be≈øechyng you bothe often and
diligently to call vnto your mynd as a meane to ≈øtyrre you hereunto, yea as a thyng which god mo≈øt ≈øtraitly requireth you to beleue, that you are beloued of god, & that he is your dere father in, through and for Chri≈øt and his deathes ≈øake: This loue & tender kyndnes of god towards vs in Chri≈øt is aboundaÃÑtly herein declared, in yt he hath to ye godly wor≈øt of creation of this worlde, made vs after his image, redemed vs beyng lo≈øt, called vs into his church, ≈øealed vs with his marke and ≈øigne manuel of Bapti≈øme, kept and con≈øerued vs all the dais of our lyfe, fed, nouri≈øhed, defended and mo≈øte fatherlye cha≈øti≈øed vs, and nowe hath kindled in our hartes the ≈øparcles of hys feare, faith, loue, and knowlege of hys Chri≈øt and truth, and therfore we lament becau≈øe we lament no more our vnthankfulnes, our frailenes, our diffidence and waueryng in things wherin we ≈øhould be mo≈øte certain. Al the≈øe thyngs we ≈øhuld v≈øe as meanes to coÃÑfyrme our faith of this, that god is our god and father, and to a≈ø≈øure vs that he loueth vs as our father in Chri≈øt: to this end (I ≈øay) we ≈øhould v≈øe the thynges before touched, e≈øpecially in that of all thinges god requyreth this faith and per≈øua≈øion of hys fatherly goodnes, as hys chiefe≈øt ≈øeruyce. For before he a≈øke any thyng of vs, he ≈øaieth: I am the Lord thy god, geuyng hym≈øelfe, and then all he hath to vs, to be our own. And this he doth in re≈øpect of hym≈øelf, of hys owne mercye and truth, and not in re≈øpect of vs, for then were grace no grace. In con≈øideration wherof, when he ≈øaieth, Thou ≈øhalte haue none other gods but me, thou ≈øhalt loue me with all thy hart &c: thoughe of duetye wee are bounde to accompli≈øhe all that he requyreth, and are culpable and gilty yf we do not ye ≈øame, yet he requyreth not the≈øe thyngs further of vs, theÃÑ to make vs more in loue and more certayne of this his couenaunt, that he is our lord and god. In certaintie wherof, as he hath geuen this whole world to ≈øerue to our nede and commoditie, ≈øo hath he geued hys ≈øonne Chri≈øte Ie≈øus, and in Chri≈øt, hym≈øelfe to be a pledge and gage, wherof the holy Gho≈øte dothe nowe and then geue vs ≈øome ta≈øte and ≈øwete ≈ømell to our eternall ioye.

Therefore (as I ≈øayde) becau≈øe God is your father in Chri≈øte, and requyreth of you ≈øtraightly to beleue it, geue
your ≈øelfe to obedience, although you do it not with ≈øuch feelyng as you de≈øyre. Fir≈øt mu≈øt fayth go before, and then feelyng wyll folow. Yf our imperfection, frailtie, and many euils ≈øhould be occa≈øions wherby Sathan woulde haue vs to doubte, as much as we can let vs abhorre that ≈øugge≈øtion as of all others mo≈øt pernicious: for ≈øo in dede it is. For when we ≈øtande in a doubt whether God be our father, we cannot bee thankefull to GOD, we cannot hartelye praye or thynke any thyng we doe, acceptable to God, we cannot loue our neighboures and geue ouer our ≈øelues to care for them and do for them as we ≈øhould do, and therfore SathaÃÑ is mo≈øt ≈øubtile hereaboutes, knowyng full well that if we doubte of Gods fatherlye eternall mercies towardes vs through Chri≈øt, we cannot plea≈øe god, or do any thynge as we ≈øhould do to man. Continually ca≈øteth he into our memories our imperfection, frailtye, falles and offences, that we ≈øhould doubt of gods mercye and fauour towardes vs. Therfore my good Sy≈øter, we mu≈øt not be ≈øluggi≈øh herein, but as Sathan laboureth to lo≈øen our fayth, ≈øo mu≈øte we labour to fa≈øten it by thynkyng on the promi≈øes and couenaÃÑt of God in Chri≈øtes blood, namely that god is our god wyth all that euer he hathe: which couenaunt dependeth and hangeth vpon gods owne goodnes, mercy and truth only, and not on our obedience or worthines in any poynte, for then ≈øhould we neuer be certayne. In dede God requyreth of vs obedieÃÑce & worthines, but not that therby we might be hys chyldren and he our father, but becau≈øe he is our father and we hys chyldren through hys own goodnes in Chri≈øt, therfore requyreth he faythe and obedience. Nowe if we wante this obedience and worthynes which he requyreth, ≈øhoulde we doubt whether he be our father? Nay, that were to make our obedience and worthynes the cau≈øe, and ≈øo to put chri≈øt out of place, for who≈øe ≈øake god is our father. But rather becau≈øe he is our father and we feele our ≈øelues to wante ≈øuch things as he requireth, we ≈øhould be ≈øtyrred vp to a ≈øhamefa≈øtnes and blu≈øhyng, becau≈øe we are not as we ≈øhoulde be: and therupon ≈øhould we take occa≈øion to goe to our father in prayer on thys manner: Deare father thou of thyne own mercy in Chri≈øt ha≈øt cho≈øen me to be thy childe, and therfore
thou woulde≈øt I ≈øhould be brought into thy church, & fayth full company of thy chyldren, wherin thou ha≈øt kept me hetherto, thy name therfore be pray≈øed. Now I ≈øee my ≈øelfe to wante fayth, hope, loue, &c. which thy children haue & thou require≈øt of me, where throughe the deuyll would haue me to doubte, yea vtterlye to di≈øpayre of thy fatherly goodnes, fauour, and mercy. Therfore I come to thee as to my mercifull father through thy deare ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and pray thee to helpe me good Lord, helpe me, and geue me faythe, hope, loue, &c. and graunt that thy holy ≈øpirite may be with me for euer, and more and more to a≈ø≈øure me that thou arte my father: that thys mercifull couenaunt thou made≈øt with me in re≈øpecte of thy grace in Chri≈øt and for Chri≈øt, and not in re≈øpecte of any my worthines, is alwayes true to me, &c.

On thys ≈øorte (I ≈øay) you mu≈øt praye and v≈øe your cogitations when Sathan woulde haue you to doubte of ≈øaluation. He doth all he can to preuaile herein. Do you al you can to preuaile herein again≈øt him. Though you feele not as you would, yet doubt not, but hope beyonde all hope, as Abraham did. Fayth always (as I ≈øaid) goeth before feeling. As certayne as god is almighty, as certayn as god is mercifull, as certayne as god is true, as certayne as Chri≈øt was crucifyed, is ry≈øen, and ≈øytteth on the ryght hand of the father: as certayne as this is gods commaundement, I am the Lord thy god: ≈øo certayne oughte you to be that God is your father. As you are bound to haue none other gods but him, ≈øo are you no le≈ø≈øe bounde to beleue that god is your God. What profyte ≈øhould it be to you to beleue thys to be true: I am the Lord thy god, to others, yf you ≈øhoulde not beleue that this is true to your ≈øelfe? The Deuil beleueth on this ≈øorte. And what≈øoeuer it bee that woulde moue you to doubte of thys, whether god be your god through Chri≈øt, that ≈øame commeth vndoubtedlye of the Deuyll. Wherfore dyd GOD make you, but becau≈øe he loued you? Myghte not he haue made you blynde, dumme, deafe, lame, frantyke &c? Myghte not he haue made you a Iewe, a Turke, a Papi≈øte &c? And whye hathe he not done ≈øo? Verelye becau≈øe he loued you. And whye dydde
he loue you? What was there in you to moue hym to loue you? Surelye nothing moued hym to loue you, & therfore to make you, and ≈øo hetherto to kepe you, but hys owne goodnes in Chri≈øt. Now then in that his goodnes in Chri≈øt ≈øtyll remayneth as much as it was: Eccle. 2. that is, euen as great as him ≈øelfe, for it cannot be le≈ø≈øoned, how ≈øhould it be but that he is your god and father? Beleue this, beleue this my good Si≈øter, for god is no chaungeling: them whome he loueth, he he loueth to the ende.

Ca≈øte therefore youre ≈øelfe wholye vppon hym, and thynke without al waueryng that you are gods child, that you are a citizen of heaueÃÑ, that you are the daughter of god, the temple of the holye Gho≈øte &c. If hereof you bee a≈ø≈øured, as you ought to be, then ≈øhall your con≈øcience be quieted, then ≈øhall you lament more and more that you wante many thynges whiche god loueth, then ≈øhall you labour to bee holye in ≈øoule and bodye, then ≈øhall you goe aboute that Gods glorye maye ≈øhyne in you in all youre wordes and workes, then ≈øhal you not bee afraid what man can do vnto you, then ≈øhall you haue ≈øuch wi≈øedome to aun≈øwer your aduer≈øaries, as ≈øhal ≈øerue to their ≈øhame and your comfort, then ≈øhall you be certayne that no man can touch one heare of your heade further then ≈øhall plea≈øe your good father to your euerla≈øtyng ioye, then ≈øhall you be mo≈øt certayne that god as your good father, wyl be more carefull for your children and make better proui≈øion for them, yf all you haue were gone, then you can, then ≈øhall you (beyng a≈ø≈øured I ≈øay of gods fauour towards you) geue ouer your ≈øelf wholye to helpe and care for others that be in neede, then ≈øhall you contempne this life, and de≈øyre to be at home with your good and ≈øweete father, then ≈øhall you labour to mortify all thynges that woulde ≈øpot eyther ≈øoule or bodye. All the≈øe thynges ≈øpryng out of thys certayne per≈øwa≈øion and fayth that god is our father, and we are hys children by Chri≈øte Ie≈øus. All thynges ≈øhould helpe our fayth herein: but Sathan goeth about in all thynges to hynder vs. Therfore let vs v≈øe earne≈øt and harty prayer. Let vs ofteÃÑ remember this couenaunt, I am the Lorde thy god: let vs looke vpon Chri≈øte and his precious bloud ≈øhed for the ob≈øignation and confyrmation
of this couenant. Let vs remember all the free promi≈øes of the go≈øpell: let vs ≈øet before vs gods benefites generallie in making this worlde, in ruling it, in gouernyng it, in calling and keping his church &c. Let vs ≈øet before vs gods benefites perticulerly, how he hath made vs creatures after his image: howe he hath made vs of perfecte limmes, forme, beautie, memorye &c: howe he hath made vs Chri≈øtians, and geuen vs a right iudgement in hys religion: howe he hath euer ≈øithen we were borne, ble≈ø≈øed, kept, noury≈øhed and defended vs: how he hath often beaten, cha≈øti≈øed and fatherly corrected vs: how he hath ≈øpared vs and doth nowe ≈øpare vs, geuing vs time, ≈øpace, place, grace. Thys if you do and v≈øe earne≈øt prayer, and ≈øo flye from all thynges whiche might wound your con≈øcience, geuing your ≈øelf to diligence in your vocation: you ≈øhall finde at the length that (whiche god graunte to me with you) a ≈øure certaintye of ≈øaluation, without all ≈øuch doubt as may trouble the peace of con≈øcience, to your eternall ioy and comfort, Amen, Amen.

div.head: An other letter full of Godly comforte written to the ≈øame per≈øon.
div.p: THe good ≈øpirite of God whiche guideth hys children, bee with you my good ≈øi≈øter in the Lord for euer, Amen.

Althoughe, as I to you, ≈øo you vnto me in per≈øon are vnknowen, yet to hym whom we de≈øire to plea≈øe, we are not onely in per≈øons, but al≈øo in harts knoweÃÑ & throughly ≈øene. And therfore as for his ≈øake you wold by yt you ≈øent, of me be perceaued how that in God you beare to me a good will: ≈øo, that I to you myght be ≈øene in God to beare you the lyke, I ≈øende to you the≈øe fewe woordes in writinge, wy≈øhing that in all youre doinges and ≈øpeache, yea euen in your very thoughtes, you woulde laboure to feele that they are all pre≈øente and open before the ≈øyghte of GOD, be they good or badde Thys
cogitation ofteÃÑ had in mind, and prayer made to god for the working of his ≈øpirit, thereby (as a meane) you ≈øhall at the leÃÑgth fele more comfort & coÃÑmodity, theÃÑ any man can know but ≈øuch as be exerci≈øed therin. Howbeit this is to be added, that in thinking your ≈øelf & al that you haue, & doe, to be in ye ≈øight of god: this (I ≈øay) is to be added that you thinke his ≈øihht is the ≈øight, not only of a Lorde, but rather of a father, which teÃÑdreth more your infirmaties theÃÑ you can tender the infirmities of any your childreÃÑ. Yea wheÃÑ in your ≈øelf you ≈øee a motherly affection to your little one that is weake: let the ≈øame be vnto you a trace to traint you to ≈øee ye vn≈øpeakeable kinde affectioÃÑ of god your father towards you. And therfore vpoÃÑ ye coÃÑ≈øideratioÃÑ of your infirmities & natural euils, which coÃÑtinually cleaue vnto vs, take occa≈øioÃÑ to go to god as your father through Chri≈øt, & before his mercifull harte lay open your infirmities & euils, wt de≈øire of pardoÃÑ & helpe after his good wil & plea≈øure, but in his time & not when you wil, & by what meanes he wil, not that way yt you woulde: in the meane ≈øea≈øon haÃÑge on hope of his fatherly goodnes, & ≈øurely you ≈øhal neuer be a≈øhamed. For if a womaÃÑ that is natural can not finally forget ye child of her woÃÑbe, be ≈øure god which is a father ≈øupernatural, can not, nor wil not forget you. Yea if a womaÃÑ could be ≈øo forgetful, E≈øaye. 4 ‚Ä¢ . yet god him ≈øelf ≈øaith, he wil not be ≈øo. This opinioÃÑ, yea rather certain per≈øua≈øion of god your father through chri≈øt, ≈øee yt you cheri≈øh, & by al meanes, a≈øwel by diligente con≈øideration of his benefites, as of hys louing corrections, whether they be inwarde or outwarde, ≈øee that you nouri≈øhe, knowing for certaine that as the deuill goeth about nothing ≈øo much as to bring you in a doubt whether you be gods childe or no: ≈øo what≈øoeuer ≈øhal moue you to admit that dubitation, be a≈ø≈øured the ≈øame to come froÃÑ the deuill. If you fele in your ≈øelf not only the want of good things, but al≈øo pleÃÑtie of euil, do not therfore doubt whether you be gods child in chri≈øt or no. For if for your goodnes, or ilne≈ø≈øe ≈øake, which you feele or feele not, you ≈øhold beleue or doubt, theÃÑ ≈øhould you make Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, for who≈øe ≈øake only god is your father, eyther nothiÃÑg, or els but a half Chri≈øt. But rather take occa≈øion of your wantes in good, & of your
plenty in euil, to go to god as to youre Father, & to pray him that in as much as he commaundeth you to beleue yt he is your God and Father: ≈øo he would geue you his good ≈øpiryte, yt you myght feele ye ≈øame, & liue as hys child to his glorye: & cea≈øe not vpoÃÑ ≈øuch prayers to loke for coÃÑfort in Gods good tyme, ≈øtil hopyng ye be≈øte & reiectyng al dubitatioÃÑ, & ≈øo al euil works words & cogitations, as ye Lorde ≈øhall enable you by hys good ≈øpirit & grace, which I be≈øech hym to geue vnto you, my good≈øi≈øter for euer. And further I praye you that as he hath made you to be a helper vnto your hu≈øbaÃÑd, ≈øo you wold endeuour your ≈øelf therin to ≈øhew ye ≈øame a≈øwel in ≈øoule as body: and begge grace of god, that your endeuours may be effectual to both your coÃÑfortes in Chri≈øt, AmeÃÑ.

Deare brother, god mo≈øt iu≈øtly hath ca≈øte me now into a dungeon but much better then I de≈øerue: wherin I ≈øee no maÃÑ but my keper, nor can ≈øee any except they come to me.
