div.head: To Mai≈øtres I. H. a faythfull woman and fearyng God, whom he exhorteth to bee pacient vnder the cro≈ø≈øe & not to feare death.
div.p:
MY dearly beloued, I be≈øech our mercifull father to comfort your heauie and pen≈øiue hart with his own coÃÑ≈øolations in Chri≈øt, as I am a≈ø≈øured he will in his good time: which with pacience loke for (good ≈øi≈øter) after the example of Iob, Iames. 5. Helias, AbrahaÃÑ, and al the deare Sainctes of God, whiche are ≈øet forth vnto vs for patrons of pacience: god graunte vs well to cutte oure clothe after them, for God is the ≈øame God nowe, and the ende will ≈øhewe that he is a mercifull Lorde and full of compa≈ø≈øion. My deare ≈øi≈øter you ≈øhall vnfaynedly feele it at the length, though pre≈øently it ≈øemeth otherwi≈øe vnto your ≈øen≈øe: you ≈øhall, after you be a litle exerci≈øed herein, Heb. 12 finde a quiet fruite of righteou≈ønes, the God of grace which hath called you vnto hys eternal glorye, confirming & ≈øtrengthning you, being ≈øome deale afflicted wt your brethren and ≈øi≈øters that be in the worlde,1. pet. 5 for alone you ≈øuffer not as I tru≈øte you knowe. It comforted me to reade in your letters that no di≈øplea≈øure of father, mother, hu≈øband, children &c. doth moue you to be ruled after the coun≈øell of the worlde, and therefore you will me not to bee afearde for you. Oh my beloued what thankes ≈øhoulde I geue to our god and deare father for thys hys excedyng kindenes towards you? His name be magnified for you for euer: his mercy be more and more multiplyed vnto you, in you & vpon you for euer and euer, Amen. God make me thankefull herefore. But you adde that ye feare of death doth now and then moue you a little. Howbeit you ≈øaye, that as I haue coun≈øeyled you, you wyll ≈øtryue there agayn≈øte. My good Ioyce I take you at your woorde, keepe promy≈øe I praye you, that is, ≈øtryue agayn≈øte it, and I promy≈øe
you in the name of the Lord, that you ≈øhall haue the victorie, which I woulde wi≈øhe you to ≈øet before your eyes al≈øo, & ≈øo ≈øhall the terrour of death trouble you the le≈ø≈øe. Souldiers goinge to warre, ≈øet not before their eyes ≈øimplye the ≈øtripe, but rather the victorye: and my good ≈øi≈øter will not you herein followe them? In your trauaile with childe doth not the hope of the babe to be deliuered, mitigate the maladye? Doth not the ≈øicke in taking bitter and loth≈øome Phi≈øicke ≈øet before him the commoditie which wil en≈øue? And my deare ≈øi≈øter, wil not you by the≈øe be ≈øomthing enformed? Con≈øider what this life is: con≈øider what death is: con≈øider what is prepared for you after death. Concerning thys life, you knowe that it is full of mi≈øerye, vanitie and woe: it is a playne exile and hath nothing in it permanente. It is therfore compared to a vapor, to a ≈ømoke, to a ≈øhadowe, yea to a warrefare, a wildernes, a vale of wretchednes, wherein we are compafed on euery ≈øide with mo≈øte fearce and fearefull enemyes: and ≈øhoulde we de≈øire to dwell here? Should we lu≈øt to liue in this loth≈øome and laborious life? Shoulde we wy≈øhe to tarrie in thys wretchednes? Shoulde we haue plea≈øure to remaine in thys perillous ≈øtate? Daniells denne is not ≈øo dreadfull as is this dongeon we dwell in.

Concerning death to them that be (as I knowe you are) Gods deare children, my tenderlye beloued ≈øi≈øter, what other thynge is it then the di≈øpatcher of all di≈øplea≈øure, the ende of al trauaile, the doore of de≈øires, the gate of gladnes, the porte of parady≈øe, the hauen of heauen, the rayle of re≈øte and quietnes, the entraunce to felicitie, the beginnyng of all bli≈øfulnes. It is the very bedde of doune (and therefore wel compared to a ≈øleepe) for the doulefull bodies of Gods people to re≈øte in, oute of the whiche they ≈øhall ri≈øe and awake mo≈øte fre≈øhe and lu≈øtye to life euerla≈øting. It is a pa≈ø≈øage to the Father, a chariot to heauen, the Lordes me≈ø≈øenger, a leader vnto Chri≈øt, a going to oure home, a deliueraunce from bondage and pri≈øon, a dimi≈ø≈øion from warre, a ≈øecuritie from all ≈øorrowes, and a manumi≈ø≈øion from all mi≈øerye. So that the very heathen dyd in ≈øome places cau≈øe the daye of their death to be celebrated with myrth, melody and min≈øtrel≈øie,
and ≈øhould we be di≈ømayde at it? Shoulde we be afrayde of it? Should we tremble to heare of it? Should ≈øuch a frend as it is, be vnwelcome? Should the foulnes of hys face feare vs from his good conditions? Should the hardenes of his hu≈øke hinder vs from his ≈øwete cornell? Shoulde the roughnes of ye tide tie vs to the bancke and ≈øhore, there to be drowned, rather then the de≈øire of oure home dryue vs to go aburde? Shoulde the hardnes of the ≈øaddle ≈øet vs on our feete to peri≈øh by the waye, rather then to leape vp and endure the ≈øame a litle, and ≈øo to be where we woulde be?

Concerning that which is prepared for you after death, if I ≈øhoulde go about to expre≈ø≈øe it, the more I ≈øhould ≈øo do, the further I ≈øhould be from it. For the eye hath not ≈øeene, neither the eare hath heard, nor the harte of man is able to conceaue in any poynte, the ioye, myrth, melodye, plea≈øure, power, welth, riches, honour, beautie, fellow≈øhippe, deynties, odours, glorye, wi≈øedome, knowledge, threa≈øures, ≈øecuritie, peace, quietnes and eternall felicitie, which you ≈øhal haue and enioye world without ende, with God ye Father, the Sonne, and the holy Gho≈øt, with the Aungels, Archangels, with the Patriarckes and Prophetes, with the Apo≈øtles and Euangeli≈øtes, with the Martyrs and Confe≈ø≈øors, and with all the Saintes of God in the Palace of the Lorde in heauen, the kingdome of God, the glorye of the Father. Oh woe to the blyndnes of our eyes that ≈øee not this: Woe to the hardnes of our hartes that feele not this: Woe to the deafnes of our eares that heare not thys in ≈øuche ≈øort as we ≈øhould do: wherthrough we might be ≈øo farre from fearyng death, that rather we ≈øhoulde wi≈øh it, crying with Simeon: Now let thy ≈øeruaunt depart in peace: With Paul, I de≈øire to be de≈øoulued and to be with Chri≈øt: With Dauid, when ≈øhall I come and appeare before thee? And agayne: Oh woe is me that my habitation is thus prolonged &c. P≈øa. 119. But halas deare ≈øi≈øter, great is oure vnbeliefe. Full faynte is oure fayth, or elles nyghte and daye teares ≈øhoulde be oure bread and drinke, P≈øal. 41. while≈øt it is ≈øayde vnto vs, where is your GOD? It is a token of little loue to God, to bee loth to goe vnto hym when he calleth. If my deare≈øt frende, of a
≈øpeciall fauoure and tender good will, ≈øhoulde ≈øende a hor≈øe for me to come vnto hym, ≈øhoulde I bee di≈øplea≈øed thereat? yea ≈øhoulde I not bee willynge and gladde to come vnto hym? And halas, yet if death the Lordes palfreye, the Lordes me≈ø≈øenger ≈øhoulde come, I thynke I ≈øhould not bee ≈øo readye, but be fearefull as you fore≈øee your ≈øelfe to be. Wherethroughe I doubte not but you take occa≈øion to lament the weakenes of youre fayth, and ≈øeeing your neede, to prepare for remedye agayn≈øte the tyme of nede, and to begge of GOD hys ayde, ≈øtrength and comforte agayn≈øte that pintche, whiche vndoubtedly you ≈øhall haue, and fynde hys promy≈øe true, that in an acceptable tyme he heard your prayer. Suche as I am, haue no ≈øuche fore≈øighte of death, and therefore are le≈ø≈øe pre≈øentlye di≈ømayde, which wil turne to oure greater griefe in the plunge, ≈øaue that for my part, I hope he will neuer tempte me further then he will make me hable to beare. Into hys handes I offer my ≈øelfe, be≈øechyng hym for hys Chri≈øtes ≈øake to keepe me ≈øoule and bodye to hys kyngdome and glorye, and to lead me, order me, and di≈øpo≈øe me as he will in all thynges, in all places and for euer, that at the length I may come whether I wil, that is into hys owne ble≈ø≈øed pre≈øence and fruition of immortalitie with you and hys Sainctes, Amen. Thus muche I thoughte good to write vnto you for thys pre≈øente, to occa≈øion you the le≈ø≈øe to feare death, which eyther needeth not or boteth not: and therefore euen rea≈øonable men, muche more ≈øpiritual meÃÑ, labour to ≈øtriue again≈øt the feare of that which they can by no meanes auoyd. But of thys hereafter I tru≈øt mouth to mouth to ≈øpeake with you. Now as to my ≈øoule, I praye and wy≈øhe vnto you my mo≈øt deare ≈øi≈øter in ye Lord, who≈øe grace guyde you, and his mercy embrace you on euery ≈øide for euer, Amen.

div.head: To my good frend in God Maister Humphrey Hales.
div.p: AS to my deare frend, I wi≈øhe vnto you geÃÑ tle mai≈øter Hales, health of ≈øoule and bodye to Gods glorye and your euerla≈øting comforte, Amen.

Although it be commonly ≈øpoken and as commonly verifyed, that ≈øeldome ≈øeene is ≈øoone forgotten: yet it is not ≈øo commonly ≈øeene or experienced amonges them, who≈øe frend≈øhip is in God the Father throughe Chri≈øt, as oures is, but in tho≈øe who≈øe frend≈øhip is begonne in re≈øpect of ≈øome earthly commoditie. And therfore le≈øte I ≈øhould incurre thys ≈øu≈øpition at your hands, which haue ≈øo many wayes de≈øerued the coÃÑ trary, I thought it my duty to refre≈øh (if it nede refre≈øhing) the amitie in God begonne betwixt vs, which I doubte not ≈øhall continue ≈øo long as we liue, or elles I would be ≈øorie. In con≈øideration whereof, both mindefull of my promy≈øe made vnto you, and careful for your ≈øafetye, I haue cau≈øed a place to be prouided for your wiues deliueraunce, where ≈øhe may ≈øo quietly and ≈øafely remaine, that for the auoyding of the perilles and daungers of the≈øe dayes. I ≈øee none more conueniente: I meane it in Hadley at D. Taylours hou≈øe, where I tru≈øt there is no peril to you ward nor to any that feareth or regardeth any perill that thereby maye happen. And herein of very loue and good wil I am the more familiar and bolde to admoni≈øh you, not as di≈øtru≈øting you (god forbid, for I thynke of you as of a very childe of god) but as one carefull for you, le≈øt you ≈øhoulde at length throughe the common infirmitie of our fraile fle≈øh & the manifold offeÃÑces geueÃÑ of the world, do exteriourly as the world doth, to ≈øaue your ≈øleue and maime your arme for euer: as tho≈øe do which for the ≈øauing of their goods, ieoperde goodes of bodye and ≈øoule in the peril of eternall dampnation. If I ≈øu≈øpected any ≈øuch thing in you (gentle mai≈øter Hales) I then would goe aboute to tell you what this life is: a ≈ømoke, a ≈øhadow, a vapoure &c. what the glorye of thys life is: gra≈ø≈øe, haye: yea how full of mi≈øery it is, and hath more allowes then honye Iob. 9. If I ≈øu≈øpected any thyng your coÃÑ≈øcience, I wold theÃÑ ≈øet before you on ye one part ye iudgemeÃÑt of Chri≈øt which ≈øhal be mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly, ye terrible ≈øenteÃÑce to theÃÑ which ar a≈øhamed
to confe≈ø≈øe his go≈øpell: the eternall woe and my≈øerye whiche they ≈øhalbe ca≈øt into that will not obey his go≈øpel here: and on the other parte, the mo≈øt plea≈øant ≈øhoute of the Angell to ≈øummon all men to come before oure captaine and brother Chri≈øt, the collectioÃÑ and catchyng of vs vp in the cloudes to mete our mai≈øter, the eternall ioye and felicitie whiche we ≈øhall receaue that here confe≈ø≈øe hym, here ≈øuffer wyth hym, here lo≈øe any thyng for hys ≈øake. If I did in any poynte ≈øo much as thynke that you would defyle your body in the Antichri≈øtian ≈øeruice nowe v≈øed, then would I go about to ≈øet forth the≈øe thinges briefly, ≈øpoken more at large. But as I ≈øayd before I ≈øay agayne, becau≈øe I am as wel per≈øwaded of you (my derely beloued brother) as of any in your profe≈ø≈øion & ≈øtate: I caÃÑnot but pray god to make perfect ye good which he hath begun in you, and de≈øyre you, as you haue begon in god, ≈øo to go forward. As your exaÃÑple hath done good to many, ≈øo ca≈øt not al down wt a type. Terrible is that wo which Chri≈øt threatneth to them by whome offences do come. You know yt the way to ≈øaluation is ≈øtraiter then men make it. You knowe the ≈øoule is to be con≈øidered aboue all thyngs. Happy is the lo≈ø≈øe of that bodily lyfe, liberty and goods, by the which a ≈øpiritual life, fredome and felicity is purcha≈øed. What ≈øhould it profit a man to winne the whole world and to lo≈øe hys own ≈øoule? Who would de≈øire a two yeres mery lyfe for an eternall ≈øorrowe? as the≈øe ma≈ø≈øe go≈øpellers doe, which yet are vncertaine of two yeres lyfe, and god knoweth what woundes their con≈øciences haue. Hard is it to recouer health to the con≈øcience: and becau≈øe I am carefull for it to you wardes, as to mine own brother and dere frende, therfore I wryte thus. We are in gods power and not in the power of our enemies: he it is that hath all our heares numbred: before he ≈øaye Amen, no man ≈øhall once touche you. Into hys handes committe your ≈øelfe: ca≈øt your care on hym, haue a care to plea≈øe hym, & then he wyll care to kepe you. You knowe the othe the Athenien≈øes dyd make: pugnabo pro ≈øacris, & ≈øolus & cum alijs. I wyll fyghte for the defence of religion both alone and with others. Which ≈øaying of the heathen wil be to our condemnation, if for his holy worde & go≈øpels ≈øake we dare not aduenture the lo≈ø≈øe of that he hath lent vs, kepeth for vs, and can when he will take away from vs, or
vs from it. If worldly men dare ieopard a iointe with god, rather then they would lo≈øe worldlye thinges (as experieÃÑce teacheth) certeinly it ≈øhould be muche to our ≈øhame, which in Bapti≈øme haue vowed and ≈øolempnely ≈øworn to for≈øake the world, if we dare not ieoperd a iointe wyth man, rather then we woulde lo≈øe a good con≈øcience and ≈øpirituall trea≈øures. He that will not haue gods ble≈ø≈øyng, it ≈øhall be taken from him, ≈øayeth Dauyd.

Therfore (my derely beloued) beware: you are now the temple of the holy gho≈øt, defile it not for the lordes ≈øake, but kepe it pure, not only from all vncleannes of the ≈øpirit, but al≈øo of the fle≈øh. 2. Cor. 7. as I tru≈øt you wil: and crye vppon your father for his ≈øtrength and ayde, which I be≈øeche him of his mercy alwais to geue vnto you, my own good frend, euen as I de≈øyre to my ≈øelfe. If in any thyng I could helpe you, you may be as a≈ø≈øured thereof as of your brother. My prayer to god nyght and day you ≈øhall haue, that for his holy names ≈øake he would ble≈ø≈øe you in al thinges & kepe you, with my good ≈øy≈øter your wyfe, vnto the verye ende, as hys deare elect children, Amen, Amen. From my lodging you knowe where thys v. of Augu≈øt.

div.head: ¬∂An other letter to Mai≈øter Humfrey Hales and his VVyfe.
div.p: THe euerliuing & merciful god our deare father through Chri≈øt, be with you both my mo≈øt dearely and entierly beloued in the Lorde, now and for euer.

I cannot forbeare but ≈øignify vnto you both, that my hart is carefull and heauy for the cro≈ø≈øe which is come vpon you by the heauy and feareful iudgement of god fallen vpon your father iu≈øtly for his denying of god for feare of men & loue of the≈øe things, which he hath left behind him vnto you & others. God graunt his fact be ≈øo imprinted in the hartes of al men, e≈øpecially of you both, that his fall maye be vnto you, I wil not ≈øay ari≈øing (for yet I tru≈øt ye are not fallen)
but an e≈øtabli≈øhing in the veritie of god, whereof who ≈øo is a≈øhamed, ≈øhal at length feele ≈øuch ≈øhame as I be≈øeche God kepe vs all from. Happy are they that marke the iudgemeÃÑts of god vpon other to come and encrea≈øe in repentance, Luke 13. to feare gods wrath and iudgements, which is alwayes lyke hym≈øefe, if we follow the ≈øteppes of them on whom he taketh puni≈øhment. I nede not to tell you the cau≈øe of thys that hath happened vnto your father, if it be as I with ≈øorrow haue heard. For you know wel enough that tyl he for≈øoke god, gaue eare to the Serpents couÃÑ≈øel, began to mamber of the truth, & to frame hym≈øelfe outwardly to doe that which his con≈øcience reproued inwardly (for that which he myngled with the loue of god, I meane the loue of ye world, cannot be in any man without the expul≈øion of gods loue) til then. I ≈øay, god did not departe and leaue him to him≈øelfe to the example of you and me and al others, that we ≈øhould feare euen our ≈øelues and our owne handes more then man & all the powers of the world, yf we therfore ≈øhould do any thing which ≈øhould wouÃÑd our con≈øcieÃÑce. The con≈øcieÃÑce (I tel you) is ≈øone wouÃÑded, yea ≈øoner theÃÑ we beware of. The deuil v≈øeth al kind of de≈øceite to blynd vs from ≈øeyng that whiche might wound it: but when the ≈øtripe is geuen, then eyther ≈øhutteth he ≈øtil vp our eies with contempt to our hardning, or els openeth theÃÑ to bring vs to vtter di≈øpairing. In your father, as ye may ≈øee ye later, ≈øo in many worldlye go≈øpellers you maye (if you will) ≈øee the other. God might deale with al ≈øuch, as he hath done now with your father: but becau≈øe ye time of his iudgement is not yet come, his wi≈øedome hath thought good to ≈øet your father forth as an exaÃÑple to al meÃÑ: as he did in the fir≈øt world Cain, in the .2. worlde Cham, in the .3. age Chore &c. in chri≈øtes tyme Iudas, in the Apo≈øtels time Ananias &c. althoughe none wil hartely coÃÑ≈øider it, but ≈øuch as be gods children in dede.

But heare in comparyng your father thus (my derelye and vnfaynedlye beloued in the Lorde) I mu≈øte praye you not to bee offended, or thynke that I doe de ‚Ä¢ ermynatelye iudge (to God I leaue all iudgement) but becau≈øe the fruite to vs declareth no le≈ø≈øe, to the admoni≈øhment of vs all, I tru≈øt ye wyll accordyngly con≈øider my collation. For your partes as I thynke godly of you both, yt in dede
ye are bothe the the children of god: ≈øo I pray you comforte your≈øelues as Dauyd dyd, though hys ≈øonne Ab≈øolon peri≈øhed ≈øo de≈øperately, and thoughe hys father in lawe Achitophell‚ñ™ father to Beth≈øabe as the Hebrewes wryte, pery≈øhed ≈øo mi≈øerablye. Ye knowe Ionathas was not the wor≈øe becau≈øe hys father ≈ølew hym≈øelfe, nor Beth≈øabe becau≈øe of her father Achitophel: they bothe were the children of god, and ≈øo I am a≈ø≈øured (as man can bee) that ye are. As they v≈øed gods iudgements vppon their parentes, ≈øo doe ye, to feare god and loue god the more & to flye froÃÑ tho≈øe things which in your father ye dyd ≈øee di≈øplea≈øed God. Oh that I were with you but one halfe houre, not only with you to lament, but al≈øo as god ≈øhould lend me hys grace, to comforte you, who by thys iudgement doth tempt your patieÃÑce & faith to ye coÃÑfort of you both, as you ≈øhal find, I am a≈ø≈øured. My dere hartes in the lord, if I could by any meanes comforte you, certainly if my lyfe lay on it, I thynke you ≈øhould forthwith perceiue it: but becau≈øe I can do no more then I can, therefore as I can I do, that is, as to wryte, ≈øo to ≈øend this me≈ø≈øeÃÑ ger my good frend and brother with the ≈øame, to learne certainly the truth herein and the conditioÃÑ of your e≈øtate. My other letter was made before I knewe of thys matter. I pray god thys whych by reporte I vnder≈øtande, be otherwy≈øe, but gods good wyll bee done, who geue vs patience and comforte in hym. To whome I commende you bothe euen as hartelye as anye frendes I haue in thys life of your e≈øtate. From my lodging you knowe where, thys eight of Augu≈øt. Anno Domini. 1554.

div.head: ¬∂To certayne of hys faythfull frendes in God, exhortyng them to bee ioyfull vnder the cro≈ø≈øe as a token of gods ≈øynguler fauour towardes them.
div.p:
GOd our deare and mo≈øt merciful father through Chri≈øte, be wyth you my good brother and Sy≈øter, as wyth hys
children for eÃÑuer, and in all thynges ≈øo guide you wyth hys holy ≈øpirite the leader of his people, as may be to his glory and your owne euerla≈øting ioye and comfort in him, Amen.

Becau≈øe I haue often tymes receyued from eyther of you comfort corporally (for the which I be≈øech the Lord, as to make me thankefull, ≈øo to recompence you both now and eternally) I cannot but go about (lord helpe hereto for thy mercies ≈øake) to wryte ≈øomthyng for your comfort ≈øpirituly. My dearely beloued, looke not vpon the≈øe dayes and the afflictions of the ≈øame here with vs ≈øimply as they ≈øeme vnto you: that is, as di≈ømall dayes, and dayes of gods vengeance, but rather as lucky dayes, and daies of gods fatherlye kindnes towardes you, and ≈øuch as ye be, that is, towardes ≈øuch as repent their ≈øynnes and euyll lyfe pa≈øt, and earne≈øtly purpo≈øe to ameÃÑd, walking not after the wil of the world, as ye mo≈øt part of men do for the pre≈øeruation of theyr pelfe, which wyl they, nyll they, they ≈øhal leaue ≈øooner or later, & to whome, or how it ≈øhall be v≈øed they know not. In deede to ≈øuche as walke in their wickednes and wynde on wyth the world, this time is a tyme of wrath and vengeance and their begynnyng of ≈øorrowe is but nowe, becau≈øe they contempne the phi≈øike of theyr father, which by the≈øe purgyng tyme and clean≈øing dayes would worke their weale, which they wil not: and becau≈øe they will not haue gods ble≈ø≈øynge which both wayes he hath offred vnto them, by pro≈øperity and aduer≈øity: therfore it ≈øhall bee kept farre enoughe from them: as when the ≈øycke man wil no kynd of phi≈øike at the handes of the phi≈øicion, he is left alone and ≈øo the malady encrea≈øeth and de≈øtroieth him at the length. To ≈øuche men in dede the≈øe dayes are and ≈øhoulde bee doleful daies, daies of woe and weepyng, becau≈øe their damnation draweth nigh. But vnto ≈øuch as be penitent, and are de≈øirous to liue after the Lordes wyll, (amongs whom I doe not onely compte you, but as farre as man may iudge I knowe ye are) vnto ≈øuch, I ≈øay, this tyme is and ≈øhould be comfortable. For fir≈øt nowe youre father cha≈øti≈øeth you and me for our ≈øynnes, for the whiche yf he would haue de≈øtroyed vs, then woulde he haue letten vs alone, & left vs to our ≈øelues in nothing to take to harte his fatherly vi≈øitation, whiche here it plea≈øeth
hym to woorke pre≈øentlye, becau≈øe el≈øewhere he wyll not remember oure tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, as Paule writeth: he cha≈øti≈øeth vs in the world, lea≈øt with the worlde we ≈øhoulde peri≈øhe.

Therefore my deare hartes, call to mynd youre ≈øinnes to lamente them and to a≈øke mercye for them in hys ≈øyghte, and wythall vndoubtedlye beeleue to obteine pardon and a≈ø≈øured forgeuenes of the ≈øame, for twi≈øe the Lorde puni≈øheth not for one thynge. So that I ≈øaye, fir≈øte we haue cau≈øe to reioyce for the≈øe dayes becau≈øe our father ≈øuffereth vs not to lye in Ie≈øabels bedde ≈ølepyng in oure ≈øynnes and ≈øecuritye, but as myndefull on vs dothe correcte vs as his children: whereby we maye bee certayne that we be no ba≈øtardes but children, for he cha≈øti≈øeth euery childe whome he receyueth. So that they whyche are not pertakers of hys cha≈øti≈øing or that contempne it, declare them≈øelues to bee ba≈øtardes and not chyldren, as I knowe ye are, which as ye are cha≈øti≈øed, ≈øo doe ye take it to harte accordingly: and therefore bee gladde my deare hartes, as folkes knowynge certainlye euen by this vi≈øitation of the Lorde, that ye are his deare electe children, who≈øe faultes your father dothe vi≈øite with the rodde of correction, but hys mercy wil he neuer take away from you, P≈øal. 89. Amen.

Secondlye ye haue cau≈øe to reioyce for the≈øe dayes, becau≈øe they are dayes of triall, wherein not onely ye your ≈øelues ≈øhall better knowe your ≈øelues, but al≈øo the worlde ≈øhall knowe that ye bee none of hys but the Lordes derlynges. Before the≈øe dayes came (Lorde GOD) howe manye thoughte of them≈øelues they had bene in Gods bo≈øome, and ≈øo were taken and would be taken of the worlde, but nowe we ≈øee who≈øe they are: for to whome we obeye hys ≈øeruauntes we are. If we obey the world (whiche god forbidde and hetherto ye haue not done it) then are we the worldes: but yf we obey GOD, then are we gods. Which thynge (I meane that ye are Gods) the≈øe dayes haue declared bothe to you, to me, and to all other that knowe you, better then euer we knewe it. Therefore ye haue no cau≈øe to ≈øorrowe, but rather to ≈øyng, in ≈øeyng your ≈øelues to bee Gods babes, and in ≈øeeyng that all Gods children
doe ≈øo counte you. What thoughe the worlde repyne thereat: What thoughe he kycke? what thoughe he ≈øeeke to trouble and mole≈øte you? My deare hartes he doth but hys kynde: he cannot loue the Lorde which lyue not the Lorde: he cannot brooke the chylde that hateth the father: he cannot mynde the ≈øeruaunte that careth not for the ma ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er. If ye were of the world, the world would loue you, ye ≈øhould dwell quietlye, there woulde be no griefe, no mole≈øtation. If the deuill dwelte in you (whiche the lorde forbydde) he woulde not ≈øtyrre vp hys knyghtes to be≈øiege your hou≈øe, to ≈ønatche at your goodes, or ≈øuffer hys frendes to enter into your hogges. But becau≈øe Chri≈øt dwelleth in you (as he dothe by faythe) therefore ≈øtyrreth he vppe his fyr≈øte begotten ≈øonne the worlde, to ≈øeeke how to di≈øquiet you, to robbe you, to ≈øpoyle you, to de≈øtroye you. And perchaunce your deare father to trye and to make knowen vnto you and to the worlde that ye are de≈øtinate to an other dwellyng then here on earthe, to an other citye then mans eyes hathe ≈øene at any tyme: hathe geuen or wyll geue power to Sathan and to the world, to take from you the thynges whiche he hathe lente you, and by takyng them awaye, to trye youre fidelitie, obedience and loue towardes hym (for ye may not loue them aboue hym) as by geuynge that ye haue and keepyng it, he hathe declared hys loue towardes you. Sathan perchaunce telleth GOD (as he dydde of Iob) that ye loue GOD for youre goodes ≈øake. What nowe then, yf the Lorde to trye you wyth Iob, ≈øhall geue hym power on youre goodes and bodye accordynglye, ≈øhoulde ye bee di≈ømayed? Should ye di≈øpayre? Should ye bee faynte harted? Shoulde ye not rather reioyce as dyd the Apo≈øtels that they were compted worthye to ≈øuffer anye thynge for the Lordes ≈øake? Oh forgette not the ende that happened to Iob: for as it happened to him, ≈øo ≈øhal it happen vnto you: for god is the ≈øame god and can not longe forgette to ≈øhewe mercye to them that looke and longe for it, as I knowe ye do, and I praye you ≈øo to do ≈øtyll, for the Lorde loueth you, and neuer can nor wyll forgette to ≈øhewe and powre out hys mercye vppon you.
After a little whyle that he hath afflycted and tryed you (≈øaieth Peter) he will vi≈øite, comforte, and confyrme you. As to Iacob wre≈øtlyng with the aungel, at the lengthe mornyng came and the ≈øonne aro≈øe: ≈øo deare harts, doutles it wil happen vnto you. Howbeit doe ye as Iob and Iacob did, that is, order and di≈øpo≈øe your thynges that god hath lente you as ye may and whyles ye haue tyme. Who knoweth whether god hath geuen you power this long euen to that end?

Go to therfore, di≈øpo≈øe your goods, prepare your ≈øelues to tryall, that eyther ye may ≈øtande to it like gods champions, or els yf ye feele ≈øuche infirmitie in your ≈øelues that ye be not hable, geue place to violence, and go where ye maye with free and ≈øafe con≈øcience ≈øerue the lord. Thinke not this coun≈øel to come by chaunce or fortune, but to come from the Lorde: other oracles we may not looke for nowe. As God tolde Io≈øeph in a dreame by an aungel that he ≈øhoulde flye: ≈øo yf ye feele ≈øuch infirmity in your ≈øelues as ≈øhoulde turne to gods di≈øhonor and your owne de≈øtruction wythal: know that at this pre≈øent I am as gods aungel to admoni≈øh you to take tyme whyles ye haue it, and to ≈øee yt in no ca≈øe Gods name by you myghte be di≈øhonoured. Io≈øeph myghte haue obiected the omi≈ø≈øion of his vocation, as perchaunce ye wil doe: but deare hartes, let vocations and all things els geue place to gods name & the ≈øanctifyeng therof. Thys I ≈øpeak not as though I wuld not haue you rather to tary & to ≈øtaÃÑd to it, but I ≈øpeake it in re≈øpect of your infirmity, which if ye feele to bee ≈øo greate in you that ye are not certayne of thys hope that god wyll neuer tempt you aboue you hability: fly and get you hence, and know that therby god wil haue you tried to your ≈øelues & to others. For by this you ≈øhal know how to take thys world, and your home here as no home, but that ye loke for an other, and ≈øo geue occa≈øion to others, le≈ø≈øe to loue thys world, and perchaunce to ≈øome to doubte of their religion, Wherin though they be earne≈øt, yet would not they loo≈øe ≈øo much as ye do for your religion, which ye confyrme to me & others by your geuyng place to violence.

La≈øte of all, ye haue cau≈øe to reioyce ouer the≈øe daies becau≈øe they be dayes of conformation, in the which and by the which god our father maketh vs lyke to chri≈øtes image
here, that we may be like to him el≈øwhere. For if we ≈øuffer with him, we ≈øhall reigne with him: if we be buryed wt him, we ≈øhal ri≈øe with him: if we coÃÑpany with him in afflictions, we ≈øhall reioyce with him in glorye: if we ≈øowe with him in teares, we ≈øhal reape with him in gladnes: if we coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe him before men, he will confe≈ø≈øe vs before his Father in heauen: if we take his part, he will take ours: if we lo≈øe ought for his names ≈øake, he wil geue vs all thinges for his truthes ≈øake: So yt we ought to reioyce & bee glad, for it is not geueÃÑ to euery one to ≈øuffer lo≈ø≈øe of couÃÑtrey, life, goods, hou≈øe, &c. for ye Lords ≈øake. What can god the father do more vnto vs then to cal vs into campe with his ≈øonne? What may Chri≈øte our Sauiour doe more for vs then to make vs his warriours? What can the holy gho≈øt doe to vs aboue this, to marke vs with the cogni≈øaunce of the Lord of ho≈øtes? This cogni≈øance of the Lord ≈øtandeth not in forket cappes tippettes, ≈øhauen crownes or ≈øuch other baggage and antichri≈øtian pelfe, but in ≈øuffering for the Lords ≈øake. The worlde ≈øhall hate you ≈øaith Chri≈øt. Loe there is the cogni≈øance and badge of gods children, the world ≈øhal hate you. Reioyce therfore my dearly beloued, reioyce that god doth thus vouch≈øafe to beginne to conforme you and make you like to Chri≈øt. By the triall of the≈øe dayes ye are acca≈øioned more to repeÃÑt, more to pray, more to contempne this worlde, more to de≈øire life euerla≈øting, more to be holy (for holy is the ende wherfore GOD doth afflict vs) and ≈øo come to gods company. Which thing, becau≈øe we can not do as long as this body is as it is, therfore by the doore of death we mu≈øt entre with Chri≈øt into eternall life and immortalitie of ≈øoule and body: which God of his mercy ≈øend ≈øhortlye, for our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øtes ≈øake, Amen.

div.head: To myne owne deare brother Mai≈øter Laurence Saunders pri≈øoner in the Mar≈øhal≈øee.
div.p: GOds ≈øweete peace in Chri≈øte be with you, my good brother in ye Lord Ie≈øus, & with all your concaptiues, AmeÃÑ.

I was letted this morning from mu≈øing on that which I was purpo≈øed to haue thought on, by rea≈øoÃÑ of you, again≈øt whoÃÑ I ≈øawe my ≈øelfe giltie of negligence euen in this poynt that I would not write, I ≈øhould ≈øay, that I had not written vnto you as yet: therfore out of hande in maner I prepared my ≈øelfe to purge my ≈øelf hereof, not that I wil go about to excu≈øe my fault (for that were more to loade me) but by a≈øking both god and you pardon, to get it no more layde to my charge. Now then as I was thus purpo≈øing & partly doing, coÃÑmeth there one with a letter from you, for ye which as I haue cau≈øe to thanke god and you (howbeit not ≈øo that you ≈øhould thinke I geue not the whole to god) ≈øo I ≈øee my ≈øelfe more blame worthye for thus longe holding my peace. Howbeit good brother, in this I haue geuen a demon≈øtration to you, to behold my negligence in all other things, and e≈øpecially in praying for you and for ye church of god, whiche for my ≈øinnes and hypocri≈øie (hypocri≈øie in dede euen in this writing, god deliuer me from it) haue de≈øerued to bee puni≈øhed. Iu≈øt is god, for we haue de≈øerued all kindes of plaggues at his hands: but yet merciful is he yt will on thys wi≈øe cha≈øti≈øe vs with this world ne cuÃÑ muÃÑdo condeÃÑnemur. He myght otherwi≈øe haue puni≈øhed vs, I meane, he might haue for other cau≈øes ca≈øt vs in pri≈øon, me e≈øpecially, then for his go≈øpell and wordes ≈øake: Pray≈øed therfore be his name whiche voucheth vs worthy thys honour. Ah good god, forgeue vs our ≈øinnes, and worke by this thy fatherly correction on vs, on me e≈øpecially, effectually to loue thee and thy Chri≈øt: and with ioyfulnes vnto ye end to cary thy cro≈ø≈øe through thicke and thinne. Alwayes ≈øet before our eyes not this gallowes on earth if we ≈øtill ≈øticke to thee, but the gallowes in hell if we denye thee or ≈øwarne from that we haue profe≈ø≈øed. Ah good brother, if I coulde alwayes haue GOD, hys maie≈øtie, mercye, heauen, hell, &c. before mine eyes, then ≈øhould I obdurare as Paule writeth of Mo≈øes. Heb. 11. obdurauit in quit, perinde qua≈øi vidi≈øset eum qui e≈øt inui≈øibilis, Praye for me, as I know you doe, and geue thankes al≈øo for in domino ≈øpero non nutabo.

otherwi≈øe will they not rea≈øon with vs: and I thynke theyr ≈øhootanker wil be, to haue vs to ≈øub≈øcribe. Therefore let vs vadere plan√™ and ≈øo ≈øan√™, I meane, let vs all confe≈ø≈øe that we are no chaungelinges, but reip≈øa are the ≈øame we were in religion, and therefore can not ≈øub≈øcribe excepte we will di≈ø≈øemble both with God, our ≈øelues, and the world. Haec tibi ≈øcribo frater mi chari≈øime in domino. I am legam tuaÃÑ epiflolam. Ah brother that I hadde practicam tecum ≈øcientiam in vite illa quaÃÑ pingis:
Iohn. 15 roga dominum vt ita ver√™ ≈øentiam, Amen. God make me thankeful for you. Salutant te omnes coÃÑcaptiui & gratias domino pro te agunt: ideÃÑ tu facies pro nobis & ores vt &c.

div.head: An other letter to Mai≈øter Laurence Saunders.
div.p: MY good brother, I be≈øech our good god & gratious father, alwayes to coÃÑtinue his gracious fauoure and loue towardes vs, & by vs as by in≈øtrumentes of his grace, to worke hys glory & confu≈øion of his aduer≈øaryes.This frend moued them to ≈øub≈øcribe to the papi≈øtes articles wyth this conditioÃÑ, ≈øo farre as they wer not again≈øt Gods worde, being in dede cleane contrary to it: and yet ≈øhortly after he valiantly ≈øuffred death for refu≈øing the ≈øame, Ex ore infantium & lactentium fundet laudem ad de≈øtruendum inimicuÃÑ &c, AmeÃÑ.

I haue peru≈øed your letters to my ≈øelf & haue redde them to others. For an≈øwere whereof, if I ≈øhould write what D. Taylour and Mai≈øter Philpotte doe thinke, then mu≈øte I ≈øaye that they thynke the ≈øalte ≈øente vnto vs by your frende is vn≈øea≈øonable. And in deede I thynke they both wyll declare it hartelye if they ≈øhoulde come before them. As for me, if you woulde knowe what I thynke (my good and mo≈øte deare brother Laurence) becau≈øe I am ≈øo ≈øynnefull and ≈øo con≈øpurcate (the Lorde knoweth I lye not) with manye greuous ≈øinnes (whiche yet I hope are wa≈øhed

Howbeit to tel you how and what I minde, take this for a ≈øumme: I pray God in no ca≈øe I may ≈øeeke my ≈øelf. And in deede (I thanke God therfore) I purpo≈øe it not. Quod reliquum e≈øt domino Deo meo committo, & ≈øpero in illum, quod ip≈øe faciet iuxta hoc: iacta in dominum curam,
P≈øa. 54 P≈øa. 36 P≈øal. 31. &c. Omni cura ve≈øtra coniecta in illum &c. Reuela domino viam tuam & ≈øpera &c. Sperantem in domino mi≈øericordia circumdabit. I did not nor do not knowe but by youre letters quod cras, we ≈øhal come, coraÃÑ nobis. Myne owne hart, ≈øticke ≈øtil to dabitur vobis:
Math. 10. 1. Cor. 10 3. pet 2 fidelis enim e≈øt dominus, dabit in tentatione euentum quo po≈øsimus ≈øufferre. Nouit dominus pios √™ tentatione &c. O vtinam pius ego e≈øsem. Nouit dominus in die tribulationis ≈øperaÃÑtes in ≈øe &c. NahuÃÑ. 1. I can not thinke that they will offer any kinde of indifferent or meane conditions. For if we wil not adorare be≈øtiam, we neuer ≈øhall be deliuered but again≈øt their will, thinke I. div.head: A letter which he wrote to a faythfull woman in her heauines and trouble: mo≈øt comfortable for all tho≈øe that are afflicted and broken harted for their ≈øinnes.
div.p:
AH my dearly beloued, & mo≈øt dearely beloued in the Lorde, howe pen≈øiue is my harte pre≈øently for you by rea≈øoÃÑ of ye feareful iudgement of our god, which eueÃÑ now I heard for truth by Richarde Proude? God oure good father for his greate mercies ≈øake in chri≈øt, haue mercy vpoÃÑ vs, & ≈øo wt his eternal con≈øolation, comforte you (my deare harte) as I de≈øyre
in my mo≈øte nede to be of him comforted, Amen.

The cau≈øe why ≈øince the recept of your letter I haue not ≈øent vnto you, this bringer caÃÑ tel you: yea if I had not heard for truth of this heuie chaunce, as yet you had not thus ≈øone heard from me. For I beganne of late a peece of woorke for your comfort, wherof I ≈øend you now but a parte, becau≈øe my hart is heauie for your ≈øake, and I can not be quiet til I heare how you do in thys cro≈ø≈øe. Wherein (my deare ≈øi≈øter) I be≈øeche you to bee of good comforte, and to bee no more di≈øcouraged then was Dauid of Ab≈øolons death, the good Ionathas of hys father Saules fearefull ende, Adam of Cain, Noe of Cham, Iacob of Ruben, and the Godly Beth≈øabee of the terrible ende of her father or at the lea≈øte her Graundfathers death Achitophell. Not that I vtterly condempne and iudge your father (for I leaue it to God) but becau≈øe the facte of it ≈øelfe declareth Gods ≈øecrets and fearefull iudgemente and iu≈øtice towardes hym and all men, and hys greate mercye towardes vs, admoni≈øhynge all the worlde howe that he is to bee dred and feared, and Sathan not to ≈øleepe, and vs his children e≈øpeciallye, howe weake and mi≈øerable we bee of oure ≈øelues, and howe happie we are in hym, whiche haue him to bee oure father, protectour and keeper and ≈øhall haue for euer more, ≈øo that no euill ≈øhall touche vs, further then ≈øhall make to oure fathers glorye and to our euerla≈øting commoditie. And therfore let thys iudgement of God be an occa≈øioÃÑ to ≈øtirre vs vp more carefully to walke before GOD, and vnfaynedly to ca≈øte oure whole care vppon oure deare father, whiche neuer can nor will leaue vs: for hys calling and giftes be ≈øuch that he can neuer repente hym of them. Roma. 11. whom he loueth, he loueth to the ende: none of hys cho≈øen can peri≈øh. Of whiche number I knowe you are my dearely beloued ≈øi≈øter: God encrea≈øe the fayth thereof dayly more and more in you: he geue vnto you to hange wholye on hym and on hys prouidence and protection. For who ≈øo dwelleth vnder that ≈øecrete thyng, and helpe of the Lorde, P≈øa. 90.31 he ≈øhall be cocke ≈øure for euer more: he that dwelleth I ≈øaye, for if we be flitters and not dwellers (as was Loth a flitter from Segor, where GOD promi≈øed hym protection if he had
dwelled there ≈øtill) we ≈øhall remoue to oure lo≈ø≈øe as he dyd into the Mountaines, Gene≈øis. 19. Dwell therefore, that is tru≈øte and that finallye vnto the ende in the Lorde (my deare ≈øi≈øter) and you ≈øhall bee as Mounte Sion. As Mountaynes compa≈ø≈øe Ieru≈øalem, ≈øo dothe the Lorde all hys people. Howe then can he forgette you whiche are as the apple of hys eye, for hys deare ≈øonnes ≈øake? Ah deare harte, that I were nowe but one halfe houre wyth you, to bee a Simon to helpe to carye youre cro≈ø≈øe with you. GOD ≈øende you ≈øome good Simon to bee with you and helpe you. I will bee a Simon ab≈øente to carye, as I can learne, youre cro≈ø≈øe, whiche you haue promy≈øed not to hyde from me. Oh that GOD woulde hartelye touche youre hu≈øbandes harte, ≈øo that he woulde gette hym beyonde the Seas, althoughe by that meanes I ≈øhoulde neuer more, corporallye ≈øee you (as in deede I feare it, I feare it) but Gods good will bee done. I haue wrytten to hym: God for hys mercyes ≈øake tourne it to youre and hys good, Amen.

But to come agayne to that from whence I am digre≈ø≈øed, whereunto you occa≈øion me al≈øo by youre letters, complayning to me of the blyndne≈ø≈øe of youre mynde and of the trouble you feele throughe talke with ≈øome: my dearlye beloued, GOD make you thankefull for that whiche he hath geuen vnto you: he open youre eyes to ≈øee what and howe greate benefytes you haue receaued, that you maye be le≈ø≈øe couetous or rather impaciente, for ≈øo (I feare me) it ≈øhould bee called, and more thankefull. Haue not you receaued at his handes ≈øyghte to ≈øee youre blyndne≈ø≈øe, and thereto a de≈øirous and ≈øeekyng harte to ≈øee where he lyeth in the mydde day, as hys deare ≈øpou≈øe ≈øpeaketh of her ≈øelfe in the Canticles? Oh Ioyce, my good Ioyce, what a gifte is thys? Manye haue ≈øome ≈øyghte, but none thys ≈øobbing and ≈øighinge, none thys ≈øeekynge whiche you haue I knowe, but ≈øuche as he hath marryed vnto hym in hys mercyes. You are not contente to ky≈ø≈øe hys feete with the Magdalen, but you woulde bee ki≈ø≈øed euen with the ky≈ø≈øe of hys mouth. Canti. 1. You woulde ≈øee hys face wyth
Mo≈øes, forgettyng howe he biddeth vs ≈øeeke hys face, P≈øalme. 27. yea and that for euer, P≈øalme. 105. Whiche ≈øygnifyeth no ≈øuche ≈øyghte as you de≈øire, to bee in thys pre≈øente life, whiche woulde ≈øee GOD nowe face to face, where as he can not bee ≈øeene but couered vnder ≈øomethynge: yea ≈øome tyme in that whiche is (as you woulde ≈øaye) cleane contrarye to God: as to ≈øee hys mercye in hys anger: in bringyng vs to hell, fayth ≈øeeth hym bring vs to heauen: in darkene≈ø≈øe it beholdeth bryghtnes: in hydyng hys face from vs, it beholdeth hys merye countenaunce. Howe dyd Iob ≈øee God, but (as you woulde ≈øaye) vnder Sathans cloke? For who ca≈øte the fyre from heauen vppon hys goodes? Who ouerthrewe hys hou≈øe and ≈øtyrred vppe men to take awaye hys cattell but Sathan? And yet Iob pearced throughe all the≈øe and ≈øawe Gods worke, ≈øaying: the Lorde hath geuen, the Lorde hath taken awaye &c. In reading of the p≈øalmes, howe often doe you ≈øee that Dauid in the ≈øhadowe of death, ≈øawe Gods ≈øweete loue? And ≈øo (my dearelye beloued) I ≈øee that you in your darkene≈ø≈øe and dymne≈ø≈øe, by fayth doe ≈øee claritie and bryghtne≈ø≈øe: by fayth (I ≈øaye) becau≈øe fayth is of thynges ab≈øente, of thynges hoped for, of thynges whiche I appeale to your con≈øcience whether you de≈øire not. And can you de≈øire anye thyng whiche you knowe not? And is there of heauenlye things any other true knowlegde then by fayth?

Therefore my deare harte, be thankefull, for (before God I write it) you haue greate cau≈øe. Ah my Ioyce, howe happye is the ≈øtate wherein you are? Verelye you are euen in the ble≈ø≈øed ≈øtate of Gods children: for they mourne, and do not you ≈øo? and that not for worldly weale, but for ≈øpiritual riches, faythe, hope, charitie, &c. How ≈øhoulde GOD wipe awaye the teares from youre eyes in heauen, if now on earth you ≈øhed no teares? How could heauen be a place of re≈øte, if on earth you dyd finde it? talke with him as I knowe you doe, if your enemye ≈øhould ≈øleepe all daye longe? Howe ≈øhoulde you el≈øwhere be made lyke vnto Chri≈øte, I meane in ioye, if in ≈øorrowe you ≈øobbed not with hym? If you wil haue ioye and felicitie, you mu≈øte fir≈øte needes feele ≈øorrowe and mi≈øerye. If you will goe to heauen, you mu≈øt ≈øayle by hell. If you will embrace Chri≈øte in hys robes, you mu≈øte not thynke ≈øcorne of hym in hys ragges. If you will ≈øitte at Chri≈øtes table in hys kingdome you mu≈øte fyr≈øte abide with hym in hys temptations. If you will drinke of hys cuppe of glorye, for≈øake not hys cuppe of ignominye. Can the head corner ≈øtone bee reiected and the other more ba≈øe ≈øtones in Gods buildyng be in thys worlde ≈øet by? You are one of hys liuely ≈øtones: be contente therefore to be hewen and ≈ønagged at, that you myghte be made the more meete to bee ioyned to youre fellowes which ≈øuffer with you Sathans ≈ønatches, the worlds woundes, contempte of con≈øcience, and frettes of the fle≈øhe, where throughe they are enforced to crye: Oh wretches that we are, Rom. 6 who ≈øhall deliuer vs? You are of Gods corne, feare not therfore the flayle, the fanne, myl≈øtone, nor ouen. You are one of Chri≈øtes Lambes, looke therefore to bee fleeced, hayled at, and euen flayne. If you were a market ≈øhepe, you ≈øhoulde goe in more fatte and gra≈øye pa≈øture. Happye and twy≈øe happye are you (my deare ≈øy≈øter) that GOD nowe haileth you whether you woulde not, Iohn. 21. that you myghte come whether you woulde. Suffer a little and bee ≈øtill. Let Sathan rage agayn≈øte you, let the worlde crye oute, let youre con≈øcience accu≈øe you, let the lawe loade you and pre≈ø≈øe you downe: yet ≈øhall they not preuaile, for Chri≈øte is Emanuell that is god with vs. If God be with vs who can be agayn≈øt vs? The Lord is with you: your father caÃÑ not forget you: your ≈øpou≈øe loueth you. Math. 8 If the waues and ≈øurges ari≈øe, crye with Peter Lord I peri≈øhe, and he wil put out his hand and helpe you. Ca≈øt out your anker of hope, and it wyll not cea≈øe for all the ≈øtormy ≈øurges, till it take holde on the rocke of gods truthe
and mercy. Thinke not that he whiche hathe geuen you ≈øo many thynges corporallye as inductions of ≈øpirituall and heauenlye mercies, and that wythout your de≈øertes or de≈øyre, can deny you any ≈øpiritual comfort de≈øiring it. phi. 2. For yf he geue to de≈øire, he will geue you to haue and enioye the thyng de≈øired. The de≈øyre to haue and the goyng aboute to a≈øke, ought to certifye your con≈øcience that they be his earne≈øt of the thyng whiche you a≈økyng, he will geue you, yea before you a≈øke and while≈øt you are aboute to a≈øke he wyll graunt the ≈øame (as E≈øay ≈øayth) to his glory and your eternal con≈øolation. He that ≈øpared not his owne ≈øonne for you, Rom. 8 wyll not nor cannot thynke anye thynge to good for you, my hartely beloued. If he had not cho≈øen you (as mo≈øt certainlye he hathe) he would not haue ≈øo called you: he would neuer haue iu≈øtified you: he woulde neuer haue ≈øo glorified you with his gratious gifts, which I know, prai≈øed be his name therefore: he woulde neuer haue ≈øo exerci≈øed youre fayth with temptations as he hathe done and dothe, yf (I ≈øay) he had not cho≈øeÃÑ you. If he haue cho≈øen you (as doutles deare hart he hath done in Chri≈øte, for in you I haue ≈øeene hys earne≈øt, and before me and to me you could not denye it, I know bothe where and when) if I ≈øaye, he haue cho≈øen you, then neither can you nor ≈øhall you euer peri≈øhe. For if you fall, he putteth vnder his hande: you ≈øhall not lye ≈øtyll: ≈øo carefull is Chri≈øt your keper ouer you. Neuer was mother ≈øo myndefull ouer her chylde, as he is ouer you. And hath not he alwayes bene ≈øo? Speake womon: when did he finally forget you? And will he now trow you in your mo≈øt nede do otherwi≈øe, you callyng vppon him and de≈øiring to plea≈øe him? For elles were he no GOD. If you ≈øhould peri≈øhe, then wanted he power: for I am certain his will towards you is not to be doubted of. Hath not the ≈øpirit, which is the ≈øpirit of truthe, told you ≈øo? And wyll you now harken with Eue to the lying ≈øpirite whiche woulde haue you, not to di≈øpaire (no he goeth more craftelye to worke, howbeit to that ende, if you ≈øhould geue eare vnto

Ah myne owne deare hart, Chry≈øt onely, Chri≈øt onely, and his mercy and truth. In hym and for hym is the cau≈øe of your election. This Chri≈øt, this mercy, this truthe of God remayneth for euer, is certayne for euer, and ≈øo is your election certaine for euer, for euer, for euer, I ≈øay for euer. If an aungel from heauen ≈øhoulde tell you contrarye, accur≈øed bee he, accur≈øed be he. Your thankefulnes and worthynes are fruites and effectes of your election, they are no cau≈øes. Therefore (my derely beloued) ary≈øe and remember from whence you are fallen. P≈øalm. 120 You haue a ≈øhepehard whiche neither ≈ølumbreth nor ≈ølepeth. P≈øal. 23 Do you not know that god ≈øparred Noe in the Arke on the out≈øide, ≈øo that he coulde not gette out? So hathe he done to you my good Sy≈øter, ≈øo hathe he done to you. P≈øa. 90. Tenne thou≈øande ≈øhall fall on your righte hande and twentye on your lefte hande: yet no euell ≈øhall touche you. Saye holdelye therfore: P≈øa. 123. many a tyme from my youth vppe they haue fought again≈øt me, but they haue not preuayled: no nor neuer ≈øhall preuaile, for the Lorde is rounde aboute his people. And who are the people of GOD, but ≈øuche as hope in hym: Happye are they that hope in the Lorde: and you are one of tho≈øe my deare harte, for I am a≈ø≈øured you haue hoped in the Lord: I haue your wordes to ≈øhew mo≈øt manife≈øtly & I know they were writen vnfaynedly. I nede not to ≈øay that euen before god you haue ≈øimply confe≈ø≈øed to me, and that often times no le≈ø≈øe. And once if you had thys hope, as you doutles had it, though now you fele it not yet ≈øhall you feele it agayne: for the anger of the Lorde la≈øteth
but a momeÃÑt, but hys mercy la≈øteth for euer. Tel me my dere harte, who hath ≈øo weakened you? Surelye not a per≈øua≈øion which came from hym that called you. Gal. 5. For why ≈øhoulde ye wauer? Why ≈øhoulde you wauer and be ≈øo heauy harted? Whome looke you on? On your≈øelfe? On your worthines? On your thankefulnes? On that whiche God requireth of you, as faythe, hope, loue, feare, ioye? &c. Then can you not but wauer in deede, for what haue you as God requyreth? Beleue you, hope you, loue you &c. as much as you ≈øhoulde do? No no, nor neuer can in this lyfe. Ah my dearelye beloued, haue you ≈øo ≈øoone forgotten that which euer ≈øhould be had in memory: namely that wheÃÑ you would and ≈øhould be certayne and quiet in con≈øcieÃÑce, then ≈øhould your fayth bur≈øt throughout all thynges not onely that you haue in you, or els are in heauen, earth or hell, vntill it come to Chri≈øt crucified, and the eternal ≈øwete mercies and goodnes of god in Chri≈øt? Here, here is the re≈øting place, here is your ≈øpou≈øes bed: creepe into it, & in your armes of faith embrace hym: be waile your weakenes, your vnworthines, your diffidence &c. & you ≈øhal≈øee he wyl turne to you. What ≈øayd I, you ≈øhal ≈øee? Nay I ≈øhould haue ≈øayd you ≈øhal feele he wil turne to you. You know that Mo≈øes, when he went into the Mount to talke with God, he entred into a darke cloude, & Helias had his face couered when God pa≈ø≈øed by. Both the≈øe dere frendes of god heard God, but they ≈øaw hym not: but you would be preferred before them. See now my deare harte, how couetous you are. Ah be thankefull be thankefull. But god be pray≈øed that your couetou≈ønes is Mo≈øes couetou≈ønes. Well with hym you ≈øhall be ≈øati≈øfied. But when? For≈øoth when he ≈øhall appeare. Here is not the tyme of ≈øeyng, p≈øa. 16. but as it were, in a gla≈ø≈øe. I≈øaac was deceyued becau≈øe he was not content with hearyng onely.

Therfore to make an ende of the≈øe many words, wherwith I feare me I do but trouble you from better exerci≈øes: in a≈ømuche as you are in deede the chylde of God electe in Chry≈øte before the begynnyng of all tymes: in a≈ømuche as you are geuen to the cu≈øtody of Chri≈øt as one of gods mo≈øt precious iewels: in a≈ømuche as Chry≈øte is faythful & ther to hath al power, ≈øo yt you ≈øhal neuer pery≈øh, no one heare of
your heade ≈øhall not be lo≈øte: I be≈øeche you, I pray you, I de≈øyre you, I craue at your hands wt al my very hart, I a≈øke of you with hande, penne, tonge & mind, in Chri≈øt, through Chri≈øte, for Chri≈øte, for his name, bloode, mercies, power and truthes ≈øake (my mo≈øte entierlye beloued Si≈øter) that you admitte no doutyng of gods fynall mercies towardes you, how ≈øoeuer you feele your ≈øelfe: but complaine to god and craue of him; as of your tender & deare father, al things, and in that tyme which ≈øhalbe mo≈øt oportune, you ≈øhal find and feele farre aboue that your harte or the hart of any creature can conceaue, to your eternall ioye. AmeÃÑ, Amen, AmeÃÑ. The good ≈øpirite of god alwayes kepe vs as hys deare children, he comfort you, as I de≈øyre to be comforted (my derely beloued) for euermore, Amen. ‚ùßAs for the report of W. P. if it be as you heare, you mu≈øt prepare to beare it. It is written on heauens dore: do wel, and heare euill. div.head: ¬∂To my louyng brethren .B. and .C. wyth their wyues and whole families.
div.p: I Be≈øech ye euerliuing god to geue to you al my good bretherne and ≈øy≈øters, the comfort of his holy ≈øpirite and the continuall feelyng of his mercye in Chri≈øte oure Lord, nowe and for euer, Amen.

The world my brethern at this pre≈øente ≈øeemeth to haue the vpperhande, iniquity ouerfloweth, the truth and veritie ≈øeemeth to be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and they whiche take part therwith are vniu≈øtly entreated. The cau≈øe of all this is gods anger, and mercy: his anger becau≈øe we haue
greuou≈øly ≈øinned again≈øt him: his mercy, becau≈øe he here puni≈øheth vs & as a father nurtereth vs. We haue ben vnthaÃÑkful for his word, we haue contemned his kindnes, we haue ben negligent in praier, we haue ben to carnal, couetous, liceÃÑtious, &c. we haue not ha≈øtened to heaueÃÑward, but rather to helward, we were fallen almo≈øt into an open coÃÑtempt of god and all his good ordinaunces: ≈øo that of hys iu≈øtice he could not long forbeare, but make vs to feele hys anger, as now he hath done in taking his word and true ≈øeruice from vs, and permittyng Sathan to ≈øerue vs with Antichri≈øtian religion, and that in ≈øuch ≈øorte, that if we wil not yelde to it and ≈øeme to allow it in dede and outwarde fact: our bodies are like to be laide in pri≈øon and our goodes geuen we cannot tell to whome. This ≈øhould we looke vppon as a ≈øygne of gods anger procured by our ≈øynnes, which (my good brethern) euery one of vs ≈øhould now cal to our memories often tymes ≈øo perticulerly as we can, that we might hartely lament them, repent them, hare them, a≈øke earne≈øtly mercye for them, and ≈øubmitte our ≈øelues to beare in this lyfe anye kind of puni≈øhment which god wil lay vppon vs for them. Thus ≈øhould we do in con≈øideration of gods anger in thys time. Now his mercy in this time of wrath is ≈øene & ≈øhould be ≈øene of vs (my derely beloued) in this, ye god doth vouch≈øafe to puni≈øh vs in this pre≈øent life. If he ≈øhould not haue puni≈øhed vs, do not ye thinke that we would haue continuin ye euils we were in? Yea verely, we would haue ben wor≈øe and haue gone forwards in hardning our harts by impenitency, & negligence towardes God & true godlines, & then yf death had come, ≈øhould not we haue peri≈øhed bothe ≈øoule and bodye into eternall fyre and perdition? Alas, what mi≈øery ≈øhould we haue fallen into, if god ≈øhoulde haue ≈øuffered vs to haue gone forward in our euils? No greater a ≈øigne of damnation there is, then to lye in euill & ≈øynne vnpuni≈øhed of god: as nowe the papi≈øts (my derely beloued) are ca≈øt into Iezabels bed of ≈øecurity, Apoc. 3 Hebr. 12 which of all plagues is the mo≈øt greuous plague that can be. They are ba≈øtardes and not ≈øonnes, for they are not vnder Gods rodde of correction. A great mercy it is therfore that god dothe puni≈øhe vs: for yf he loued vs not, he wuld not puni≈øh vs. Now doth he cha≈øtice
vs that we ≈øhuld not be damned with the world.1. Cor. 2 Now doth he nurture vs, becau≈øe he fauoureth vs. Now may we thynke our ≈øelues to be Gods hou≈øeholde and children,1. pet. 4 becau≈øe he beginneth his cha≈øti≈øing at vs. Nowe calleth he vs to remeÃÑber our ≈øynnes pa≈øt. Wherfore? That we myght repent and and a≈øke mercy. And why? That he might forgeue vs, pardon vs, iu≈øtify vs, and make vs his chyldren, and ≈øo begin to make vs here lyke vnto Chri≈øt, Rom. 8 that we myght bee like vnto hym el≈øewhere, euen in heauen, where already we are ≈øet by faith with Chri≈øte, and at hys commyng in verye dede ≈øhall enioye his pre≈øence, when our ≈øynfull and vile bodies ≈øhalbe made lyke to chri≈øtes glorious body, phil. 3. accordyng to the power whereby he is able to make al thynges ≈øubiect to hym≈øelfe.

Therfore my brethren, let vs in re≈øpect hereof, not lament, but laude god: not be ≈øory but be mercy: not wepe but reioyce and be glad that god doth vouch≈øafe to offer vs hys cro≈ø≈øe, Rom. 8 2. Timo. 3. Math. 10. therby to come to him to endles ioyes and comforts. For if we ≈øuffer, we ≈øhall raigne: If we confe≈ø≈øe hym before men, he wil confe≈ø≈øe vs before hys father in heauen: If we be not a≈øhamed of his Go≈øpell nowe, he wyll not bee a≈øhamed of vs in the la≈øt day, Math. 5. 1. pet. 4 1. pet 5 but wyl be glorifyed in vs, crownyng vs with crownes of glory and endeles felicity. For ble≈ø≈øed are they yt ≈øuffer per≈øecutioÃÑ for rightuou≈ønes ≈øake, for their is the kingdom of heaueÃÑ. Be glad ≈øayth Peter, for the ≈øpirit of God re≈øteth vpoÃÑ you. After that ye are a litle while afflicted, god will comfort, ≈øtrengthen, & confyrme you. And therfore (my good bretherne) be not di≈øcouraged for cro≈ø≈øe, for pri≈øon or lo≈ø≈øe of goodes, for the confe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtes go≈øpell and truth, whiche ye haue beleued and lyuely was taught emongs you in the days of our late good & mo≈øt holy prince Kyng Edwarde. This is mo≈øt certayne, if ye lo≈øe any thyng for Chri≈øtes ≈øake, Math. 19 and for contemnyng the Antichri≈øtian ≈øeruice ≈øet vp agayne amonge vs, as ye for youre partes euen in pri≈øon ≈øhall find gods greate and riche mercies farre pa≈ø≈øing all worldly wealth: ≈øo ≈øhall your wyues & children in thys pre≈øent lyfe, fynd and feele gods prouideÃÑce more plentifully then tounge can tell: for he wyl ≈øhew merciful kindnes on thou≈øaÃÑds of them that loue him: The good
mans ≈øede ≈øhal not go a begging his bread. Ye are good meÃÑ ≈øo many as ≈øuffer for chri≈øtes ≈øake. P≈øalm. 27 I tru≈øt ye all (my dearely beloued) wil coÃÑ≈øider this geare with your ≈øelues, and in the cro≈ø≈øe ≈øee gods mercy, which is more ≈øwete and more to bee ≈øet by then life it ≈øelf: much more theÃÑ, then any mucke or pelfe of thys world. Rom. 8. This mercy of god ≈øhould make you merye and chearefull: for the afflictions of this lyfe are not to bee coÃÑpared to the ioyes of the lyfe prepared for you. Ye know the way to heauen is not the wyde way of the world, which wyndeth to ye deuil, but it is a ≈øtrayt way, Math. 7 2. Timot. 3 2. Cor. 5 Math. 14. which few walke in: for fewe lyue godly in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu, few regard the lyfe to come, few remember the day of iudgement, fewe remember how Chri≈øt will deny them beforh hys father that do denye him here, few con≈øider that Chri≈øt wyll be a≈øhamed of them in the la≈øt day, which are a≈øhamed now of hys truthe & true ≈øeruice, few ca≈øt theyr accomptes what will be laid to theyr charge in the day of vengeauÃÑce, fewe regard the condemnation of their owne con≈øciences in doyng that which inwardly they di≈øalow, few loue god better then theyr goodes: Rom. 14. but I tru≈øt yet ye are of the≈øe few my derely beloued, I tru≈øt ye be of the little flocke which ≈øhall enherite the kyngdome of heauen, I tru≈øt ye are of the mourners and lameÃÑters which ≈øhalbe comforted with comfortes which neuer ≈øhalbe taken from you, if ye nowe repente your former euils, Luke. 10 if nowe ye ≈øtryue agayn≈øte the euyls that are in you, if now ye coÃÑtinue to call vppon God, if nowe ye defile not your bodies with anye Idolatrous ≈øeruice v≈øed in the Antichri≈øtian churches, Ephe≈øi. 4. if ye mole≈øte not the good ≈øpirite of God which is geuen you as a gage of eternal redeÃÑption, a couÃÑ≈øeller & ma≈øter to lead you into all truth: whiche good ≈øpirit I be≈øeche ye father of mercy to geue vs all for hys dere ≈øonnes ≈øake Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our lord, Acts. 20 to whom I coÃÑmend you al & to the word of his grace, which is able to helpe you all & ≈øaue you all yt beleue it, follow it, & ≈øerue god therafter. And of this I would ye were al certain, that al ye heares of your heades are numbred, ≈øo that not one of theÃÑ ≈øhal peri≈øh, Math. 8. Iob. 1. P≈øa. 104 P≈øa. 13. 1. pet. 5 neither ≈øhal any man or deuil be able to attempt any thing, much le≈ø≈øe to doe any thing to you or any of you, before your heaueÃÑly father which loueth you mo≈øt teÃÑderly, ≈øhal geue theÃÑ leaue, & when he hath geuen them leaue, they ≈øhal go no further then he wyll, nor
kepe you in trouble any longer then he wyll. Therfore ca≈øte on hym all your care, for he is carefull for you: onely ≈øtudye to plea≈øe him and to kepe your con≈øciences cleane and your bodies pure from the Idolatrous ≈øeruice, which now euery where is v≈øed, and god will meruelou≈øly and mercifully defend and comforte you: whiche thing he doe for hys names ≈øake in Chri≈øt our Lord. Amen.

div.head: To my good Lady Vane.
div.p: THe true ≈øen≈øe and ≈øwete feelyng of gods eternall mercies in Chri≈øte Ie≈øus, bee euer more and more liuely wrought in your hart by the holy gho≈øt. Amen.

I mo≈øt hartely thanke you (good madame) for your comfortable letters, & where as you would be aduerti≈øed what were be≈øte to bee done on your behalfe concernyng your iij. que≈øtions: the truthe is, that the que≈øtions are neuer well ≈øene nor aun≈øwered, vntil the thynge whereof they ari≈øe, bee well con≈øidered: I meane vntill it be ≈øene how great an euill the thing is. If it be once in dede in your hart perceaued vpon probable and pithy places gathered out of gods booke, that there was neuer thing vpon ye earthe ≈øo great & ≈øo much an aduer≈øary to gods true ≈øeruice, to Chri≈øtes death, pa≈ø≈øion, prie≈øthode, ≈øacrifice, and kingdome, to the mini≈øtery of gods worde and ≈øacraments, to the church of God,The≈øe que≈øtions were concerning the ma≈ø≈øe wherin ≈øhe de≈øired hys iudgement. to repentaunce, faith and all true godlines of life, as that is wherof the que≈øtioÃÑs ari≈øe (as mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly it is in dede) then cannot a chri≈øtiaÃÑ hart but ≈øo much the more abhorre it and al thynges that in any point might ≈øeme to allow it or anye thyng pertainyng to the ≈øame, by howe much it hath the name of gods ≈øeruice. Agayne, your Ladi≈øhip doth know that as all is to be di≈øcommended and auoyded which is followed or fledde from in re≈øpect of our ≈øelues, in re≈øpecte of auoyding Chri≈øtes cro≈ø≈øe: ≈øo the ende of all our doynges ≈øhould be to godwards, to his glory, to our neighbours, to edification and good example, wherof none
can be geuen in allowing anye of the .iii. que≈øtions by you propouÃÑded. But becau≈øe this which I write now, is breefe and needeth the more con≈øideration or explication: as I doubt not of the one in you, ≈øo from me by Gods grace you ≈øhall receaue the other ≈øhortly. For I haue alreadye written a little booke of it which I will ≈øend vnto you,He meaneth his booke whiche he calleth the hurt of heariÃÑg ma≈ø≈øe. in the which you ≈øhall haue your que≈øtions fully aun≈øwered and ≈øati≈øfied, and therefore I omitte to write any more hereaboutes pre≈øentlye: be≈øeching God our good father to guide you as his deare childe with his ≈øpirite of wi≈øedome, power and comforte vnto eternall life, that you may be ≈øtronge and reioyce in him and with his church, to cary Chri≈øtes cro≈ø≈øe if he ≈øhall ≈øo thinke it neede. 1. Pet. 1. which is a thyng to be de≈øired, wi≈øhed, and embraced if we looked on thinges after the iudgement of Gods word, and tryed them by that touch≈øtone. If you be accu≈øtomed to thinke on the breuitie, vanitie, and mi≈øerie of this life, and o ‚Ä¢ the eternitie, truth and felicitie of euerla≈øting life: if you looke on thinges after their endes and not after their pre≈øent appearaunce only: if you v≈øe your ≈øelf to ≈øet gods pre≈øence, power and mercy alwayes before your eyes, to ≈øee theÃÑ as god by euery creature would you ≈øhould: I doubt not but you ≈øhall finde ≈øuch ≈øtrength and comforte in the Lord, as you ≈øhall not be ≈øhaken with all the power of Sathan. Gods mercy in Chri≈øt be with you and his good ≈øpirite guide you for euer, Amen.

div.head: An other letter to the Lady Vane.
div.p: AS to myne owne ≈øoule, I wi≈øhe to your Ladi≈øhip grace and mercy from God our deare Father in Chri≈øte our Lorde and Sauioure.

I thanke God that ≈øomething he hath ea≈øed you, and mitigated his fatherly correction in vs both: I woulde to God he had done ≈øo much in the behalfe of the greefe of ye body to you as he hath done to me. For as for the ≈øoule I tru≈øt you feele that which I pray god encrea≈øe in you, I meane his fatherly loue, and graunte that I may with you feele the ≈øame in ≈øuch degree as may plea≈øe him: I wil not ≈øay as you feele, lea≈øt I ≈øhould
≈øeeme to a≈øke to muche at one time. God doth often muche more plentifullye vi≈øet with the ≈øen≈øe of hys mercye, them that humble them ≈øelues vnder his mightye hande, and are ≈øore exerci≈øed, as you long haue bene: then others, whiche to the face of the worlde haue a more ≈øhewe and appearaunce. Therfore I wy≈øh as I do, and that not only for myne own commoditye, but al≈øo that I myght occa≈øion you to the con≈øideration of the goodne≈ø≈øe of God, which I by your letters doe well e≈øpye, which is in deede the hygh waye whereby as God encrea≈øeth his giftes, ≈øo ≈øheweth he more linelye hys ≈øaluation, P≈øalme. 50.107. I haue receaued Gods ble≈ø≈øing froÃÑ you, the which I haue partly di≈øtributed vnto my three fellowe pri≈øoners Mai≈øter Farer, Mai≈øter Taylour, Mai≈øter Philpot, and the re≈øidue I will be≈øtowe vppon .iiii. poore ≈øoules which are impri≈øoned in the coÃÑmon Iayle for religioÃÑ al≈øo. As for mine own part, if I had had nede, I would haue ≈øerued my turne al≈øo. But becau≈øe I had not, nor (I thanke God) haue not, I haue beene and will hee your Almner in ≈øuche ≈øorte as I haue already aduerti≈øed you. God rewarde you and geue you to finde it ≈øpiritually and corporally. Becau≈øe otherwi≈øe I can not talke with you, therefore on thys ≈øort, as occa≈øion and opportunitie wil ≈øerue, I am readye to ≈øhewe my good will and de≈øire of youre healpe and furtheraunce in the Lorde to euerla≈øting life, whereunto GOD bryng vs ≈øhortlye for hys mercyes ≈øake, Amen. Good Madame bee thankefull to God, as I hope you be, be earne≈øt in prayer, continue in readynge and hearinge Gods woord, and if Gods further cro≈ø≈øe come, as therein God doth ≈øerue hys prouidence (for elles it ≈øhall not come vnto you) ≈øo bee certayne the ≈øame ≈øhall tourne to your eternal ioy and comforte, Amen.

div.head: To the Lady Vane.
div.p:
THe euerla≈øting and mo≈øt merciful god, which is the father of our ≈øauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, encrea≈øe in your ladi≈øhip ye knowledge & loue of hys truth, with the gift of per≈øeueraÃÑce to coÃÑtinue therin to ye end, AmeÃÑ. Albeit at this pre≈øent I haue no coÃÑuenient lea≈øure to write
is ≈øhold be ≈øemely to ≈øend to your per≈øonage, yet coÃÑ≈øidering your geÃÑtle good wil for gods cau≈øe towards me, I thought I mought be ye more bold to write ≈øomthing, although not in ≈øuch ≈øort as I would & perchaunce on your behalfe might be loked for. I doubt not but that your ladi≈øhip con≈øidereth often with your ≈øelf, ye you are the childe of god and a citizen of heaueÃÑ by Chri≈øt, in whoÃÑ God the father before the worlde was made, hath cho≈øen you of his own mere mercy and not of your de≈øertes done or to be done. That you ≈øhoulde with thankefulnes cal this to minde often, thereby to excite and ≈øtirre vp your≈øelf to ye loue of god in his ≈øight, and to al holine≈ø≈øe of life in the ≈øight of man, many things ≈øhould moue & occa≈øion you iu≈øtly: as that you were borne of Chri≈øten parents, that ye name of god was called vpon you in bapti≈øme, which is a ≈øacrament of regeneratioÃÑ and adoption into the children of god, with all other benefites which hytherto you haue receaued. Amonges which ≈øurely, your ladi≈øhip ≈øhould not thinke the lea≈øt, euen the cro≈ø≈øes that god hath hetherto exerci≈øed you with all: as the lo≈ø≈øe of youre good hu≈øband, landes, and other worldly commodities &c. But aboue al, next to Chri≈øt crucifyed, this is mo≈øt thankefully to be con≈øidered, that god, as he hath geuen you pacience (I tru≈øt) in your trouble: ≈øo in the≈øe daungerous dayes he hath geuen you a de≈øire to know him, and to helpe them which for hys ≈øake be in trouble: for thys I gather and euidentlye ≈øee by your twi≈øe ≈øending to me, which am not otherwi≈øe knowen to you but by name. I pray god I may be hartely thankeful to him for you, and ≈øo di≈øpo≈øe your benefites as you de≈øyre. My be≈øt I will doe by gods grace: but enough of thys.

My de≈øire is, good Madame (although I haue no doubt (as I ≈øaid) but yt you be diligeÃÑt herein) that you would ofteÃÑ call to minde your ≈øtate before god, I meane howe that you be hys childe through Chri≈øt: and this I would you dyd for diuer≈øe cau≈øes. Fyr≈øt that you myghte be quiet in con≈øcience before him in this trouble≈øome worlde, as we neuer can bee vntill thys be ≈øomething ≈øetled. Secondly that you myghte bee carefull to appeare in hys ≈øyghte and in the ≈øyghte of man, as one of Gods children. Thyrdly that you myght in all troubles boldelye by prayer throughe Chri≈øte, goe to hym and cal hym by the name of father, with hope of hys
helpe alwayes to your comforte. Fourthly that you myghte not bee di≈ømayed if trouble come vnto you, as it can not be but more or le≈ø≈øe it mu≈øt needes come: for the worlde loueth none but ≈øuche as be his: the deuill can neuer ≈øuffer the children of God to be quiet. I will not ≈øpeake of our mortal and familiar enemye the fle≈øhe, which cea≈øeth not to fyght agayn≈øt the ≈øpirite. But God your father being hartely called vpon, in and through Chri≈øt, as he will with hys holye ≈øpirite helpe you, ≈øo will he geue you the victorye at ye length to your ≈øingular comforte: Which I pray God you may daily more and more feele, Amen. From the Kings Benche in ha≈øt as appeareth.

div.head: To my deare frendes and brethren. R. and E. with their wiues and families.
div.p: THe comfort of Chri≈øt felte commonly of hys children in their cro≈ø≈øe for his ≈øake, the euerliuing God worke in both youre hartes my good brethren, and in the hartes of bothe your yokefellowes, e≈øpecially of good Mary my good ≈øi≈øter in the Lorde, Amen.

If I had not ≈øomthing heard of ye hazard which you are in for the go≈øpels ≈øake if you continue the profe≈ø≈øion & confe≈ø≈øion therof, as I tru≈øte you doe and will doe and that vnto the end God enabling you, as he will doubtles for his mercyes ≈øake if you hope in him (for this bindeth him as Dauid in Chri≈øtes per≈øon witne≈ø≈øeth, our father keped in thee, and thou deliuere≈øt them &c. P≈øal. 22 ) yet by coniectures I could not but ≈øuppo≈øe (though not ≈øo certainly) the tyme of ≈øuffering and probation to bee at hande. For nowe is the power of darkene≈ø≈øe fullye come vppon this Realme mo≈øte iu≈øtlye for oure ≈øynnes and abu≈øynge the lyghte lente vs of the Lorde, to the ≈øettynge forthe of oure ≈øelues more then of Gods glorye, that a≈øwell we myghte bee broughte into
the better knowledge of our euilles, and ≈øo hartely repente (which god grauÃÑt vs to do) as al≈øo we might haue more feling & ≈øen≈øe of our ≈øwete ≈øauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, by the humbling and deiecting of vs, therby to make vs, as more de≈øirous of him, ≈øo him more ≈øweete and plea≈øaunt vnto vs: the which thing the good ≈øpirite of God woorke ≈øen≈øiblye in all our hartes for Gods holy names ≈øake. For thys cau≈øe I thoughte it my dutye, being now where I haue ≈øome libertie to write (the Lorde bee pray≈øed) and hearing of you as I heare: to doe that which I ≈øhould haue done if I had hearde nothing at all: that is, to de≈øire you to be of good cheare and comfort in the Lorde (although in the worlde you ≈øee cau≈øe rather to the contrarye) and to go on forwardes in ye waye of God wherinto you are entred, con≈øidering that the ≈øame can not but ≈øo much more and more waxe ≈øtreite to the outwarde man, by howe much you drawe nearer the ende of it. EueÃÑ as in ye traueil of a womaÃÑ, the nearer ≈øhe draweth to her deliuerye, the more her paynes encrea≈øe: ≈øo it goeth with vs in the Lordes way, the nerer we drawe to our deliuerance by death to eternall felicitie. Example whereof we haue, I will not ≈øay in the holy Prophetes & Apo≈øtles of god, which when they were yong girded them≈øelues and went in maner whether they woulde, but when they waxed olde, they wente girded of others, whether they woulde not, Iohn. 21. concerning the outwarde man: but rather and mo≈øte liuely in our Sauioure Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, who≈øe life and waye was muche more paynefull to him towardes the ende, then it was at the beginning. And no maruaile, for Sathan can ≈øomething abide a man to beginne well and ≈øet forewardes, but rather then he ≈øhould goe on to the ende, he will vomyt his gorge and ca≈øte floudes to ouerflowe hym, before he will ≈øuffer that to come to pa≈ø≈øe. Therefore as we ≈øhoulde not bee di≈ømayde, now at this world as though ≈øome ≈øtraunge thynge were happened vnto vs, in that it is but as it was wonte to bee to the Godlye, in that the deuill declareth hym ≈øelfe after hys olde wonte, in that we haue profe≈ø≈øed no le≈ø≈øe but to for≈øake the worlde and the deuill as gods very enemye, in that we learned no le≈ø≈øe at the fyr≈øte when we came to Gods ≈øchole, then to denye oure ≈øelues and to take vp oure
cro≈ø≈øe and followe oure Mai≈øter, whiche leadeth vs none other waye then he hym ≈øelf hath gone before vs: as (I ≈øay) we ≈øhoulde not bee di≈ømayde, ≈øo we ≈øhoulde wyth pacience and ioye goe forwardes, if we ≈øette before vs as pre≈øent, the tyme to come, like as the wyfe in her trauaile doth the deliueraunce of her childe, and as the Sainctes of God dyd, Hebr. 12 but e≈øpeciallye oure Sauioure and paterne Ie≈øus Chri≈øte: for the Apo≈øtle ≈øayeth, he ≈øet before hym the ioye and glorye to come, and therefore contempned the ≈øhame and ≈øorrowe of the cro≈ø≈øe: ≈øo if we dyd, we ≈øhoulde finde at the length as they founde. For whome woulde it grene which hath a longe iourney to goe, to goe throughe a peece of foule waye, if he knewe that after that, the waye ≈øhoulde be mo≈øte plea≈øaunte, yea the iourneye ≈øhoulde be ended and he at hys re≈øtinge place mo≈øte happye? Who will be afearde or lothe to leaue a little pelfe for a little tyme, if he knewe he ≈øhoulde ≈øhortlye after receaue mo≈øte plentifull ryches? Who wyll bee vnwillinge for a little whyle to for≈øake hys wyfe, children, or frendes &c. when he knoweth he ≈øhall ≈øhortlye after bee a≈ø≈øociated vnto them in≈øeperablye, euen after hys owne hartes de≈øire? Who will bee ≈øorye to for≈øake thys lyfe, whiche can not but bee mo≈øte certayne of eternall lyfe? Who loueth the ≈øhaddowe better then the bodye? Who can loue thys lyfe, but they that regarde not the lyfe to come? Who can de≈øire the dro≈ø≈øe of thys worlde, but ≈øuch as bee ignorante of the trea≈øures of the euerla≈øtyng ioye in heauen? I meane, who is afearde to die, but ≈øuche as hope not to liue eternallye? Chri≈øte hath promy≈øed plea≈øure, Math. 19. ryches, ioye, felicitye, and all good thynges to them that for hys ≈øake lo≈øe anye thynge, or ≈øuffer anye ≈øorrowe.1. pet. 2. And is he not true? How can he but bee true, for guile was neuer founde in hys mouth? Halas then whye are we ≈øo ≈ølacke and ≈ølowe, yea harde of harte to beleue hym promy≈øing vs thus plentifullye eternall bli≈øfulne≈ø≈øe: and are ≈øo readye to beleue the worlde promy≈øyng vs manye thynges and paying vs nothyng? If we wyll currye fauoure nowe and halte on both knees, if ≈øo: then it promy≈øeth vs peace, quietne≈ø≈øe, and manye thynges
elles. But howe doth it paye thys geare? or if it paye it, with what quietne≈ø≈øe of con≈øcience? Or if ≈øo: howe longe I praye you? Doe not we ≈øee before oure eyes men to dye ≈øhamefullye, I meane as rebelles and other malefactours, whiche refu≈øe to dye for Gods cau≈øe? What waye is ≈øo ≈øure a waye to heauen, as to ≈øuffer in Chri≈øtes cau≈øe? If there bee anye waye on hor≈øebacke to heauen, ≈øurelye thys is the waye. By many troubles ≈øayeth the Apo≈øtle, Act 14. 2. Timo. 3. we mu≈øte enter into heauen. All that wyll liue Godlye in Chri≈øte Ie≈øu mu≈øte ≈øuffer per≈øecution. For the worlde can not loue them that are of GOD: the deuill can not loue hys ennemyes: the worlde will loue none but hys owne: but you are Chri≈øtes, therefore looke for no loue here. Shoulde we looke for fyre to quenche oure thur≈øte? And as ≈øoone ≈øhall Gods true ≈øeruauntes fynde peace and fauoure in Antichri≈øtes regimente. Therefore my dearlye beloued, be ≈øtonte in the Lorde, and in the power of hys myghte. Putte on you hys armour: ≈øtande in the libertye of Chri≈øt which you haue learned: reioyce yt you may be counted worthye to ≈øuffer anye thynge for Gods cau≈øe: to all men thys is not geuen. Youre rewarde is greate in heauen, though in earth you fynde nothing. The iourney is almo≈øte pa≈øte: you are almo≈øte in the hauen, hale on a pace I be≈øeche you, and merely hoy≈øe vppe youre ≈øayles. Ca≈øte youre ≈øelfe on Chri≈øte who careth for you. Keepe companye with hym nowe ≈øtill to the ende: he is faythfull and will neuer leaue you, nor tempte you further then he wyll make you able to beare: yea in the midde≈øt of the temptation he wyll make an out≈økape. Nowe praye vnto hym hartelye, be thankefull of hys dignation, reioyce in hope of the health you ≈øhall receaue, and bee myndefull of vs which are in the vowarde, and by Gods grace tru≈øt in Chri≈øte to be made able to breake the I≈øe before you, that you followynge maye fynde the waye more ea≈øye. God graunte it maye ≈øo bee, Amen, Amen.
