div.head: To May≈øtres VVylkin≈øon.
div.p: ALmightie God our mo≈øte louing Father encrea≈øe in your hart (my good mother and dere Mai≈øtres in the Lorde) hys true knowledge and loue in Chri≈øt, to the encouraging & comforting of your fayth in the≈øe ≈øtormy dayes: as nece≈ø≈øarye vnto vs, ≈øo profitable if we per≈øi≈øte vnto the ende, which thing God graunte to vs, Amen.

My right dearly beloued, I know not what other thing to write vnto you, then to de≈øire you to be thankefull vnto the Lord, in that amonges the not many of your calling and ≈øtate, it plea≈øeth him to geue you his rare ble≈ø≈øing, I meane to kepe you froÃÑ all the filth wherewith our countrey is horribly defiled. This ble≈ø≈øing a≈ø≈øuredly is rare as you ≈øee. But now if he ≈øhall ble≈ø≈øe you wt an other ble≈ø≈øing which is more rare, I meane to cal you forth as a Martyr and as a witnes again≈øt this filth, I hope you will become double thankful. For a greater tokeÃÑ commonly we haue not to iudge of our election and ≈øaluation, next to Chri≈øt and fayth in him, then the cro≈ø≈øe, e≈øpecially when it is ≈øo glorious as on thys ≈øorte to ≈øuffer any thing, but chiefly lo≈ø≈øe of this life, which in dede is neuer founde til it be ≈øo lo≈øte: excepte the graine of wheate fal and be dead, it remaineth fruitles. You know how that he which was rapte into the third heauen & did know what he wrote, doth ≈øay that as the corne liueth not excepte it bee dead and ca≈øt into the earth, ≈øo truly our bodyes. And therefore the cro≈ø≈øe ≈øhould ≈øo litle feare vs, that euen death it ≈øelfe ≈øhold altogether be de≈øired of vs, as the taylour which putteth of our ragges and arayeth vs with the royall robes of immortalitie, incorruptioÃÑ, and glory. Great ≈øhame it ≈øhould be for vs, that al the whole creatures of God ≈øhould de≈øire, yea grone in their kinde for our libertie, Rom. 8. & we our ≈øelues to loth it: as doubtles we do if for the cro≈ø≈øe, yea for death it ≈øelf we with ioye ≈øwallow not vp all ≈øorrow that myght let vs from followyng the Lordes calling, and obeying the lords prouidence: wherby doubtles all cro≈ø≈øes and death it ≈øelfe doth come and not by hap or chauÃÑce. In con≈øideratioÃÑ wherof (righte deare Mother) in yt this prouidence ≈øtretcheth it
≈øelf ≈øo vnto vs and for vs, that euen the heares of our heads are numbred with GOD, not one of them to fall to oure hurt: ≈øurely we declare our ≈øelues very faint in faith, yf we receiue not ≈øuch comfort, that we can willinglye offer oure ≈øelues to the Lord, and ca≈øt our whole care vpon his backe, honouring him wyth this honour that he is & euer wyll be carefull for vs and all we haue, as for hys deare chyldren. Be therfore of good chere euen in the mydde≈øt of the≈øe mi≈øeries, be thankefull to the Lorde and prepare your ≈øelfe for a further trial, which if god ≈øend you: as I hope, ≈øo do you beleue, that god therin will helpe and comfort you, and make you able to beare what≈øoeuer ≈øhall happen. And thus much hauyng this oportunitie. I thoughte good to wryte, praying god our father to recompence into your bo≈øome, all the good that euer you haue done, to me e≈øpecially, and to many others bothe in this tyme of trouble and alwaies heretofore.

div.head: An other letter to Mai≈øter Richarde Hopkins then Shriefe of Couentrye and pry≈øoner in the Fleete for the faythfull and con≈øtant confe≈ø≈øing of gods holy Go≈øpell.
div.p: DEarelye beloued in the Lorde, I wy≈øhe vnto you, as vnto myne owne brother, yea as to myne owne harte roote, Gods mercye and the feeling of the ≈øame plentifullye in Chri≈øte our ≈øweete Sauioure, who gaue hym ≈øelfe a raun≈øome for oure ≈øynnes, and price for oure redeÃÑption, pray≈øed therefore be hys holy name for euer and euer. I will not goe aboute to excu≈øe my ≈øelfe for not ≈øending vnto you hetherto ≈øufferynge for the Lordes ≈øake as you doe, to the comforte of me and of all that loue you in the truth: but rather accu≈øe my ≈øelfe both before GOD and you, de≈øirynge you of forgeuene≈ø≈øe, and with me to praye to GOD for pardon of thys my vnkynde forgettinge you, and all other my ≈øynnes, whiche I be≈øeche the Lorde in his mercye to doe awaye for hys Chri≈øtes ≈øake, Amen. Nowe to make amends to your ward, I would be glad if I could,
but bycau≈øe I cannot, I ≈øhall hartely de≈øire you to accepte the will, and thys whiche I ≈øhall nowe wryte vnto you, thereafter: I meane, after my will and not after the dede, to accept and take it. At this pre≈øent my deare hart in the lord you are in a ble≈ø≈øed ≈øtate, although it ≈øeme otherwi≈øe to you, or rather vnto your olde Adam, the which I dare now bee ≈øo bolde as to di≈øcerne froÃÑ you, becau≈øe you would haue him not only di≈øcerned, but al≈øo vtterly de≈øtroyed. For if god be true, then is his word true. Now his word pronounceth of your ≈øtate that it is happie, therfore it mu≈øt nedes be ≈øo. To proue this I thinke it nede not: for you know that the holy gho≈øt ≈øayth, that they are happie which ≈øuffer for righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øake, & that Gods glorye and ≈øpirite re≈øteth on them which ≈øuffer for con≈øcience to God. Now this you can not but know, that this your ≈øuffering is for righteou≈ønes ≈øake and for con≈øcience to god wards, for els you might be out of trouble eueÃÑ out of hand. I know in very dede that you haue and feele your vnthankefulnes to god and other ≈øinnes, to witnes to you that you haue de≈øerued this pri≈øonment, and lacke of libertie betwixt god & your ≈øelf, and I would you ≈øo would confe≈ø≈øe vnto god in your prayers, with peticion for pardon & thanke≈øgeuing for his correcting you here. You may thinke your ≈øelf borne in a ble≈ø≈øed time, that haue found this grace with God, to be a ve≈ø≈øel of honour to ≈øuffer with his Saints, yea with his ≈øonne. My beloued, god hath not done ≈øo with many. The Apo≈øtle ≈øaith not many noble,1. Cor. 8 not many riche, not many wi≈øe in the world hath the Lord god cho≈øen. For≈øoth they that ≈øuffer for ye lord. And are not you one of theÃÑ? Yea verely are you. Then as I ≈øaide, happie, happie, and happie againe are you my dearly beloued in the Lord. Thynke how great a benefite it is, if God wil vouche you worthye this honoure to ≈øuffer lo≈ø≈øe of any thing for his ≈øake. He might iu≈øtly ca≈øt mo≈øt greuous plages vpon you, & now he will correct you with that rodde wherby you ≈øhal be made like to his Chri≈øt, that for euer ye maye reygne wt him. The deuill would gladly haue you now to ouerthrow that which godly ye haue of long time profe≈ø≈øed. Oh how would he triumphe if he could winne hys purpo≈øe? Oh how would the papi≈øtes triumphe again≈øt gods go≈øpel in you? Oh how would you confirme them in their wicked popery? Oh how would the poore children of god be di≈øcomforted if nowe ye ≈øhoulde goe to Ma≈ø≈øe and other Idolatrous ≈øeruice, & doe as the world doth? Hath God deliuered you from ye Sweat to ≈øerue hym ≈øo? Hath GOD miraculou≈ølye re≈øtored you to health froÃÑ your greuous Agewes for ≈øuch a purpo≈øe? Hath God geuen you ≈øuch ble≈ø≈øings in this world & good things al the dayes of your life hetherto, & now of equitie wil ye not receaue at his hands & for hys ≈øake, ≈øome euil? God forbyd. I hope better of you. V≈øe prayer, and ca≈øte your care vppon God: commit your childreÃÑ into his hands: geue to god your goods, bodyes and liues as he hath geuen them, or rather lent them vnto you. Say with Iob, God hath geuen & God hath taken away, his name be pray≈øed for euer. Ca≈øte your care vpon him (I ≈øay) for he is careful for you: and take it amonges the greate≈øt ble≈ø≈øings of God to ≈øuffer for hys ≈øake. I tru≈øt he hath kept you hetherto to that end. And I be≈øech thee O merciful father for Ie≈øus Chri≈øtes ≈øake, that yu woulde≈øt be mercifull vnto vs, comforte vs with thy grace, and ≈øtrengtheÃÑ vs in thy truth, that in harte we maye beleue & in toung boldly confe≈ø≈øe thy go≈øpel, to thy glorye and our eternal ≈øaluation, Amen. div.head: An other letter to the ≈øame per≈øons.
div.p: GOds mercy in Chri≈øt I wi≈øh you to fele, my dere brother, with my faythful ≈øi≈øter your wife now & for euer, Amen.

Hauing thys occa≈øion, I could not but write ≈øomething, as wel to put my ≈øelf in remembraunce of my duty to godwardes for you both, in thankfulnes & prayer, as to put you in remeÃÑbrance of me & your dutye towards god for me, in praying for me: for I dare not ≈øay in thankfulnes for me: not that I woulde haue you to geue no thankes to God for his wonderful great & ≈øweete mercies towardes me & vpon me in Chri≈øt his ≈øonne: but becau≈øe I haue not de≈øerued it at either of your haÃÑds. For ye both know right wel, at lea≈øt my con≈øcience doth accu≈øe me, how yt I haue not only not exhorted & taught you (as both my vocatioÃÑ & your de≈øertes required) to walke worthy of that vocation which god hath made you worthy of, & with trembling & feare to worke out your ≈øaluatioÃÑ, that is in ye feare of god to geue your ≈øelues to great vigilaÃÑcie in prayer for ye encrea≈øe of fayth, & to a wary circuÃÑ ≈øpection in al your coÃÑuer≈øatioÃÑ, not only in works & wordes but al≈øo in thoughts, becau≈øe god is a ≈øercher of ye hart, & out of ye hart it coÃÑmeth that defileth vs in gods ≈øight: I haue (I ≈øay) not only not done this but al≈øo haue geuen you exaÃÑple of negligence in prayer, watching, fa≈øting, talking & doing, ≈øo that woe to me for geuing you ≈øuche offence. Partely for thys cau≈øe deare brother & ≈øi≈øter god hath ca≈øt me and kepeth me here that I might repent me and tourne to hym, & that ye might al≈øo by this correction vpon me, be more diligence to redre≈ø≈øe the≈øe things and others, if they in your con≈øcience do accu≈øe you.

My dearly beloued, heuie is gods anger falleÃÑ vpon vs al: doulefull is this day. Now hath Antichri≈øt all his power again, now is Chri≈øtes go≈øpel trodeÃÑ vnder fote, now is gods people a deri≈øion & a praye for ye wicked. Nowe is ye greate≈øt plague of al plagues falleÃÑ, ye want of gods word: and al the≈øe we haue, yea I alone haue iu≈øtly de≈øerued. Oh yt as I write (I alone) I could wt Dauid, 1. Par. 21. & with Ionas in hart ≈øay ≈øo. But I do not, I do not, I ≈øe not howe greuou≈ølye I haue ≈øinned, & how great a mi≈øery is falleÃÑ for mine vnthaÃÑkfulnes for gods word, for mine hypocri≈øie in profe≈ø≈øing, preaching, hearing & ≈øpeaking of gods word, for my not praying to
God for ye continuance of it, for my not liuing of it throughly as it requireth &c. I wil ≈øpeake nothing of my manyfe≈øte euils, for they are knoweÃÑ to you wel enough. Deare brother & ≈øi≈øter, with me ≈øay ye the like for your owne parts, & with me ioyne your hartes, & let vs goe to our heauenly father & for his Chri≈øtes ≈øake be≈øech him to be mercifull vnto vs and to pardoÃÑ vs: Oh good father it is we that haue de≈øerued the taking away of thy worde, it is we that haue de≈øerued the≈øe thy iu≈øt plagues fallen vppon vs, we haue done a my≈ø≈øe, we haue dealt vniu≈øtly with thy Go≈øpel, we haue procured thy wrath, & therfore iu≈øt art thou in puni≈øhing vs, iu≈øt art thou in plaging vs, for we are very mi≈øerable. But good Lorde and deare father of mercy, who≈øe iu≈øtice is ≈øuch that yu wilte not puni≈øh the poore ≈øoules of thys realme, which yet haue not thus ≈øinned again≈øt thee as we haue done (for many yet neuer heard thy word) for our tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, & who≈øe mercye is ≈øo great that thou wilt put our iniquities out of thy remembraunce for thy Chri≈øtes ≈øake, if we repent & beleue: graunt vs we be≈øech thee true repeÃÑtaunce and fayth, that we hauing obtayned pardon for our ≈øinnes, may through thy Chri≈øt get deliueraunce froÃÑ the tyrannye of Antichri≈øt now oppre≈ø≈øing vs. Oh good father which ha≈øte ≈øayd that the Scepter of the wicked ≈øhould not long lie vpon and ouer the iu≈øte, le≈øt they put forth their hands to iniquitie al≈øo: make vs iu≈øt, we pray thee in Chri≈øtes name, & cut a ≈øunder the cordes of theÃÑ that hate Sion: let not ye wicked people ≈øaye where is their god? Thou our god art in heauen & doe≈øt what ≈øoeuer it plea≈øeth thee vpoÃÑ earth. Oh that yu woulde≈øt in the meane whiles, before yu do deliuer vs, that (I ≈øay) thou woulde≈øt open oure eyes to ≈øee al the≈øe plagues to come froÃÑ thee, & al other that ≈øhal come what≈øoeuer they be publike or priuate, that they come not by chaunce nor by fortune, but that they come eueÃÑ froÃÑ thy hand, and that iu≈øtly & mercifully: iu≈øtlye becau≈øe we haue & do de≈øerue them, not only by our birthpoy≈øon ≈øtil ≈øticking & working in vs, but al≈øo by our former euil life pa≈øt, which by this puni≈øhment & al other puni≈øhments yt woulde≈øt haue vs to cal to our remeÃÑbrance & to ≈øet before vs, that ye mighte≈øt put theÃÑ froÃÑ before thee, where as they ≈øtaÃÑd ≈øo long as they are not in our remeÃÑbrance to put theÃÑ away by repentance. Mercifully oh lord god doe≈øt thou puni≈øh, in that thou
doe≈øt not correct to kil, but to amend, that we might repent our ≈øinnes, a≈øke mercy, obteine it freely in Chri≈øt, and to beginne to ≈øuffer for righteou≈ønes ≈øake: to be part of thy hou≈øe, wherat thy iudgement beginneth: to be pertakers of ye afflictions of thy church and thy Chri≈øt, yt we myght be pertakers of the glory of ye ≈øame: to weepe here, yt we might reioice el≈øwhere: to be iudged in this world yt we might wt thy Saints iudge hereafter the world: to ≈øuffer with Chri≈øt yt we might reigne with him: to be like to Chri≈øt in ≈øhame, that we might be like to him in glory: to receaue our euelles here, that we might with poore Lazarus finde re≈øt el≈øwhere: re≈øt (I ≈øay) & ≈øuch a re≈øt as ye eye hath not ≈øene, the eare hath not heard nor the hart of man is able to coÃÑceaue. Oh yt our eyes were open to ≈øee this, that ye cro≈ø≈øe coÃÑmeth froÃÑ thee to declare thy iu≈øtice & thy mercy, and hereto, yt we might ≈øee how ≈øhort a time ye time of ≈øuffring is: how long a time the time of reioy≈øing is to theÃÑ that ≈øuffer here: but to theÃÑ that wil not, how long and mi≈øerable a time is appointed and prepared, a time without tyme in eternal woe and perditioÃÑ too horrible to be thought vpon. FroÃÑ the which kepe vs deare father & geue more ≈øight in ≈øoule to ≈øee this geare, and how that al thy deare≈øt childreÃÑ haue caried the cro≈ø≈øe of greuous affliction in thys lyfe, in who≈øe coÃÑpany do thou place vs, and ≈øuch a cro≈ø≈øe lay vpoÃÑ vs as thou wilt make vs able to beare, to thy glory and our ≈øaluation in Chri≈øt, for who≈øe ≈øake we pray thee to ≈øhorten the dayes of thys our great mi≈øery fallen vpon vs mo≈øt iu≈øtlye, and in the meane ≈øea≈øon geue vs pacience, repeÃÑtaunce, faith, and thy eternal con≈øolation, Amen, Amen, Amen.

And thus deare hartes I haue talked (me thinkes) a litle while with you, or rather we haue all talked with god. Oh that god would geue vs his ≈øpirite of grace and prayer. My dearly beloued pray for it, as for your ≈øelues, ≈øo for me, and that god would vouch≈øafe to make me worthy to ≈øuffer with a good con≈øcience for his names ≈øake. Pray for me, & I ≈øhal do the like for you. This .20. of December, by him whom by this bringer ye ≈øhal learne. I pray you geue my commendations to all that loue me in the Lord. Be mery in Chri≈øt, for one day in heauen we ≈øhall mete and reioyce together for euer more, Amen.

div.head: To my good brother Iohn Careles pry≈øoner in the King Bench.
div.p: THe father of mercy & god of all coÃÑfort, vi≈øet vs with his eternal con≈øolatioÃÑ, according to his great mercies in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Sauiour, Amen.

My very deare brother, if I ≈øhall report ye truth vnto you, I can not but ≈øignify that ≈øitheÃÑ I came into pri≈øoÃÑ, I neuer receaued ≈øo much con≈øolation as I did by your la≈øt letter, the name of god be mo≈øt hartely pray≈øed therfore. But if I ≈øhal report the truth vnto you, and as I haue begonne, ≈øpeake ≈øtil the verity, I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe that for mine vnthankfulnes to you wardes & to god e≈øpecially, I haue more nede of gods merciful tydings, theÃÑ I had euer heretofore. Ah that SathaÃÑ enuieth vs ≈øo greatly. Ah that our Lord would tread hys head vnder our feete ≈øhortly. Ah that I myght for euer, both my ≈øelf beware, & be a godly example to you & others to beware of vnthankefulnes. Good brother Careles, we had more nede to take hede after a lightning, of a foile theÃÑ before. God therfore is to be pray≈øed euen wheÃÑ he hideth & that of long, a chearful countenaunce from vs, le≈øt we being not expert how to v≈øe it as we ≈øhould do, do hurt more our ≈øelues thereby: ≈øo great is our ignorance and corruptioÃÑ. Thys my good brother & ryghte deare to my very hart, I write vnto you as to one whoÃÑ in the Lorde I embrace, and I thanke god yt you do me in like maner. God our father more & more geue vs both his good ≈øpirite, that as by fayth we may fele our ≈øelues vnited vnto him in Chri≈øt, ≈øo by loue we may fele oure ≈øelues linked in the ≈øame Chri≈øte one to an other, I to you and you to me, we to all the children of God and all the children of God to vs, Amen, Amen.

Commend me to our good brother Skelthrop, for whom I hartely pray≈øe my God whiche hath geuen him to ≈øee hys truth at ye leÃÑgth, & to geue place to it. I dout not but yt he wil be ≈øo heedye in al his coÃÑuer≈øatioÃÑ yt his old acquaintance may euer therby thinke theÃÑ≈øelues a≈øtray. Woe & woe again ≈øhold be vnto vs, if we by our exaÃÑple ≈øhould make meÃÑ to ≈øtuÃÑble at ye truth. Forget not ≈øalutatioÃÑs in Chri≈øt, as you ≈øhal thinke good
to Trewe & hys fellowes. The Lord hath his time (I hope) for them al≈øo, although we perchaunce thinke otherwi≈øe. A droppe maketh the ≈øtone hollow, not with once but with often dropping: ≈øo if with harty prayer for them and good example, you ≈øtil and droppe vpon them as you can, you ≈øhal ≈øee gods worke at the length. I be≈øech God to make perfect all the good he hath begonne in vs all, Amen. I de≈øire you all to pray for me the mo≈øt vnworthy pri≈øoner of the Lord.

div.head: To Maister Iohn Hall and hys wife pry≈øoners in Newgate for the te≈øtimonye of the Go≈øpell.
div.p:
ALmightie god our heauenly father throught Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, be with you both my dearlye beloued, as with hys deare children for euer, and he ≈øo ble≈ø≈øe you with his holy ≈øpirite that you maye in thys youre cro≈ø≈øe (for hys cau≈øe doubtles) reioyce, and gladlye take it vp to beare it ≈øo long as he ≈øhall thinke good. I haue heard (my good brother & ≈øi≈øter) how that God hath brought you both into hys Scholehou≈øe, where as you were both purpo≈øed by hys leaue to haue playd the Trewands, that therby you might ≈øee hys carefulnes and loue toward you. For if it bee a token of a louinge and careful father for hys children, to preuent the purpo≈øe and di≈øapoynte the intente of hys children purpo≈øing to departe a while froÃÑ the ≈øchole for feare of beating, which thyng they would not do if they dyd a≈ømuch con≈øider the comoditie of learning which there they might get: how ≈øhoulde you take thys worke of the Lord preuentyng your purpo≈øe, but as an euidente ≈øigne of loue and fatherly carefulnes that he beareth towards you? If he ≈øhould haue wincked at your willes, then would you haue e≈øcaped beating, I meane the cro≈ø≈øe: but then ≈øhould you haue lo≈øte the comoditie of learning, which your father wil now haue you to learne & feele, & therfore hath he ≈øent to you his cro≈ø≈øe. He I ≈øay, hath brought you where you be: & thoughe your rea≈øon and wit will tell you it is by chaunce or fortune or
or otherwy≈øe, yet (my derelye beloued) know for certayne that what≈øoeuer was the meane, GOD your father was the worker hereof; and that for your weale, althoughe otherwy≈øe your olde Adam doth tell you, and you feele: yet I ≈øay, of truthe that your duetye is to thynke of thys cro≈ø≈øe, that as it is of gods ≈øendyng and commeth from him: ≈øo although your de≈øertes be otherwi≈øe, it is of loue and fatherly affection for your weale and commodities ≈øake.

What commoditie is hereby, you will perchaunce obiect? You are now kept in clo≈øe pri≈øon you wyl ≈øay: your family and children be without good ouer≈øeers: your ≈øub≈øtaÃÑce demini≈øheth by the≈øe meanes: pouertye will approche, and perchaunce more perils al≈øo, as lo≈ø≈øe of lyfe &c. the≈øe are no commodities but di≈øcommodities, and that no ≈ømal ones: ≈øo yt iu≈øtly you woulde be glad to know what commoditie can come to you by thys cro≈ø≈øe, wherby commeth ≈øo greate di≈øcommodities.

To the≈øe thinges I aun≈øwer, that in dede it is true you ≈øay of your bodies, families, chyldren, ≈øub≈øtaunce, pouertye, lyfe &c. Which thynges, if you would con≈øider a while wyth inward eyes as you behold them wyth outward, then perhappes you ≈øhould fynd more ea≈øe. Do not you now by the inward ≈øen≈øe perceyue that you mu≈øt part from al the≈øe, and all other commodities in the world? Tell me then, haue not you this commoditye by your cro≈ø≈øe, to learne to lothe and leaue the world and to long for and de≈øyre an other world where is perpetuitie? You oughte of your owne heade and freewyll to haue (accordyng to your profe≈ø≈øion in bapti≈øme) for≈øaken the world and al earthly thynges, v≈øing the world as though you v≈øed it not, your hart only ≈øette vppon your hourde in heauen, or els you coulde neuer be Chri≈øtes true di≈øciples, that is be ≈øaued and be where he is. And trow you (my good hartes in the lord) trow you I ≈øay, that this is no commoditye, by this cro≈ø≈øe to be compelled hereto, that you myght a≈ø≈øuredly enioy wyth ye lord endles glory? How now doth god (as it were) fatherly pul you by the eares to remeÃÑ ber your former offences concernyng the≈øe thinges and all other thynges, that repentance and remi≈ø≈øion myght en≈øue? How doth god now compell you to cal vpon hym and to be earne≈øt in prayer? Are the≈øe no commodities? Doth not the
fcripture ≈øay that God doth correcte vs in the worlde becau≈øe we ≈øhall not bee dampned wyth the worlde? that god cha≈øteneth euery one whome he loueth? that the ende of this correction ≈øhall be ioy and holines? Doth not the ≈øcripture ≈øaye that they are happye that ≈øuffer for rightuou≈ønes ≈øake, as you now doe? that the glorye and ≈øprite of God is vpon them? that as you are now made lyke vnto Chri≈øte in ≈øufferyng, ≈øo you ≈øhall bee made lyke to him in raignyng? Doth not the ≈øcripture ≈øay that you are now going the high and ryghte waye to heauen? that your ≈øuffryng is Chri≈øtes ≈øufferyng? My dearely beloued what greater commodities then the≈øe can a godlye harte de≈øyre? Therefore ye are commaunded to reioyce and be glad when ye ≈øuffer, as nowe ye doe: for through the goodnes of god, great ≈øhalbe your rewarde. Where? Forfoth on earth, fir≈øt for your chyldren: for now they are in gods mere and immediate protection. Neuer was father ≈øo carefull for hys chylderne as God is for yours pre≈øently. Gods ble≈ø≈øyng which is more worth then all the worlde, you leaue in dede to your chyldern. Though all your prouidence for them ≈øhould be pulled away: yet god is not poore, he hath promy≈øed to prouyde for them mo≈øte fatherly. P≈øalm. 55 Ca≈øte thy burthen vppon me (≈øayth he) and I wil beare it. Do you therfore ca≈øt them and commend them vnto god your father, and doubte not that he wyll dye in your dec. He neuer yet was found vnfaythfull, and he wyl not now begynne wyth you. The good mannes ≈øede ≈øhall not go a beggyng hys breade: P≈øal. 37, for he wyll ≈øhewe mercye vppon thou≈øandes of the po≈øteritie of them that feare hym. Therfore as I ≈øaid, gods rewarde fyr≈øt vpon earth ≈øhalbe felt by your children euen corporally, and ≈øo al≈øo vpon you if God ≈øee it more for your commoditie, at the lea≈øt inwardly you ≈øhal feele it by quietnes and comforte of con≈øcience: and ≈øecondly after this lyfe you ≈øhal fynd it ≈øo plentifullye, as the eie hath not ≈øene, the eare hath not heard, the hart caÃÑnot conceiue how great & glorious gods reward wyl be vpoÃÑ your bodies, much more vpon your ≈øoules. God opeÃÑ our eies to ≈øee and fele this in dede. Then ≈øhal we thynke ye cro≈ø≈øe which is a meane herto, to be commodious. Then ≈øhall we thanke god yt he would cha≈øtice vs. TheÃÑ ≈øhall we ≈øaye with Dauid, happy am I that thou ha≈øt puni≈øhed me, for before I wente
a≈øtray, but now I kepe thy lawes. This that we may do in dede my derely beloued, let vs fir≈øte knowe that our cro≈ø≈øe coÃÑmeth from god. Secondly that it commeth from god as a father, yt is to our weale & good. Therfore let vs thirdly cal to mind our ≈øinnes & a≈øke pardon. Whereto let vs fourthly loke for help certainly at gods hand in his good time: helpe I ≈øay, ≈øuch as ≈øhal make mo≈øt to gods glory, & to the comfort & coÃÑmoditie of our ≈øoules & bodies eternally. This if we certainly conceiue, theÃÑ wil there i≈ø≈øue out of vs harty thankes geuiÃÑg which god requireth as a mo≈øt precious ≈øacrifice. That we may al through Chri≈øt offer this, let vs v≈øe earne≈øt praier to our god and dere father, who ble≈ø≈øe vs, kepe vs, and coÃÑ fort vs vnder hys ≈øwete cro≈ø≈øe for euer, Amen, Amen.

My dere hartes, if I could any way comfort you, you ≈øhould be ≈øure therof though my lyfe laye theron, but now I mu≈øt do as I may becau≈øe I caÃÑnot as I would. Oh that it would plea≈øe our deare father ≈øhortly to bring vs where we ≈øhould neuer departe, but enioy continually the ble≈ø≈øed fruicion of hys heauenly pre≈øence: pray, pray that it may ≈øpedely come to pa≈ø≈øe, pray. To morow I wyll ≈øende vnto you to knowe your e≈øtate, ≈øend me worde what are the chiefe≈øt things they charge you wythall. From the Counter.

closer.signed: By your brother in the Lorde. Iohn Bradford.

div.head: To My≈øtres Hall pry≈øoner in Newgate and ready to make aun≈øwer before her aduer≈øaries.
div.p: OVr mo≈øt merciful god and father throughe Chri≈øt Ie≈øus our lord and ≈øauiour, be merciful vnto vs, and make perfect the good he hath begonne in vs vnto the ende, Amen.

My deare Si≈øter, reioyce in the lord, reioyce, be glad (I ≈øay) be mery and thankful, Math. 5 not only becau≈øe Chri≈øt ≈øo coÃÑmaundeth vs, but al≈øo becau≈øe our ≈øtate wherin we are pre≈øeÃÑtly, requireth no le≈ø≈øe, for we are ye lords witne≈ø≈øes. God ye father hath vouched
≈øaffe to choo≈øe vs emonges many, to witnes and te≈øtify, that chri≈øt hys ≈øonne is Kyng and that hys word is true. Chri≈øt our ≈øauiour for hys loues ≈øake towards vs, wil haue vs to beare recorde that he is no v≈øurper nor deceyuer of ye people, but Gods Emba≈ø≈øadour, Prophet, and Me≈ø≈øias: ≈øo that of al dignities vpon earthe this is the highe≈øt. Greater honoure had not hys Prophetes, Apo≈øtles nor deare≈øt frendes, then to beare witnes wyth Chri≈øt, as we now doe. Not that I would excu≈øe other men, which exteriorly haue walked much more gro≈ø≈øely then manye of you haue done: but that I woulde prouoke you all as my ≈øelfe, to more harty repentaunce and prayer. Now the ≈øecond (I meane the ≈øequell, or that whyche wil follow on the ≈øtraungers) my derely beloued, let vs wel loke vpon. For if ≈øo be that god iu≈øtly do thus geue to Sathan and hys ≈øede, to vexe and mole≈øt Chri≈øte and hys penitente people: oh what and how iu≈øtly maye he and wyll he geue to Sathan to intreate the rechle≈ø≈øe and impenitent ≈øynners? Wherfore by theÃÑ (my derely beloued) be admoni≈øhed to remeÃÑber your profe≈ø≈øioÃÑ, how that in Bapti≈øme you made a ≈øoleÃÑpne vow to renouÃÑce ye deuil, ye world, &c. fyght lyke men and valiant men vnder Chri≈øtes ≈øtanderde: take vp your cro≈ø≈øe and follow your mai≈øter, as your brethern M. div.p: MY dearly beloued, I hartely coÃÑmeÃÑd me vnto you in our common Chri≈øt, whom I ≈øo cal, not that I would make him as common things be, that is nothing ≈øet by, but becau≈øe by him we are broughte into a coÃÑ munioÃÑ, & that as with him, ≈øo with his father, & as with his father, ≈øo with al gods people, if we be his people, as I tru≈øt we are: and therefore write I vnto you as one careful (but not ≈øo much as I ≈øhold be) for you, as for them who≈øe well doing comforteth me & is profitable to me, and who≈øe euil doing maketh me heuie, and woundeth me.

The dayes are come in the which we can not but declare what we be, if we be in deede as we ≈øhoulde be, as I tru≈øte we are, that is, if we be Chri≈øtes Di≈øciples. For albeit God hath not done thus to all that haue in deede done that he purpo≈øed to doe, yet in thys example he teacheth vs howe fearefull a thyng it is to wound our con≈øcience, and doe any thynge ther agayn≈øte, to the offence of the Godly, and comforte of the ob≈øtinate.

I wryte not thys as thereof to accu≈øe you or eyther of you, for as I can not lyghtlye bee per≈øuaded of anye ≈øuche thynge of you, ≈øo I am a≈ø≈øured you hetherto. div.head: To my good brother Maister Coker at Maldon in E≈ø≈øex.
div.p:
ALthoughe I haue pre≈øentlye both litle tyme and le≈ø≈øe oportunitie otherwy≈øe to write as I would, yet as I maye I thoughte better to write ≈øomethynge theÃÑ vtterlye to be ≈øilente. And to confe≈ø≈øe the truth, we haue double cau≈øe: as wel becau≈øe we haue de≈øerued this ≈øower ≈øauce by rea≈øoÃÑ of our vnthankfulnes and many ≈øinnes (which the Lord pardon) as becau≈øe gods glory is troden vnder foote. But thys comfort we haue, that as God our good father will not the death of a ≈øinner, ≈øo wyll

God graunte vs hys holy ≈øpirite to ≈øtrengthen vs in his truth profe≈ø≈øed, that we may per≈øeuer to the end in the ioyfull and couragious confe≈ø≈øing of his Chri≈øt, Amen.

I pray you continue as I tru≈øt you do, to kepe both ≈øoule and body pure in gods ≈øeruice. Striue to enter in at yt narrowe gate, thoughe you leaue your landes and goodes behinde you. It is not lo≈øte which for Chri≈øtes ≈øake we leaue, but lent to a great v≈øurye. RemeÃÑber that this time is come but to trye vs. God make vs faythfull to the end, God kepe vs alwayes as his children, Amen. I pray you coÃÑmende me to Mai≈øter O≈øburne, & to al our good brethren in the Lord. The peace of Chri≈øt be with vs all, Amen, Amen.

div.p: MY good brother, our mercifull God and deare father through Chri≈øt, open your eyes effectually to ≈øee, and your harte ardentlye to de≈øire the euerla≈øting ioy which he hath prepared for his ≈ølaughter ≈øheepe, that is for ≈øuche as ≈øhrinke not froÃÑ his truth for any ≈øtormes ≈øake, Amen.

Becau≈øe the chiefe≈øt matter they will trouble you & go about to deceaue you withal, is ye Sacrament, not of Chri≈øts body and blod but of the alter (as they cal it) therby de≈øtroying the ≈øacrament which Chri≈øt in≈øtituted: I would you noted the≈øe. 2. things. By this meanes, as you ≈øhal not allow tran≈øub≈øtantiation, nor none of their popi≈øh opinions: ≈øo ≈øhal you declare the ≈øacrament to be a matter of faythe and not of rea≈øon, as the papi≈øtes make it. div.head: ¬∂ A letter writen to a deare frende of hys, wherein he entreateth, as briefely, ≈øo mo≈øte perfectlye, godly, ≈øoundly and pithely, of gods holy election, free grace and mercy in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.
div.p:
FAythe of gods election, I meane to beleue that we be in very dede the chyldren of god through Chry≈øt, and ≈øhalbe for euer inheritours of euerla≈øtyng lyfe throughe the onely

But this notwyth≈øtanding, there is that haue gone aboute together, yea to ≈øette abroade enormities out of the doctryne of gods mo≈øte holye and comfortable election and prede≈øtination: where the ≈øame doctrine hath moe commodities then all the whole worlde can bee hable to conceyue, muche le≈ø≈øe to expre≈ø≈øe. It comforteth mo≈øt comfortablye in the cro≈ø≈øe, and ca≈øteth downe all cogitations that would els couer vs wyth ≈øorrowe and dolour, in tellyng that all thynges ≈øhall turne to the be≈øt. Rom. 8 It maketh vs mode≈øt and putteth away pride in pro≈øperitie by pulling froÃÑ men merityng or de≈øeruing. It enforceth men to loue & carefully to trauail for their brethreÃÑ, vtterly impugning the coÃÑ tempt of any.1 Cor. 1. 1. Iohn. 1 ‚Ä¢ . Cor. 6.3. It prouoketh to piety, & is the greate≈øt enemy to vngodlines yt can be, by teachyng vs of what dignity we be, of what pryce euen our bodies be, teÃÑples of the holy go≈øt, & meÃÑbers of Chri≈øt, It engendreth a true de≈øire of our home
in heaueÃÑ, & ≈øo to de≈øpi≈øe this world & the things yt this world hath in e≈øtimation. It helpeth very much to ye true vnder≈øtaÃÑding of ye ≈øcriptures, & pre≈øerueth froÃÑ errours, by knowyng what is to be attributed to the law, to ye go≈øpel, to the mini≈øtery, to ye vocal word, to ye old te≈øtameÃÑt, to the newe te≈øtament, to the ≈øacramentes, to faythe, to workes, to prayer, to penauÃÑce, to god, to man &c. For by the ≈øpirit of election we ≈øee & know Chri≈øt, Collo≈øs. 1 in whoÃÑ dwelleth al ye riches & trea≈øures of knowledge. It ≈øetteth vppe Chri≈øtes kingdome, and vtterly ouerthroweth the wi≈ødome, power, choyce, and hahlenes of man, yt al glory may be geuen onely vnto god. But what go I about to recken ye coÃÑmydities coÃÑ ming out of ye doctrine of gods election, in yt they be innumerable? This is a ≈øuÃÑme, Tit. 2. that where a chri≈øtiaÃÑ maÃÑs life hath re≈øpect to god, to man & to him≈øelf, to liue godly, iu≈øtly, and ≈øoberly: al is grouÃÑded in prede≈øtinatioÃÑ in Chri≈øt. For who liueth godly, but he yt beleueth? Act. 13. And who beleueth but ≈øuch as ar ordeined to eternal life? who liueth iu≈øtly, but ≈øuch as loue their neighbors? Wherfore (my derely deloued in ye lord) I haue takeÃÑ in haÃÑd at this pre≈øent ≈øomething to write to you & for your ≈øake in this mater, which herewtal I haue ≈øent vnto you, a≈øwel to be a help to you herein, as al≈øo to be a pledge of my careful loue & harty de≈øire I haue for your continuaÃÑce in ye truth, (wher in I tru≈øt you ≈øtand pre≈øeÃÑtly) wheÃÑ I am dead & burned, as I loke for none other, ≈øo ≈øone as god ≈øhal geue leaue to hys enemies for my weale & endles ioy in Chri≈øt: to whoÃÑ as to a mo≈øt faithful pa≈øtour, from the bottom of my hart, I do coÃÑ mend & bequeth you, be≈øeching him to watch ouer you night & day as ouer one of his poore laÃÑbes, to kepe you out of the clawes of the Lion & mouth of the wolues, to his glory and your eternall ioy and comfort in him. Amen.Al things mu≈øt be e≈øtemed after gods wy ‚Ä¢

THere is neither vertue nor vice to be coÃÑ≈øidered according to any outward action nor according ye wil & wi≈ødom of
man, but according to the wyll of god. Gene. 22. Mark 9. and the reque≈øt of ≈øome which would haue had fyer to come down from heauen vpon a zeale to god &c.

Gods will mu≈øt be ≈øought for in his worde.Now, the wyl of god is not ≈øo knowen as in his word: therefore according to it mu≈øt vice and vertue, good and euil be iudged, and not accordyng to the iudgemeÃÑt, wi≈ødom, rea≈øon and collection of any man or of al the whole world, if al the aungels in heauen ≈øhould take their part.

Gods word is written in the Bible.But thys word of God which is writen in the canonicall bokes of the Byble, doth plainly ≈øette forthe vnto vs, that god hath of hys owne mercy and good will, and to the pray≈øe of hys grace and glory,In the Bible is prede≈øtinatioÃÑ publi≈øhed. in chri≈øt elected ≈øome and not all, whome he hath prede≈øtinate vnto euerla≈øtyng lyfe in the ≈øame Chri≈øt, and in hys tyme calleth them, iu≈øtifyeth them, and glorifieth them, ≈øo that they ≈øhal neuer peri≈øhe and erre to damnation finally.

Therfore to affyrme, teach, and preache thys doctryne, hath in it no hurt,No enormitye is therfore in it. no vyce, no euil, much le≈ø≈øe then hath it any enormities (as ≈øome doe affyrme) to the eyes and ≈øpirite of them whyche are guided and will be by the word of god.

The propo≈øition that ≈øheweth what is ment by election and prede≈øtination, Which he after proueth by the partes out of the text of S. Paule immediatly followyng.That god the eternall father of mercies before the begynnyng of the world, hath of hys owne mercye and good wil, and to the pray≈øe of hys grace & glory, elected in Chri≈øt ≈øome and not al of the po≈øterity of Adam, whom he hath prede≈øtinate vnto eternal lyfe, and calleth them in his tyme, iu≈øtifieth them, and glorifyeth them, ≈øo that they ≈øhall neuer pery≈øh or erre to dampnation finally: that this propo≈øition is true and accordyng to gods playne and manife≈øt worde, by the helpe of his holy ≈øpiryte (which in the name of Ie≈øus
Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, I huÃÑbly be≈øech him of his mercy, pleÃÑteou≈øly to geue to me at this pre≈øent and for euer, to the ≈øanctification of hys holy name: by the helpe (I ≈øay) of hys holye ≈øpirite, I tru≈øt ≈øo euidently to declare, that no man of God ≈øhall be able by the worde of God, euer to impugne it, muche le≈ø≈øe to confute it.

In the fir≈øt chapter of the epi≈øtle to the Ephe≈øians,Ephe≈øi. 1. the Apo≈øtle ≈øayeth thus: Ble≈ø≈øed be god the father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which hath ble≈øsed vs wyth all maner of ble≈øsynges in heauenly thinges by Chri≈øt, accordyng as he hath elect or cho≈øen vs in hym before the foundation of the world was layed that we ≈øhould be holy and without blame before hym through loue: and hath prede≈øtinate vs (or ordeyned vs) thorough Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, to bee heyres vnto hym≈øelfe, accordyng to the good plea≈øure of hys wyll, to the pray≈øe of the glory of hys grace, wherwyth he hath made vs accepted in the beloued, by whom we haue receyued redeÃÑption thorough hys bloud, and the forgeuenes of our ≈øinnes, accordyng to the riches of hys grace, which grace he hath ≈øhed on vs aboundauntly in all wi≈øedome and vnder≈øtandyng, and hath opened vnto vs the my≈øterye of hys wyll accordyng to hys good plea≈øure, which he purpo≈øed in hym≈øelfe, to haue it declared when the tyme was full come, that he myght gather together all thynges by (or in) Christe, as well the thynges that be in heauen, as the thynges that be in earth, euen in (or by) hym: by (or in) whome we are made heyres, beyng thereto predestinate accordyng to the purpo≈øe of hym whiche worketh all thynges accordynge to the decree (or coun≈øayle) of hys owne wyll, that we which hoped before (you) in Chri≈øte, ≈øhoulde bee vnto the pray≈øe of hys glory: in whome ye al≈øo hoped, after that ye heard the word of truth, the go≈øpell of your ≈øaluation, wherein ye al≈øo beleuyng, were ≈øealed wyth the holy ≈øpirite of promy≈øe, whyche is the earne≈øt of our inheritaunce, vntyll the redeÃÑption (or full fruition) of the purcha≈øed po≈øse≈øsion, vnto the pray≈øe of hys glory.

The≈øe be the wordes of Paule, which I haue faithfullye tran≈ølated accordyng to the very texte in the Greeke, as by the iudgement of all that be learned I de≈øyre herein to bee tried. Out of the which wordes of Paule we may wel perceiue
euerye thing affirmed in my propo≈øitioÃÑ, as I wil geue occa≈øion plainly to them that wil, to ≈øee it.

The papi≈øts do place in preeminence ouer the whole church the Pope, therby vnplacing Chri≈øt which is the heade of the church that geueth life to the whole bodye, & by his ≈øpirite doth make liuely euery member of the ≈øame. As for that (which perchauÃÑce they wil vrge) that he ≈øpake to Peter by name, if they had any learnyng, they would ea≈øelye perceaue howe that it was not for any ≈øuch cau≈øe as they pretend, but rather by a threfolde coÃÑmaundement to re≈øtore to him the honour of an Apo≈øtle, which he had lo≈øt by his threfold denyal. And how dare they interpretate thys worde, my ≈øhepe, my LaÃÑbe ‚Ä¢ , to be the vniuer≈øal Church of Chri≈øt? I trowe a man might ea≈øely by the like rea≈øon proue that Peter hym≈øelf had re≈øigned that which Chri≈øt had geuen to hym, in exhortyng hys fellowe pa≈øtoures to feede the flocke of Chri≈øt. Is not thys pretye ≈øtuffe? Becau≈øe Chri≈øt ≈øayth to Peter, feede my ≈øheepe, therfore he ought to rule the vniuer≈øal and whole church of Chri≈øt. If Peter do truly write vnto others yt they ≈øhold do the lyke, that is fede Chri≈øtes flocke, eyther he tran≈ølateth hys right & authority coÃÑmitted to him vpon them, or els he doth participate & coÃÑmunicate it with them. So that foly≈øhly they goe aboute to e≈øtabli≈øhe that which hath no ground. Peter in dede was a ≈øhepeheard of the ≈øhepe, but ≈øuche a one as be≈øtowed hys labour on them ≈øo farre as he could ≈øtretch out hym ≈øelfe by hys mini≈øterye. But the papi≈øtes prate that he had ful power ouer all Churches: Wherin they maye ≈øee Paul to improue them, for els he had done vniu≈øtly in denying them the ≈øuperiour place. Howbeit, who euer yet redde that Peter dyd take any thyng vppon him ouer Churches
committed vnto other men? Was not he ≈øent of the churche, & ≈øent as one not hauing rule ouer the reaile I grauÃÑt that he was an excellent in≈øtrument of God, and for the excellencye of hys gyftes, when ≈øoeuer they meete together, place therfore was commonlye geuen vnto hym. But what is thys to the purpo≈øe, to make hym ruler & head ouer all the whole Churche becau≈øe he was ≈øo ouer a ≈ømall congregation?

But be it ≈øo that Peter had as much geuen to him as they do affyrme: who yet will graunt that Peter had a patrimony geuen for his heires‚ñ™ He hath left (≈øay the papi≈øtes) to hys ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, the ≈øelf ≈øame right which he receaued. Oh Lord God, then mu≈øt hys ≈øucce≈ø≈øour be a Sathan: Math. 4. for he receaued that title of Chri≈øt hym ≈øelfe. I woulde gladly haue the papi≈øtes to ≈øhew me one place of ≈øucce≈ø≈øioÃÑ mencioned in the Scriptures. I am ≈øure that when Paule purpo≈øely paynteth oute the whole admini≈øtration of the Churche, he neyther maketh one head, nor anye enheritable Primacye, and yet he is altogether in commendation of vnitye. After he hath made mencion of one God the father, of one Chri≈øte, of one ≈øpirite, of one body of the Churche, of one faythe, and of one bapti≈øme, then he de≈øcribeth the meane and manner howe vnitye is to be kept: namelye becau≈øe vnto euerye pa≈øtour is grace geuen after the mea≈øure wherewyth Chri≈øte hath endowed them. Where I praye you is now any title of Plenitudinis pote≈øtatis, of fulnes, of power? When he calleth home euery one vnto a certayne mea≈øure, whye dyd he not forthwith ≈øay, one Pope? Which thyng he coulde not haue forgotten, if the thinge had beene as the papi≈øtes make it.

But let vs graunt that perpetuitie of the Primacye in the Church, was e≈øtably≈øhed in Peter: I woulde gladlye learne why the Seate of the Primacye ≈øhoulde bee rather at Rome, then el≈øwhere. Marye ≈øaye they, becau≈øe Peters chaire was at Rome. Thys is euen lyke to thys, that becau≈øe Mo≈øes the greate≈øt Prophette, And Aaron the fyr≈øte Prie≈øte exerci≈øed theyr offyces vnto theyr deathe in the de≈øerte, therefore the principalle≈øt place of the Iewy≈øhe Churche ≈øhoulde bee in the wylderne≈ø≈øe.
But graunt them theyr rea≈øon, that it is good. What ≈øhould Antioche clayme? For Peters chaire was there al≈øo: wherin Paule gaue him a checke, which was vn≈øemely and vnmanerlye done of Paule, that would not geue place to hys pre≈øident & better. No ≈øaie the papi≈øtes, Rome mu≈øte haue this authoritie becau≈øe Peter died there. But what and if a man ≈øhould by probable coniectures ≈øhewe, that it is but a fable, which is fayned of Peters Bi≈øhoprike at Rome? Read how Paule doth ≈øalute very many priuate per≈øons when he writeth to the Romaines. Three yeres after hys Epi≈øtle made, he was brought to Rome pri≈øoner. Luke telleth, that he was receaued of the brethren, and yet in al the≈øe, no mention at all of Peter, whiche then by their Storyes was at Rome. Belike he was proude, as the Pope and Prelates be, or elles he woulde haue vi≈øited Paule. Paule beinge in pry≈øon in Rome, dyd wryte diuer≈øe Epi≈øtles, in whiche he expre≈ø≈øeth the names of manye whiche were in compari≈øon of Peter but ra≈øcall per≈øonages, but of Peter he ≈øpeaketh neuer a woorde. Surelye if Peter had beene there, thys ≈øilence of hym had beene ≈øu≈øpicious. In the ≈øecond Epi≈øtle to Timothye,2. Timo. 4. Paule complayneth that no man was with hym in his defence, but all had left hym. If Peter had beene then at Rome, as they write, then eyther Paule had belyed hym, or Peter had played hys Peters parte. Luke. 23. In an other place, howe doth he blame all that were with hym, Phi. 2. only Timothy excepted? Therfore we may well doubte whether Peter was at Rome By≈øhoppe as they prate: for all thys tyme and longe before, they ≈øaye that Peter was By≈øhoppe there. But I will not ≈øtyrre vppe coles in thys matter. If Rome bee the chiefe Seate becau≈øe Peter dyed there, whye ≈øhoulde not Antioche bee the ≈øecond? Why ≈øhoulde not Iames and Iohn whiche were taken with Peter to bee as pillers, Whye (I ≈øaye) ≈øhoulde not theyr Seates haue honour next to Peters Seate? Is not thys geare prepo≈øtorous, that Alexandria where Marke which was but one of the Di≈øciples, was By≈øhop, ≈øhould be preferred before Ephe≈øus where Iohn the EuaÃÑ geli≈øt taught and was bi≈øhop, and before Ieru≈øalem where not only Iames taught and dyed bi≈øhop, but al≈øo Chri≈øt Ie≈øus
our lord and high prie≈øt for euer? By whom beyng Mai≈øter (I hope) honour ≈øhold be geuen to his chaire, more then to the chayre of hys chaplaines. I neede to ≈øpeake nothing how that Paule telleth Peters Apo≈øtle≈øhip to concerne rather circumci≈øion or the Iewes, and therfore properly perteyneth not to vs. Neyther do I nede to bryng in Gregorius the ≈øixt bi≈øhop of Rome, which was about the yere of our Lord .600. Who plainly in his workes doth write, that this title of Primacy, & to be head ouer al churches vnder Chri≈øt, is a title mete and agreeing only to Antichri≈øt, and therfore he calleth it a prophane, a my≈øchieuous, and an horrible tytle. Who ≈øhould we beleue now, yf we wyll neyther beleue Apo≈øtle nor Pope?

If I ≈øhould go about to tell how this name was fir≈øt gotten by Phocas, I ≈øhould be to long. I purpo≈øe god willyng to ≈øet it forth at large in a worke whiche I haue begun of Antichri≈øt, yf god for hys mercies ≈øake geue me lyfe to fini≈øhe it. For thys pre≈øent therfore I ≈øhall de≈øyre your Ladi≈øhip to take thys in good part. If they will nedes haue the Bi≈øhop of Rome to bee acknowledged for the heade of the church, then wyll I vrge them that they ≈øhall geue vs a bi≈øhop. But they obtrude vnto vs a butcher rather, or a bite≈øhepe, then a bi≈øhop. They bragge of Peters ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, of Chri≈øtes Vycar, this is alwayes in theyr mouth. But alas, how can we call hym Chri≈øtes Vicar that re≈øi≈øteth Chri≈øte, oppugneth hys veritye, per≈øecuteth hys people, and lyke a Prelate preferreth hym≈øelfe aboue God and man? Howe, or wherin dothe the Pope and Chri≈øt agree? Howe ≈øupplyeth he Peters mini≈øtery that boa≈øteth of hys ≈øucce≈ø≈øion? Therfore to beginne withal, which I wyl v≈øe pre≈øently for a conclu≈øion, yf the papi≈øtes wyll haue the bi≈øhop of Rome Supreme head of the church of Chri≈øt in earthe, they mu≈øt afore they attaine this, geue vs a bi≈øhop in dede and not in name. For who≈øoeuer he be that wyl make this the bonde of vnitye, what ≈øoeuer the bi≈øhop of Rome be, ≈øurelye thys mu≈øte nedes follow, that they do nothyng els but teache a mo≈øte wycked defection and departyng from Chri≈øt. But of thys, if God lende me lyfe, I purpo≈øe to ≈øpeake more at large hereafter. Nowe wyll I betake your Lady≈øhip, vnto the
tuition of god our father and Chri≈øt our only head pa≈øtour & keper, to whome ≈øee that you cleane by true fayth whiche dependeth only vpon the worde of god, which if you do follow as a lanterne to your feete and a light to your ≈øteppes, you ≈øhall then auoyde darkenes, and the daungerous depts wherinto the Papi≈øts are falleÃÑ by the iu≈øt iudgemeÃÑt of god, and ≈øeke to bryng vs into the ≈øame dungeon wyth theÃÑ, that the blynde followyng the blynd, they both may fal into the dy≈øche: out of the which god deliuer them accordyng to hys good wyl, & pre≈øerue vs for hys names ≈øake, that we beyng in his lyght may continue therin and walke in it while≈øt it is daye: ≈øo ≈øhall the nyght neuer oppre≈ø≈øe vs, we going troÃÑ lyght to lyght, from vertue to vertue, from fayth to faythe, from glory to glory by the gouernaunce of gods good ≈øpirite, whiche God our father geue vnto vs all for euer and euer. div.head: To myne owne good brother Mayster Iohn Phylpot, pry≈øoner in the Kynges Benche.
div.p:
MY dere brother, God our father be pray≈øed for the good he dothe worke in you and by you. Euen nowe I haue receyued your louyng letters, wherein I ≈øee cau≈øe to ble≈ø≈øe God for the wi≈ødome, loue, and efficacy he hathe and doth worke in you and by you. Go on for gods ≈øake to ≈øeke vnitie in chri≈øt. If any wyl go to worke di≈ø≈øemblingly, refu≈øe it not: either ≈øhal it encrea≈øe hys dampnation, or occa≈øion hym the ≈øoner to conuer≈øion. Iudas di≈ø≈øembling turned to the hurt of him ≈øelfe onely. If once we come into an vnitye and loue, then ≈øhall we not re≈øpecte one an other, neyther take thynges in to the wour≈øe part. Nothyng hyndreth them more, then for
that nowe they heare all that euer we ≈øpeake Cum preiudicio, He meaneth here certayne freewyl men. Where if an vnitye bee had, this preiudicium wyll bee taken away, and ≈øo then ≈øhal they ≈øee the truth the ≈øoner. Therfore myne owne deare≈øt brother, go on & bring it to a good ende. Praye my good brother, and de≈øyre myne owne fellowe and beloued brother. I. Careles to doe the lyke. I ≈øhall praye for you, bothe in my prayers wyth others, and wyth my ≈øelfe alonely, as for my mo≈øte deare brother vpon earth. I wyll not forget by gods grace, to wryte in the behalf of our brethern in nece≈ø≈øitie. Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our ≈øwete Sauiour be wyth vs all Emanuell for euer. Amen.

div.head: To my frendes and brethren in the Lorde R. Cole, and N. Sheterden.
div.p: I Wi≈øh to you my good bretherne, ye ≈øame grace of God in Chri≈øt, which I wy≈øh and pray the father of mercies to geue to me for hys holye names ≈øake, Amen.

Your letter though I haue not redde my ≈øelf, becau≈øe I would not alienate my mynd from conceiued things to wryte to others, yet I haue heard the ≈øumme of it, that it is of gods election: where in I wyll briefly write to you my faith, & how I thinke it good & mete for a chri≈øtiaÃÑ man to wade in it. I beleue that Chri≈øt for man being thus falleÃÑ, did appo≈øe him≈øelf to the iu≈øtice of god a mediator, paying the raun≈øome and price of redeÃÑption for AdaÃÑ and his whole po≈øteritie that refu≈øe it not finally. Act. 8. or by rea≈øon of earthly coÃÑmodity Mat. 13. cu≈øtome & autority of me which is

Thus do I wade in prede≈øtination,For the certeyntie of this fayth ≈øearch your hartes. If you haue it, pray≈øe the Lord, for you are happy, and therfore cannot fynally pery≈øhe: for then happynes were not happynes, yf it could be lo≈øt. when you fal, the Lord wil put vnder hys hande that you ≈øhall not lye ≈øtill. But if ye feele not thys fayth, then know that prede≈øtination is to hygh a matter for you to be di≈øputers of, vntyl ye haue ben better ≈øcholers in the ≈øcholehou≈øe of repentaunce and iu≈øtification, which is the Grammer ≈øchole wherin we mu≈øt be conuer≈øant and learned, before we go to the vniuer≈øity of gods mo≈øt holy prede≈øtination and prouidence. in ≈øuch ≈øort as god hath pacifyed and opened it. Though in god it be the fir≈øt, yet to vs it is la≈øt opened. And therfore I beginne wyth creation, from thence I come to redemption, ≈øo to iu≈øtification, and ≈øo to election. On this ≈øort I am ≈øure that warelye & wy≈øely a man may walk in it ea≈øely by the light of gods ≈øpirite, in and by hys worde, ≈øeyng thys faith not to be geuen to al men, 2. The≈øs. 3. but to ≈øuch as are borne of god, prede≈øtinate before the worlde was made, after the purpo≈øe and good wyll of God: whiche will we may not call into di≈øputation, but in tremblyng and feare ≈øubmit our ≈øelues to it as to that which can will none otherwi≈øe then that which is holy right & good, how farre ≈øo euer otherwy≈øe it ≈øeme to ye iudgement of rea≈øon, whych mu≈øt nedes bee beaten downe to bee more careful for gods glory then for mans ≈øaluation, which dependeth onelye thereon, as all gods chyldren full well ≈øee, for they ≈øeeke not the glorye whyche commeth of men: but the glory whyche commeth of GOD. Ieremye. 9. Ioan. 5. They knowe God to bee a God whiche dothe on earthe not onely mercy but al≈øo iudgement, which is iu≈øtyce & mo≈øt iu≈øtice, although our foli≈øhe rea≈øon cannot ≈øee it. And in this knowlege they glory and reioyce, thoughe others through vayne curio≈øity, grudch and murmure there agayn≈øt. Thus briefly I haue ≈øent you my mynd and meanyng concernyng thys matter. Hereafter you ≈øhal haue (I thynke) your letter particulerlye aun≈øwered by M. Philpotte: as al≈øo if I haue tyme and you ≈øo require it, I will do,

div.head: To my good brother R. Cole.
div.p: MYne owne good brother, our good & mo≈øt merciful father more and more embrace vs in the armes of hys mercy as hys louyng & own natural children, and geue vs one to embrace an other in the armes of loue as true bretherne, that wyth one hart and mynde we may pray≈øe hys holye name in Chri≈øte our Sauiour, and throughe the grace of hys ≈øpirite may mightely euery one fyght again≈øte ≈øinne and all that is again≈øt the kyngdome of Chri≈øt: wherunto (my beloued) we are called effectually to our euerla≈øting felicity (I dout not) pray≈øed be the name of our good god therefore for euer and euer, Amen.

Myne owne hart in the lord, de≈øire our bretherne that euery one would bend him≈øelf to bowe: let vs neuer breake. Loue ≈øuffreth long and ≈øeeketh not her ≈øelfe. We haue al one father, we are all brethern, God kepe vs from di≈ø≈øention. If we caÃÑnot agree in al pointes, eyther the poyntes perchauÃÑce bee not ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarye, or elles by loue we ≈øhall hereafter hee brought to ≈øee that which yet is hidde. If loue may appeare in al our doynges, and that we ≈øeeke one an other wyth a ≈øymple and a ≈øyngle eye in gods ≈øyght, doubtle≈ø≈øe all preiudice wherby we are letted to ≈øee manife≈øt thynges, wyll bee had away, and we will take thyngs ≈øpoken and done in the be≈øt part: and ≈øo doutles the name of our father ≈øhalbe ≈øanctified in vs and by vs, as by in≈øtruments of grace, and gods kingdome ≈øhal encrea≈øe apace in vs and by vs al≈øo, whiche thing he graunt for his mercies ≈øake, Amen.

Commend me hartely I pray you to bothe tho≈øe good women. Good I cal them, becau≈øe I am per≈øuaded that god wil deliuer them, e≈øpeciall my good Mary. I will not cea≈øe but euen as for my ≈øelf to pray to god for them, and for you, my right deare brother in the Lorde. If you were acquainted with M. div.head: ¬∂To my good Sy≈øter My≈øtres Elizabeth Browne.
div.p: GOod Si≈øter, god our father make perfecte the good he hath begunne in you vnto the ende.

I am afrayd to wryte vnto you becau≈øe you ≈øo ouercharge your ≈øelf at al times, eueÃÑ wheÃÑ≈øoeuer I do but ≈øend to you coÃÑmendatioÃÑs. I wold be more bold on you then on many others, and therfore you myght ≈øu≈øpend ≈øo great tokens till I ≈øhoulde wryte vnto you of my nede, which thyng doutles I would do, if it vrged me. Deare Sy≈øter, I ≈øee your vnfayned loue to me wardes in god, and haue done of long time, the which I do recompence wyth the like and wil doe by gods grace ≈øo long as I liue, and therfore I hope not to forget you, but in my poore praiers to haue you in remeÃÑbraunce, as I hope you haue me. Otherwi≈øe I can do you no ≈øeruice, excepte it be now and then by my writing to let you from better exerci≈øe, where yet the ende of my writing is to excite & ≈øtyrre vp your harte more earne≈øtlye to go on forwardes in your well begunne enterpry≈øe.2. Timo. 2. For you know none ≈øhalbe crowned but ≈øuch as ≈øtriue lawfully, and none receiueth the gleue but tho≈øe that runne to the appointed marke. None ≈øhal be ≈øaued but ≈øuche as per≈øi≈øte and continue to the verye ende. Therfore (dere Sy≈øter) remember that we haue nede of patience, Hebr. 20 that when we haue done the good wyll of God we may receiue the promi≈øe. Patience and per≈øeueraunce be the proper notes wherby gods children are known from counterfaites. They that per≈øeuer not, were alwayes but hypocrites. Manye make godly beginnings, yea their progre≈ø≈øe ≈øemeth meruelous, but yet after the ende they fayle. The≈øe were neuer of vs, ≈øayth S. Iohn: for yf they had bene of vs, they woulde haue continued vnto the verye ende. Goe to therefore myne owne beloued in the Lorde: as you haue
well begunne and well gone forwarde, ≈øo well per≈øy≈øt and happely ende, and then all is yours. Though this be ≈øharpe and ≈øower, yet it is not tedious or long. Doe all that euer you doe, ≈øymplye for GOD and as to God, ≈øo ≈øhall neuer vnkyndnes nor anye other thynge make you to leaue of from well doyng, ≈øo longe as you may do well. Accu≈øtome your≈øelfe nowe to ≈øet GOD continuallye, that he may be all in all vnto you. In good thynges beholde hys mercye and applye it vnto your ≈øelfe. In euyl thinges and plagues beholde hys iudgementes, wherthorough learne to feare hym. Beware of ≈øynne as the Serpente of the ≈øoule, which ≈øpoyleth vs of all oure or nature and ≈øeemelye apparell in Gods ≈øyghte. Let Chry≈øt crucifyed be your booke to ≈øtudye on, and that bothe nyghte and daye. Marke youre vocation, and be diligente in the workes thereof: v≈øe hartye and earne≈øte prayer and that in ≈øpyryte. In all thynges geue thankes to GOD our father throughe Chry≈øte. Laboure to haue here lyfe euerla≈øtynge begonne in you: for elles it wyll not be el≈øewhere enioyed. Set Gods iudgement often before your eies that now examinyng your ≈øelfe, you maye make diligent ≈øute and obtayne neuer to come into iudgemente. Vncouer your euyls to God, that he maye couer them. Beware of thys Antichri≈øtian tra≈øhe: defyle not your ≈øelfe in ≈øoule or bodye therewyth, but accomply≈øhe holynes in the feare rf GOD, and beare no yoke wyth vnbeleuers. Looke for the commyng of the Lorde, whyche is at hande: by earne≈øt prayer and godly lyfe, ha≈øten it. GOD oure father accomply≈øhe hys good worke in you. Amen.
Commende me to my good Mother My≈øtres Wylkyn≈øon, and to my verye deare Sy≈øter My≈øtres Warcuppe. I ≈øhal dayly commende you all to GGD, and I praye you do the lyke for me.

div.head: To Mystres Browne.
div.p: GOod Sy≈øter I be≈øeche god to make perfecte the good he hath begonne in you vnto, the very ende, Amen.

Thys lyfe more and more waxeth vnto vs as it ≈øhoulde be, that is a mi≈øerable life, a wepyng lyfe, a wofull lyfe, and therfore let vs long for our happy life, our laughing life, our ioyfull lyfe, which we ≈øhall enioy & then haue in very dede, wheÃÑ we depart by death out of this dauÃÑgerous ≈øtate, wherin we nowe are by rea≈øon of this ≈øynful fle≈øh which we cary about vs. Therfore let vs prepare our ≈øelues accordyngly, and in mi≈øery and ≈øorrow, be glad through hope. Now we are di≈øper≈øed, but we ≈øhal be gathered together again there, where we ≈øhall neuer part, but alwayes be together in ioye eternall. In hope hereof let vs beare wyth better wyl, our bytter burthens which we feele and ≈øhall feele in thys mi≈øerable world. We haue cau≈øe to thanke god that maketh this worlde vnto vs a wyldernes. If ≈øo be therein we bee patient, ki≈ø≈øe gods todde, and humble oure ≈øelues before God: a≈ø≈øuredly we ≈øhall come into the mo≈øt plea≈øaunt land of re≈øt. Wherfore (good Si≈øter) as I ≈øaid I ≈øay again, be mery with ≈øorrow, reioyce in hope, be pacient in trouble, pray in affliction, & amonge≈øt other, I pray you hartely pray for me, that god woulde forgeue me my vnthankefulnes, not onelye again≈øt you which is great in dede, but al≈øo agayn≈øte all hys people, but ≈øpecially agayn≈øt hys maie≈øty. As I can, I ≈øhall commende you vnto the tuition of our ≈øhepeharde Chri≈øte, who alwayes kepe vs as hys Lambes, for hys holy names ≈øake, Amen.

div.head: ¬∂To a faythfull frende of hys, whome for hys godly ≈øymplicity and ≈øynglenes of hart in the wayes of the Lorde, he called Nathanaell, as he doth al≈øo here in thys letter.
div.p:
THe merciful God, and father of our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which loueth vs as a mo≈øt dere father, and hath put vpon hym towardes vs the affectioÃÑ of a mo≈øt tender mother towards her chyldren, ≈øo that he can no le≈ø≈øe thynke vpon
vs (althoughe of oure ≈øelues we bee mo≈øte vnworthye and de≈øerue nothyng le≈ø≈øe) then ≈øhe can thynke on her onelye begotten childe in hys di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, yea if ≈øhe ≈øhould forget her childe as ≈øome vnnaturall mother will doe, yet wyll he neuer forgette vs, althoughe for a tyme he ≈øeme to ≈ølepe, that we myghte bee occa≈øioned to call loude and awake hym: thys good GOD keepe you my deare brother Nathanaell, and your good yokefellowe, my hartelye beloued Si≈øter in the Lorde, in all thyngs nowe and for euer, to hys glorye and your eternall comforte, and al≈øo of hys goodne≈ø≈øe he graunte you both the feeling of that hope, whiche vndoubtedlye he hath layde vppe in ≈øtoore for you both, farre pa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtore and proui≈øion, not onely whiche you had made, but all the worlde is hable to make, as I tru≈øte alreadye he hath wroughte it in you, but I be≈øeche hym to encrea≈øe it more and more, and kindle in you a hartye longing for the enioying of the ≈øame: the whiche once felte and had indeede, then the meanes by the whiche we come thereto, can not be ≈øo greatly dredde, as mo≈øt meÃÑ do dread theÃÑ, becau≈øe either they want this feling (I meane it of altogether) or elles becau≈øe the ≈øen≈øe of thys pre≈øente tyme and thynges therein, are as a my≈øte to the hyding of tho≈øe thynges from oure ≈øyghte, lea≈øt we ≈øhoulde runne and embrace them by hartye prayer: the ≈øpirite whereof God graunte vs, and in deede we ≈øhoulde attayne enough in this behalfe, if we continued therein.

For auriculer confe≈ø≈øion, wherein you de≈øyre my aduice for your good yokefellowe and familye (my mo≈øte dere brother) I am as readye to geue it, as you to de≈øire it, yea more gladde, fora≈ømuch as halfe a ≈øu≈øpitioÃÑ was in me (at the lea≈øt touching my dere ≈øi≈øter your wife) of a lothing of my aduice, that too muche had beene geuen, where in deede I ≈øhoulde lamente my to little feeding you ≈øpirituallye, as both you oute of pry≈øon and in pry≈øon haue fedde me corporallye. But as I alwayes thoughte of her, ≈øo I yet thynke, that ≈øhe is the childe of GOD, whom God dearely loueth, and wyll in hys good tyme, to her eternall comforte, geue her her hartes de≈øire in ≈øure feelyng and ≈øen≈øible beleuyng of thys, which I would ≈øhe had often in her mynde: namely
that he is her God and father throughe Chri≈øte Ie≈øus oure deare Lorde and Sauiour. A greater ≈øeruice to God, ≈øhee can not geue then to beleue thys. If Sathan ≈øaye ≈øhe beleueth not, to aun≈øwere, not him but the Lord, and to ≈øaye, yea Lorde helpe my vnbeliefe and encrea≈øe my poore faythe, whiche Sathan ≈øayeth is no fayth: make hym a lyer Lorde as alwayes he hath beene, is, and ≈øhall bee. Vndoubtedlye ≈øooner or later, God will graciou≈ølye here her groues, and keepe all her teares in hys bottell yea wryte them in hys counting booke: for he is a ryghteous God and hath no plea≈øure in the death of hys creature: he loueth mercye, he will retourne and ≈øhewe her his mercye: he will ca≈øte all her ≈øinnes and iniquities into the bottome of the ≈øea: and the longer that he taryeth (as he doth it but to proue her) ≈øo the more liberallye will he recompence her longe lookyng, whiche no le≈ø≈øe plea≈øeth hym, then it greueth nowe her outward Adam. For the mortification whereof, God v≈øeth this cro≈ø≈øe, and therefore if ≈øhe de≈øire to beare the ≈øame, doubtles God will make her able to beare it: and in pre≈øumption of hys goodne≈ø≈øe and ≈øtrengthe, let her ca≈øte her ≈øelfe wholye vppon hym: for he is faythfull and wyll a≈ø≈øuredlye confyrme and bring to a happye ende that good whiche graciou≈ølye he hath begonne in her. The whiche thing I de≈øyre hym to doe for hys owne glorye and names ≈øake, Amen, Amen.

And nowe to the matter. Confe≈ø≈øion auriculer, as it was fyr≈øt v≈øed and in≈øtituted (whiche was by the way of a couÃÑ≈øel a≈øking) I take to be amonges tho≈øe traditioÃÑs which are indifferent, that is, neyther vnlawfull, nor nece≈ø≈øarilye binding vs, excepte the offence of the weake could not be auoyded. But to con≈øider it as it is now v≈øed) I write to you but as I thinke and what my minde is, the whiche followe no further then good men by Gods woorde doe allowe it) to con≈øider it I ≈øaye, as it is nowe v≈øed, me thynkes it is plainelye vnlawfull and wicked, and that for the≈øe cau≈øes. Fyr≈øte becau≈øe they make it a ≈øeruice of God and a thynge whiche plea≈øeth God of it ≈øelfe, I will not ≈øaye meritorious. Thys brynger my brother can tell you at large howe greate an euill thys is. Secondlye becau≈øe they make it
of nece≈ø≈øitye, ≈øo that he or ≈øhee that v≈øeth it not, is not taken for a good Chri≈øtian. Thyrdlye becau≈øe it requireth of it ≈øelfe an impo≈ø≈øibilitie, that is, the numbring and tellyng of all oure ≈øinnes, whiche no man perceaueth, muche le≈ø≈øe can vtter. Fourthlye becau≈øe it e≈øtabli≈øheth and confyrmeth, at the lea≈øt alloweth praying to Sainctes: precor Sanctam Mariam you mu≈øte ≈øaye or the prie≈øte for you. Fyfthly becau≈øe it is verye iniurious to the libertye of the Go≈øpell, the whiche to affyrme in example and facte, I take to bee a good worke and a deare in Gods ≈øighte. Sixtlye becau≈øe (as it is v≈øed) it is a note, yea a verye ≈øynowe of the popy≈øhe Churche, and therefore we ≈øhoulde be ≈øo farre from allowing the ≈øame, that we ≈øhoulde thynke oure ≈øelues happye to lo≈øe anye thynge in bearyng witne≈ø≈øe there again≈øt. Seuenthly, becau≈øe in ≈øtead of coun≈øell, thereat you ≈øhoulde receaue poy≈øon, or if you refu≈øe it vnder Syr Iohns benedicite, you ≈øhoulde no le≈ø≈øe there bee wounde in the bryers. Eyghtlye becau≈øe the ende and purpo≈øe why we goe thether, is for the auoyding of the cro≈ø≈øe, that is; for oure owne cau≈øe and not for Chri≈øtes cau≈øe or for oure brethrens commoditye. For in yt they make it ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarye a thyng and a wor≈øhipping of God, it can not but be agayn≈øte Chri≈øte and the freedome of hys Go≈øpell: and the ≈øame thing teacheth vs that it is agayn≈øte the commoditie of oure brethren, whiche eyther be weake, eyther be ≈øtronge, eyther be ignoraunt, either be ob≈øtinate. If they be weake, by your re≈øorting to it they bee made more weake. If they bee ≈øtrong, you do what you can to infyrme their ≈øtrengthe, if they bee ignoraunte, therein you helpe to keepe them by your facte. If they be ob≈øtinate, your re≈øortyng to it, can not but rocke them a ≈ølepe in their ob≈øtinate error of the nece≈ø≈øitye of this rite and ceremonie. The≈øe cau≈øes recited do ≈øhew you what I thinke in thys: but my thinking mu≈øte no further binde you then a mannes thought ≈øhould do, except the ≈øame be grounded vpon gods word which bindeth in dede, as I thinke they do. I dout not but you waying the≈øe cau≈øes, and e≈øpeciallye .ii. of the fyr≈øte and the la≈øte, if you pray to
God for hys ≈øpirite to directe you, and thereto a≈øke the aduice of thys my good brother and other godly learned meÃÑ, I doubte not (I ≈øay) but you ≈øhoulde bee guided to doe that whiche is be≈øte in Gods ≈øyght, althoughe in the ≈øyghte of the world, perhappes you ≈øhoulde bee counted foly≈øhe and precy≈øe. But be at a point with your ≈øelues, as the Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt whiche had for≈øaken them≈øelues, to followe, not your wyll but Gods will, as you daylye praye in the Lords prayer. The cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt, be willyng to carye, lea≈øte you carye the cro≈ø≈øe of the worlde, the fle≈øhe, or the deuill. One of the≈øe .iiii. cro≈ø≈øes you mu≈øte cary. Three of them bryngeth to hell,why the more part goe that way that leadeth to perdition. and therfore the more parte goeth that way, whiche is a broade way. Only the fourth bryngeth to heauen, but fewe goe that waye, a≈øwell becau≈øe the waye is ≈øtrayte, as al≈øo becau≈øe fewe walke in it. Howbeit, thoughe it be ≈øtraite it is but ≈øhorte, and the fewe are manye if you con≈øider the godly, as the Patriarkes, Prophettes, Apo≈øtles, Martyrs, Confe≈ø≈øours, and Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, with all hys Gard & traine. Thinke not ≈øcorne to come after them which are gone before you, and after them whiche nowe goe before you, in who≈øe number I tru≈øt I am appoynted to bee one, and I be≈øeche you pray for me that god woulde vouche me worthye that honour. Our ≈øinnes de≈øerue plagues, pri≈øon, and the lo≈ø≈øe of al that euer we haue: therfore if god remoue our ≈øinnes out of ≈øyght, and ≈øend vs pri≈øon, or lo≈ø≈øe of goods and liuing for his names ≈øake, Oh how happye are we? My deare hartes in the Lorde, con≈øider this geare, and be a≈ø≈øured yt he whiche lo≈øeth any thyng for Chri≈øtes ≈øake, the ≈øame in his po≈øteritie ≈øhal finde it here, and in heauen el≈øwhere. As for vnablenes to an≈øweare for your fayth: it ≈øhall be enough to will theÃÑ to di≈øpute with your teachers. Fayth ≈øtaÃÑdeth not in di≈øputing. I thinke fewe, if it came to di≈øputing, could defend the Godhead of Chri≈øt, and many other articles: I ≈øpeake it for the ≈øimple ≈øort. Pray for me. Lacke of paper maketh thys ende. Commend me to my good brother Richard Bleacher, and my good ≈øi≈øter his wyfe: I pray them to pray for me. I tru≈øt by this bearer to heare how you doe.

div.head: To certayne Godly men, whom he exhorteth to bee patient vnder the cro≈ø≈øe & con≈øtant in the true doctrine which they had profe≈ø≈øed.
div.p: MY dearely beloued in the Lord, as in hym I wy≈øhe you well to fare, ≈øo I praye God I and you maye continue in hys true ≈øeruice, that perpetually we maye enioye the ≈øame welfare, as here in hope, ≈øo in heauen in deede and eternallye.

You knowe thys worlde is not your home, but a pilgrimage and place wherin God tryeth hys children, and therfore as it knoweth you not, nor can know you: ≈øo I tru≈øt you know not it, that is, you allowe it not, nor in any poynte wyll ≈øeme ≈øo to do, althoughe by manye you be occa≈øioned therto. For thys whote ≈øunne which now ≈øhineth, burneth ≈øo ≈øore, that the corne which is ≈øowen vpon ≈øand and ≈øtonye ground, beginneth to wyther: that is, many which before tymes we toke for hartye Go≈øpellers, beginne nowe for the feare of afflictions to relente, yea to turne to their vomytte agayne, thereby declaring that thoughe they go from amonge≈øt vs, yet were they neuer of vs: for els they would haue ≈øtill taryed with vs,1. Ioh. 2 and neyther for gayne nor lo≈ø≈øe, haue left vs eyther in word or deede. As for their hart (whiche vndoubtedly is double, and therfore in daunger to Gods cur≈øe) we haue as muche with vs, as the papi≈øtes haue with them, and more too by theyr owne iudgenente. For they playing wilie begile them≈øelues, thynke it enough inwardlye to fauour the truth, though outwardly they currye fauour. What though with my body (≈øay they) I do this or that, GOD knoweth my harte is whole wyth hym. Ah brother, if thy harte be whole with GOD, why doe≈øt not thou confe≈ø≈øe and declare thy ≈øelfe accordynglye by woorde and facte? Eyther that whiche thou ≈øaye≈øt thou beleue≈øt in thy hart, is good or no. If it be good, whye arte thou a≈øhamed of it? If it be euill, whye doe≈øt thou keepe it in thy harte? Is not GOD hable to defende thee, aduenturing
thy ≈øelfe for hys cau≈øe? Or wyll not he defende hys wor≈øhippers? Doth not the Scripture ≈øaye that the eyes of the Lorde are on them that feare hym, and tru≈øte in hys mercye? P≈øal. 33 And whereto? For≈øoth to deliuer theyr ≈øoules from death, and to feede them in the tyme of hunger. If thys bee true, as it is mo≈øte true, whye are we afrayde of death, as thoughe GOD coulde not comforte or deliuer vs, or woulde not, contrarye to hys promy≈øe? Whye are we afrayde of the lo≈ø≈øe of oure goodes, as thoughe GOD woulde leaue them that feare hym, de≈øtitute of all good thynges, and ≈øo doe agayn≈øte hys mo≈øte ample promy≈øes? Ah faythe faythe, howe fewe feele thee nowe a dayes? Luke. 18. Full trulye ≈øayde Chri≈øte that he ≈øhoulde ≈øcarcelye finde faythe when he came on earth. For if men beleued the≈øe promy≈øes, they woulde neuer doe anye thynge outwardlye, whiche inwardlye they dy≈øallowe. No example of men, howe many ≈øo euer they bee, or howe learned ≈øo euer they bee, can preuaile in thys behalfe: for ye paterne which we mu≈øt follow, is Chri≈øt hym ≈øelfe, and not the more companye, or cu≈øtome. Hys woorde is the lanterne to lyghten oure ≈øteppes, P≈øalm. 118 and not learned men. Companye and cu≈øtome are to bee con≈øidered accordinge to the thyng they allowe. Learned men are to be li≈øtened to, and followed accordyng to Gods lore and lawe, for elles the more parte goeth to the deuill. As cu≈øtome cau≈øeth erroure and blyndne≈ø≈øe, ≈øo learnyng, if it bee not accordinge to the lighte of Gods woorde, is poy≈øon, and learned men mo≈øte pernicious. The deuill is called Demon for hys cunnynge, and the children of this worlde are muche wy≈øer then the children of lyghte in theyr generation: Luk. 16. and I knowe the deuill and his dearelynges haue alwayes for the mo≈øte parte, more helpes in this life then Chri≈øtes Churche and her children. They (the Deuill and hys Sinagoge I meane) haue cu≈øtome, multitude, vnitye, antiquitye, learning, power, riches, honoure, dignitie, and promotions plentye, as alwaies they haue hadde, and ≈øhall haue commonlye and for the mo≈øte parte, vntyll Chri≈øtes comminge, muche more then the true Churche haue pre≈øentlye, heretofore haue hadde, or hereafter ≈øhall
haue. For her glorye, riches and honoure is not here: her triall, cro≈ø≈øe, and warrefare is here. And therefore (my deare hartes in the Lorde) con≈øider the≈øe thinges accordinglye. Con≈øider what you bee, not worldlynges but Gods children. Con≈øider where you bee, not at home but in a ≈øtraunge countreye. Con≈øider among whom you are conuer≈øante, euen in the midde≈øt of youre ennemies, and of a wicked generation, and then I tru≈øte you will not muche mu≈øe at affliction, which you can not be without, being as you bee, Gods children, in a ≈øtraunge countreye, and in the midde≈øt of youre ennemies, excepte you woulde leaue youre Captaine Chri≈øte, and followe Sathan for the mucke of this moulde, re≈øte and quietne≈ø≈øe, whiche he maye promy≈øe you, and you in dede thinke you ≈øhal receaue it by doing as he woulde haue you to doe, but (my ≈øweete hartes) he is not hable to paye that he promi≈øeth. Peace and warre come from GOD, riches and pouertye, wealth and woe. The deuill hath no power but by Gods permi≈ø≈øion. If then GOD permitte him a little on youre goodes, bodye or life, I praye you tell me, what can muche hurte you (as Peter ≈øayeth) you being followers of godlyne≈ø≈øe?1. Pet. 3. Thinke you that GOD will not remember you in hys tyme as mo≈øte ≈øhall bee to youre comforte? Can a woman forgette the childe of her wombe? E≈øay. 49. And if ≈øhee ≈øhoulde, yet will not I forgette thee, ≈øayeth the Lorde. Loke vppon Abraham in his exile and mi≈øerye, looke vppon Iacob, Io≈øephe, Mo≈øes, Dauid, the Prophettes, Apo≈øtles, and all the Godlye from the beginning: and my good brethren, is not GOD the ≈øame God? Is he a chaungeling? You haue heard of the patience of Iob (≈øaith Saint Iames) and you haue ≈øene the ende howe that God is mercifull, Iacob. 5 patiente and longe ≈øuffering: euen ≈øo ≈øaye I vnto you, that you ≈øhall fynde accordinglye, if ≈øo bee you bee patiente, that is, if ≈øo bee you feate hym, ≈øette hys woorde before you, ≈øerue hym thereafter, and if he laye hys cro≈ø≈øe on you, you beare it with pacience: the which you ≈øhal do, wheÃÑ you con≈øider it not according to the pre≈øente ≈øen≈øe, but accordyng to the end. Hebru. 12.2, Corin. 4.

Therefore I hartely be≈øeche you, and oute of my bondes which I ≈øuffer for your ≈øake, pray you (mine own ≈øwete hartes in the Lord) that you would cleaue in harte & humble obedience, to the doctrine taughte you by me and many other my brethren. For we haue taught you no fables nor tales of meÃÑ, or our own phanta≈øies, but the very word of god, which we are ready with oure liues (God ≈øo enhabling vs, as we tru≈øte he will) to confirme, & by the ≈øheding of our bloodes, in all pacience & humble obedience to the ≈øuperiour powers, to te≈øtifye and ≈øeale vp, as wel that you mighte be more certaine of the doctrine, as that you myght be ready to confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame before this wicked world, knowing that if we confe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øt and his truth before men, he will confe≈ø≈øe vs before hys father in heauen: if ≈øo be we be a≈øhamed hereof for lo≈ø≈øe of life, frendes or goodes, he wil be a≈øhamed of vs before his father and his holy Angels in heauen.

Therfore take hede, for ye Lords ≈øake take hede, take hede, & defile not your bodies or ≈øoules wt this Romi≈øh & Antichri≈øtiaÃÑ religioÃÑ ≈øet vp amoÃÑge≈øt vs again: but come away, come away as the Angell cryeth, Apoca. 18. from amonge≈øt them in their Idolatrous ≈øeruice, lea≈øt you be partakers of their iniquitye. HarkeÃÑ to your preachers as the The≈ø≈øaloniaÃÑs did to Paul: that is, conferre their ≈øayinges with the Scriptures, and if they ≈øound not therafter, E≈øay. 8. ye morning light ≈øhal not ≈øhine vppon them. V≈øe much and harty prayer for the ≈øpirit of wi≈øedome, knowledge, humblene≈ø≈øe, mekene≈ø≈øe ≈øobrietye and repentauÃÑce: which we haue great nede of, becau≈øe our ≈øynnes haue thus prouoked the Lords anger agayn≈øt vs: but let vs beare his anger, & acknowledge our faultes wt bitter teares, and ≈øorowful ≈øighes, & doubtles he wil be merciful to vs after hys wonted mercy. The which thing he vouch≈øafe to do for his holy names ≈øake in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu our Lord, to whom with the father and the holy gho≈øte bee all honoure, glorye, pray≈øe, and euerla≈øtynge thankes from thys tyme forth for euermore, Amen.
