div.head: To my dearely beloued in the lord My≈øtres VV. and My≈øtres VV.
div.p: ALmighty God our deare and mo≈øt mercifull father, be always with you both (my entierly beloued mother and Sy≈øter in the Lorde) and as hys babes, he for euer kepe you vnto hys eternal kingdome throughe Chri≈øte our Sauiour, Amen.

I purpo≈øe not to go about to render thankes to you for gods great goodnes towardes me by you, becau≈øe I can not. Either of you hath ≈øo heaped vpon me benefits, that it were hard for me to recken ye tythes. He for who≈øe ≈øake you haue done it, and all the good you do, one daye recompence you after your hartes de≈øyre in hym. In the meane ≈øea≈øon, I be≈øeche hym to reueale vnto you more and more the ryches of hys grace and loue in Chri≈øt, by whom ye are beloued and were, before the worlde was, and ≈øhall be doutles worlde wythout ende. Accordyng to the reuelation, & your ≈øen≈øe or fayth herein, ≈øo wyll you contend to all pietie and godlines, as S. Iohn ≈øaith: he that hath thys hope wyll purify hym≈øelfe as Chri≈øt is pure.1. Iohn. 3 For howe ≈øhould it otherwy≈øe bee, but if we bee certainlye per≈øuaded that heauen is ours and we citizens therof, but (I ≈øay) we ≈øhould de≈øire the di≈ø≈øolution of our bodies, and death to di≈øpatche vs, and to do hys office vpon vs? If we dyd certainly beleue we were members of Chri≈øt and gods temples, how ≈øhould we but flie from all impuritie and corruption of the worlde whiche commeth by concupi≈øcence? If we dyd certainly beleue that god in dede of hys mercy in Chri≈øt, is become our father, in that hys good wyll is infinite, and hys power accordyng therto, how coulde we be afrayde of man or Deuil? Howe coulde we doubte of ≈øaluation, or any good thynge whiche myght make to Gods glorye and our owne weale? Now that we ≈øhoulde be certayne and ≈øure of thys, that we are Gods children in Chri≈øt, marke whether all thynges teache vs not? Beholde the creation of thys worlde, and the gubernation of the ≈øame: doe not the≈øe teache vs that God
loueth vs? And is gods loue out of Chri≈øt the beloued? If not his loue as he is vnchangeable? Iohn. 13. Doth not S. Iohn ≈øay, that he loueth to the ende whom he loueth? Therfore I ≈øay, the very creatures of god, concernyng both their creation & con≈øeruation, tell vs that god loueth vs: that is, that we in Chri≈øt be his childreÃÑ and dearlinges, although in our ≈øelues and of oure ≈øelues wee bee otherwy≈øe: namelye chyldren of wrathe. Agayne loke vpon the law of god, and tell me whether it do not requyre this certainty of you, namely that you be gods dere childreÃÑ in Chri≈øt? Doth not god plainly affirme & ≈øay: I am the Lord thy God? Doth he not charge you to haue none other gods but hym? How then can you peri≈øhe if god be your god? p≈øal. 143 Doth not that make god no god? Doth not Dauid ≈øay that tho≈øe people be happy which haue the Lord for their God?

Be≈øides this, loke on your beliefe: do you not profe≈ø≈øe that you beleue in God your father almighty, whiche wanteth no power to helpe you, as he wanted no good wyll in Chri≈øt to choo≈øe you? Do you not ≈øay that you do beleue remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øynnes, re≈øurrection of the body, life euerla≈øting, felow≈øhip wyth the ≈øainctes? &c. But how doe you ≈øaye you beleue thys geare, and be not certayne therof? Is not fayth a certaintie? Is not doubtyng again≈øt fayth, as S. Iames ≈øayeth? Pray in faythe and doubte not, for he that doubteth obteyneth nothyng. Math. 8 When Peter beganne to doubte, he had lyke to haue bene drowned: beware of it therfore.

Moreouer, for to certifye youre con≈øciences that you be gods childerne, & ≈øhal neuer finally peri≈øh, through gods goodnes in Chri≈øte, beholde your heade, your Capitaine, I meane Chri≈øte Ie≈øus. Wherefore came he into this world, but to redeme you? to marry you vnto hym≈øelfe? to de≈øtroye the workes of Sathan? to ≈øaue and ≈øeeke that whiche was lo≈øte? Wherfore ≈øuffered he ≈øo greate and bytter pa≈ø≈øions? Dydde he it not to take awaye your ≈øynnes? Wherefore dydde he ry≈øe from deathe? Dyd he it not to iu≈øtifye you? Wherfore dyd he a≈øcende into heauen? Dyd he it not to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion there for you? to leade your captiuitye captiue? to prepare and make ready all thynges for you? to appeare before the father, alwayes praying for you? If the≈øe be true, as
they be mo≈øt true, why theÃÑ ≈øtand you in a doubt? Do you not therby deny Chri≈øt? Wherefore were you borne of Chri≈øtian parentes and in gods churche, but becau≈øe you were Gods chylderne by Chri≈øt before you were borne? For thys cau≈øe you were bapti≈øed, and hetherto the Lorde hathe thus delte wyth you, ≈øparyng you, correctyng you, and ble≈ø≈øyng you. but why? Verely becau≈øe you be hys children, and ≈øhal be for euer through Chri≈øt. Tell me, why hath God kepte you till thys tyme, but that he wyll for hys ≈øake haue you euen here made lyke vnto Chri≈øt, th ‚Ä¢ t el≈øewhere you may ≈øo be? Why hathe he opened youre eyes from Popery, but becau≈øe you be hys childerne in deede? When you do praye, doe you not call hym father? Why doe you doubte of it then? Why wyll you beleue the Deuil more theÃÑ God your father, the Sonne, and the holy gho≈øte? more then the holye worde of GOD, bothe in the lawe and in Go≈øpell? more then all the ble≈ø≈øynges and ca≈øtigations of God? Do not all the≈øe preach to you and tell you that you are gods babes throughe Chri≈øt? Therefore my derely beloued, beleue it and geue not place to the Deuill, but with≈øtand hym ≈øtrong in fayth. Marke. 9 Luk. 19 Say wyth the poore man: I beleue Lord, helpe my vnbelief. Say with the Apo≈øtels, Lord encrea≈øe oure fayth.

This myne owne hartes in the Lorde, I wryte not that you ≈øhoulde lyue more ≈øecurely and carnally, doing as the Spiders doe, whiche gather poy≈øon where bees gather honye: but that as the electe of god, you mighte liue in all puritie, godlines and peace, which god encrea≈øe in vs all for his Chri≈øtes ≈øake, Amen.

I pray you hartelie pray for vs, that to the verie ende we may (as I hope we ≈øhall) goe lu≈øtelie and cherefullie whether ≈øoeuer our heauenly father ≈øhal bring and lead vs. His will whiche is alwaies good, bee done in earthe as it is in heauen, Amen.

signed.hi: Your brother in bondes for the te≈øtimonye of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Iohn Bradforde.

div.head: To my good Syster M. H.
div.p: THe peace of God, wyth encrea≈øe of fayth and feeling of his mercy to your coÃÑfort in Chri≈øt, the holy gho≈øt worke in your hart now and for euer, Amen.

As it is much to my comfort that God hath geuen you ≈øuch a loue and zeale to hys truth: ≈øo I exhort you (my good Sy≈øter) diligeÃÑtly to labour, as by coÃÑtinual readyng and meditation of gods holy word, ≈øo by earne≈øt prayer and other godly exerci≈øes, to maintayne and encrea≈øe the ≈øame: that by the feelyng of gods gratious ≈øpirite workyng in you ≈øuche good fruites as wytne≈ø≈øes of your fayth, you may growe in ≈øtrength therof, and certayntie of gods fauour and good wyl towardes you. For aboue all thyngs, of thys I woulde haue you to be mo≈øte a≈ø≈øured, that you are beloued of god: that you are hys dere chylde, and ≈øhall bee for euermore throughe Chri≈øte, in whome you are by fayth, and he in you. Out of thys certeintie (the cau≈øe wherof is gods owne goodnes, grace, and truth) ≈øpryngeth true loue, and louyng feare, and obedience to god continually and in all thynges. Where it is (I meane thys fayth, certaintie and per≈øua≈øion of gods eternall goodnes to you in Chri≈øte) there no ≈øynnes are imputed to you, or layd to your charge to condeÃÑnation nor ≈øhalbe: though for correctioÃÑ ≈øake, now & theÃÑ your heauenly father vi≈øit them fatherly, or rather you for them. Where it is not, there is nothyng be it neuer ≈øo well done, that plea≈øeth God. Labour therfore for this certainty of faith, through Chri≈øt. WheÃÑ≈øoeuer you dout, you heape ≈øinne vpoÃÑ ≈øinne. If Satan, your coÃÑ≈øcieÃÑce, or gods law do accu≈øe you, confe≈ø≈øe your fault, & hide it not before the lord. But wheÃÑ they woulde inferre yt becau≈øe of your ≈øynne you are condemned, you are ca≈øt away: then aun≈øwer them that it is but their office to accu≈øe and witnes, not to geue ≈øentence & iudge: it onely apperteyneth to god to geue iudgement. Paule ≈øayth, it is god that ab≈øolueth, who then ≈øhall condemne vs? God hym≈øelfe promi≈øeth, before he demaund
any thyng of vs, that he is our Lord and our god: and are not they happy which haue the lord for their god? Is he god to any who≈øe ≈øinnes he remitteth not? Through Chri≈øt he is our father, and therfore we are commaunded ≈øo to call him: and can there want any fatherly kyndnes in hym towardes vs, which be hys children? No verely. Therfore be ≈øure, and wauer not of gods loue & fauour towardes you in Chri≈øt. The cau≈øe of hys loue is his owne goodnes and mercy: this la≈øting for euer, hys loue lo≈øeth for euer. How can you then but be quiete & happy? V≈øe this geare to comforte the weake con≈øcience, and not to vnbridle the mighty affections of the fle≈øhe or olde Adam, which mu≈øt haue other meate.

div.head: ¬∂ An exhortation to the patient ≈øufferyng of trouble and afflictions for Chri≈øtes cau≈øe, wrytten to all the vnfayned profe≈ø≈øours of the go≈øpell thoroughout the realme of England, at the beginning of hys impri≈øonmente, and here placed as it came to our handes.
div.p: THe holy ≈øpirite of God, whiche is the earne≈øt and pledge of God, geuen to hys people for theyr comfort and con≈øolation, be powred into our hartes by ye mighty power & merites of our alone Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, now and for euer, Amen.

Becau≈øe I perceiue plainly, that to the euils fallen vpoÃÑ vs which profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtes go≈øpell, greater are mo≈øt like to en≈øue, and after them greater, Gene. 15. Luke. 9. Gene≈ø. 19 tyl the mea≈øure of iniquity be vp heaped (except we ≈øhrynke, & hauyng put our handes to the plough do loke back, and ≈øo wyth Lothes wyfe and the I≈øraelits, de≈øiryng to returne into Egipt, fal into gods heauy di≈øplea≈øure vncurably, al which god forbidde) and becau≈øe I am per≈øuaded of you, my derely beloued brethern and Sy≈øters throughe out the realme of Englande, which haue profe≈ø≈øed
vnfainedly the go≈øpell of our Lord and Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt (for vnto ≈øuch do I wryte this epi≈øtle) that as ye haue begonne to take parte wyth gods go≈øpell and truth, ≈øo throughe his grace ye will per≈øeuer and goe on forwardes notwith≈øtandyng the ≈øtormes ri≈øen and to ari≈øe: I cannot but wryte ≈øomething vnto you, lu≈øtely to goe on forwardes in the way of the Lord, and not to become faynte harted or fearefull, Apoca. 25. who≈øe place S. Iohn appointeth with the vnbeleuers, murtherers, and Idolaters in eternall perdicion, but cherefully to take the Lordes cuppe and drynke of it afore it drawe towardes the dregges and bottom, P≈øal. 75, wherof at the length they ≈øhall drynke with the wycked to eternal de≈øtruction,1. pet. 4 which wil not receiue it at the fir≈øt with gods children: with whome god beginneth hys iudgemente, that as the wicked world reioyceth when they lament, Iohn. 16. ≈øo they may reioyce when the wycked world ≈øhall mourne, and without ende fynde woe intollerable.

Fir≈øt therfore my dearely beloued in the Lord, I be≈øech you to con≈øider, Iohn. 14 P≈øal. 17 2. Cor. 4. Apoc. 12 Heb. 11 1. pet. 2 Heb. 13 P≈øalm. 119 Heb. 12 Mat. 28 Rom. 9 1. Ioh. 5 Apo. 13 Luke. 6. EZech. 9. Math. 5. E≈øay. 22 1. Cor. 15 that thoughe ye be in the worlde yet ye are not of the world. Ye are not of them whiche looke for their porcioÃÑ in this lyfe, who≈øe Captain is the god of this world, euen Sathan, who now ruffleth it apace as he were woode becau≈øe his tyme on earthe is not long. But ye are of them that loke for a Citye of gods owne ble≈ø≈øing. Ye are of them that know your ≈øelues to be here but pylgrimes and ≈øtrauÃÑ gers: for here ye haue no dwellyng place. Ye are of them who≈øe porcion is the lorde, and whiche haue their hope in heauen: who≈øe captayn is Chri≈øt Ie≈øus the Sonne of God and gouernour of heauen and earth. Vnto him is geuen all power, yea he is god almighty with the father and the holy gho≈øt, pray≈øe worthy for euer. Ye are not of them which receyue the bea≈øtes marke, which here reioyce, laugh and haue their hartes ea≈øe ioye, paradi≈øe and plea≈øure: but ye are of them whiche haue receyued the Aungels marke, yea Gods marke, which here lament, mourne, ≈øyghe, ≈øobbe, wepe, and haue your wyldernes to wander in, your purgatory and euen hell to purge and burne vp your ≈øynnes. Ye are not of them which crye, let vs eate and drynke for to morowe we ≈øhal die. Ye are not of that noÃÑber which ≈øay they haue made
a couenaunt with death and hel for hurting of them. E≈øay. 28 Mal. 3. Apo. 3. Ezech. 8. P≈øa. 73. Math. 4. Dani. 3. Ye are not of theÃÑ which take it for a vaine thing to ≈øerue the lorde. Ye are not of theÃÑ which are lulled and rocked a ≈ølepe in Ie≈øabels bed, a bed of ≈øecuritie. Ye are not of the number of theÃÑ which ≈øay, tu≈øhe god is in heauen and ≈øeeth vs not nor much pa≈ø≈øeth what we doe. Ye are not of the number of theÃÑ which wil fall downe for the mucke of the world to wor≈øhyppe the Feende, or for di≈øplea≈øing of men to wor≈øhippe the golden mage. Math. 8. 1 Mach. 1.2 Exod. 13 3. Reg. 22. Rom. 6.7. Colo≈øs. 3 Finallye yeare not of the number of them which ≈øet more by your pygges then by Chri≈øt, which for ea≈øe and re≈øt in this lyfe wil ≈øay and doe as Antiochus byddeth you do or ≈øay, and wil follow the multitude to do euil with Zedechias and the 300. fal≈øe Prophets, yea Achab, Ie≈øabel, and ye whole courte and countrey. But ye are of the number of theÃÑ which are dead alredy or at lea≈øt be in dyeng daily to your ≈øelues & to this world. Ye are of them which haue made a couenauÃÑt wyth god to for≈øake your ≈øelues in thys worlde and Sathan al≈øo. Ye are of theÃÑ which ≈øay, Luk. 12. Mala. 3. nay the lord hath al things written in hys memoriall booke for ≈øuche as feare hym and remember hys name. Luke. 12. p≈øa. 33.14.101. Luke. 3. Dan. 3. 1. pet. 2. P≈øal. i20. i. Mac. 2 Math. 7 3. Reg. 22. Ye are of the number of them whiche will wor≈øhyp the only lord god and wyl not wor≈øhyp the workes of mans handes, though the ouen burne neuer ≈øo hote. Ye are in the nuÃÑber of them to whom Chri≈øt is precious & deare, which cry out rather becau≈øe your habitation is prolonged here, as Dauyd did. Ye are of them whiche follow Mathathias and the godly Iewes: which know the way to lyfe to be a ≈øtraite way and few to go through it: whiche wyll not ≈øtycke to follow poore Micheas although he be racked and ca≈øt into pry≈øon, hauing the Sunne, Moone, ≈øeuen Starres and all agayn≈øte hym.

Thus therfore (dearely beloued) remember fyr≈øte that (as I ≈øayde) ye are not of thys worlde: that Sathan is not your Captayne: your ioye and Parady≈øe is not here: your companions are not the multitude of worldlings and
≈øuch as ≈øeke to plea≈øe men and liue here at ea≈øe in the ≈øeruice of Satan. phil. 3. Heb. 13 But ye are of an other world: Chri≈øt is your Captayne: your ioy is in heaueÃÑ, where your coÃÑuer≈øation is: your companions are the fathers, Patriarkes, Prophetes, Apo≈øtles, Martyrs, Virgins, confe≈ø≈øors, and the deare ≈øainctes of God, Apo. 7 Iob. 78.14. P≈øalm. 9. Iames. 4 whych follow the Lambe whether ≈øoeuer he goeth, dippyng their garments in hys blood, knowyng this lyfe and world to be full of euill, a warfare, a ≈ømoke, a ≈øhadow, a vapour, and as repleni≈øhed, ≈øo enuironed wyth all kynde of my≈øeries. This is the fyr≈øt thyng which I would haue you often and diligently wyth your ≈øelues to con≈øider & to mu≈øe wel vpon, namely what ye be and where ye be.

Nowe ≈øecondlye forgette not to call to mynde that ye oughte not to thynke it anye ≈øtraunge thyng if mi≈øerye, trouble, aduer≈øitie, per≈øecution, and di≈øplea≈øure come vpon you.1. pet. 4 Iohn. 14. 1. pet 5 For howe can it otherwy≈øt bee, but that trouble and per≈øecution mu≈øte come vppon you? Canne the world loue you which are none of hys? Can worldlye men regard you, which are your chiefe enemies ≈øouldiours? Can Satan ≈øuffer you to be in re≈øt, Math. 7. which wyl do no homage vnto hym? Can this way be cho≈øen of any that make it ≈øo narrow and ≈øtraite as they doe? Wyll ye looke to trauayle and to haue no fowle way or rayne? Are not ye trauailing to your heaueÃÑly City of Ieru≈øaleÃÑ, where is all ioye and felicitie: and w≈øll ye now tary by the way for ≈øtormes or ≈øhowers? Iohn. 9 Mat. 25 The Marte and faier wil then be pa≈øt: the night wil ≈øo come vpon you that ye cannot trauayle: the dore wyll be ≈øparde, and the bryde will be at ≈øupper. Therfore away wyth daintye nicene≈ø≈øe. Wyll ye thynke the father of heauen wyll deale more gently wyth you in thys age, theÃÑ he hath done wyth others hys deare≈øt frends in other ages? What way, Gen. 4 6.7.8.9. &c. yea what ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts, what troubles and di≈øquietnes founde Abell, Noe, Abraham, I≈øaac, Iacob & good Io≈øeph? Which of the≈øe had ≈øo fayre a lyfe and re≈øteful tymes as we haue had? Exod. 2.3.4.5. &c Moy≈øes, Aaron, Samuell, Dauyd the kyng, and all the good kynges, Prie≈øtes, Prophetes in

As for the new Te≈øtament, Lord god how great was ye affliction, of Marye, of Io≈øephe, of Zacharye, of Elizabeth, of Iohn Bapti≈øte, of all the Apo≈øtles and Euaungeli≈øtes,Math. ii yea of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord, the deare ≈øonne and dearlyng of God? And ≈øince the time of the Apo≈øtles,Eu≈øeb. eccl hi≈øt. Tripart. hi≈øt. howe many and great are the number of Martyrs, Confe≈ø≈øours and ≈øuch as haue ≈øuffered the ≈øheeding of their bloode in this life, rather then they would be ≈øtayed in their iourney, or lodge in anye of Sathans Innes, le≈øte the ≈øtormes or windes whiche fell in their trauailinges, myght haue touched them? P≈øa. 49 But with what face can we looke for thys, that are ≈øo fearefull, vnwilling and ar≈øward to leaue that, which will we nyll we, we mu≈øte leaue, and that ≈øo ≈øhortly, as we know not the time when? Where is oure abrenouncing and for≈øaking of the worlde and the fle≈øhe, whiche we ≈øolemnely toke vpon vs in bapti≈øme? Howe manye nowe goe with you lu≈øtelye, as I and all your brethren in bondes and exile for the Go≈øpell? Pray for vs, for God willing we wyll not leaue you nowe: we will goe before you. Ye ≈øhall ≈øee in vs by Gods grace,1. Pet. 2 that we preached no lies nor tales of tubbes, but euen the verye true woorde of God: for the confyrmation whereof, we by Gods grace, and the helpe of your prayers, will willinglye and ioyfully geue our bloode to be ≈øhedde, as already we haue geuen our liuings, goods, frendes and naturall countrey: for nowe bee we certayne that we be in the highe waye to heauens bly≈ø≈øe, as Saincte Paule ≈øayeth, Act. 14. by manye tribulations and per≈øecutions we mu≈øte enter into Gods kingdome. And becau≈øe we woulde goe thether our ≈øelues and bring you thether al≈øo, therefore the deuill ≈øtirreth vppe the coles. And fora≈ømuche as we all
loytered in the way, Math. 8. Math. 14. he hath therfore receaued power of god to ouerca≈øt the whether and to ≈øtirre vp ≈øtormes, yt we gods children, might more ≈øpedely go on forwards, & make more ha≈øt: as the counterfaites and hipocrites will tary & linger tyl the ≈øtormes be pa≈øte, and ≈øo when they come, the market will be done and ye doores ≈øparde, as it is to be feared. div.p: ALmightye God our deare father geue to you dailye more and more, the knowledge of hys truth, and a loue and lyfe to the ≈øame for euer in all thynges, throughe Ie≈øus Chry≈øte oure Lorde, Amen.

ALmyghtye God oure heauenlye father, recompence aboundauntlye into youre bo≈øome (my dearelye-beloued) here and eternallye, the good whiche from hym by you I haue continuallye receaued, ≈øythen my comming into pry≈øon. div.head: A letter writen to hys Mother, as a farewell, when he thoughte he ≈øhoulde haue ≈øuffered ≈øhortlye after.
div.p: TThe Lord of lyfe and Sauiour of the world Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, ble≈ø≈øe you and comfort you, my good and deare Mother, wyth hys heauenly comfort, con≈øolation, grace and ≈øpirite nowe and for euer Amen.

If I thought that dayly, yea almo≈øte hourlye you dyd not crye vpon God the father throughe Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, that he woulde geue me hys ble≈ø≈øing, euen the ble≈ø≈øing of his children: then would I write more hereaboutes. And for my lodging, beddyng, meate, drinke, Godlye and learned companye, bookes and all other nece≈ø≈øaryes for myne ea≈øe, comfort,
and commoditye, I am in muche better ca≈øe then I coulde wy≈øhe, and Gods mercifull prouidence here is farre aboue my worthines. Worthines quoth I? Alas I am worthye of nothyng but dampnation. But be≈øides all this, for my ≈øoule I finde much more coÃÑmoditie. For god is my father, I now perceaue, through Chri≈øt: therefore in pri≈øonyng me for hys Go≈øpel, he maketh me lyke to the image of hys Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt here, that when he coÃÑmeth to iudgement, I might then belike vnto him, as my tru≈øte and hope is I ≈øhall bee. Nowe maketh he me like to hys frendes the Prophets, Apo≈øtles, the holye Martyrs and Confe≈ø≈øours. Which of them dyd not ≈øuffer, at the lea≈øt, impri≈øonmente or banny≈øhment for hys Go≈øpell and woorde? Nowe Mother, how farre am I vnmeete to bee compared to them? I (I ≈øay) whiche alwayes haue beene and am ≈øo vyle an hypocrite and grieuous a ≈øynner? And in dede good Mother, ≈øo I am, as euer I was, yea neuer ≈øo merye and gladde was I, as I nowe ≈øhoulde bee, if I coulde get you to bee merye with me, to thanke God for me, and to praye on thys ≈øorte. Ah good father whiche doe≈øt vouch≈øafe that my ≈øonne being a greuous ≈øynner in thy fyghte, ≈øhoulde fynde thys fauoure with thee, to be one of thy Sonnes captaynes, and men of warre to fyghte and ≈øuffer for hys Go≈øpelles ≈øake. As Anna dyd applye and geue her fyr≈øte childe Samuell vnto thee: ≈øo doe I deare father, be≈øechyng thee for Chri≈øtes ≈øake to accepte thys my gifte, and geue my ≈øonne Iohn Bradford grace alwayes trulye to ≈øerue thee and thy people as Samuell did, Amen, Amen.

If on thys ≈øorte Mother, from your harte you woulde praye, as I ≈øhould be the mo≈øt merye≈øt man that euer was, ≈øo am I certayne the lettes of your prayer for my impri≈øonment, woulde be taken awaye. div.head: To my dearely beloued Sy≈øter My≈øtres A. VV.

Although I know it to be more then nedeth, to write any thing vnto you, good Sy≈øter, beiÃÑg (as I dont not you be) diligeÃÑtly exerci≈øed in reading of ye ≈øcriptures, meditating ye ≈øame, & harty praier to god for the helpe of his holy ≈øpirit, to haue the ≈øen≈øe & feelyng e≈øpecially of the comfortes you reade in gods ≈øwete boke: yet hauing ≈øuch opportunitie, & knowing not whether hereafter I ≈øhall haue the like (as this bringer can declare) I thought good in few wordes to take my farewel in writing, becau≈øe otherwi≈øe I can not. Thynke on this commaundement, which precedeth all others, that you mu≈øt haue no other gods but the Lorde Iehouah, which is your Lord and god: the which he could not be, if that he dyd not pardon your ≈øynnes in very dede. Remember that Chri≈øte commaundeth you to call hym father for the ≈øame entente. And hereto call to mynde all the benefites of god hetherto ≈øhewed vpon you: and ≈øo ≈øhal you fele in very dede, that which I wy≈øhe vnto you now, and praye you to wy≈øhe vnto me, farewell or welfare in the Lord Ie≈øus: wyth whome he graunte vs ≈øhortlye to meete as hys chyldren, for hys name and mercyes ≈øake, to oure eternall welfare, Amen, Amen,

closer.signed: Your owne in the Lorde. Iohn Bradford.

div.head: ¬∂An other letter to Mystres A.VV.
div.p:
ALmighty god our heauenly father for hys chri≈øtes ≈øake, encrea≈øe in vs fayth, by which we may more and more ≈øee what glory and honour is repo≈øed,
and ≈øafely kept in heauen, for all them that beleue wyth the hart, and confe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øte and hys truthe wyth the mouthe, Amen.

My derely beloued, I remember that once heretofore I wrote vnto you a Vale or a farewell vpon coniecture: but now I wryte my farewell to you in thys lyfe in dede, vpon certaine knowledge. My ≈øtaffe ≈øtandeth at the dore: I continually looke for the Shiriffe to come for me, and I thank God, I am ready for hym. Now go I to practi≈øe that which I haue preached. Now am I climing vp the hil: it wil cau≈øe me to puffe and blow before I come to the cliffe. The hill is ≈øtepe and high: my breath is ≈øhort, and my ≈øtrength is feble: pray therfore to ye lord for me, that as I haue now through hys goodnes, euen almo≈øt come to the toppe, I may by hys grace, be ≈øtrengthned, not to re≈øt til I come where I ≈øhould be. Oh louing Lord, put out thy hande and drawe me vnto thee: for no man coÃÑmeth, but he whome the father draweth. Se (my derely beloued) gods louing mercy: he knoweth my ≈øhort breath and great weakenes. As he ≈øent for Helias a f ‚Ä¢
ry chariote, ≈øo ≈øendeth he for me: for by fyre my dro≈ø≈øe mu≈øte be purifyed, that I may be fine gold in hys ≈øyghte. Oh vnthankefull wretche that I am: Lorde do thou forgeue me myne vnthankfulnes. In dede I confe≈ø≈øe (ryghte deare to me in the lord) that my ≈øynnes haue de≈øerued hell fyre: much more then, thys fyer. But loe, ≈øo louyng is my Lorde, that he conuerteth the remedye for my ≈øynnes, the puni≈øhmente for my tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, into a te≈øtimoniall of hys truth, and a te≈øtification of hys verity, which the Prelates doe per≈øecute in me, and not my ≈øynnes: therfore they per≈øecute not me but Chri≈øt in me, which I doubte not wyl take my part vnto the very ende, Amen.

Oh that I had ≈øo open an harte, as coulde ≈øo receiue as I ≈øhould do, this great benefite and vn≈øpeakable dignitye, which God my father offreth to me. Now pray for me (my derely beloued) pray for me yt I neuer ≈øhrinke. I ≈øhal neuer ≈øhrynke I hope, I tru≈øt in the Lorde, I ≈øhal neuer ≈øhrinke: for he that alwayes hath taken my parte, I am a≈ø≈øured wil not leaue me when I haue mo≈øt nede, for hys truth & merties ≈øake. Oh Lord helpe me: into thy handes I commende me wholy. In the Lorde is my my tru≈øte, I care not what
man can do vnto me, Amen. My derely beloued ≈øay you Amen al≈øo, and come after if ≈øo god call you. Be not a≈øhamed of the go≈øpell of Chri≈øt, but kepe company wyth hym ≈øtil. He wyll neuer leaue you: but in the mydde≈øt of temptation wil geue you an out≈øcape, to make you able to beare the brunte. V≈øe harty prayer: reuerently reade and heare gods worde: put it in practi≈øe: looke forthe cro≈ø≈øe: lift vp your heades, for your redeÃÑption draweth nigh: know that the death of gods ≈øaintes is precious in hys ≈øyght: be mery in the Lorde: pray for the mitigation of gods heauy di≈øplea≈øure vpon our countrey. God kepe vs for euer: God ble≈ø≈øe vs wyth his ≈øpirituall ble≈ø≈øynges in Chri≈øt. And thus I bydde you farewell for euer in thys pre≈øent lyfe. Pray for me, praye for me, for gods ≈øake, pray for me. God make perfecte hys good worke begonne in me, Amen. Out of pri≈øon this 7. of February.

closer.signed: Yours in the Lorde. Iohn Bradford.

div.head: ¬∂To certayne godlye men relieuers and helpers of hym and others in theyr impri≈øonmente.
div.p: THe peace of Chri≈øt which pa≈ø≈øeth all plea≈øure and worldly felicity, be daily more and more felte in your hartes (my right derely beloued in the Lord) by the inwarde workyng of the holy ≈øpirite, the earne≈øt of our inheritaunce, and guider of gods electe: wyth the whyche god our dere father more & more endue vs al vnto the ende, for hys beloued ≈øonnes ≈øake our lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Amen.

Pray≈øed be god the father of our lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which is a father of mercy & a god of al con≈øolation, that hath ble≈ø≈øed you wt the knowlege & loue of his truth, not only to your own coÃÑfortes, but al≈øo the great ea≈øe & coÃÑfort of many, which without the helpe of god by you hetherto, had bene in much more mi≈øery. By your releuing the lordes pri≈øoners, I am brought to ≈øee the rote wherof the worke doth ≈øpring, euen ye knowlege & loue of gods truth, wherfore we are in haÃÑdes.
The which knowledge & loue, in that it is a ble≈ø≈øyng of all ble≈ø≈øings the greate≈øt (for it is euen eternal life. Ioh. 17) I caÃÑ not but prai≈øe god for you on this behalfe, that it hath plea≈øed hym to much you worthy ≈øo excelleÃÑt & ≈øinguler a benefit: which is more to be e≈øtemed, de≈øired & cared for, theÃÑ any thyng els. The world, for al that euer it hath, caÃÑnot attayne by any meanes to this ble≈ø≈øing, which God our father hath geueÃÑ you freely of his own good wil through chri≈øt, eueÃÑ before ye were purpo≈øed to de≈øire it. Therfore I be≈øech you al to be thankful with me & to reioyce in ye lord. For if he haue geueÃÑ vs ≈øuch a gift vna≈øked, vnde≈øired, yea vnthought vpoÃÑ: how can it be ye he wil deny vs any good thing now, which may be nece≈ø≈øary for vs? Wil he (trow ye) ≈øowe his ≈øede in the ground of your hartes, & not kepe away the foules from picking it vp? would he ≈øo be≈øtow his ≈øede in you as he hath, if that he would not hedge in your hartes his field, froÃÑ commoÃÑ pathes & froÃÑ breaking in of bea≈øtes to de≈øtroy it? Wil he be more careles theÃÑ a good hu≈øbandmaÃÑ to wede out ye wedes which are in vs, le≈øt they ≈øhould ouergrow the corne of hys word? Wil not he be≈øtow mucke & marle vpon vs, that we may bring forth more fruite? Yf in a good hu≈øbandman this be not lacking, alas how ≈øhould we thinke then but yt ye lord god, a good hu≈øbandman & nothing but good, & only good: how (I ≈øay) ≈øhould it be, but that he is mo≈øte careful to kepe his ≈øede alredy ≈øoweÃÑ in your hartes by ye mini≈øtery of vs & other his preachers, & that to ye bringing forth of iu≈øt and ful frutes? He that hath begoÃÑne with you doute not (my derely beloued) but that he wil happely make an end with you. He hath begon to ≈øow his ≈øede in you, as I dare ≈øay ye feele it: be ≈øure theÃÑ that al this wil follow: Fir≈øt he wil haue Skarecrowes in your hartes: I meane, ≈øuch ≈øparkcles of his feare wil he droppe, yea already he hath dropped into you, that ye birdes of ye aire, vain & euil cogitatioÃÑs ≈øhal not be cheri≈øhed of you, but expelled, by crieng to ye lord for his help. SecoÃÑdly he wil make ≈øuch hedges, as ≈øhal kepe you a≈øwell from by pathes of al euil cu≈øtomes & v≈øages, as al≈øo pre≈øerue you froÃÑ ye power of euil, & dominioÃÑ of ≈øinne, which would haue ye vpper haÃÑd on you. Thirdly he wil doutles poure ≈øuch ≈øhowres vpoÃÑ you to ≈øupple you, ≈øo ‚Ä¢ ede you, ≈øo mucke & marle you by teÃÑptation & other exerci≈øes, yt the Sun≈øhine of per≈øecutioÃÑ
≈øhall make more to the ripenyng of hys ≈øeede in you, then to the witheryng of it away.

The≈øe thynges (my dearely beloued) the Lord god, which hath begonne them in you and for you, wyll continue with you: that in the ende you maye be broughte into hys barne, there to re≈øte wyth hym in eternall felicitie. For Gods ≈øake therfore wayte and looke for no le≈ø≈øe then I haue told you, at hys handes: a greater ≈øeruice can you not geue him. Yf god kepe not ye order I haue told you, but perchauÃÑce beginne to mucke and marle you: to poure hys ≈øhowers vpoÃÑ you: to nippe you with his weeding tonges, &c: reioice & be glad that God wyll doe that in you and wyth you at once, which a long tyme he hath bene a workyng in & for others. Now vndoubtedly great ≈øhowers are fallen, to ≈øupple our hartes that gods word might enter therin and take roote. Now the Lord goeth a weedyng, to weede out of vs oure carnality, ≈øecurirye, couetou≈ønes, ≈øelfe loue, forgetfulnes of God, loue of this world. Now the lord doth mucke & mar ‚Ä¢ e vs, loading vs wyth heapes and burdens of cro≈ø≈øes, that our hartes myghte be made good grounde to bryng forthe fruite to gods glory by patience, as well in ≈øuffryng inward temptations and griefes, wherof we mu≈øt complayn to the Lord for hys Skarecrowes to dryue them forth of vs, ‚Ä¢ s al≈øo in ≈øufferyng outward a≈ø≈øaultes: for the which we mu≈øt cry to our Mai≈øter for hys hedges and defence. Which hathe ij. partes: the one concernyng vs, to helpe and deliuer vs: and the other concernyng our, or rather hys ob≈øtinate aduer≈øaries, to take vengeaunce vpon them: which he will do in hys tyme.

Therfore let vs by patience po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe our ≈øoules, knowing that they which per≈øeuer to the ende ≈øhalbe ≈øaued. Let vs not be werye of well doyng: for in our tyme we ≈øhall reape the fruites therof. But rather whiles we haue tyme, let vs redeme it in doyng well to al men, but ≈øpecially to the hou≈øhold of fayth. which thyng hether to you haue done (the lord therfore be pray≈øed, and in the day of hys comming, he recoÃÑ pence you) and in the re≈øt I hope well: I meane, that you haue declared no le≈ø≈øe in coÃÑfe≈ø≈øyng the truth planted in your hartes, by your wordes and workes after your uocation, to
the glory of God. I hope you haue godly behaued your ≈øelues, not being as too many be now a daies, euen mungrels, geuing halfe to God & halfe to the worlde, halting on both knees, going two waies: I meane it of ye Ma≈ø≈øe go≈øpellers, which are wor≈øe theÃÑ any papi≈øtes. In this point I hope wel of you (my dearly beloued) that you haue not contaminated your ≈øelues, that you haue both confe≈ø≈øed the truth as ofte as nede hath requyred, and al≈øo haue refrayned from comming to church now, where is nothing but idolatrous ≈øeruice. ‚Ä¢ hope you haue glorifyed god both in ≈øoule and body. I hope you haue gathered wt Chri≈øt & not ≈øcattered abroad. I hope you haue drawen no yoke with vnbeleuers, nor communicated with other mens ≈øynnes, but haue ab≈øtayned from all appearaunce of euill, confe≈ø≈øing in harte, confe≈ø≈øing in tong, confe≈ø≈øing in dede & acte the true knowledge of God, which he hath of hys great mercye geuen vnto you, not to bee as a candle vnder a bu≈øhell, but vppon the candle≈øticke, to geue light that men may ≈øee your good workes and glorifie your father which is in heauen. All thys I hope of you (my beloued) and al≈øo of al puritie of life and godly conuer≈øation, not doubting but in this behalf al≈øo, you haue declared gods veritye in your harte, and for the Lordes ≈øake do ≈øo ≈øtill in all poyntes: that is, in your vocations be diligent and ryghteous, towards your ≈øelues be ≈øober and pure, towards your neyghbours be charitable and iu≈øte, towardes god be faythfull and thankefull, louing and obedient. V≈øe earne≈øt and often hartye prayer. Meditate much vpon, and often hearken to ye word of god. If you be called, geue with mode≈øtye an accompt of the hope whiche is in you. Be not a≈øhamed of Gods true ≈øeruice: allow not that with your pre≈øence which is contrary to Gods wil. Make not the meÃÑbers of Chri≈øtes Church, that is, your ≈øelues, meÃÑbers of Antichri≈øtes church. Be not a≈øhamed of ye go≈øpel, or of ≈øuch as be bound therfore: but rather be partakers therof, fir≈øt inwardly by coÃÑpa≈ø≈øion, prayer, &c: then outwardlye by geuing according to that the Lord hath lent you to that ende: and la≈øte of all, by ≈øuffering wyth vs if God ≈øo will, and if it be nedeful for you. For my dearly beloued, be certayne that no maÃÑ can touch you or lay handes vpon you, but by the will of God, which is all good towards you, euen as the wil of a mo≈øt deare father, which
an not alwayes be angrye, or otherwy≈øe v≈øe his rodde, then only to cha≈øtice and correct, not to de≈øtroy hys children. Agayne, be certayne that no cro≈ø≈øe ≈øhall come vnto you before you nede it. For God is oure Phi≈øicion, and when he ≈øeeth oure ≈øoules in perill, he preuenteth the peryll by purgation and mini≈øtring Phi≈øicke, which is the cro≈ø≈øe. As therfore for the body, we follow the aduice of the Phi≈øicions for ye health thereof, thankefully v≈øing their coun≈øell and obeying theyr preceptes: ≈øo for gods ≈øake, let vs for our ≈øoules being ≈øicke, thankefullye receaue the heauenlye Phi≈øicions phi≈øicke and dyet: ≈øo ≈øhall we waxe ≈øtronge men in GOD and in hys Chri≈øte. Which thyng I be≈øech thee O holy ≈øpirite to worke in vs all, Amen.

My dearly beloued, thys haue I brieflye written vnto you, Phil. 4. not as one that ≈øeketh any giftes, as Paul ≈øayth, but as one that ≈øeeketh aboundaunt fruites on your behalfe, and to your commoditye. For it is better to geue then to receaue, ≈øayteh Chri≈øte by hys Apo≈øtle S. Paule: who te≈øtifyeth that according to that we ≈øowe, ≈øo ≈øhal we reape. He that ≈øoweth little,2. Cor. 9. ≈øhall reape little: he that ≈øoweth muche ≈øhall reape much. Neuer ≈øhoulde we forgette, how that the Lorde Ie≈øus being riche, for our ≈øakes became poore, that we myght be made riche by hym. Agayn, neuer ≈øhoulde we forget that we are dead to ≈øinne, and aliue to ryghteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. Therefore ≈øhold we liue wholy vnto god & for god, & not for our ≈øelues. In al things therfore we mu≈øt auoide the ≈øekyng of our ≈øelues, as wel in doing, as in leuing things vndone. If ye cro≈ø≈øe come vpon vs therfore, then are we happy, for the ≈øpirite of God and the glorye of God, re≈øteth vpon vs. Therefore reioyce (≈øaith chri≈øt) for your reward is great in heaueÃÑ. Math. 5 In this we are made like to Chri≈øte here: therefore we ≈øhal be ≈øo els where, eueÃÑ in eternal ioye & endle≈ø≈øe glory. The high way to heaueÃÑ, you know is affliccioÃÑ: ≈øo that al that wil liue godly in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu, mu≈øt ≈øuffer per≈øecution. If we were of ye world, the world wold loue vs: Iohn. 15 but we are not of ye world, but beare witnes again≈øt ye world, & therfore the worlde doth hate vs. But let vs reioice, our lord hath ouercome ye world. He ≈øuffred out of ye Citie, beariÃÑg our rebuke, ≈øaith ye Apo≈øtle. Let vs then go out of oure tentes & beare hys rebuke: that is, let vs denye our ≈øelues, Heb. 13 take vp our cro≈ø≈øe, which is his al≈øo, & followe him. Let vs know & e≈øteme this more riches, theÃÑ al the
trea≈øures of ye world, as Mo≈øes did. Let vs know, yt he that ≈øaueth his life, ≈øhal lo≈øe it. Let vs know yt the way to ≈øaluatioÃÑ is a ≈øtrait waye, and a waye wherein we can not carye oure bagges and che≈øtes wt vs. Let vs know yt no excu≈øe of wife, farme, hou≈øe or childreÃÑ, wil excu≈øe vs. Let vs know yt in this ca≈øe we mu≈øt be ≈øo far froÃÑ louing father, mother, Luke. 14‚ñ™ wife & children, that we mu≈øt hate theÃÑ & our own ≈øelues al≈øo. Though this be a hard ≈øaying, yet we mu≈øt not leaue our loades man for a litle foule way. Yea rather we ≈øhoulde knowe in dede, that it is but hard to ye fle≈øh, which, if ≈øhe be haÃÑdled deintely, will be imperious: vnder mu≈øte ≈øhe be kepte, that ye ≈øpirit, which is a precious thing in gods ≈øight, may haue her coÃÑmodities. If we ≈øhould follow ye fan≈øye of the fle≈øhe, we coulde not plea≈øe god. Again≈øt it we haue made a ≈øolemne profe≈ø≈øioÃÑ, as al≈øo agayn≈øt the deuil & the world in oure bapti≈øme. And ≈øhal we now loke for ea≈øie thyngs of our enemies? Shal we not loke rather to be hardly entreated of theÃÑ? O yt we con≈øidered ofteÃÑ & in dede what we haue profe≈ø≈øed in bapti≈øme: then ye cro≈ø≈øe & we ≈øhould be wel acquainted together. For we are bapti≈øed into Chri≈øts death: that is, as to be pertakers of the benefite of his death, which is remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes: ≈øo to bee made like therunto coÃÑtinually by dying to ≈øinne. O that we coÃÑ≈øidered what we be: where we be: whether we are going: who calleth vs: how he calleth vs: to what felicitie he calleth vs: wherby he calleth vs: then my deare harts in the Lord, we ≈øhould ≈øay to al worldly per≈øua≈øions & per≈øuaders, follow me Sathan, thou ≈øeuere≈øt not tho≈øe things yt be of god, but the things that be of men. Shall we not drinke ye cuppe which our heauenly father hath appoynted for vs? O Lord god opeÃÑ yu our eyes yt we may ≈øee the hope wherunto yu ha≈øte called vs. Geue vs eyes of ≈øeing, eares of hearing, & hartes of vnder≈øtanding. In the fauour yu beare≈øt to thy people, remember vs: vi≈øite vs with thy ≈øauing health, that we maye ≈øee the good things thou ha≈øt prepared for thy elect childreÃÑ: that we may haue ≈øome ≈øyght of thy heauenly Ieru≈øaleÃÑ, and haue ≈øome ta≈øt of the ≈øwetenes of thy hou≈øe. O deare father, kindle in vs an earne≈øte de≈øire to bee with thee in ≈øoule and body, to pray≈øe thy name for euer withall thy ≈øaintes in thy eternall glorye, Amen.

div.head: To my deare fathers. D. Cranmer. D. Ridley and. D. Latimer.
div.p: IE≈øus Emanuell. My deare fathers in the Lorde, I be≈øeche God oure ≈øweete father, throughe Chri≈øt, to make perfecte the good he hath begonne in vs all, Amen.

I had thought that euery of your ≈øtaues had ≈øtande nexte the doore, but nowe it is otherwi≈øe perceaued. Our deare brother Rogers hath broken the I≈øe valiauntlye, and as thys daye (I thinke) or to morrowe at the vttermo≈øte, hartye Hoper, ≈øyncere Saunders, and tru≈øtye Taylour ende theyr cour≈øe and receaue their crowne. The nexte am I, whiche hourely looke for the porter to open me the gates after them, to enter into the de≈øyred re≈øte. God forgeue me myne vnthankefulne≈ø≈øe for thys exceedyng greate mercye, that amonges ≈øo manye thou≈øandes, it plea≈øeth hys mercye to choo≈øe me to be one in whom he wyll ≈øuffer. For althoughe it bee mo≈øt true, that lu≈øte patior (for I haue beene a greate hypocrite and a greuous ≈øynner, the Lorde pardon me, yea he hath done it, he hath done it in deede) yet, hic autem quid mali fecit? Chri≈øte whom the Prelates per≈øecute, hys veritye whiche they hate in me,This is a ≈øinguler mercye of God, to haue death which is a due puny≈øhmente for ≈øynne, turned into a demon≈øtratioÃÑ and ‚Ä¢ e≈ø ‚Ä¢ fication of the Lordes truth. hath done no euill, nor de≈øermeth death. Therefore oughte I mo≈øte hartelye to reioyce of thys dignation, and tender kindne≈ø≈øe of the Lorde towardes me, whiche v≈øeth the remedye for my ≈øynne, as a te≈øtimoniall of hys te≈øtament, to hys glorye, to my euerla≈øting comforte, to the edifying of hys Church, and to the ouerthrowing of Antichri≈øte and hys kyngdome. O what am I Lord, that thou ≈øhoulde≈øt thus magnifye me ≈øo vyle a man and my≈øer, as alwayes I haue bene? Is this thy wonte to ≈øende for ≈øuche a wretche and an hypocrite as I haue bene, in a fierye chariot,4. ReguÃÑ. 2 as thou didde≈øt for Helias? Oh deare fathers, be thankfull for me, and praye for me, that I ≈øtyll maye bee founde worthie, in whom the Lord would ≈øanctifye hys holy name.
And for your parts, make you readye, for we are but your gentlemen hu≈øhers. Nuptiae agni paratae ≈øunt, venite ad nuptias. I now goe to leaue my fle≈øh there, where I receaued it.He meaneth that he ≈øhold be coÃÑueyed by the Queenes Garde into Lanke≈øhire to be burnt, as the aduer≈øaries had one ‚Ä¢ determined: like as ignatius was by a company of ≈øouldiers conueyed to Rome, & ca≈ø ‚Ä¢ to the Leoperdes. Eccle. hi≈øt. Libr. 3. Cap. 36. I ≈øhal be conueyed thether, as Ignatius was to Rome, Leopardis: by who≈øe euil I hope to be made better. God graunt, if it be his will that I a≈øke, it maye make them better by me, Amen. For my farewell therefore, I write and ≈øende thys vnto you, tru≈øting ≈øhortlye to ≈øee you, where we ≈øhall neuer be ≈øeperated. In the meane ≈øea≈øon I will not cea≈øe, as I haue done to commende you to our father of heauen. And that ye would ≈øo do by me, I mo≈øt hartely pray euery one of you: You know now I haue mo≈øt nede. But fidelis deus, qui nunquam finet nos tentari ≈øupra id qu√≤d po≈øsumus. He neuer did it hetherto, nor now, I am a≈ø≈øured, he wyll neuer do, Amen. A dextris est mihi, non mouebor. Propter hoc laetabitur cor meum, quia non derelinquet animam meam in inferno, nec dabit me ≈øanctum ≈øuum, per gratiam in Chri≈øto, videre corruptionem. E carcere raptim, expectans omni momento carnificem. The. 8. of febr. Anno. 1555.

div.head: To the Ladye Vane.
div.p: OVr deare and mo≈øte meeke father, alwayes be with vs for his Chri≈øtes ≈øake, and as his children guide vs for euer, Amen

Your comfortable and nece≈ø≈øarye letters la≈øte ≈øente to me, ryghte wor≈øhipfull and dearely beloued, doe de≈øerue at my hands, as other your benefites haue done, that which I can not geue. The Lord my God recompence you, as he can and will vndoubtedly. Nowe am I going to my good father and your father: now am I going to my Chri≈øt and your Chri≈øte: nowe am I going to my home and your home. I goe before but you ≈øhall followe: howbeit when or which way, I know not, the Lord knoweth. Vnto his prouidence and will, commend your ≈øelfe. For as it can not but
come to pa≈ø≈øe, ≈øo is there nothing ≈øo good to vs as it is. Happy were we that euer we were borne, that God myghte ≈øet forth his glory by vs, how ≈øoeuer he do it. Though I am led (as to Peter was ≈øayd) whether I woulde not, yet with me and for me geue thankes yt it plea≈øeth my father thus to lead me. I haue de≈øerued, yea eueÃÑ ≈øince I came into this pri≈øon, many a ≈øhamefull death: ≈øuch and ≈øo great is my ingratitude and ≈øinnes. But loe, the tender kindne≈ø≈øe of my father doth correct me as a childe & ≈øonne, making the remedie for my ≈øinnes an occa≈øion of his glory, a witne≈ø≈øing of his veritie, a confirmation of his true religion, heretofore ≈øet forth & preached by me. Wherin (good Madame) per≈øi≈øte & you ≈øhal be ≈øafe. Be not now a≈øhamed of it, for though it ≈øeme to be ouercome, yet by ≈øuffering it ouercommeth: that Gods wi≈øedome, which is foli≈øhne≈ø≈øe to ye world, gods power, which is weaknes to the rea≈øon of man, may triumph and confound that which with the world is wi≈øe and mightie. Now do I beginne to be Chri≈øtes di≈øciple: now I beginne to be fa≈øhioned like to my Mai≈øter in ≈øuffering, that ≈øo I maye bee in reygning: nowe do I for euer take my farewell of you for thys lyfe: nowe commend I my ≈øelfe into the handes of my father, by who≈øe prouidence I came into thys worlde, by who≈øe prouidence I haue bene kept in thys worlde, and by who≈øe prouidence I do departe hence. And as his prouidence is towardes me, ≈øo doubte you nothing but it is towardes you: thoughe not in ≈øuch ≈øorte exteriourlye, yet in ≈øuch loue, ≈øollicitude, and carefulne≈ø≈øe for you interiourlye. God, our God, & father of mercy, for the blood of his Chri≈øt, wa≈øhe away al our ≈øinnes, comfort hys Church, ≈øtrengthen the weake, conuert or confouÃÑd, as may make mo≈øt to his glory, his ennemies, and he with vs Emanuell for euer, Amen, Amen.

div.head: To my good brother Augu≈øtine Berneber.
div.p:
MYne own good Augu≈øtine, the Lorde of mercy ble≈ø≈øe thee my deare brother for euer. I haue good hope
that if you come late at nyght, I ≈øhall ≈øpeake with you, but come as ≈øecretly as you can. Howbeit, in the meane ≈øea≈øon if you can, and as you can, learne what Mai≈øter G. hath ≈øpoken to Doctor Storie and others. The cau≈øe of al this trouble both to my keper and me, is thought to come by him. It is ≈øayd that I ≈øhall be burned in Smithfield and that ≈øhortlye. Domini voluntas fiat. Ecce ego domine, mitte me. Ah myne owne ≈øweete frend, I am nowe alone, le≈øt I ≈øhoulde make you & others wor≈øe. If I ≈øhoulde liue, I would more warely v≈øe the companye of gods childreÃÑ then euer I haue done. Iram domini portabo, quon ‚Ä¢ am peccaui ei.
Mich. 6. Commend me to my mo≈øt dere Si≈øter, for whom my hart bledeth, the Lord comfort her and ≈øtrengthen her vnto the ende. I thinke I haue taken my leaue of her for euer in this life, but in eternal life we ≈øhal mo≈øt ≈øurely meete and pray≈øe the Lord continually. I haue now taken a more certayne aun≈øwere of death, then euer I dyd: and yet not ≈øo certayne as I thinke I ≈øhoulde do. I am now as a ≈øheepe appoynted to the ≈ølaughter. Ah my God the houre is come, glorifye thy mo≈øte vnworthye childe. I haue glorifyed thee, ≈øayth thys my ≈øwete father, & I will glorify thee, Amen. Ah myne own bowels, pray≈øe God for me, and pray for me: for I am his I hope: I hope he wil neuer for≈øake me, though I haue aboue all other mo≈øte de≈øerued it. I am the mo≈øte ≈øinguler example of hys mercye: prai≈øed be hs name therefore for euer. Cau≈øe My≈øtres Perpoynte to learne of the Shriefe M. Che≈øter, what they purpo≈øe to do with me, and knowe if you can, whether there be any writ forth for me. Factus ≈øum ≈øicut nicticorax in domicilio,
P≈øa. 101.
‚Ä¢ pa≈øser ≈øolitarius in tecto. Ah my Augu≈øtine, how long ≈øhall Gods enemyes thus triumphe? I haue ≈øent you thys of the bapti≈øme of children to write oute, when thys is done, you ≈øhall haue other thyngs. Pray, pray myne owne deare hart, on whom I am bolde. The keper telleth me that it is death for any to ≈øpeake with me, but yet I tru≈øt that I ≈øhal ≈øpeake with you.

div.head: To myne owne good Augu≈øtine.
div.p: DEare brother Augu≈øtine, I can not but bee bolde of you in my nede, and therfore I write as I do. Come hether betimes, I pray you, in the mornyng, & v≈øe ≈øo to do: for then I thinke you ≈øhall ≈øpeake with me. Al≈øo v≈øe to come late in the euenyng, & let me know whether, in the daye tyme I may ≈øend for you. Pray Wal≈øhe to ≈øteale you in, as I hope he will doe. If he do bryng you in, then ≈øhall thys whiche followeth not neede: but doubtyng the wor≈øt, thys do I write. Fyr≈øt wil my man William to make all thinges readye for me, for I am per≈øuaded I ≈øhall into Lanke≈øhire there to be burnt: howbeit fir≈øt they ≈øay I mu≈øt to the Fleete. Then will him to harken earelye in the morning, whether I be not conueyed away before men beware. Al≈øo I pray you, will Robert Harrington, who I hope wil go with me, to looke for that iourney. Vi≈øit often my deare ≈øi≈øter, and although I can not nowe write vnto her, as I would (for al things are more ≈øtraunge here, & ca≈øes more & more perelous) yet tell her that I am carefull for her: de≈øire her to be of good comforte: God ≈øhall geue vs to meete in hys kingdome. In the meane ≈øea≈øon I will praye for her as my deare≈øt ≈øi≈øter. Of truth I neuer did loue her halfe ≈øo well as I now do, and yet I loue her not halfe ≈øo well as I woulde doe: ≈øhee is the very daughter of Abraham. I pray thee hartelye bee merye my good brother, and de≈øire all my frendes ≈øo to be: for I thanke god, I feele a greater benefite then all the By≈øhops in England can take from me. Prai≈øe God and praye for me, mine owne deare harte in the Lord, whom I hope I ≈øhall neuer forget.

signed.hi: Your poore brother in the Lorde. Iohn Bradford.

div.head: To certaine men, not ryghtly per≈øuaded in the mo≈øt true, comfortable, and nece≈ø≈øarye doctrine of Gods holy election and prede≈øtination.
div.p: GRace, mercye, and peace, wyth encreace of all godly knowlege and liuing, from god the eternal father of al con≈øolation, through the bloudy death of our alone and full redemer Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, by the mighty and liuely workyng and power of the holy ≈øpirit the comforter. I wi≈øh vnto you now and for euer, Amen.

Although I loke hourely for officers to come and haue me to execution, yet can I not but atteÃÑpt to write ≈øomthing vnto you, my dearely beloued (as alwayes you haue bene, how ≈øoeuer you haue taken me) to occa≈øion you the more to wey the things wherin ≈øome controuer≈øy hath bene emonge≈øt vs, e≈øpecially the article and doctrine of prede≈øtination. Wherof I haue writeÃÑ a little treati≈øe: therin, as briefly ≈øhewing my faith, ≈øo an≈øwering ye enormities gathered of ≈øome, to ≈ølauÃÑder the ≈øame nece≈ø≈øary & comfortable doctryne. That litle piece of worke I commend vnto you, as a thing wherof I doute not to an≈øwer to my comfort before the trubual ≈øeat of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: and therfore I hartely pray you and euery of you, for the tender mercies of God in Chri≈øte, that you woulde not be ra≈øhe to condemne thinges vnknowen, le≈øt gods woe ≈øhould fall vpon you for callyng good euyll and euyll good. For the greate loue of god in Chri≈øte, cauil not at things that be wel ≈øpoken, nor con≈øtrue not things to the euil part, when ye haue occa≈øion otherwi≈øe. Do not ≈øuppo≈øe that any man, by affirmyng prede≈øtination (as in that boke I haue truly ≈øet it forth accordyng to gods worde, and the con≈øent of chri≈øtes church) either to ≈øeke carnalitie, or to ≈øet forth matter of de≈øperation. Only by the doctrine of it, I haue taught, as to my ≈øelfe, ≈øo to others, a certaintie of ≈øaluation: a ≈øetting vp of Chri≈øt only: an exaltatioÃÑ of gods grace, mercye, righteou≈ønes, truth, wi≈ødom, power and glory, and a ca≈øting downe of man and al hys power, that he that glorieth may glory onelye and altogether, and continuallye in the Lorde.

Man con≈øi≈øteth on .ij. partes, the ≈øoule and the body, & euery man of god hath (as a man wold ≈øay) ij. men, an outward or old man, and an inward or new man. The Deuils drifte is, to bryng the one into a carnalitie, and the other into a
doubt, and ≈øo to di≈øpayre, and hatred of god: but god for remedy hereof, hath ordeined hys word: which is deuided into ij. partes: the one is a doctrine which demaundeth of vs our duety, but geueth no power thereto, the other is a doctrine which not ≈øo much demaundeth as geueth. The former is called the law, which hath hys promi≈øes, coÃÑditionals and comminations, or threates accordinglye. The other is called the go≈øpel, or rather the free promi≈øes hanging not on conditioÃÑs on our behalfe, but ≈øimply on gods verity & mercy, although they requyre conditions, but not as hangyng theron: of which promy≈øes the go≈øpell may well be called a puplication. The former, that is, the law wyth her promy≈øes and comminations, tell man what he is, and ≈øhew hym what he can do. The later, that is the go≈øpell and free promi≈øes, tell and ≈øet forth Chri≈øt, and what mercy at Gods hand throughe Chri≈øt, we haue offred and geuen vnto vs. The former parte ≈øerueth to keepe the olde man from carnalitie and ≈øecurity, and to ≈øtirre hym vp to diligence and ≈øollicitude. The later parte ≈øerueth howe to kepe the newe and inwarde man from doubtyng and di≈øpayre, & to bryng vs in to an a≈ø≈øured certayntye and quietenes wyth God, through Chry≈øte. The olde man and the fielde he re≈øteth in, maye not be ≈øowen with any other ≈øeede then is agreable to the former doctrine. The newe man and the fielde he re≈øteth in, maye not be ≈øowen wyth anye other, then is agreeynge to the later doctryne. By thys meanes man ≈øhall be kepte from carnalitie, and from de≈øperation al≈øo, and broughte into diligence and godlye peace of con≈øcience. It is forbydden in the olde law, Deut. 22. to ≈øowe .ij. kyndes of ≈øeedes in one fielde, to weare lyn≈øey wol≈øey perticotes, or to eate bea≈øtes that dyd not cleaue the hofes. Deut. 14. God graunte vs to be wy≈øe hu≈øbandmen, to ≈øowe accordyng as I haue ≈øayd. God graunte vs to bee wy≈øe tayloures to cutte oure coates for two men of one whole clothe, as is declared. GOD graunt vs to be cleane bea≈øts, to cleaue the hofes accordinglye, that is to geue the olde man meate, meete for the mowers, that is the lawe wyth hys appurtenaunces, conditionals, promi≈øes, and comminations, and to geue to the newe
man the go≈øpel and ≈øweete free promi≈øes, as appertayneth: and then doutles we ≈øhall walke in the ryghte hyghe waye vnto eternal lyfe, that is in Chry≈øte Ie≈øu the ende of the lawe and the fulfyllyng of the promi≈øes, in whome they be yea and, Amen.

If thys my poore adui≈øe bee ob≈øerued (my deare bretherne in the Lorde) I doubte not but all controuer≈øies, for prede≈øtination, originall ≈øynne, freewyll, &c: ≈øhall ≈øo cea≈øe, that there ≈øhall be no breache of loue, nor ≈øu≈øpicion emonges vs: which GOD graunte for hys mercies ≈øake. I am per≈øuaded of you, that you feare the Lord, and therfore I loue you, and haue loued you in hym, (my deare hartes) thoughe otherwy≈øe you haue taken it wythout cau≈øe on my parte geuen, ≈øo farre as I know. For hetherto I haue not ≈øuffred any copye of the treati≈øe aboue ≈øpecified to goe abroade, becau≈øe I woulde ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe all occa≈øions ≈øo farre as myghte bee. Nowe am I goyng before you to my God and your God, to my father and your father, to my Chri≈øt and your Chri≈øte, to my home and your home. I goe before, but you ≈øhall come after, ≈øooner or later. Howebeit I could not but before I goe, ≈øygnify thus much vnto you, as I haue done, that you myghte ≈øee my loue, and thereby bee occa≈øioned to increa≈øe in loue, and learne rather to beare then breake. My poore & mo≈øt dere Sy≈øter to me that euer I had, with whoÃÑ I leaue thys lettter, I commende vnto you all and to euery of you, be≈øeechyng you, and hartelye praying you in the bowels and bloode of Ie≈øus Chry≈øte, to care for her, as for one whyche is deare in Gods ≈øyghte, and one whiche loueth you all in GOD, and hath done, as I can and doe beare her wytnes: althoughe in the poynte of prede≈øtination, it hathe plea≈øed God by my mini≈øterye, to open vnto her hys truthe. Wherein as ≈øhe is ≈øetled, and I tru≈øte in God, confyrmed: ≈øo yf you cannot thynke wyth her therein as ≈øhe dothe, I hartelye praye you, and as I can, in Gods behalfe charge you, that you mole≈øt her not, nor dy≈øquiete her, but lette loue abounde, and therein contende who can goe mo≈øte before. I commende al≈øo vnto you my good Sy≈øter M. C. makyng for her the lyke ≈øure vnto you all.

Ah dere hartes, be not faint harted for the≈øe euyll dais, which are come to trie vs & purify vs, yt we may the more be parteners of gods holines: as to our ≈øelues, ≈øo to ye worlde we ≈øhal be beter knowen. Continue to walke in the feare of the Lord, as ye haue wel begonne. Kepe your ≈øelues pure, as I hope you do, from thys rotten Romi≈øh, yea Antichri≈øtian religion. Reuerently read gods word, therto ioyning prayer: that as you heare in readyng god ≈øpeake vnto you, ≈øo in praying you may ≈øpeake vnto hym. Labour after your callyngs to helpe other. As you haue done, do ≈øtyll, and I pray god geue you grace to continue, as I dout not but he wil, for hys goodnes ≈øake. At ye leÃÑgth we ≈øhal mete together in Chri≈øtes kyngdome, and there neuer part a ≈øunder, but pray≈øe the name of our good god and father, wyth the Patriarkes, Prophets, Apo≈øtels, Aungels, Archaungels, and all the Saintes of God. Oh ioyfull place, oh place of all places de≈øyred. My brethren, I thynke my ≈øelfe more happye then you, by how much I am nowe more nere vnto it. Helias chariote I hourely loke for,4 Reg. 2 to come and catch me vppe. My cloke that is, my carcas, I ≈øhall leaue behind me in a≈øhes, which I doute not, my Lord wyl ray≈øe vp and re≈øtore to me again in the la≈øt day, glorifyed euen lyke vnto hys owne mo≈øt glorious body. The portion of the good ≈øpirit, which my father hath lent me, I wy≈øhe, yea double and treble vnto you al. God the father of mercy in the blood of his chri≈øt, geue to euery of you (my dere hartes) in hym, hys ble≈ø≈øyng, and poure plentifullye vpon you hys holy ≈øpirite, that you may increa≈øe in all godly knowledge and godlines, to your owne comfort and ye edification of many others, Amen. Yet once more I commend vnto you my fore≈øaid mo≈øt dere and beloued Sy≈øter in the lord: who alwais be vnto her a mo≈øt louyng father, ≈øpou≈øe and pa≈øtour, Amen, Amen. Out of pri≈øon the 16. of February. 1554.

div.head: To Trewe, and Abyngton, wyth other of their company, teachers and maynteiners of the errour of mans freewyll.
div.p: YEt once more beloued in the Lord, before penne and yuke be vtterly taken from me (as I looke it to bee thys after noone) I thought good to write vnto you, becau≈øe I ≈øtande in a doubte, whether at any tyme hereafter, I ≈øhall ≈øee or ≈øpeake wyth you: for within this ≈øeuen night my lord ChauÃÑ celour bade loke for iudgement. God knoweth I lye not, I neuer did beare you malice, nor ≈øought the hynderance of any one of you, but youre good bothe in ≈øoule and bodye,Read the 1. Cor. 13. chap. and compare the≈øe ≈øpirites wyth the ≈øpirit of humblenes, vnity and loue, which here you ≈øe in this man of God, doyng good euen to his aduer≈øaries, and then iudge of them & theyr doctrine. as when we ≈øhall all appeare together before God, I am certayne you ≈øhall then know, though now you doubte it, and that cau≈øes, I am right well a≈ø≈øured. For myne owne con≈øcience can and doth beare witnes wyth me, that I neuer defrauded you or any of you, of the valewe of one peny or peny worth of any thyng, but haue ≈øought wyth that whyche hath bene geuen, not onely in common, but al≈øo vnto me & to myne owne v≈øe, di≈øcretion, and di≈øtribution: to doe you good. Therfore di≈ødaine not the good will of your louer in god. And in hope that you wil not, I haue eft≈øones eueÃÑ now ≈øente vnto you .xiij.s. iiij d. Yf you nede as much more, you ≈øhall haue it, or any thyng olles I haue, or can doe for you. Though in ≈øome thyngs we agree not, yet let loue beare the bell away, and let vs one pray for another,He meaneth concerning freewyl, original ≈øume, prede≈øtinatioÃÑ, &c. wherein they are playne Pelagians and papi≈øtes. and bee carefull one for another: for I hope we bee all Chri≈øtes. As you hope your ≈øelues to perteyne to hym, ≈øo thinke of me: and as you be hys, ≈øo am I yours.

div.head: ¬∂At thys letter, the≈øe men were ≈øo ≈øore offended, becau≈øe he ≈øayde he had hyndered hym≈øelfe to further them, as though be had therby vpbrayded them: that in dy≈øplea≈øure they ≈øent it to hym agayne. Whereupon he wrote vnto them as followeth.
div.p:
HE that ≈øeketh not to hynder hym ≈øelfe temporally, that he may further hys brother in more nede, the ≈øame wanteth true loue. I haue done, do, and wil (except you refu≈øe it) hynder my ≈øelfe thys way that I may further you, and in
dede my ≈øelfe al≈øo that way,Though he di≈øtributed to them, emoÃÑges other pri≈øoners there, not only that which was geuen in coÃÑmon but al≈øo to hys owne v≈øe: yet they ≈øu≈øpected hym of euil dealyng. Thus do not they, in whom the loue of God dwelleth wherein I de≈øyre to be furthered. Yf I would ≈øeke mine owne gaynes temporallye, then coulde I haue taken & v≈øed many portioÃÑs of mony, whiche haue bene geuen to me mine owne v≈øe. I neuer mynded to vpbraide you: but that whiche I dyd wryte of myne owne hynderance, was that you myght ≈øee I loued you, and ≈øought your weale, as I doe, and wyll be glad to doe it continually. The lord of mercy hath forgeuen vs all, wherefore henceforth lette vs rather beare then breake.

closer.signed: Yours in the Lorde. Iohn Bradford.

div.head: ¬∂A letter whyche he ≈øet as a preface before a ≈øupplication ≈øente to Quene Marye, her coun≈øel, and the whole Parliamente: whiche ≈øupplication commeth not yet to our handes.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaineth vnto your Maie≈øty and honours, a poore ≈øubiect per≈øecuted for the confe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtes verity: the which verity de≈øerueth at your handes to be maintayned and defended, as the thynge, by the which you reigne and haue your honoure and authorities. Althoughe we that bee profe≈ø≈øours, and through the grace of GOD, the con≈øtaunte confe≈ø≈øoures of the ≈øame, are (as it were) the out ≈øwepynges of the worlde: yet (I ≈øay) the veritye it ≈øelfe is a thyng not vnworthye for your eares to heare, for your eies to ≈øee, and for your hands to handle, helpe, and ≈øuccour, accordyng to that the Lord hathe made you able, and placed you where you are, for the ≈øame purpo≈øe. Your hyghnes and honours ought to know, that there is no innocency in wordes or dedes, where it is enoughe and ≈øuffi≈øeth, onely to accu≈øe. It behoueth kynges, Quenes, and all that be in authoritye, to knowe that in the

to Marye Chri≈øtes Mother when he ≈øayde, Luke. 2. the ≈øworde, that is, the cro≈ø≈øe of per≈øecution ≈øhall pear≈øe thy ≈øoule that the thoughtes of manye hartes maye be opened. For like as a King that ≈øhoulde goe to battell, is compelled to looke in hys cofers what trea≈øure he hath, and al≈øo what number and pui≈øaunce of men and weapons, ≈øo that if he ≈øee hym≈øelfe vnreadye and vnarmed to bycker wyth hys ennemye, he ≈øurcea≈øeth and taketh truce for a tyme: euen ≈øo we by per≈øecutions haue oure hartes opened that we maye looke therein to ≈øee what faythe in Chri≈øte we haue, and what ≈øtrengthe to wyth≈øtande the enemyes and to beare the cro≈ø≈øe, that if we bee ryche in the≈øe trea≈øures, we myghte reioyce and valiauntlye goe to battell, or if we wante the≈øe thinges, with all ≈øpeede to call and crye vppon him, whiche geueth all good giftes to tho≈øe that a≈øke them. Item the cro≈ø≈øe trieth the good people from the badde, the faithfull froÃÑ the worldlings & hypocrites, & al≈øo cleÃÑ≈øeth & ≈øcoureth the faythful hartes from al corruption & filthyne≈ø≈øe both of the fle≈øh & the ≈øpirit. And eueÃÑ as an yron, except it be ofteÃÑ ≈øcoured, wil ≈øone waxe ru≈øtye: ≈øo except our ≈øinfull hartes & fle≈øh be often ≈øcoured with the whet≈øtone of the cro≈ø≈øe, they wil ≈øone corrupt & ouergrow with the ru≈øt of al filthyne≈ø≈øe and ≈øinne. And therfore it is mete & good for vs (as the wi≈ømaÃÑ ≈øayth) yt as gold & ≈øiluer are tryed in the fyre, Sirach. 2. ≈øo ≈øhoulde the hartes of acceptable men be tryed in the fornace of aduer≈øitie. Fyght manfully in thys the Lords cau≈øe, yt ye may obteyne a gloryous victory here, and receaue a great reward in heauen hereafter. As ye are called Chri≈øtians, and would be angrye to be called Iewes or Turkes, ≈øo declare your chri≈øtianitye by followyng the ≈øteppes of Chri≈øte, who≈øe name ye beare: ≈øuffer with hym and for hys Go≈øpelles ≈øake, rather then to denye hym or to defyle youre fayth and con≈øcience wyth fal≈øe wor≈øhippyng or Romy≈øhe religion. Take vppe your cro≈ø≈øe (my deare hartes) nowe when it is offered you, and goe vppe wyth Chri≈øte to Ieru≈øalem amonge≈øt the By≈øhoppes, Prie≈øtes, and rulers (yf GOD call you thereto) and they wyl anone ≈øend you to Caluarye: from whence (dying in the cau≈øe of the Go≈øpell, wherin oure good preachers and brethren haue geuen their lyues) your ≈øoules, I
warrant you, through Chri≈øte Ie≈øu, Eccle. 12. ≈øhall a≈øcende to GOD that gaue them, and the bodye ≈øhall come after at the la≈øte daye, and ≈øo ≈øhall ye dwell wyth the Lorde for euer in vn≈øpeakeable ioye and bly≈ø≈øe. O ble≈ø≈øed are they that ≈øuffer per≈øecution for ryghteou≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øake, as Chri≈øtes people in thys Iewy≈øhe Englande now doth, for theirs is the kyngdome of heauen. O my beloued, ≈øette your myndes on this kyngdome where Chri≈øte our heade and Kyng is, con≈øideryng that as the brute bea≈øte looketh downewardes wyth the face towardes the earth, ≈øo is man made contrarye wi≈øe wyth hys face looking vpwardes towardes the heauens, becau≈øe hys conuer≈øation ≈øhoulde be in heauen and heauenly thyngs, and not vppon the earth and earthlye chynges, Col. 3 as Sainct Paule ≈øayth: ≈øet your myndes on thynges which are are aboue where Chri≈øte is. The ≈øeconde thyng that I note in the fore≈øayde wordes of Peter, is, that he calleth per≈øecution no ≈øtraunge thynge. And truth it is: for whiche of the Prophettes were not per≈øecuted wyth Chri≈øte and hys Apo≈øtles, and ≈øome of them in the ende cruellye kylled for the truthes ≈øake? Act. 14, All the holy Prophettes, Chri≈øte and hys Apo≈øtles ≈øuffered ≈øuche afflictions, not for euel doing, but for preachinge Gods woord, for rebukyng the worlde of ≈øynne, and for their fayth in Ie≈øus Chri≈øte. Thys is the ordinaunce of GOD (my
frends) this is the hygh way to heauen, by corporal death to eternal lyfe: Iohn. 5. as Chri≈øt ≈øayth, he that heareth my words & beleueth in hym that ≈øent me, hath eternal life, & ≈øhal not come into iudgemeÃÑt, but is e≈øcaped from death to lyfe. Let vs neuer feare death, which is kylled by chri≈øt, but beleue in him & liue for euer, Roman. 8. as Paul ≈øayth: there is no damnation to them yt are in chri≈øt Ie≈øu, which walke not after the fle≈øhe, but after the ≈øpirit.1. Corin. 15. And agayne, Paule ≈øayth: Death where is thy ≈øting? Hel where is thy victory? Thankes be to god whiche hath geuen vs victory through Ie≈øu Chri≈øt. Be≈øides this, ye haue ≈øene & dayly do ≈øee the blood of your good preachers, & brethren which hath bene ≈øhed in the go≈øpels cau≈øe in thys ≈øinful Sodome, thys bloody Ieru≈øaleÃÑ, this vnhappie citie of LondoÃÑ. Let not their blood be forgotteÃÑ, nor ye blood of your good by≈øhop Ridley, who like a good ≈øhepeherd, to your coÃÑ fort & exaÃÑple, hath geueÃÑ hys lyfe for his ≈øhepe. S. Paul ≈øaith, remember them yt haue ≈øpokeÃÑ to you the word of god, Iohn. 10. Heb. 13 & loke vpon ye end of their conuer≈øation, and folow their faith. The deuil euer ≈øtirreth vp fal≈øe teachers, as he hath done now ouer al England,2. peter. 2. 1. Timot 4. 2. Timo. 3. Iude. 1. as Peter, Paul, & Iude prophecyed it ≈øhold be, to poi≈øon & kil our ≈øoules wyth fal≈øe doctrine. And where he fayleth hys purpo≈øe that way, then moueth he hys members to per≈øecute ye ≈øely carca≈øes of the Saints, becau≈øe they wyl not denye nor di≈ø≈øemble theyr pure fayth in our liuyng Chri≈øt, & confe≈ø≈øe a dead bready chri≈øt, and honour the ≈øame as Chri≈øt god & man, Exod 20. 1. Iohn. 5. 2. Corin. 10 contrary to gods coÃÑmaundements. Thys is the working of SathaÃÑ, who knowing hys own iu≈øt daÃÑpnation, would al mankynd to be pertakers wyth him of the ≈øame: ≈øuch a mortal hatred beareth he agayn≈øt god & his people. Matth. 4. And therfore when thys wicked tempter could not kyll Chri≈øt with ≈øuttel temtation to fal down & wor≈øhip him, theÃÑ he ≈øtirred vp hys ≈øeruantes the by≈øhops & Phari≈øees to kil hys body, wherby notwith≈øtanding the deuyl lo≈øt hys title & entere≈øt which he had to mans ≈øoule, and maÃÑ by his precious pa≈ø≈øion and death was raun≈øomed froÃÑ ye deuil, death & hel, to immortalitie & lyfe euerla≈øting: and ≈øo when Sathan thought to haue wonne all in kylling of Chri≈øt he lo≈øt all, and ≈øo ≈øhall he do in vs if we abyde con≈øtant and ≈øtrong in the fayth of our lord and Sauiour Ie≈øu Chri≈øt vnto the end. God graunt it, for his mercyes ≈øake in Chri≈øt: ble≈ø≈øed are al they that put their tru≈øt in hym, Amen.

Wherfore (my hartely beloued brethreÃÑ & ≈øi≈øters) be of good coÃÑ fort through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, for he yt is in vs, is ≈øtroÃÑger theÃÑ he that is in the world. Therfore draw ye nere to god, Iames. 2 & he wil draw nere to you. Re≈øi≈øt the deuil & he wil (as Iames ≈øaith) flee froÃÑ you. Beware of the leueÃÑ of the Phari≈øees. Math. 16. Touch not pitche, lea≈øt ye be defiled therewith. Eate no ≈øwynes fle≈øhe, for it is again≈øt ye lawe: I meane defyle not your ≈øelues neither inwardly nor outwardly with thys fal≈øe & wicked religion of Antichri≈øt: for it is nothing els but pitch, Apo. 13.14. Apo. 18 2. Cor. 6. & ≈øwynes fle≈øh. Beware of ye bea≈øtes marke, le≈øt ye drinke of the cup of gods wrath. If god haue geueÃÑ you knowlege & fayth, di≈ø≈øeÃÑ ble not therwith. Deny not the knowen verity before men, le≈øt Chri≈øt denie you before hys father. Come away froÃÑ Babilon, as Iohn biddeth you, & touch no vncleane thing, but ≈øeperate your ≈øelues from the companye of the vngodly, as Paul commaundeth you. What ≈øoeuer ye haue done amy≈ø≈øe heretofore, now repent and amend, p≈øal. 129. for with the lord there is mercye and plenteous redemption.

The third thing & note which I gather out of ye fore≈øayd words of Peter, is this, yt he ≈øayth reioyce becau≈øe ye are pertakers of Chri≈øts pa≈ø≈øioÃÑs. Our ≈øufferings (my welbeloued) are chri≈øts ≈øufferings: and that iniury yt is done to vs for his ≈øake, he rekoneth it to be done to him≈øelf: as he ≈øaid to Paul, Act. 9. Therfore we ought to reioyce in our ≈øufferings, as Paul writeth, which we ≈øuffer wt Chri≈øt & one with an other, as Peter ≈øayth, & ≈øo to fulfyll yt which is behinde of ye pa≈ø≈øions of Chri≈øt in our fle≈øh: which Chri≈øt hath by hys pa≈ø≈øion, fully redemed & ≈øaued vs in hys own per≈øon: howbeit hys elect mu≈øt ≈øuffer wt him & for him vnto the worldes end, Mat. 5. that he may be glorifyed in theÃÑ and they therby corrected & clen≈øed froÃÑ ≈øinne in thys world, & be made more mete temples for the holy gho≈øt, and al≈øo obtain a great reward in heaueÃÑ for their ≈øuffering for righteou≈ønes ≈øake, according to his promi≈øe. And therfore I ≈øay (my brethreÃÑ) reioyce in the lord alwayes, & agayne I ≈øay reioice. Let vs reioyce in the cro≈ø≈øe of our lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Phil 3. Galat. 6. wherby the word is crucifyed to vs & we to it. And why ≈øhoulde we ≈øo greatly reioyce in the cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt, which we now ≈øuffer? Becau≈øe (≈øaith Peter) when his glory appeareth, we may be mery & glad. And this is ye fourth note yt I gather out of his words aboue writeÃÑ: Wherin is ≈øet out ye reward of ≈øuffering,
not to be had in this world, but at his coming to iudgement when we ≈øhal be ray≈øed agayn, and then ≈øhall they that haue ≈øowen in teares, reape in ioy, as chri≈øt ≈øayth: ble≈ø≈øed are they that wepe here, for they ≈øhal laughe. Ble≈ø≈øed are ye when meÃÑ hate you, & thru≈øt you out of their company, rayling on you, & abhorring your name as an euel thiÃÑge for the ≈øonne of maÃÑs ≈øake, Luke. 6 reioyce ye in that day and be glad, for your rewarde is great in heauen.

Continue in prayer, & pray for me yt I may end my cour≈øe wt ioye. Haue brotherly loue amonge≈øt your ≈øelues, Iohn. 14 which is a tokeÃÑ that ye be Chri≈øts di≈øtiples. For your liberalitie & kindne≈ø≈øe ≈øhewed vpoÃÑ the pri≈øoners & afflicted people of god in this time of per≈øecutioÃÑ, the lord wil reward you wheÃÑ he cometh to reward euery maÃÑ according to their dedes, and wil not leaue a cup of cold water be≈øtowed vpon his faythfull people, vnrewarded. div.head: To my louyng and faythfull brother Iohn Careles, pri≈øoner in the Kynges Benche.
div.p:
THe ≈øame faith for the which AbrahaÃÑ was accompted iu≈øte and Mary ble≈ø≈øed, wherby al≈øo al iu≈øt men liue, the lorde god our louing father encrea≈øe and ≈øtably≈øhe in you and me, to the obteining of eternal life in our alone and ≈øwete Sauiour
Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Amen.

I caÃÑ not worthely & ≈øufficiently pray≈øe god (my hartely be loued brother) for the con≈øolation & ioye that I receaued by rea≈øoÃÑ of your louing letters, repeÃÑting me much that I being ≈øo long ≈øo nere you, did not enterpry≈øe to ≈øtirre vp familiaritie & comunicatioÃÑ betwene vs by writing, to our mutual coÃÑ ≈øolation in Chri≈øte. For what is there vpon earth wherin to reioyce (where al things are tran≈øitory & vaine, yea maÃÑ him ≈øelf, re≈øpecting this life) but, as Dauid ≈øaith, P≈øal. 16 the Saints that dwel vpon the earth, & ≈øuch as excel in vertue? But here now I con≈øider, yt if the felow≈øhip, loue, & ioy of faythful men and children of god, being as we now be in double bondage, the body within clay walles, & the ≈øoule wtin the≈øe frayle earthly bodies, be ≈øo great and comfortable: howe vn≈øpeakeable wil tho≈øe ioyes be, when we ≈øhal be deliuered froÃÑ al corruption into ye glorious libertie of the ≈øonnes of god, Where we ≈øhal be pre≈øent together continually in our glorified bodies, beholding ye face of our father pre≈øently (whoÃÑ now we ≈øee but in the gla≈ø≈øe of fayth) with his dere ≈øonne chri≈øt our redemer & brother, and the ble≈ø≈øed companye of Angels & al faithful ≈øaued ≈øoules? Oh the incomparable good things and heauenly trea≈øures layd vp for vs in heauen by chri≈øt Ie≈øu. For the obteyning wherof, we ought to ≈øet light by al teÃÑporal grefes and tran≈øitory afflictions ≈øo much the more, in that our good God is faythful & wil not ≈øuffer vs to be teÃÑpted aboue oure ≈øtrength, & that namely in ye end of our life, Eccle. 11. wheÃÑ ye tree where it falleth, lieth ≈øtil, as the preacher ≈øayeth: when euerye one, cau≈øa ≈øua dormit & cau≈øa ≈øua re≈øurget: for els before ye end he ≈øuffereth hys ≈øomtime to fal, but not finally to pery≈øh: as Peter ≈øincked vpon the ≈øea, but yet was not drowned, and ≈øynned greuou≈øly vpon the lande throughe infirmitie denying his Mai≈øter, but yet found mercye: for the ryghteous falleth oftentymes. And Chri≈øts holy Apo≈øtles are taught to ≈øay, remitte nobis debita no≈øtra: Yea thoughe the righteous fall, ≈øaieth Dauid, he ≈øhal not be ca≈øt away, for the Lord vpholdeth hym wyth hys hande. Oh the bottomle≈ø≈øe mercy of God toward vs mi≈øerable ≈øinners. He vouch≈øafe to plante in my harte true repentance and fayth, to the obteyning of remi≈ø≈øion of al my ≈øynnes in the mercyes of God, and merites of Chri≈øte hys ≈øonne, and therto I pray you ≈øay, Amen. Oh my hartely beloued, it greueth me to ≈øee ye ≈øpoyle & hauocke ye Saule maketh with the congregation of Chri≈øte, but what remedye?
This is gods wil & ordinance, that his people ≈øhal here both be puni≈øhed in the fle≈øh, & tried in their fayth, as it is writteÃÑ: many are the troubles of the righteous, but the lord deliuereth theÃÑ out of al, for by a ≈øtrait path & narowe dore mu≈øt we enter. Whether? Into ye ioyful kingdome of heaueÃÑ. Therfore ble≈ø≈øed are you, & other that ≈øuffer per≈øecutioÃÑ for chri≈øts ≈øake, for the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing of ye ≈øame. Pray for me & my felowes (good brother) that we may fyght a good fyght, that we may kepe the fayth, and end our cour≈øe with ioyful gladnes, for now the tyme of our deliueraÃÑce is at hand. The lord guide, defeÃÑd, and kepe vs & you, & al his people in our iourney, yt we may ≈øafely through a ≈øhort death, pa≈ø≈øe to that long la≈øting life.

Farewel my dere and louing brother & fellow ≈øouldiour in Chri≈øt, farewel I ≈øay in him, who receaue our ≈øoules in peace when they ≈øhal depart froÃÑ the≈øe tabernacles, and he graunt vs a ioyfull re≈øurrection, and a mery metyng at the la≈øt day, and continuall dwelling together in hys eternall and heauenly kingdome, through Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our Lord, Amen.

div.head: To my deare brethren .M. Filles and Cutbert.
div.p:
MY dere and welbeloued brethren in Chri≈øt M. Filles and Cutbert, I wi≈øh you al welfare of ≈øoule & body. Welfare to the ≈øoule, is repentance of ≈øynne, faythful affiance in chri≈øt Ie≈øus, & a godly life. Welfare to ye body, is the health of the ≈øame, wt al nece≈ø≈øary things for this bodely life. The ≈øoule of maÃÑ is immortal, & therfore ought to be wel kept, le≈øt immortalitie to ioy, ≈øhould turne to immortalitie of ≈øorow. As for the body, be it neuer ≈øo wel kept & much made of, yet ≈øhortly by nature wil it pery≈øh & decay. But tho≈øe that are engraffed and incorporated into Chri≈øt by true fayth, feeling the motion of Gods holy ≈øpirite, as a pledge of their electition and enheritaunce, excityng and ≈øtirring them not onelye to ≈øeke heauenly thyngs, but al≈øo to hate vyce & embrace vertue: wyll not onely do tho≈øe things, but al≈øo if neede requyre, wyll gladlye take vppe theyr cro≈ø≈øe and followe theyr Captayne, Mat. 26. Mar. 14 theyr Kynge, and theyr Sauioure Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, as hys poore afflicted Churche of Englande nowe doth, agayn≈øte that fal≈øe and Antichri≈øtian doctrine & religioÃÑ
nowe v≈øed, and ≈øpecially that bla≈øphemous ma≈ø≈øe, wherein chri≈øtes ≈øupper and holy ordinauÃÑce is altogether peruerted and abu≈øed contrary to his in≈øtitution, Luke. 22. 2. Cor. 1 ‚Ä¢
and to Paules procedinges: ≈øo that, that whiche they haue in their Ma≈ø≈øe is neyther ≈øacrameÃÑt of chri≈øt nor yet ≈øacrifice for ≈øinne, as the prie≈øtes fal≈øely pretende. It is a ≈øacrament, that is as S. Augu≈øtine ≈øaith, a vi≈øible ≈øigne of inui≈øible grace, when it is mini≈øtred to the communicantes accordyng to chri≈øtes example, and as it was of late yeares in thys realme. And as for ≈øacrifice, there is none to be made now for ≈øinne: Heb. 9.10 for Chry≈øte with one ≈øacrifice hath perfited for euer tho≈øe that are ≈øaÃÑctified. Beware of fal≈øe religion and mens vaine traditioÃÑs, and ≈øerue god wyth reuerence and godly feare, accordyng to the doctryne of hys Go≈øpel, Luke. i1 whereto cleane ye that ye maye be ble≈ø≈øed, though of wycked men ye be hated & accur≈øed. Rather drinke of the cup of Chri≈øt wyth his church, Apo. 18. then of the cup of that ro≈øe coloured whore of Babylon. which is ful of abhominatioÃÑs.
