Timot. 2. whiche no man elles can haue but he that fyghteth lawfullye: as at thys pre≈øente daie, if he can not induce hym throughlye, as other doe, to fauoure hys deuily≈øhe religion, and of good will and free harte to helpe to vpholde the ≈øame, yet he will enuegle hym to re≈øort to his wicked and whory≈øh Scholehou≈øe, and

I Now (mo≈øt dere chri≈øtians) hauyng the ≈øwete comforte of gods ≈øauing health, and beyng confirmed wyth hys free ≈øpirit (be he only pray≈øed therefore) am con≈øtrayned in my con≈øcience, thinkyng it my very duety, to admoni≈øh you, as ye tender the ≈øaluation of your ≈øoules, by al maner of meanes to ≈øeparate your ≈øelues from the companye of the Popes hirelinges, con≈øideryng what is ≈øaid in the reuelation of S. This bea≈øt is none other but the carnall and fle≈øhly kingdome of Antichri≈øt, the Pope wyth hys rable of fal≈øe Prophetes and mini≈øters, as it is mo≈øt manife≈øt: the which to maintayn their high titles worldly promotions and dignities, do with much crueltye daily more and more ≈øet forth and e≈øtabli≈øh their owne traditions, decrees, and decretals, contrary to gods holy ordinaunces, ≈øtatutes, lawes and commaundements, and wholy repugnant to hys ≈øyncere & pure religion and true wor≈øhippyng. Nowe what doe they elles but wor≈øhippe thys bea≈øt and hys image, which after they had once already e≈øcaped from the fylthines of the world,2. peter. 2. through the knowlege of the lord and Sauioure Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, are yet again taÃÑgled therin, and ouercome, v≈øing di≈ø≈øimulation vnfaithfully, for feare of their di≈øplea≈øure, doing one thyng outwardlye, and thinkyng inwardlye an other: ≈øo hauing them in reuerence
vnder a cloke and colour, to whom they ought not ≈øo much as to ≈øay god ≈øpede: Iohn. 3. & adioining them≈øelues to the malignauÃÑt congregatioÃÑ which they ought to abhorre as a deÃÑne of theues & murtherers, Iohn. 10 EZe. 16 & as the brothel hou≈øe of mo≈øt bla≈øphemous fornicators, who≈øe voices being contrary to chri≈øtes voice, if they were of his flocke, they would not know, but wold fly froÃÑ theÃÑ: as he him≈øelf being the good ≈øhepehard of our ≈øoules doth ful wel in his holy go≈øpel te≈øtify. Iohn. 10. Agayn, what do they els I pray you, but receiue ye bea≈øtes marke in their foreheades & in their hands, which do beare a faire face and couÃÑtenance outwardly in ≈øupporting them as other do, being a≈øhamed openly to confe≈ø≈øe chri≈øt and his holy go≈øpel. But this fainednes & di≈ø≈øimulatioÃÑ, Mar. 18. chri≈øt and hys go≈øpel wil in no wi≈øe allow: of whoÃÑ it is ≈øaid, who≈øoeuer ≈øhalbe a≈øhamed of me & my words in this adulterous and ≈øynful generation, Luke. 9. of him al≈øo ≈øhall the ≈øonne of man be a≈øhamed, when he ≈øhal come in the glory of his father with his holy angels. Wherfore (good chri≈øtiaÃÑs) for gods mo≈øt dere loue, deceiue not your ≈øelues through your own wi≈ødoÃÑ, & through ye wi≈ødoÃÑ of ye world which is foli≈øhnes before god, but certify & ≈øtay your owne con≈øcience wyth the ≈øure truth & faithful word of god,1. div.head: ‚ùß Letters of Mai≈øter Robert Glouer, a gentleman of muche godlye learnynge, innocencye and vpryghtnes of lyfe, and hartye zeale to the worde of God, burnte at Couentrie for the faythfull te≈øtimonye of the ≈øame, the .14. daye of September, In the yere of our Lord .1555.

So long as God ≈øhall lende you continuance in this mi≈øerable worlde, aboue all thinges geue your ≈øelfe continuallye to prayer,1. Timo. 2 lifting vp, as Saint Paul ≈øayth, cleane or pure handes withoute anger, wrath, or doubting, forgeuing (as he ≈øayeth al≈øo) if you haue any thing again≈øte anye man, as Chri≈øt forgeueth vs. And that we may be the better willing to forgeue, it is good often to call to remembrance the multitude and greatne≈ø≈øe of our own ≈øinnes, which Chri≈øt dayly and hourely pardoneth and forgeueth vs, & then we ≈øhal, as Saint Peter affirmeth,1. peter. 4. be ready to couer and hide the offences of our brethren, be they neuer ≈øo many. And becau≈øe gods word teacheth vs, not only the true maner of praying, but al≈øo what we ought to doe or not doe in the whole di≈øcour≈øe and practi≈øe of this life: What plea≈øeth or di≈øplea≈øeth God: and that, as Chri≈øt ≈øayth, the worde of god that he hath ≈øpoken ≈øhall iudge in the la≈øt daye: let your prayer be to this end ≈øpecially, that god of his greate mercy woulde open and reuele more & more daily to your hart the true ≈øen≈øe, knowledge, and vnder≈øteanding of his mo≈øte holy word, and geue you grace in youre liuing, to expre≈ø≈øe the fruites thereof. And for as muche as it is, as the holye gho≈øte calleth it, the woorde of affliction,1. Cor. 1. that is, it is ≈øeldome withoute hatred, per≈øecution, peryll, daunger of lo≈ø≈øe of life and goodes, and what≈øoeuer ≈øeemeth plea≈øante in this worlde, as experience teacheth you in this time: call vpon GOD continuallye for hys a≈ø≈øi≈øtance alwayes, as Chri≈øt teacheth, ca≈øting your accomptes what it is lyke to co≈øte you, endeuoring your ≈øelfe, throughe the helpe of the holye gho≈øte, by continuance of prayer, to laye youre foundation ≈øo
≈øure, that no ≈øtorme or tempe≈øte ≈øhall be able to ouerthrowe or ca≈øte it downe: remembryng alwayes (as Chri≈øte ≈øayeth) Lothes wyfe, Luke. 17. that is to beware of lookinge backe to that thinge that di≈øplea≈øeth GOD. div.p:
VEry frendes are they which are knit together wyth the knotte of Charity. Charity dothe not decay, but increa≈øe in them that dye faythfullye. Whereof it
followeth that though we be ab≈øent in body, yet are we pre≈øent in ≈øpirite, coupled together wyth the vnitie of fayth in the bond of peace, which is loue. How is be worthy ye name of a frend, that mea≈øureth hys friend≈øhip wyth the di≈øtance of place, or partyng of per≈øons? If thy frende be out of ≈øight, is thy frend≈øhip ended? If he be gone into the couÃÑtrey, wilt thou cea≈øe to loue hym? If he be pa≈ø≈øed the ≈øeas, wilt thou ≈øo for≈øake him? If he be caried into heauen, is charity hyndred therby? On the one ≈øyde, we haue the v≈øe of the fathers from the primatiue church, that gaue thaÃÑkes for their frends that died in the fayth, to proue that charity died not wyth death. On the other ≈øide (≈øaith Horace) Coelum non animum mutant qui trans mare currunt. What ≈øpeake I of Horace? Saith not S. Paule the ≈øame thyng? For we are meÃÑbers of hys body, of hys fle≈øhe, and of hys blood: yea we are members one of another. Is the hande, or arme, foote, or legge, a member when it is di≈ø≈øeuered from the body? How can we be members except we be ioyned together? What is ye line that coupleth vs but loue? When all thinges ≈øhall fayle, loue fayleth neuer. Hope hath his ende, when we get that we hoped for. Fayth is fyny≈øhed in heauen. Loue endureth for euer: loue I ≈øay that procedeth of charity. For carnall loue (when that which he loued is lo≈øt) doth pery≈øhe wyth the fle≈øh. Neither was that euer but fle≈øhly loue, which by di≈øtaunce of place, or ≈øeueryng of bodies, is parted a ≈øunder. If loue be the end, or ≈øuÃÑme of the lawe: yf heauen and earth ≈øhal peri≈øhe: if one iote of gods word ≈øhall not decay, why ≈øhould we thynke that loue la≈øteth not euer? I nede not to wryte much to you my frends, neyther can I haue ley≈øure now that the kepers are ri≈øen. But thys I ≈øay, if we kept Chri≈øtes commaundement in louyng eche other, as he loued vs, then ≈øhould our loue be euerla≈øtyng. Thys frend≈øhyp Paule felt when it moued hym to ≈øay, that neyther length nor bredth (meaning no di≈øtance of place) neither height nor depth ≈øhould ≈øeuer him from the loue of Chri≈øte. Wey well thys place, and mete it wyth Paules mea≈øures: ≈øo ≈øhall you finde, that if oure loue bee vnfayned, it can neuer be ended. Nowe maye you ≈øaye, why write≈øt thou this? For≈øoth, to the end that if our frend≈øhip be ≈øtable, you may accompli≈øh thys the la≈øt reque≈øte of
your frende, performe after my death the frend≈øhip we beganne in our life, that amitie may encrea≈øe, vntil god make it perfect at our next meting together. Mai≈øter Fletewode, I be≈øech, you remeÃÑber Wittrance & Cooke, two ≈øingular meÃÑ amoÃÑges coÃÑmon pri≈øoners. Mai≈øter FernhaÃÑ & M. Bel wt M. Hu≈ø≈øey (as I hope) wil di≈øpatche Palmer and Richard≈øon, with his companions. I praye you M. Calthrop thinke on Iohn Groue, an hone≈øt poore man, Traiford and Rice Aprice his accoÃÑplices. My Co≈øin Thomas Witton, a ≈øcriuener in Lomberd ≈øtrete, hath promi≈øed to further their deliuerye: at the lea≈øt he can in≈øtruct you which way to worke. There be al≈øo diuer≈øe other wel di≈øpo≈øed men, who≈øe deliuerance if ye will not labour for: yet I humbly be≈øech you to ≈øeke their reliefe as you ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe: namely of Henry Aprice, Lancelote, Hobbes, Lother, Homes, Carre, and Buckingham a yong man of goodly giftes in wit and learning, and (≈øauing that he is ≈øomwhat wilde) likely to do wel hereafter. For the≈øe and al other poore pri≈øoners here, I make this my humble ≈øuite and prayer to you all my Mai≈øters, and e≈øpeciall good frendes, be≈øeching you of all bondes of amitie, for the precious bloode of Ie≈øus Chri≈øte in the bowels of mercye, to render the cau≈øes of mi≈øerable captiues. div.head: ‚ùß Letters of that faythfull man of God John Careles, who by cruell impri≈øonmente and vnmercifull dealing of the papi≈øtes, dyed in the Mar≈øhal≈øee and was buryed in the fieldes on a dungehill: and therefore is not vnworthye here to be placed amonges the Martyrs.

div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the coÃÑtinual ioy, ≈øtrength & coÃÑfort of his mo≈øt pure, holy & mighty ≈øpirit, with the encrea≈øe of faith & liuely feeling of his eternal mercy, be with you my mo≈øt dere & faithfull louing brother Timmes, and with al the re≈øte of my deare harts in the Lord, your faithful fellow ≈øouldiours, and mo≈øt con≈øtant companions in bondes, yea of men condemned mo≈øt cruelly for the ≈øyncere te≈øtimony of gods euerla≈øtiÃÑg truth, to ye ful fini≈øhing of that good worke, which he hath ≈øo graciou≈øly begonne in you all, that the ≈øame maye be to hys glory, the coÃÑmoditie of his pore afflicted church, and to your euerla≈øting comfort in him, Amen.

Ble≈ø≈øed be god ye father of
al mercy, & pray≈øed be his name, for yt he hath ≈øo graciou≈ølye performed vpoÃÑ you his dere dareliÃÑgs, his mo≈øt ≈øwete & comefortable promi≈øes, in not only geuing you the coÃÑtinual aide, ≈øtreÃÑgth & coÃÑfort of his holy & mightie ≈øpirite, to the faythfull confe≈ø≈øioÃÑ of his chri≈øt, for who≈øe cau≈øe (O mo≈øt happie meÃÑ) ye are condeÃÑned to die: but al≈øo in geuing you ≈øuch a mouth & wi≈ødome, as al your wicked enemies were not able to re≈øi≈øt, but were faine to crie peace, peace, and not ≈øuffer you to ≈øpeake. As truly as god liueth (my dere brethreÃÑ) this is not only vnto you a mo≈øt euideÃÑt probatioÃÑ yt god is on your ≈øide, & a ≈øure certaintie of your euerla≈øting ≈øaluatioÃÑ in him, but al≈øo to your cruell aduer≈øaries (or rather Gods cur≈øed enemyes) a plaine demon≈øtration of their iu≈øt eternal woe and dampnation, whiche they ≈øhall be full ≈øure ≈øhortlye to feele, when ye ≈øhal full ≈øweetely po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the place of felicitie and plea≈øure prepared for you from the beginning.

Therfore (my dearly beloued) cea≈øe not ≈øo long as ye be in this life, to prai≈øe the lord wt a lu≈øtye courage, for that of hys great mercy & infinite goodnes, he hath vouched you worthy of this great dignitie, to ≈øuffer for his ≈øake, not only the lo≈ø≈øe of goods, wife & children, long impri≈øonment, cruel oppre≈ø≈øion &c: but al≈øo the very depriuation of this mortal life, with the di≈ø≈øolution of your bodies in the fyer. The whiche is the greate≈øt promotion that god can bring you or any other vnto in this vale of mi≈øery, yea ≈øo great an honour, as the highe≈øt Angel in heauen is not permitted to haue: and yet hath the lord (for his deare ≈øonne Chri≈øtes ≈øake) reputed you worthy of ye ≈øame, yea & that before me and many other, which haue both long loked & longed for the ≈øame. Ah my mo≈øt deare brother Timmes, who≈øe time re≈øteth altogether in the hands of thy Lord, in a ful happye time came≈øt yu into this trouble≈øome worlde, but in a much more ble≈ø≈øed houre ≈øhalt yu depart forth of ye ≈øame: ≈øo that the ≈øwete ≈øaying of SalomoÃÑ, or rather of the holy gho≈øt, ≈øhalbe ful wel verified vpoÃÑ thee, yea & al thy faithful felowes: Eccle. 7 better is the day of death (≈øaith he) then the day of birth. This ≈øaying can not be verified vpon euery man, but vpon thee my deare brother, and ≈øuch as thou art, who≈øe death is mo≈øt precious before God, and full deare ≈øhal your bloode be in his ≈øighte. Ble≈ø≈øed be god for thee my deare brother Timmes, and ble≈ø≈øed be god again yt euer I knew thee, for in a mo≈øt happy time I came
fyr≈øt into thy company. Pray for me deare brother, pray for me that God wyll once vouch me worthy of that great dignitie whereunto he hath nowe brought you. Ah my louing brother Drake, who≈øe ≈øoule draweth nowe nygh vnto god, of whom you haue receaued the ≈øame, full gladde maye you be that euer God gaue you a lyfe to leaue for hys ≈øake. Full well will he re≈øtore it to you agayne in a thou≈øand fold more glorious wy≈øe. Pray≈øe God good brother, as you haue great cau≈øe, and pray for me, I be≈øech you, which am ≈øo muche vnworthy (≈øo great are my ≈øynnes) of that great dignity wherunto the Lorde hath called you and the rea≈øt of your godlye brethreÃÑ: whom I be≈øech you to comforte in the Lord, as you can full well, pray≈øed be God for hys giftes, which you haue hartely applyed to the ≈øetting forth of his glory and the coÃÑ moditie of his pore afflicted church. Which thing ≈øhal ≈øurely redownde to your euerla≈øting ioy and comfort, as you ≈øhall mo≈øt effectually feele or euer it be long, though the wycked of the world iudge farre otherwi≈øe.

Ah myne own hartes, and mo≈øt dearly beloued brethren. Cauell, Ambro≈øe, and both the Spurges: ble≈ø≈øed be the Lord on your behalfe, and pray≈øed be his name, which hath geuen you ≈øuch a glorious victory. Ful valiaunt haue you ≈øhewed your ≈øelues in the lords fyght, and ful faithful in your painfull ≈øeruice. Faint not but go on forward as ye haue mo≈øt godly begonne, for great ≈øhal your reward be at ye end of this your trauell. Ah my good faithfull brethren al, what ≈øhal I ≈øay, or what ≈øhall I write vnto you, but euen the ≈øame that good Elizabeth did ≈øaye to her godly kinne≈øwoman Mary the ble≈ø≈øed Mother of Chri≈øte. Luke. 1. Happie art thou (quoth that good woman) whiche ha≈øte beleued: for all thinges whiche the Lord hath ≈øpoken to thee, ≈øhall be fulfilled. So I ≈øaye to you (my deare hartes in the Lorde) happye are ye all, yea twy≈øe happye ≈øhall ye bee for euermore, becau≈øe ye haue ≈øtedfa≈øtlye beleued the mo≈øte ≈øwete promi≈øes which god the father hath made vnto you with his own mouth, in that he hath promi≈øed you (which are the faythful ≈øeede of the beleuing Abraham) that ye ≈øhal be ble≈ø≈øed euer world wtout end. The promi≈øes of God your ≈øweete father as ye do beleue, ≈øo do ye beare record ye god is true. The te≈øtimony wherof ye
haue full worthely borne to the world, and ≈øhortly will full ≈øurely ≈øeale the ≈øame wt your blood, yea euen to morow I do vnder≈øtand. Oh con≈øtant Chri≈øtians: oh valiaunt ≈øouldiers of the high Captaine Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who for your ≈øake hath conquered the deuill, death, ≈øinne & hell, and hath geuen you full victory ouer theÃÑ for euer more. Oh worthy witne≈ø≈øes & mo≈øt glorious Martyrs, who≈øe inuincible fayth hath ouercome that proud, ≈øturdie, bragging prince of ye world, and al his wicked army, ouer whoÃÑ ye ≈øhall ≈øhortly triumphe for euermore. Ah my ≈øwete hartes, the euerla≈øting trea≈øures are full ≈øurely layd vp for you in heaueÃÑ. The immerce≈ø≈øible and mo≈øt glorious crowne of victory is already made and prepared for you, to be ≈øhortly clapt vpon al your happy heads. The holy Aungels of your heauenly father are already appointed to conduct your ≈øweete ≈øoules into Abrahams bo≈øome. All the heauenly ho≈øt reioyceth alreadye, for that they ≈øhall ≈øhortlye receaue you with ioye and felicitye into their ble≈ø≈øed fellow≈øhip. Selach.

Reioyce with double ioy, & be glad my deare brethren, for doubtles ye haue more cau≈øe then caÃÑ be expre≈ø≈øed. But (alas) I that for my ≈øinnes am left behinde, maye lie and lamente with the holye Prophet ≈øaying, p≈øalm. 119. woe is me that the daies of my ioyfull re≈øt are prolonged. Ah cur≈øed Sathan, which hath cau≈øed me ≈øo ≈øore to offende my mo≈øte deare louing father, wherby my exile and bani≈øhment is ≈øo much prolonged. Oh Chri≈øt my aduocate, pacifie thy fathers wrath which I haue iu≈øtelye de≈øerued, that he maye take me home to him in his ≈øweete mercy. And now farewell my deare hartes, mo≈øte happye in the Lord. I tru≈øt in my good God, yet ≈øhortlye to ≈øee you in the cele≈øtiall Citye, wherof vndoubtedly the Lord hath already made you free Citizens. Though ye be yet with vs for a litle time, your very home is in heauen, where your trea≈øure doth remaine with your ≈øwete lord & redemer Ie≈øus chri≈øt, who≈øe calling you haue heard with ye eares of your harts, & therfore ye ≈øhall neuer come into iudgement, but pa≈ø≈øe from

Your ≈øinnes ≈øhal neuer be remeÃÑbred, be they neuer ≈øo many, ≈øo greuous, or ≈øo great: for your Sauiour hath ca≈øt theÃÑ all into ye bottome of the ≈øea: he hath remoued them froÃÑ you as farre as the ea≈øt is froÃÑ the we≈øt, p≈øalm. 103. & his mercy hath much more preuailed ouer you, then is di≈øtance betwene heauen and earth: and he hath geuen you for an euerla≈øting po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame, al his holines, righteou≈ønes, & iu≈øtification, yea and the holy gho≈øt into your hartes, wherwith ye are ≈øurely ≈øealed vnto the day of redemption, to certifie you of your eternal electioÃÑ, and ye ye are his true adopted ≈øoÃÑnes, wherby ye may boldely crie vnto god, Abba deare father, for euer more: ≈øo that nowe no creature in heaueÃÑ, earth, nor hel ≈øhall be able to accu≈øe you before the throne of the heauenly King. Ah my dere harts, & mo≈øt faithful brethreÃÑ & ≈øi≈øters in ye lord, what high laudes & prai≈øe, yea what humble and continuall thankes am I bouÃÑd to geue to god oure father for you & on your mo≈øte happie behalfe, who ≈øo mightely hath magnified him≈øelf in you thus farforth, in geuiÃÑg you his holy & mighty ≈øpirit, to ye con≈øtant confe≈ø≈øing of chri≈øtes veritye, euen to the cruel condeÃÑpnation, & I dout not but he wil do ye ≈øame to the death. Be thaÃÑkful deare harts, be thankful & reioice in ye lord: for mighty is his mercy towards you, & great is your rewarde in heaueÃÑ, the which you like faithful per≈øons, haue plucked to you wt a godly violeÃÑce of an inuincible faith. Oh worthie warriours of ye mo≈øt high captain: oh coÃÑ≈øtant confe≈ø≈øours of ye euerla≈øting verity: howe glorious a crown of victory ≈øhal you ≈øhortly receaue, which is prepared for al ≈øuch as do coÃÑ nue to ye end? Oh you ≈øwete Saints of ye lord, how precious ≈øhal your death be in his ≈øight? Oh how dere are your ≈øoules to your
redemer, in whole hand they ≈øhal mo≈øt ioyfully re≈øt, and the paynes of death ≈øhall neuer touch you? Oh howe ble≈ø≈øed ≈øhall you be, when Chri≈øte ≈øhall appeare, at the which tyme you ≈øhal receaue your bodies againe ful of immortalitie: Oh how ioyful ≈øhal you be, when Chri≈øt, according to his promi≈øe, ≈øhall knowledge you before his father & his holy Angels, as you haue mo≈øt con≈øtantlye confe≈ø≈øed him to be your Lord and only Sauiour before men?

Oh ble≈ø≈øed Grene, thou meeke & louing lambe of the lord, how happy art thou to be appoynted to die for hys ≈øake? A full deintye di≈øhe arte thou for the lords own to the. Fre≈øh & grene ≈øhalt thou be in ye hou≈øe of the Lord, & thy fruites ≈øhal neuer wither nor decay. Althoughe yu go here forth ≈øowyng thy good fruites with teares, the tyme ≈øhall come yt thou ≈øhalt reape wt ioy and gladnes, the fruites of euerla≈øting life, and that without cea≈øing. Be mery therefore and feare not, for it is thy fathers will to geue thee a kingdome, Luke. 12. whereunto he hath cho≈øen thee before the foundations of the worlde were layde.

Oh happye Mini≈øter, thou man of God, how glad maye≈øt thou be of Gods gracious fauour, which hath preuented thee in ye day of thy triall? Oh happy Peter, who≈øe part thou ha≈øt wel played: therfore thy reward and portion ≈øhalbe like vnto his. Now ha≈øt thou good experience of mans infirmitie, but much more profe & ta≈øte, yea ≈øen≈øe and felyng of gods aboundaunt bottomles mercy. Although Sathan de≈øired to ≈øifte thee, Luk. 22 yet Chri≈øt thy good Captaine, prayed that thy fayth ≈øhould not faile. Gods ≈øtrength is made perfect by thy weakenes, and his grace is ≈øufficient for thee his dere child. Thine example did ≈øo encourage and ≈øtrength thy pore brethren, that God is euery way glorified by thee, and ≈øhortlye wil he glorifie thee with him ≈øelfe, with that glory which he hath prepared for thee his elect dearling, before the worlde was made. Therfore reioyce and be gladde, for thou ha≈øte good occa≈øion in finding ≈øuch fauour in his ≈øyght.

This is mo≈øt true (Oh my other brethren whoÃÑ I do not knowe, neyther haue I heard much of you) happye are you that euer you were borne, and ble≈ø≈øed be our god which hath geuen you ≈øuch victorye ouer the bloody bea≈øt. Apo. 1 ‚Ä¢ . Shortly ≈øhal you be clothed in large white garmentes, and fyne raynes
of righteou≈ønes, & ≈øo ≈øhall you follow the Lambe on mount Syon wyth new ≈øonges of myrth and melody, for your delyuery forth of Satans power and tyranny. God for euermore be ble≈ø≈øed for you, and ≈øtrengthen you to the end, as I doute not but he wyll: for he neuer fayled them that put their tru≈øt in hym.

Oh my deare and faithfull Si≈øter Ioane Warner, what ≈øhall I ≈øay to thee? Thy triall hath bene great: thy victorye in Chri≈øt hath bene notable. Thou ha≈øt ouercome manye a ≈øharpe ≈øhower & ≈øtorme. Shortly ≈øhalt yu ariue at ye hauen of quiet re≈øt, & receiue a reward due to a coÃÑ≈øtant Martyr. Thou ≈øhalt goe home to thy heauenly father, & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe for euer the inheritance which Chri≈øt hath purcha≈øed for thee, where thy earthly parentes be, ≈øtill lokyng for thee, whiche haue triumphed ouer Antichri≈øt mo≈øt victoriou≈øly. Oh ble≈ø≈øed Parentes of happy children, which haue ≈øhewed ≈øuch an example, as the like hath bene ≈øeldome ≈øene. I ≈øalute thee deare Sy≈øter of lyke con≈øtant mynde: who≈øe con≈øtant example is worthy of continuall memory. Pray≈øed be God for you my owne ≈øwete Sy≈øters, which hath made you to playe ≈øuche wy≈øe Virgines partes. Math. 25 He hath pleÃÑtifully powred the oyle of hys ≈øpirite into the lampes of your fayth, ≈øo that the light thereof ≈øhall neuer be extincte. You ≈øhall enter wyth your bridegrome into euerla≈øtyng ioy, wherunto you were cho≈øeÃÑ in hym from the beginning.

Oh my deare bretherne and Sy≈øters, you ble≈ø≈øed ≈øaints of the Lord, how much & how depely am I bound to prai≈øe god for you both day and nyght? Pray, pray for me (my dere hartes) for the tender mercye of God, that I maye be made worthy to folow your trace. Oh that I had runne the race of my lyfe, as farre as you haue done yours, and were as nigh my iorneyes ende as you be vnto yours. But alas, I lie lyke the lame man at the pooles ≈øide by SalamoÃÑs porch, Iohn. 5. and euery man goeth into the place of health before me. But God wyl appoint me one, one day to put me in. I tru≈øt my Lord of Londons colehou≈øe is empty, and all his officers idle. Therfore they mu≈øte ≈øhortlye fetche more ≈øhepe to the Shambles: for he is the common ≈ølaughter ≈ølaue of al England. But happy are you that are pa≈ø≈øed through the pikes, and deliuered out of his handes, and from all the aungels
of the darkenes of this world, whiche long tempted you in the wyldernes of the ≈øame: but now ≈øhal the aungels of god come and mini≈øter vnto you, for they are your ≈øeruantes to hold you vp in their handes, that you ≈øhall not hurte your fote, p≈øal. 60. 4. Reg. 2. no nor one heare of your head ≈øhal peri≈øh. They ≈øhal cary you vp to heaueÃÑ in a fiery chariot, though you leaue your mantell behind you for a tyme, tyll God re≈øtore the fame to you agayne in a more ample and glorious ≈øorte.

Thus in ha≈øt, as it doth appeare, I am con≈øtrayned to make an ende, committyng you all to gods mo≈øte mercifull defence: who euer haue you in hys ble≈ø≈øed kepyng, de≈øiring you all to remember me in your godlye and faythfull prayers, as I wyll not forget you in myne by gods grace. The ble≈ø≈øyng of God bee wyth you all my deare bretherne and Si≈øters. All our brethern and fellow pri≈øoners here, haue them mo≈øt hartely commended vnto you, and pray for you wythout cea≈øyng. God ≈øende vs a mery metyng in his kingdome, Amen.

closer.signed: By your brother and vnfayned louer Iohn Careles pry≈øoner, abidyng his mo≈øt mercifull wyll and plea≈øure. Praye, praye, praye.

div.head: To my deare and faythfull brother VV. Tymmes pry≈øoner in Newgate.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, with ye coÃÑtinual ioy, comfort, & ≈øtrength of his ≈øwete ≈øpirit, be multiplied, & daly more & more encrea≈øed in your good hart (my mo≈øt faythful & dere brother Tymmes) to the ful quietyng of your con≈øcience, and beating backe of al the fiety dartes of the wycked, that you maye ≈øhortly receaue the glorious crowne of victory, and in the ≈øame tryumphe ouer all your enemies foreuermore, Amen.

I cannot expre≈ø≈øe the excedyng great ioy & con≈øolation of my poore hart, con≈øidering the meruelous workes of God mo≈øt gratiou≈øly wrought vpoÃÑ you, not only in prouing you & tryeng your faith by his great & huge cro≈ø≈øes both inwardly and outwardly, but al≈øo in geuyng you ≈øo great con≈øolation & con≈øtancy in the middes of the ≈øame. Faithful is god & true of his promi≈øes, who hath ≈øaid that he wil neuer ≈øuffer
his cho≈øen children to be teÃÑpted aboue their ≈øtrength, but in the middes of their temptatioÃÑ wil make an out≈øcape for theÃÑ, by ≈øuch meanes as may make to his glory and their euerla≈øtyng con≈øolation. My deare hart, great cau≈øe haue you to be of good comfort, for I ≈øee in you as lyuely a token of Gods euerla≈øting loue & ≈øauour in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, as euer I perceiued in any man. In re≈øpect wherof I do eueÃÑ with my hart, loue, honour and reuerence you, be≈øechyng god for his glorious names ≈øake, in ye bowels & blood of our lord and only Sauiour Ie≈øus chri≈øt, to fini≈øh his good worke in you, as I doubt not but he wil do, according to his vnfallible promy≈øes: yea I am wel a≈ø≈øured therof, fora≈ømuch as you haue ≈øo effectuallye receiued his holye ≈øpirite into your harte, as a pledge & ≈øure ≈øeale of your eternal redeÃÑption, & a te≈øtimonye of your adoptioÃÑ in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu. For which cau≈øe Sathan ≈øo ≈øore enuieth you, that he hath now bente all his fierce ordynaunce again≈øt you, thinking therby vtterly to de≈øtroy the inuincible forte of your faith founded mo≈øt firmely vpon the vnmoueable rocke chri≈øt, again≈øt the which, the deuil, ≈øinne, nor yet hell gates ≈øhal neuer preuaile, Selah.

Therfore mine owne bowels in the lord, be not di≈øcomforted for this your conflicte, which doutles ≈øhal greatly encrea≈øe your crowne of glorye, triumphe, and victorye: but take a good hart vnto you, and buckle boldly with Sathan both in him≈øelf and in his ≈øuttle meÃÑbers. It is the very diuine ordinaunce of god, that all his regenerate children ≈øhalbe tempted, proued and tried: as we ≈øee by the exaÃÑple of our Sauiour Chri≈øte, who as ≈øone as he was bapti≈øed, was ≈øtraight waies led of the holy gho≈øt into the wildernes, ther to be teÃÑpted of the deuill. But there got he ≈øuch a glorious victory of Satan, that he could neuer ≈øince finally preuaile again≈øt any of his poore meÃÑbers, but in euery a≈ø≈øault that he maketh either inwardly or outwardly, he getteth a foile and taketd ≈øhame: ≈øo yt now he rageth with al the ≈øpite po≈ø≈øible, ≈øpecially becau≈øe he knoweth his tyme is but ≈øhort. Iames. 4. Saincte Iames te≈øtifieth that he is but a very coward, that wil ≈øone flye if he be faithfully re≈øi≈øted. And as for his temptinge tooles, the Lord hath made them manife≈øt vnto vs, ≈øo that he cannot deceiue vs, though he a≈ø≈øaulte vs: for as Sainte Paule ≈øaythe,2. Cor. 3 hys verye thoughtes are not vnknowen to vs, as it dothe in you largely appeare, pray≈øed bee the
Lordes name therfore.

You ≈øee deare brother, that now to mole≈øt you & ≈øuche as you are, yt be euen pa≈ø≈øyng froÃÑ this vale of mi≈øery, he hath but two waies, or two pieces of ordinance to ≈øhoote at you, wyth the whiche he cannot hurte you becau≈øe you haue two bulwarkes to defend you. The fir≈øt of the≈øe terrible gunnes that Sathan hath ≈øhotte at you, is the very ≈øame that he continually ≈øhooteth at me, that is to ≈øay feare and infidelity for the vgle≈øomnes of death, & horrour of my ≈øinnes, which be ≈øo many, greuous, and greate. But this pellet is ea≈øily put away with the ≈øure ≈øhield of faith in the mo≈øt precious death and blood≈øheding of our deare Lord and only Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, whome the father hath geuen vnto vs wholy to be oures for euermore, & wyth him hath geuen vs al things, as Paule ≈øaith: ≈øo that though we be neuer ≈øo great ≈øinners, yet Chri≈øt is made vnto vs holines, righteou≈ønes and iu≈øtification. He hathe clothed vs wyth all hys merites, mercies and mo≈øt ≈øwete ≈øufferyngs, and hath taken vnto hym al our mi≈øery, wretchednes, ≈øynne and infirmitie. So that if anye ≈øhould nowe be condemned for ye ≈øame, it mu≈øt nedes be Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which hath taken them vpoÃÑ him. But in dede he hath made ≈øati≈øfactioÃÑ for theÃÑ to the vttermo≈øt iote: ≈øo that for his ≈øake thei ≈øhal neuer be imputed to vs, if they wer a thou≈øaÃÑd times ≈øo many moe as they be. This do you mo≈øt effectuou≈øly feele and know, dere brother, a great deale better then I can tel you, ble≈ø≈øed be God therefore.

And now Sathan, ≈øeyng that he cannot preuaile wyth hys boi≈øtrous battery again≈øt this bulwarke of fayth, which doth ≈øo quenche al his fiery dartes that they can do you no harme, but rather do you good ≈øeruice to ca≈øt you down vnder the mighty hand of God, that he may take you vp by his only grace & power, & ≈øo you may render hym al the glory by Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, (which thyng the enemy cannot abyde in no wi≈øe) therfore he ≈øhooteth of his other piece mo≈øt pe≈øtilent, to prouoke you to put ≈øome parte of your tru≈øte and confidence in your ≈øelfe, & in your own holines & righteou≈ønes, yt you might that way robbe god of hys glory, Chri≈øt of his honour and dignity of his death. But ble≈ø≈øed be ye Lord God, you haue al≈øo a full ≈øtrong bulwarke to beate backe
this pe≈øtiferous pellet al≈øo, euen the pure law of god, which proueth the be≈øt of vs al daÃÑnable ≈øiÃÑners in the ≈øight of god, if he would enter into iudgement with vs, accordyng to ye ≈øeuerity of the ≈øame, & that euen our be≈øt workes are polluted & defyled in ≈øuch ≈øort, as the Prophet de≈øcribeth them. Wyth which maner of ≈øpeakyng, E≈øay. 64. our freewyl Phari≈øeis are muche offended: for it felleth all mans righteou≈ønes to the grouÃÑde (I had lyke to haue ≈øayd to the botome of hel) and extolleth only the righteou≈ønes of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which is allowed before god, & is frely geuen to all tho≈øe that firmely beleue, as ble≈ø≈øed be god you do.

Ah my good brother Tymmes, Satan hath put his hand in a wrong boxe when he beginneth to tempt you, either to vayne glory or my≈øtru≈øt: for you are an olde beaten ≈øouldiour, and haue had good experience of the≈øe maner of temptations both by your ≈øelfe & other, whom you know wel were the beloued of god. Be of good chere therfore, deare harte, be of good chere, for now Satan hath wrought al hys malice: he hath done al yt he can, and hath ≈øhotte of al hys la≈øt pieces wherwt he had thought to haue done mo≈øt mi≈øchief: but now he ≈øeeth he can not preuaile (ye ≈øtrong tower of your fayth beyng ≈øo inuincible) he wyll plucke vp al hys tentes, and gette him to ≈øome other place to practi≈øe the like a≈ø≈øaultes: and then wil the aungels of god come and mini≈øter vnto you ye mo≈øt ≈øwete and heaueÃÑly con≈øolations of the holy gho≈øt. To him therfore who is able to do exceding abouÃÑdaÃÑtly aboue al yt euer we can de≈øire or thinke, I do mo≈øt hartely coÃÑmit you, with al the re≈øt of your godly pri≈øon fellowes, who comfort ≈øtrengthen, and defend you wyth hys grace and mighty operatioÃÑ of his holy ≈øpirit, as he hath he therto done, yt you hauing a mo≈øt glorious victory ouer the ≈øuttle SerpeÃÑt and all his wicked ≈øede, may al≈øo receiue ye crown of glory & immortalitie prepared for you before ye fouÃÑdations of ye world wer laid, & is ≈øo ≈øurely kept for you in ye hands of him who≈øe promi≈øe is vnfaflible, that the Deuill, ≈øinne, death, or hell ≈øhall neuer be able to depriue you of the ≈øame. The ble≈ø≈øyng of God be with you now and for euermore, Amen. Pray, pray, pray, for me.

div.head: ¬∂To my derely beloued in the lord My≈øtres A. K.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the helpe, comfort, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtaunce of his mo≈øt pure and holy ≈øpirite, be wyth you my mo≈øte deare Sy≈øter, to the performaunce of that he hath ≈øo graciou≈øly begon in you, that it maye be to hys glory, the profit of hys churche, and your eternall comfort in hym, Amen.

As I am ryght ≈øory at my poore hart (O wor≈øhipfull Matrone) that any afflictioÃÑs or pa≈ø≈øioÃÑs of heauines ≈øhould trouble your godly and louing hart (vnto the which I wi≈øh vnfainedly all godly ioye & quietnes) eueÃÑ ≈øo am I glad and geue god mo≈øt harty thankes, that he of hys great goodnes hath v≈øed me poore wretched mi≈øer by any meanes, to be an occa≈øion of the increa≈øe of your godlye mirthe and gladnes. But O my good and faithfull Sy≈øter, I ≈øee wherabout you go. You play wyth me as a good louyng mother doth with her vnwilling child. When it dothe any thyng at her de≈øyre, ≈øhe pray≈øeth it and maketh her ≈øelfe glad therof, that it maye take courage to do better, and be more willing again≈øt an other tyme. Euen ≈øo do you (right reuerend Matrone) make your ≈øelfe glad of my ≈øymple doinges, to comforte & encourage me, to coÃÑtinue in that which is good, and to grow and go forwarde willingly in the ≈øame. God for Chri≈øtes ≈øake, geue me hys grace that in all thinges I maye ≈øati≈øfye your godly expectation, that I may do ≈øome honour to hys heauenly doctrine.

And as you haue greatly comforted me with your mo≈øt godly and louyng letter: euen ≈øo I be≈øeche you to a≈ø≈øi≈øte me wt your faythful and harty praier, as I dout not but you do, for I feele the pre≈øent helpe therof, prai≈øed be God therfore. God make me thankeful for you my (deare Sy≈øter) and al≈øo mindfull of my duetye towardes you & all other the lordes elect children. Ah my deare and faithfull hart in the Lorde, how much and how depely am I bound to pray≈øe god for you, and to geue hym thankes day and night on your good behalfe? Oh happy are you that euer you were borne, ye God wil ≈øo mightely be magnified in you. O ble≈ø≈øed woman that ≈øo ≈øurely beleue≈øt and ha≈øt ≈øo plentifully ta≈øted of gods holy
≈øpirit, that out of thy woÃÑbe doe flow the ryuers of the water of lyfe: to whoÃÑ god hath made manife≈øt yt myght of his meruelous mercy, and hath geuen con≈øolatioÃÑ in the ≈øame, ≈øo that you are able of your own good experieÃÑce, to comfort others in all their afflictions: which thyng I can wytnes (I prai≈øe god therfore) in that I do depely ta≈øt & fele of the ≈øame. God for chri≈øtes ≈øake recompence the ≈øame & all other your good doinges, ≈øeuen folde into your bo≈øome, as I doute not but he wil do, according to hys promi≈øe. God make me ≈øuche a one as you report me to be, that my frutes might take ≈øuche effect as you ≈øpeake of. But (alas) I am a great, horrible, & mo≈øt greuous ≈øinner: therefore I feare me, god be angry wt me for pre≈øuming to take his word in my mouth. God hide my ≈øinnes from the ≈øight of the world, that I be not a ≈ølauÃÑ der to his truth. But it is you (O dere daughter of AbrahaÃÑ) whiche doe ≈øo loue & liue the go≈øpel, that I & other are more confirmed in the truth therof by your good example. God hath at thys day in hys poore afflicted church, a ≈øort of worthy women, which do him and his ≈øuch ≈øeruice as is acceptable in hys ≈øight. I ≈øpeake of experience (I pray≈øe god therfore) and not to the ende to flatter you or any other, the lord is my witnes.

God for my ≈øinnes hath taken from me the companye of godly learned men, to my great grief and heauy di≈øcomfort: but of his great goodnes & mercy he doth ≈øupply my ≈øpiritual lacke by ye good mini≈øtery of godly & vertuous womeÃÑ. Of which faithful labourers in ye go≈øpel, who≈øe names are writeÃÑ in ye boke of life (my derely beloued Si≈øter) you are not the lea≈øt. The lord be thaÃÑked for you, & ble≈ø≈øed be ye time yt euer I knew you: for your loue & faithful amity is to me a ≈øure ≈øigne & ≈øeale of gods loue & mercy. Oh dere lord what am I vpon whoÃÑ yu ≈øhoulde≈øt vouch≈øafe to ≈øhew ≈øuch great tokens of thine ine≈øtimable loue & kindnes? Oh faithful father, forgeue me my great ingratitude & ≈øinnes. Oh let me be no loÃÑ ger negligent in doing my duty towardes thy dere childreÃÑ, whiche thou ha≈øte lincked in loue wyth me, knitting oure hartes together in a perfecte bonde of Chri≈øtian charitye, wherby all men may ≈øee that we are thy Di≈øciples. O my good Sy≈øter, I would you knewe what ioy & coÃÑfort I doe fele in my good chri≈øt, at this pre≈øeÃÑt houre. God make you
partaker of the ≈øame: for this which I haue, partly commeth by you whom god hath v≈øed as his good in≈øtrumeÃÑt therto.

And where as you do mo≈øt godly coun≈øell me with S. Peter,1. Pet. 5 to ca≈øt all my care vpon the Lorde, and to be careles, not only in name but al≈øo in effecte, ≈øpecially in re≈øpecte of hym for who≈øe ≈øake I do ≈øuffer, and the ≈øyncere truth which I do profe≈ø≈øe: I thanke you hartely for your mo≈øt godly and comfortable exhortation, and I entend by gods grace to folow the ≈øame as farreforth as he ≈øhall a≈ø≈øi≈øt me with his holy and mighty ≈øpirit, wythout the which I can neither take things patiently, neither reioyce vnder ye cro≈ø≈øe as I ought for to do. And now, as concerning the mo≈øt comfortable doctrine of our eternall election in him, before the foundation of the world was laid: I do prote≈øt before God & man, that if euery heare of my head were a mans lyfe, I would willingly geue them all in the defence therof. Full litle wotteth our free wil men what they do, wheÃÑ they go about ≈øo ra≈øhely to condeÃÑne that doctrine. In dede deare frend, in the re≈øpect of theÃÑ and the peril which they be in, you and I both haue good cau≈øe to mourne, lament, and be ≈øory, & to pray for them day & night, that the Lord if it be his wil, would conuert them. And whether their blindnes be of ≈øimplicitye (as I hope it is) or of wilful ob≈øtinacie (which thing is greatly to be feared) yet haue I no cau≈øe to be angry with them, for it is their own harme: where as mine ≈øhould haue bene the like, if god had left me to my ≈øelf, as he myght mo≈øt iu≈øtly haue done: and for that I am as I am, his name only haue the pray≈øe, and for hys ≈øake I will alwayes ≈øeeke to do them good as much as lyeth in me. And what ≈øoeuer they haue ≈øayd, or ≈øhall ≈øaye or do again≈øte me, I doe and will as

For ≈øure I am that what ≈øoeuer he be, that hath any true ta≈øt or liuely felyng of the great mercye, loue, and kyndne≈ø≈øe of God towardes hym in Chri≈øte, he can not beare hate or di≈øplea≈øure agayn≈øte anye thynge but ≈øynne & SathaÃÑ ye only author therof. div.head: To my deare Si≈øter. M. C.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the coÃÑ tinuall ayde, ≈øtrength, & comfort of hys mo≈øt pure, holy, and mightye ≈øpirite, with the increa≈øe of faith and liuely feling of hys eternall mercyes, be mo≈øte effectuou≈ølye wrought in your hart (my deare and faithfull Sy≈øter) to the full accompli≈øhing of that good worke which the Lorde hath ≈øo graciou≈øly begonne in you, yt it may be to the ≈øetting forth of his glory, the comfort of hys poore afflicted church, and to your owne eternall con≈øolation in hym, Amen.

I thanke God mo≈øt hartely for you (my deare hart in the Lord) with all remeÃÑbrance of you in my prayers, as of duty I am bound, not douting but you do the ≈øame for me to my great ioy & comfort in the midde≈øt of my cro≈ø≈øes, which daily do increa≈øe, yea and that in ≈øuch ≈øort that if the faythful god by your hartye prayer and others gods deare children, dyd not put to hys helpyng hand, I ≈øhould ≈øurely ≈øyncke downe vnder theÃÑ. Ah good ≈øi≈øter, begge hard of our deare father for me, that he would ≈øhortly tread Sathan vnder my feete, and yt I may play ye man in ye Lordes battel, as you bydde me, & be ioyfull in my Chri≈øt, what payne or peril ≈øoeuer I ≈øuffer. And reioyce wyth me (good ≈øi≈øter) in the Lord, and let vs be mery in him, not only to chere ye good harts of al our faythfull frends, but al≈øo to anger ye cankered hart of SathaÃÑ that
croked Serpent our ancient enemy. For I know yt there is nothyng yt can greue his malicious mind more, theÃÑ ye myrth, gladnes, and hartye reioy≈øyng of the childreÃÑ of God in their good Chri≈øt.

Ah my faythfull frend, if your good hart be heuye, who caÃÑ make mine light? If you be ≈øory, who caÃÑ make me glad? But if you be mery and reioyce in ye Lord, there ≈øhal no trouble, make me ≈øad or ≈øorowful. Be of good cheare therfore my good ≈øi≈øter, & comfort my ≈øwete brother. V. Oh yt I mighte once heare that he and his bridegrome were in bedde both together, and that he had taken a ≈øwete ≈ølepe in hys louers armes, as Iohn dyd vpon hys lappe on ye Maundie night. Iohn. 13 Commend me vnto him mo≈øt hartelye, and de≈øyre hym for the Lords ≈øake, to fulfyl my ioye & increa≈øe my crowne. Bid hym be mindefull of me in hys harty prayers, as I neyther wyll nor can forget hym in myne. Full deare is he vnto my ≈øoule. So are you my good ≈øi≈øter (the Lord he knoweth) eueÃÑ ≈øo are you: you haue ≈øo ≈øurely knitte me to you wt that bond of vnfayned loue, whereby you are lyncked to the chyldren of God. Oh ble≈ø≈øed bonde of perfection, and true badge of Chri≈øtes Dy≈øciples. Oh true and vnfayned loue, wroughte by hys ≈øpyrite in the hartes of all hys elect. This is to vs a true ≈øygne and ≈øure ≈øeale that we are the verye children of GOD. Thys loue is that flower that neuer ≈øhall fade, but flory≈øhe daylye more and more, and bee made perfect in that place where fayth and hope ≈øhall haue no offyce,1. Cor. 13. but po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe for euer that which they haue here long loked for wyth patience. My deare hart, be of good cheare: for though our bodyes be here ≈øeperated a ≈øuÃÑder for a litle time, yet ≈øhal ye lord bring vs together againe ere it be long, into a place of great ioy, where we ≈øhal dwel for euer. Yea god caÃÑ & wyll, if he ≈øee it good for vs, bring vs together agayn in this lyfe, that we maye haue a mery meting & further occa≈øion to pray≈øe hys holy name. He can worke wonders when hym ≈øelf li≈øteth. P≈øa. 91. Oh what it is to dwell vnder the defence of the mo≈øt highe≈øt, and to ≈øit vnder ye ≈øhadow of the almighty? The buggy≈øh By≈øhops can not make ≈øuch a one a feard, becau≈øe they can not take awaye one heare from our head vntil god geue them leaue: which I am ≈øure he wil not doe vntyl ≈øuch time as he ≈øhall ≈øee it mo≈øte to hys glorye, and the profytte
of hys ≈øainctes: and when that time is once come, who wyll de≈øire to tarie here any longer?

Thus deare ≈øi≈øter, I haue ≈øcribled a fewe lines to you in ha≈øte: I will not ≈øay that it ≈øhalbe my la≈øt farewell, although it be very like in this life. CoÃÑmend me to my good brethren M. Heath, Robert Cole, Iohn Lydley &c. I would be glad to ≈øee them, & take my leaue of them, if they may do it without daunger, as I thinke they may: but in no wi≈øe let them not daunger theÃÑ≈øelues for that matter: ≈øure I am we ≈øhall all haue a mo≈øt ioyfull meting ≈øhortly. God ≈øtrengthen you al in his truth, and make you in≈øtrumentes of hys glory, to defend the go≈øpell of his grace again≈øt al ≈øortes of enemyes therof. Amonge≈øt whoÃÑ, me thinkes I do fore≈øee deare ≈øi≈øter, the great plague that the≈øe frewill men ≈øhall poure vpon the poore afflicted Church of God: for withoute all doubt the Dragon wil make the riuer of reproch, Apo. 12 which you now ≈øu≈øtaine for the verities ≈øake, a great floud or euer it be longe: but in the end they ≈øhall drinke it vp all them ≈øelues, as they now do that, which they ≈øpued forth again≈øt our ble≈ø≈øed brethren, Bradford and Philpot. And yet the veritie doth flory≈øhe, and ≈øhall ≈øpyte of the Pye, which greueth Sathan at the hart, & therfore he be≈øtirreth him like a wode LioÃÑ, knowing that his time is ≈øhort. The lord deliuer vs froÃÑ the≈øe poy≈øoned tonges. Verely I can not tell whether I maye more lament my long tarying amonges the≈øe I≈ømalites, ≈øo geuen to malice, or the leauing of you and other my deare louers in the Lord, amonges them. The Lord be mercifull vnto his elect, and ≈øhorten the≈øe ≈øorowful daies for their ≈øakes, as he hath ≈øayd he will. Farewel mine owne deare hart, farewell in the Lord Ie≈øus chri≈øt, who poure his holy ≈øprite plenteou≈øly vpon you, that by the mighty operation of ye ≈øame, you may daily more & more effectuou≈øly feele the ≈øure certaintye of your eternall ≈øaluatioÃÑ in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, that you may euer be able to comfort other with the ≈øame coÃÑfortes, wherwyth you are comforted in him. To who≈øe mo≈øt mercifull defence I do hartely coÃÑmit you now & euer more. Amen. The ble≈ø≈øing of God be with you all now and euer, Amen.

div.head: To my good Si≈øter. M. C.
div.p: THe peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, the eternall comfortes of his ≈øweete ≈øpirite, be with you my deare and fatithfull ≈øi≈øter: to the full accomply≈øhment of that good worke whiche he hath mo≈øt graciou≈øly begoÃÑne in you, that the ≈øame may be effectuall to ye ≈øettyng forth of hys glorye, and to your euerla≈øtynge con≈øolation in hym Amen.

My louing and faythfull ≈øy≈øter in the Lorde, I thanke you for all your louing kindnes ≈øhewed vnto me, but ≈øpecially for your godly remembrance of me in your feruent and faythfull prayers, and for your mo≈øt godly and comfortable letter, wherby you do not only much encrea≈øe my ioye and comfort, but al≈øo put me in remeÃÑbrance of my duty towards you. Ble≈ø≈øed be the Lord our God, which of hys great mercy hath ≈øo beautifyed hys church in the≈øe our dayes, that euen vnto many godly women, he hath geueÃÑ mo≈øt excellent giftes of knowledge and vnder≈øtanding of hys truth, ≈øo that they are not only wel able to enforme their own con≈øciences in al things nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øaluation, but al≈øo mo≈øt ≈øwetely to coÃÑfort their ≈øorowful brethreÃÑ & ≈øi≈øters that ≈øu≈øtaine any trouble for the te≈øtimony of gods truth, yea & that which is more, euen in the middes of their greate confllictes of con≈øcience. Of which mo≈øt happye nuÃÑber of godly & vertuous women, my deare hart, you are one & that of the chiefe≈øt, being plentifully endewed wt the giftes of gods mo≈øt gracious ≈øpirit, as it doth ful well appeare in your dayly doinges, God only haue the pray≈øe therfore. For as much then as God hath geuen you the gifte to write, I ≈øhall mo≈øt hartely de≈øyre you to let me heare froÃÑ you ≈øomtymes, be it neuer ≈øo litle, for truly I take great comfort & courage therby, ≈øpecially in my poore con≈øcience, which is ≈øore a≈ø≈øaulted of ≈øubtyll Sathan, & in a maner oppre≈ø≈øed of my ≈øynnes. Pray deare ≈øy≈øter, that god may geue me true, harty, and earne≈øt repentance, and increa≈øe my fayth, for they are both the good giftes of God only, & farre pa≈ø≈øe the reache of my power to take at my plear≈øure. Therfore deare ≈øy≈øter, if you wil helpe me to begge ye ≈øame of oure

div.head: To my mo≈øte deare and faythfull brother in the lord. T. V.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, with continuall ioy comfort and quietnes of con≈øcience, through the mightye operation of the holy gho≈øt, be with you my mo≈øt dearelye beloued brother. V. to the encrea≈øe of your crowne and victorye, nowe and euer, Amen.

I haue bene often times earne≈øtlye minded to write vnto you (my deare hart in the Lord) ≈øyth I receaued your mo≈øte godly and louing letter: but the likelyhode & hope which I haue often ≈øince conceaued to ≈øee you & talke wt you mouthe to mouth, hath cau≈øed me to forbeare, that loue hath ≈øo often prouoked me vnto. The which I de≈øire you to take in good worth: for as I haue done ye ≈øame altogether in ha≈øt, ≈øo is it ye contentes of an hart ≈øomthing troubled, and not altogether in ≈øo ≈øwete a ≈øecuritie as it hath bene in tymes pa≈øt, and I dout not but it ≈øhalbe ≈øo full wel agayne.

But ble≈ø≈øed be my God, and mo≈øt deare louing father, which of his great mercy & infinite goodnes in Chri≈øt, wyl vouch me worthy wyth you & other of hys deare dearlings, to cary as well the inward cro≈ø≈øe, which is mo≈øt greuous and heauye, as the outward cro≈ø≈øe, which is ≈øo lyght & ea≈øy.2. Cor. 4 I know there is an exceding waight of glory prepared for me, although Sathan now, by gods permi≈ø≈øion ≈øeketh all meanes po≈ø≈øible to per≈øuade me to ye contrary, by ca≈øtyng of hys cloudes & mi≈øtes ouer me yt he myght darkeÃÑ the loue of my deare lord & Chri≈øt, which dyed for me, yea & that wheÃÑ I was hys vtter enemye, & by nature ye very chyld of wrath and perdition: but I know that the loue of my Chri≈øte being ≈øo great, wyll bur≈øt out agayne mo≈øte gloryou≈ølye. Oh God, me thynkes euen now I feele it beginne to kyndle in my bre≈øt meruelou≈øly. Praye for me deare hart, pray for me, that my ≈øoule maye ≈øweetely turne to her olde re≈øte agayne: for verelye Sathan hath made a ≈øore ruffelyng wyth her of late, that he myghte haue bereft her of her vyrginitye, wyth the fornication of mi≈øtru≈øte and infidelitye. But I ≈øee wel, my God is faythfull (as Sainct Paule ≈øayth) and wyll not ≈øuffer her to be tempted aboue the ≈øtrength he wyl geue der. Praye for me deare harte I ≈øaye agayne, and pray≈øe GOD mo≈øte hartely for hys greate mercy extended towardes me, as by your letter I vnder≈øtand you doe: I thanke you mo≈øt hartelye therefore, and I promy≈øe you (by Gods grace) I wil neuer forget you ≈øo long as the breth is in my body, neither can I though I would.

And now myne owne bowels in the Lord, I long much to heare of your ≈øtate, which I tru≈øt be mo≈øt happy & ble≈ø≈øed. Gladly would I heare that the cele≈øtiall brydegrome were at home wyth you, and that in re≈øpecte of hys mo≈øte ble≈ø≈øed and cherefull pre≈øence, you had ca≈øte awaye all your mournyng garmentes. Oh that I myght once beare you hartely ≈øynge wyth the ≈øpou≈øe thys ≈øweete ver≈øe: Can. 2. My delyght is to ≈øitte vnder the ≈øhadowe of my loue, for hys fruite is

Oh my deare hart, I am nowe con≈øtrayned to end for thys tyme, but god will ≈øend me an other I doubte not, to who≈øe mo≈øt mercifull defence I do hartely committe you.

div.head: To my deare brother. T. V.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus chri≈øt, the continuall comfortes of hys mo≈øt pure & holy ≈øpirit, be with you my mo≈øt deare frend and faythfull brother V. to the encrea≈øe of your fayth, & comfort of your ≈øorowfull ≈øpirite, which is to the father a ≈øweete ≈øacrifyce through Chri≈øte: for who≈øe ≈øake he wyll neuer de≈øpy≈øe your humble and contrite hart, but doth fauourablye accepte the ≈øame, and wil in mo≈øt ample wi≈øe performe the de≈øyre therof to hys glory and your eternall comfort in hym.

The Lorde God for hys great mercyes ≈øake, accompli≈øh my de≈øire, as I doubt not but he wil, wheÃÑ he ≈øeeth it good & mo≈øt to hys glory, & to your comfort and commoditye. Oh that I myght once ≈øee you ≈øo mery in chri≈øt as you haue iu≈øt cau≈øe to be, yt you might ≈øay with Dauyd: p≈øalm. 57. Awake my glory, awake Lure and Harpe, bryng forth the P≈øalter with the mery ≈øong, that I myght ≈øynge a new ≈øonge of pray≈øe and thanke≈øgeuynge vnto the Lorde for the lyghte of hys fauourable countenaunce, hys helpe and deliueraunce. ≈øorrow moe waies then one. div.p: WHen I had with my ≈øelfe well waied and con≈øidered (right wor≈øhipfull citizens) the greate charge and burden that you haue borne and ben at, not only wyth me (which am mo≈øt vnworthye of your liberall benefites) but al≈øo wyth many other the poore afflicted people of God, euer ≈øince the tyme that Tyranny la≈øt broke lo≈øe into this mi≈øerable land &c: I was euen a≈øhamed and in con≈øcience confounded to thinke of my great ≈ølouthe and negligence, yea ingratitude and vnthankfulnes towardes you, in not ≈øowing ≈øome of the≈øe ≈øpirituall gyftes whiche God hath geuen me, emonge≈øt you, of whome I haue reaped ≈øo manifoldly your temporall benefites.

For thys is the firme decree and purpo≈øe of the immutable God reueled in hys euerla≈øting worde, that al they which will liue godlye in Chri≈øte Ie≈øu, mu≈øt ≈øuffer per≈øecution,2. Timo. 3. and that euerye one of his elected ≈øonnes ≈øhalbe ≈øcourged, proued, & tried, as gold in the furnace or fire. And the≈øe wordes of Chri≈øt ≈øhall continue for euer, and be mo≈øt effectuou≈øly fulfilled, that who≈øoeuer ≈øhal be a≈øhamed of hym, Marke. 8. or of his word amonge≈øt this ≈øinful and adulterous generation, of hym wil the ≈øonne of man bee a≈øhamed before his father and hys aungels, and he that goeth about by ≈øuch wycked meanes to ≈øaue his life, ≈øhal ≈øurely lo≈øe it for euermore.

Therfore deare hartes, loke to your ≈øelues in time, and coÃÑ≈øider your callyng. Lay away al vayne excu≈øes, for verely they wil not ≈øerue for your di≈øcharge when he ≈øhal come
that will rewarde euery man after the workes of their bodies: but he will require of you in thys pointe, all that he hath coÃÑmaunded you, as he afore hand hath told you bothe plainly and often enough: God geue you grace to take it as a warning. And if you fele your ≈øelues to weake to confe≈ø≈øe gods truthe before the tyrannes, then for your refuge, the Lord hath geuen you leaue to flye from place to place, and that is the vttermo≈øt that he will permitte you to do: which doing yet is a good confe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt and his verity before the wycked world. Oh that you would follow the good example of a great nuÃÑber of your godly neighbours, which are graciou≈øly e≈øcaped ye ≈ønares of SataÃÑ, & are nowe where they ≈øerue the Lord with a ≈øafe con≈øcience, and enioy ye right and free v≈øe of hys worde and ≈øacramentes: followe them for the lordes ≈øake, & get you ha≈øtely out of Sodom, for ≈øurely the lorde is vtterlye minded to de≈øtroy it. Lynger not as Lothe did, if you loue your owne liues, le≈øt you find not altogether ≈øo much mercy at ye lordes hands as he did: for verely you haue tempted him to farre alredy, & haue to much de≈øpi≈øed his long ≈øufferyng, leuitie and gentlenes, whiche ought to leade you to earne≈øt and hartye repentaunce. He hath mercifully forborne you the≈øe ij. yeres pa≈øt and more: if he fynd no fruite in you ≈øhortly, make reckening to be pulled vp by the rotes euery mothers ≈øonne of you: for the axe is alredy laid at ye rote of EnglaÃÑd, as it was by ye Romains at the roote of the Iewes, when Iohn Bapti≈øte began hys preachyng I pray god that we fele not the ≈øharpe ≈øtroke of it as they did. Pray, pray, pray, and repent in time: conuerte to the lord that he may heale your back≈ølidings before your woundes be vncurable.

I could here ≈øay much more, but time wil not ≈øuffer me. I tru≈øt this ≈øhalbe ≈øufficient to al ≈øuch as haue any ≈øparke of faythe, loue, or true feare of God. As for the re≈øt, they are as a point with them≈øelues: what≈øoeuer any man either write or ≈øay, thei wil ≈øurely di≈ø≈øeÃÑble one way or other to ≈øaue their pigges, yea thoughe they doe but put their names in the Popes bookes. Wel, yet ≈øaye not an other daye but that
ye were warned and though it were but by a poore ≈øymple man, yet it was by him that wi≈øheth wealthe to all youre ≈øoules, & one that in this pointe hath told you the truth, and he tru≈øteth ≈øhortly you ≈øhal ≈øee him ≈øeale the ≈øame wyth his blood through the helpe of the good prayers of all you that truly repeÃÑt and mind vnfainedly to turne the lord in time. As for the re≈øt, I wil pray for them, but let them kepe their owne praiers to them≈øelues in goddes name, for I wil bee no pertaker wyth them, ≈øith I know the ≈øame is turned vnto ≈øinne. Thus with mo≈øt harty thankes for all your benefites and manifolde kindnes ≈øhewed vnto me & my poore brethren, be≈øeching god to recompence the ≈øame ≈øeuen folde into all your bo≈øomes, as I doubt not but he wil, according to his vnfallible promi≈øes, I do hartely coÃÑmit you al vnto gods mo≈øt merciful defeÃÑce, who euer haue you al in his ble≈ø≈øed kepyng, Amen. The ble≈ø≈øyng of God be wt you al, Amen.

closer.signed: Your poore, daily, and mo≈øt bounden Oratour Iohn Careles, pri≈øoner of the Lorde in the kinges Bench, at all tymes abiding gods mo≈øte mercifull will and plea≈øure. Pray for me for gods ≈øake, as I will neuer forget you by gods grace.

div.head: To hys VVyfe.
div.p:
AS by the great mercye of God, at the tyme of hys good wyl and prouidence appointed (my dearely beloued wife) you and I were ioyned together in the holy and chri≈øtian ≈øtate of godly matrimony, as well to our great ioye and comfort in Chri≈øte, as al≈øo to the encrea≈øe of his ble≈ø≈øed churche and faithfull congregation, by hauyng lawful children by and in the ≈øame, with the which God of his mercy hath ble≈ø≈øed vs, prai≈øed be his name therfore: euen ≈øo now, by his merciful wil and deuine ordinaunce, the tyme is come (≈øo farre as I can perceiue) wherin he wyl, for his glory and our eternal comfort, di≈ø≈øolue the ≈øame and ≈øeparate vs a≈øunder agayne for a tyme. Wherfore I thought it good, yea and my bounden duetye, by this ≈øimple letter
to prouoke, ≈øtirre, and admoni≈øh you, to behaue your ≈øelf in all your doinges ≈øayinges, and thoughtes, mo≈øt thankfully vnto our good God for the ≈øame. And therefore (my deare wyfe) as you haue hartely reioyced in ye lord, & ofteÃÑtimes geuen god thankes for his goodnes in bringing vs together in his holy ordinaunce: euen ≈øo now I de≈øire you, wheÃÑ thys tyme of our ≈øeparation ≈øhal come, to reioyce with me in the lord, and to geue him mo≈øt harty thanks, that he hath (to his glory and our endles commoditie) ≈øeparated vs agayne for a little time: and hathe mercifullye taken me vnto him ≈øelfe forth of this mi≈øerable world, into his cele≈øtial kingdom: beleuing and hoping al≈øo a≈ø≈øuredly, that God of his goodnes, for his ≈øonne Chri≈øtes ≈øake, will ≈øhortly bryng you & youre dere child ‚Ä¢ rne thether to me, that we may mo≈øt ioyfully together ≈øing prai≈øes vnto his glorious name for euer. And yet once again I de≈øire you for ye loue of god, & as euer you loued me, to reioyce with me, and to geue GOD continuall thankes for doing his mo≈øt mercifull wil vpon me.

I heare ≈øaye that you doe oftentimes v≈øe to repete this godlye ≈øayinge, the Lordes will be fulfilled. Doubtles it reioiceth my pore hart to heare that report of you, and for ye Lordes ≈øake v≈øe that godly praier continually, & teach your children and family, to ≈øay the ≈øame day and nighte: and not onely to ≈øay it wyth your tonges, but al≈øo with your hart & mind ioyfully to ≈øubmit your wil to gods wil in very dede, knowing and beleuing a≈ø≈øuredly that nothing ≈øhal come to you or any of yours, otherwi≈øe then it ≈øhall be his almyghty & fatherly good will & plea≈øure, & for your eternall comfort and commodity. Which thing to be mo≈øte true and certaine, Chri≈øt te≈øtifieth in his holy go≈øpell, ≈øaying: are not .ij. Math. 10. little ≈øparrowes ≈øold for a farthing, and yet not one of them ≈øhal peri≈øh without the wil of your heauenly father? And he concludeth ≈øaying: feare not ye therfore, for ye are better theÃÑ many ≈øparowes. As though he ≈øhould haue ≈øaid, if god haue ≈øuch a re≈øpecte and care for a poore ≈øparrow, whiche is not worth one farthing, that it ≈øhal not be takeÃÑ in ye lime twig, nette, or pitfall, vntil it be his good wyll and plea≈øure: you may be wel a≈ø≈øured that not one of you (whom he ≈øo derely loueth, that he hath geuen his only dere ≈øonne for you) ≈øhal
peri≈øh, or depart forth of this mi≈øerable life without his almighty good will and plea≈øure.

Therfore deare wyfe, put your tru≈øte and confidence wholy and only in him, and euer pray that his wyll be fulfilled and not yours, excepte it be agreeing to his wil, the which I praye GOD it may euer bee, Amen. And as for worldly things, take you no care, but bee you well a≈ø≈øured the Lorde your deare God and father wyll not ≈øee you nor yours lacke, if you continue in his loue and childly feare, and kepe a cleare con≈øcience from al kind of idolatry, ≈øuper≈øtition and wickednes, as my tru≈øt is that you will doe, althoughe it bee with the lo≈ø≈øe and daunger of this temporall life. And good Margaret, feare not them that can but kil the bodye (and yet can they not do that vntill God geue them leaue) but feare to di≈øplea≈øe him that can kill both body and ≈øoule, and ca≈øt them into hel fire. Let not the remembraunce of your children kepe you from God. The Lorde hym≈øelfe wil be a father and a mother, better then euer you or I could haue bene vnto them. He him≈øelfe will do al things nece≈ø≈øary for them: yea as much as rocke the cradell if nede be. He hath geuen his holy aungels charge ouer them, therfore coÃÑ mit them vnto hym. But if you may liue with a cleare con≈øcience (for els I would not haue you to lyue) and ≈øee the bringyng vp of your children your ≈øelf, loke that you nourture them in the feare of God, and kepe them farre from Idolatry, ≈øuper≈øtition, and all other kynd of wickednes: and for gods ≈øake helpe them to ≈øome learning, if it bee po≈ø≈øible, that they may increa≈øe in vertue & godly knowledge, which ≈øhalbe a better dowry to mary them withal, then any worldly ≈øub≈øtaunce: and when they be come to age, prouide them ≈øuch hu≈øbandes as feare god, and loue hys holye worde. I charge you take heede that you matche them wyth no papi≈øtes, and if you lyue, and marrye agayne your ≈øelf (which thing I would wi≈øhe you to do if nede require, or els not) good wyfe take heede howe you be≈øtowe your ≈øelfe, that you and my poore children be not compelled to wickednes. But if you ≈øhalbee able well to lyue gods true widowe, I would coun≈øell you ≈øo to lyue ≈øtil, for the more quietnes of your ≈øelfe and your poore children. Take hede Margaret & play ye wi≈øe womaÃÑs part. You haue warning by other if you
wil take an example. And thus I committe you & my ≈øwete children vnto gods mo≈øt merciful defence. The ble≈ø≈øing of god be with you, & god ≈øend vs a mery meeting together in heauen. Farewel in Chri≈øt, farewel myne own deare harts all. Pray, pray

div.head: To my deare Sy≈øter, M. C.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus chri≈øt, the coÃÑtinuall comfortes of his mo≈øt pure and holy ≈øpirit, be wyth you (my deare and faithful louing Si≈øter) and comforte your harte with the plenteous con≈øolation in Chri≈øt, that with the aboundance of the ≈øame you may (according to your old cu≈øtome) comfort me in my ≈øorowful e≈øtate, that I may be occa≈øioned therby to prai≈øe the lord with and for you, and other his deare children, Amen.

Albeit my dere & faithful louing Si≈øter, yt it were now my part & very duty to ≈øhew my≈øelf ≈øo coÃÑfortable & ioyful in god for ye greate triuÃÑphe & glorious victory yt he hathe ≈øo graciou≈øly geueÃÑ vnto his dere & faithful child good M. Philpot, yt you & al other (who≈øe ≈øorrowes I dare ≈øaye are much encrea≈øed) might be ≈øolaced by ye ≈øame: yet (alas) ≈øuch is my lo≈ø≈øe & lack of him, yt I caÃÑnot but ≈øo ≈øore lameÃÑt ye ≈øame, yt I feare me I ≈øhal not onely di≈øcoÃÑfort you therwt, but al≈øo di≈øplea≈øe god, which for my ≈øiÃÑne hath takeÃÑ him away. And thoughe it had ben both mine hone≈øty & duty, ≈øeing my ≈øelf to be in ≈øo much ≈øorrow, to haue kept ye ≈øame to my ≈øelf, & not to haue encrea≈øed yours therwith: yet could I no loÃÑger forbeare but to coÃÑ municate ≈øome part therof, to ye ende yt you might communicate again to me either your ioy or ≈øorrow, whether ≈øo euer you haue mo≈øt ≈øtore of. If your ioy in chri≈øt haue ye victory, as doutles it ought to haue in ye re≈øpect of gods glory, which is ≈øo mightely ≈øet forth by his ≈øwete ≈øaint: theÃÑ I pray you come to me as ≈øhortly as you can, & coÃÑmunicate ≈øome part thereof vnto me, who≈øe froward and ≈øtubborne harte cannot yet be coÃÑtent to preferre the good wil & glorye of god, before myne own wil & coÃÑmodity, as I ought to do. But if ≈øorrow in you haue gotteÃÑ ye vpper hand (as in very dede it doth be guide to do in me) good Si≈øter come & ≈øpeake with me ‚Ä¢ o lo ‚Ä¢ e as you can, yt we may mea≈øure our mourning together, and in coÃÑforting one an other, may be both coÃÑ≈øtrained to forget our ≈øorrowes, & prai≈øe god wt him, who is now ≈øynging in ≈øola ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢
hys ≈øwete companions that ≈øo con≈øtantly went before hym, loking and wi≈øhing for vs two, I dare wel ≈øay: god graunt vs grace to follow their faith and fote≈øteppes vnto the end, Amen.

Ah my dere harte, me thinkes I am like a ve≈ø≈øel of wine, that after it hathe bene tumbled and to≈ø≈øed to and fro, if it ≈øhould not haue a vente, would bur≈øt in pieces: Euen ≈øo the takyng away of this very man of god (who≈øe ≈øwete coÃÑ fort my poore ≈øoule doth lacke) ≈øo to≈ø≈øeth and tormoileth my poore heuy harte, that excepte I ≈øhoulde, as it were wyth a vent, expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame to god wyth weping teares, and opeÃÑ the ≈øame to you wyth wordes and letters: I thinke verelye it would bur≈øt in pieces: which thyng were to me mo≈øt happely welcome, ≈øo that god were plea≈øed therewithall. Oh, yf nature wil ≈øo worke in a wycked worldlyng, to make hym hartely to lameÃÑt ye lo≈ø≈øe of his frende, by who≈øe death he doth yet obtaine diuers commodities: howe can it be but the tender harts that be mollified with the good ≈øpirit of god, mu≈øt nedes bewayle the taking awaye of tho≈øe deare hartes, by who≈øe death they are depriued of ≈øo many heaueÃÑly benefits, which ≈øo farre without compari≈øon do pa≈ø≈øe al earthly trea≈øures? Ah deare hart, I neuer wi≈øte what the benefit of that worthy Bradford was, vntil now that I feele the wante of hys deare fellow Philpotte, which full oft poured the precious water of lyfe and comforte vppon my poore afflicted foule. But now (alas) for my great ingratitude, negligence & other my great ≈øinnes, god hath taken them bothe from me: I ≈øhal no more hear theÃÑ in thys life (the more is my ≈øorrow) declare vnto me ye mo≈øt coÃÑfortable me≈ø≈øage of gods great mercy towards me. Their worthy writings (alas) ≈øhal no more bring me the mo≈øt ioyfull newes and mery tidinges of the Go≈øpel, to tel me that al my horrible ≈øinnes and offences are frely forgeueÃÑ me. Oh my great lo≈ø≈øe which maketh me much to lament, and ≈øo vexeth and tormenteth my minde, that I cannot wel tel what I write. Oh true token of gods terrible wrath agayn≈øt me, in takyng away ≈øuche precious iewels of comforte from me. But iu≈øt is the iudgement of god again≈øt me for my ≈øynne, which haue largely de≈øerued to be depriued of their ≈øwete and comfortable company, not onely
in thys life, but al≈øo in the lyfe to come. But yet I know the Lord wil not ≈øo do, but of his great mercy he hath taken theÃÑ at thys time froÃÑ me, yt I might make the more ha≈øte with harty de≈øyre, to be di≈ø≈øolued & to be with them. Oh gracious god, how much is thy mercy? How meruelous is thy louiÃÑg power, & how great is thy goodnes and the aboundance of thine exceding kindnes, which turne≈øt all things to thy glory & the commoditie of thy cho≈øen children? Oh make me ≈øo much to reioyce in the re≈øpecte of thy glory, whiche thou ≈øo mightely ha≈øt magnifyed in thy ≈øwete Martyrs, that ye ≈øame may ≈øone ≈øwallow vp my de≈øerued ≈øorrowes, Amen. Commend me to my good ≈øi≈øter .C. and bring her with you if you can. Iohn was wonte to coÃÑfort Mary: but now good ≈øwete Maryes come comfort Iohn.

closer.signed: Written in ha≈øt with plentifull teares, by your own in Chri≈øt, Iohn Careles.

div.head: To my dere & faithful brother, Augu≈øtine Bernher.
div.p: THe peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, the helpe, comfort, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his eternal ≈øpirit, be with you my dere and faythful brother Augu≈øtine, and with al the re≈øt of my good brethren & ≈øi≈øters of ye hou≈øes of Baxterley, & Mancetur (which mourneth for ye mi≈øerye of gods people) to your euerla≈øting con≈øolation in him, AmeÃÑ.

Right glad I am to heare (my deare & faythfull brother Augu≈øtine) that god of his great mercy & infinite goodnes, hath yet ≈øo graciou≈øly deliuered & pre≈øerued you out of your enemies hands, be≈øeching almighty god al≈øo, from the bottome of my hart, to be your continual defence vnto the end, as hetherto he hath mo≈øt graciou≈øly bene, that you may both liue & die to gods glory, the coÃÑmodity of his church, & to the encrea≈øe of your own euerla≈øting ioy & comfort in him.

Know you dere brother yt I haue receaued your letter, for the which I hartely thanke you. Indede I thinke it verye ≈øhort, although it ≈øemeth ≈øomthing ≈øharpely to rebuke me in the beginning, for the breach of my promy≈øe in not writing to you of this long time. Wel brother, I am coÃÑtent to beare it with pacience, coÃÑ≈øidering that you are troubled otherwi≈øe (the Lord coÃÑfort you and al heuie harts) neither wil I ≈øpeÃÑd ynke & paper for my purgatioÃÑ in this point. God he knoweth whether I be ≈øo mindles of my promi≈øe as it appeareth
in your ≈øight I am. Your reque≈øt I will trulye performe to the vttermo≈øte of my power, as gladly as any poore wretch ≈øhall doe in the worlde, and I thanke GOD I haue done no le≈ø≈øe of longe tyme. And as my poore prayer ≈øhall be a hand mayde to wayte vppon you whiche waye ≈øo euer you tyde or goe, ≈øo I be≈øeche you that my ≈øimple coun≈øell maye take ≈øome place in you, in thys time of your pilgrimage, whiche you pa≈ø≈øe in no ≈ømall parell: GOD keepe and pre≈øerue you for his names ≈øake. I doe not di≈øalowe, but muche pray≈øe and commende your hartye boldene≈ø≈øe in puttyng your ≈øelfe in prea≈ø≈øe, when any one of Gods people needeth your helpe in anye poynte. But yet I woulde not haue you thru≈øte your ≈øelfe in daunger, when you can doe them no good, or at lea≈øt wy≈øe when they maye well enoughe ≈øpare that good you woulde doe them. For if you ≈øhoulde then chaunce to bee taken, you ≈øhall not onelye bee no comforte vnto them, but al≈øo a greate di≈øcomforte, adding ≈øorrowe vnto their ≈øorrowe. I doe not per≈øuade you to ab≈øente your ≈øelfe from anye place where your pre≈øence of nece≈ø≈øity is requyred, for in all ≈øuch places, I know, GOD will pre≈øerue you, as he hath hetherto wonderfullye done, pray≈øed be his name therefore: or if it ≈øhal plea≈øe him to permitte you in any ≈øuch place to bee taken, I know he will mo≈øte ≈øweetelye comforte your con≈øcience with this con≈øideration, that it is the verye prouidence and appointmente of GOD that you ≈øhoulde there and then bee taken vppe for a witne≈ø≈øe of hys truth vnto the worlde: but I can not allowe you, nor bee contented that you ≈øhoulde ra≈øhelye or negligentlye thru≈øte your ≈øelfe into that place where your wicked enemies doe continually haunte, yea and laye waite for you, when no nece≈ø≈øitie of your ≈øelfe nor of anye other of Gods people doth require your companye. Yf they neede anye of your Godlye coun≈øell, you maye write vnto them that thing that you thinke good: whiche, I dare ≈øaye, will be ≈øufficient vnto them. For (continuall thankes and pray≈øes bee geuen vnto the euerla≈øting God) there is none of tho≈øe that be cruellye condemned for Gods truth, that now be weakelings: for they haue manfully pa≈ø≈øed through the pikes, and they haue boldely abidden the brunte of the battel, and therfore I recken ye wor≈øt is pa≈øt wt theÃÑ alreadie. So that nowe and then a Godlye letter from you to them,
≈øhall doe as muche good as your companye ≈øhall doe, and perchauÃÑce more too. For writing ≈øticketh longer in the memorye then wordes doe: yea thoughe your letters were as ≈øhorte to them, as your la≈øte was to me, ≈øo that the ≈øame bee ≈øomething ≈øweter and not all thing ≈øo ≈øharpe.

This (deare brother) is the ≈øimple couÃÑ≈øel which I would gladly haue you ob≈øerue, partely for that I hartely pray for your pre≈øeruation to the commoditie of Chri≈øts church, and partly for yt I vnfainedly wi≈øh the peace, comfort, & tranquilitie of your own con≈øcience, which I know will be quickly ready to accu≈øe you if you do any thing wherein you haue not the worde of God for your warrante. For in a gla≈ø≈øe that is cleere, a ≈ømall mote wil ≈øone appeare: euen ≈øo ye good con≈øcience of Gods cho≈øen children being more cleere then Chri≈øt all, wil quickely accu≈øe them at the lea≈øt faulte they do commit, where as the wicked worldlings haue their con≈øcience clogged and corrupted throughe the cu≈øtome of ≈øinne, that they can not once ≈øee nor perceaue their owne ≈øhameful deedes and wicked workes, vntil GOD ≈øet the ≈øame before them for their vtter de≈øtruction, and then di≈øpayre they immediatly. But ≈øeing ye god hath geueÃÑ you a cleere con≈øcience & a pure, ≈øharpe, quicke, & liuely ≈øight in your ≈øoule, I wold wi≈øhe you to beware that you do nothing vnadui≈øedly, but vppon a good grounde. For an accu≈øing con≈øcience is a ≈øore thing wheÃÑ death doth approche, & then SathaÃÑ wil not ≈øticke to tel you yt you haue to much teÃÑpted god, wheÃÑ peradueÃÑture you haue done nothiÃÑg ≈øo at all. For this cau≈øe (I ≈øaye) partly I haue thought it good to admoni≈øh you (as I haue done often) to be circum≈øpecte, according to the coun≈øel of Chri≈øt, Math. 10. which biddeth you beware of men. Other thinges I haue not for to write, for I know this bearer can certefye you of al things at large, better then I can declare it by writyng.

I be≈øeche you good Augu≈øtine, helpe me forwardes with your hartye prayers, for I tru≈øte I haue but a ≈ømal time to tarye in this trouble≈øome world. Doctor Storye tolde oure Mar≈øhal yt we ≈øhould al be di≈øpatched ≈øo ≈øone as he came froÃÑ Oxforde, whether he & other bloodye butchers be gone to make ≈ølaughter of Chri≈øts ≈øhepe, ye lye there appointed to be ≈ølaine. God for Chri≈øtes ≈øake put them and ≈øuch lyke, be≈øides their cruell purpo≈øe, if it bee his good will and plea≈øure:
Amen good Lord. I praye you doe my mo≈øte hartye commendations to my deare ≈øi≈øter and faythfull frende, good My≈øtres Marye Glouer. I be≈øeche GOD be her comfort, as I doubte not but he is. I am very gladde to heare that ≈øhee doth ≈øo ioyfullye and ≈øo patientlye beare thys greate cro≈ø≈øe that God hath layde vppon her. I praye GOD ≈øtrengthen her, and all other hys deare Sainctes vnto the ende, Amen. Commende me vnto my deare and faythfull

Si≈øter Elizabeth. B. I thanke her mo≈øte hartelye for my napkin, and ≈øo I doe you deare brother, for my ≈øherte. Trulye that daye that we were appoynted to come to oure aun≈øweare before the Commi≈ø≈øioners, whiche had ≈øente worde the ≈øame morning, that they woulde come to the Kynges Benche by viii. of the clocke, and the hou≈øe and all thinges were trymmed and made ready for them: I gotte that ≈øhert on my backe and that napkin in my hande, and me thought that they dyd helpe to harne≈ø≈øe me and weapon me well, to goe fighte agayn≈øte that bloodye bea≈øte of Babilon. And tru≈øte me trulye, if they hadde come, I woulde haue ≈øtryken iij. ≈øtrokes the more for your two ≈øakes, as well as GOD woulde haue abled me to haue ≈øette them on, as by Gods grace I will not fayle to doe at the nexte ≈økirmy≈øhe that I come to: Wherefore I praye you praye for me, that I maye be ≈øtronge and hardye to laye on good loade. Oh that I myghte ≈øo ≈øtrike hym downe, that he ≈øhoulde neuer be able for to ry≈øe agayne: but that ≈øtroke belongeth only vnto the Lord to ≈øtrike at his comming, the whiche I tru≈øte will be ≈øhortly. Oh ha≈øten it good Lord, and ≈øhorten the≈øe ≈øorowful and ≈øinnefull dayes, for thy greate mercyes ≈øake. Fare well my deare and faythful brother: the Lord defend, kepe, & pre≈øerue you from the power of your enemies vi≈øible and inui≈øible, and ≈øende vs a mo≈øte ioyful and merye meting here or el≈øwhere, as it ≈øhall plea≈øe hys goodnes to appoynt vs. In the meane ≈øpace I ≈øhal mo≈øt earne≈øtly de≈øire you to pray for me, for I neuer had more nede in my life: and doubtles you ≈øhal neuer want my poore prayer, if it ≈øhal plea≈øe god to accept the prayer of ≈øo ≈øynnefull a wretch as I am. The Lord impute not my ≈øynnes to me, for Ie≈øus Chri≈øtes ≈øake, vnto who≈øe mo≈øt mercifull defence, I do mo≈øt hartely coÃÑmit you. The ble≈ø≈øing of God be with you now and euer, Amen. I
pray you do my mo≈øt harty commendations vnto M. Iohn Glouer. I do not forget him in my daily prayers, & I tru≈øt he doth remember me.
