div.head: To my deare brother Harry Adlington pry≈øoner in the Lolardes Tower.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of GOD in Ie≈øus Chri≈øte, the continuall ayde, ≈øtrength, ioye, and comforte of hys mo≈øte pure, holye, and mightye ≈øpirite, with the encrea≈øe of fayth and liuelye feelyng of hys mercyes: bee mo≈øte effectuou≈ølye wroughte in your hart, my deare and faythfull louing brother Adlington, and in the hartes of all your other Godlye pry≈øon fellowes, to the full fini≈øhyng of that good woorke, whiche the Lorde hath mo≈øte graciou≈ølye begonne in you: that the ≈øame maye be to the ≈øetting forth of his glorye, the commoditye of hys poore afflicted Church, and to your owne eternall ioye and comforte in him, Amen.

My mo≈øte deare and faythfull louing brother in our Lord, I with al the re≈øt of my louing brethren here with me, do mo≈øte humbly & hartely commende vs vnto you, with al faythfull remembrance of you in our daily prayers, geuing god earne≈øt thankes on your mo≈øt happy behalfe, for that he hath geuen you ≈øuch hartye boldne≈ø≈øe and Chri≈øtian con≈øtaÃÑ cye in the faithful confe≈ø≈øion of his euerla≈øting verity. Ble≈ø≈øed bee God for thee my dearly beloued brother, which hath vouched thee worthye of ≈øo greate dignitie, as to ≈øuffer for hys ≈øake and the ≈øetting forth of his glorye. Oh gladde in hart maye≈øt thou bee, to whom it is geuen, not onelye to beleue in thy Lorde and Chri≈øte mo≈øte liuelye: but al≈øo to ≈øuffer for hys ≈øake, as one of hys ≈øeelye ≈øhepe appoynted to the ≈ølaughter. Be of good comforte therefore my good
brother, for your callynge vnto the cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øte, was after a merueilous ≈øorte. Surelye, it was only the Lords appoyntmente, and therefore he will well performe hys owne woorke in and vppon you, to the greate magnifying of hys glorye, and comforte of your brethren: who≈øe hartes are mightelye refre≈øhed, to heare howe hartelye you haue behaued your ≈øelfe hetherto. Thys pre≈øente daye I receaued a letter from you, at the reading whereof my brethren and I were not a litte comforted, to ≈øee your con≈øcience ≈øo quieted in Chri≈øte, and your continuance ≈øo ≈øtedfa≈øte in him: whiche thinges be the ≈øpeciall giftes of GOD, not geuen vnto euery man, but to you his deare dareling, elect, and cho≈øen in Chri≈øte, and ≈øuche as you be. And where as you do require to know my ≈øimple minde concerning your aun≈øweare vnto Doctor Storye and the Chauncelour: trulye I ≈øaye you did aun≈øweare them very well: for there are but two Sacramentes in deede: that is to ≈øaye, the Sacrament of Bapti≈øme, and the Sacrament of the bodye and bloode of Chri≈øte, as you haue full well aun≈øweared them: pray≈øed be God for hys good giftes, who cho≈øeth the weake to confounde the ≈øtronge, and the fooly≈øhe to confounde the worldlye wy≈øe. If, when you come before them againe, they doe a≈øke you what a Sacramente is, ≈øaye you that a Sacramente, being mini≈øtred according to Chri≈øtes in≈øtitution, is a vi≈øible ≈øigne of an inui≈øible grace, and hath the promy≈øe of Gods mercye annexed vnto it, auaileable to all ≈øuche as doe worthelye receaue it, and not vnworthelye wor≈øhippe it: as they woulde haue vs to doe, contrarye to Gods commaundemente. And the≈øe properties belonging to Chri≈øtes true Sacramentes, can not be applyed vnto anye one of tho≈øe fiue Sacramentes whiche they haue inuented of their owne braine, ≈øince Antichri≈øte beganne to reigne, to blinde the people with all.

I perceaue deare harte, that vpon fridaye they do entende to condempne you and to geue you your iudgement. Therefore I thinke they will haue no greate rea≈øoning with you, but bydde you aun≈øweare them directlye, eyther
yea or naye, to all ≈øuche thinges as they haue to charge you with all, whiche they haue gathered of you ≈øince you came into their cruell handes. But if they will needes make manye woordes with you, becau≈øe you are but a ≈øimple man, and therefore perchaunce they will be the bu≈øier with you to ttouble you with manye que≈øtions to comber your knowledge, and then ≈øeeme to triumphe ouer you and that truth that you doe holde: if (I ≈øaye) they doe thys, as perhappes for ≈øome euill purpo≈øe they will: then bee you ≈øo plaine and ≈øhorte as you can, ≈øaying roundlye vnto them the≈øe or ≈øuche lyke woordes as nyghe as you can. Bee it knowen vnto you, that I in all pointes doe beleue as it becommeth a true Chri≈øtian, and as I haue bene truelye taughte in the daies of that good Kyng Edwarde, of ≈øuche godlye Preachers and Prophetes ≈øente of GOD, as haue ≈øealed their doctrine with their bloode: from whom I will di≈ø≈øente in no poynte: for I am a poore man without learning, but am commaunded of GOD to followe the coun≈øel of his con≈øtante Preachers, and ≈øo doe I entend to doe, god geuing me grace and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance thereto. As for you, I know you to be none of Chri≈øtes ≈øhepeheards, but rauening wolues whiche come to kill and ≈øcatter the flocke of Chri≈øte, as the Lorde ≈øayde you ≈øhoulde: and doth will vs to beware of you and your poy≈øoned doctrine, bidding vs to iudge you accordyng to your fruites, whereby all men maye ≈øee and knowe what you bee, that will not be wilfullye blynd. But the good ≈øhepeheardes haue geuen their liues for the defence of Chri≈øtes flocke: and I am commaunded to followe their faythfull and Godlye example, and to confe≈ø≈øe with them one truth, euen to the fyre, if GOD ≈øhall ≈øee it good: and thys as a true Chri≈øtian. I haue hetherto done and hence forth by Gods grace entende for to doe. And if for the ≈øame, GOD ≈øhal ≈øuffer you to take away my lyfe, as you haue done theirs, I am contented therewith‚ñ™ hys will bee done, for that onelye is good. But of thys be you ≈øure, the Lorde wil ≈øhortelye call you to accompte for all the innocente bloode that is ≈øhedde with in thys Realme:
which you haue brought into a mo≈øt wofull ca≈øe, and made many a heauye harte in the ≈øame, and moe I perceaue you will make, ≈øo long as the Lord for our ≈øinnes wil ≈øuffer you to pro≈øper, and vntill the time that your owne iniquitye be full rype. But then be you ≈øure, the Lord will ≈øitte in iudgement vpon you, as well as you do now vpon his Saincts, and will reward you according to your de≈øeruings: to whoÃÑ with my whole harte I commit my cau≈øe, and he will make aun≈øwere for me, when the full tyme of my refre≈øhyng commeth. In the meane ≈øpace I will keepe ≈øilence with thys that I haue ≈øayde, tru≈øting that I haue ≈øufficiently di≈øcharged my con≈øcience in confe≈ø≈øing my fayth and religion to you, declaring of what Church I am, euen of the catholyke Church of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which was wel knowen to be here in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ glande in our late good Kings dayes, by two ≈øpeciall tokens which can not deceaue me, nor ≈øuffer me to be deceaued: that is to ≈øay, the pure preaching of his holy worde, and the due admini≈øtratioÃÑ of the holy ≈øacramentes: which is not to be ≈øene in your Romy≈øhe church, and therfore it can not iu≈øtly be called the Church and ≈øpou≈øe of Chri≈øt. I beleue in the holy Trinitie, and al the other articles of the Chri≈øtian faith contained in the three Credes, and finally al the canonicall Scripture to be true in euerye ≈øentence. And I dete≈øt al ≈øectes both of the Arrians and Anabapti≈øtes, or any other that diuide them≈øelues froÃÑ the true church of Chri≈øt, whiche is his my≈øticall body, the ground and piller of truth, and the very hou≈øe of ye liuing God. And if for the≈øe things you take away my life, and make your≈øelues giltye of my blood, you may: for I am in your handes, as the ≈øhepe brought to the Shambles, abyding the grace of the Butcher. And bee you ≈øure, your iudgement ≈øtepeth not, but when you crye peace, peace,2. The≈ø. 5. and all is ≈øafe: then ≈øhall your plagues beginne lyke the ≈øorowes of a woman trauelyng with child, according to Chri≈øtes infallible promi≈øe.

This kinde of aun≈øweare my deare harte, it ≈øhall bee be≈øte for you to make, and by Gods grace, I doe entende to take the ≈øame order my ≈øelfe in tyme to come, when the Lorde ≈øhall vouche me worthye of that greate dignitye,
wherunto he hath called you. And if they ≈øhall laugh you to ≈øcorne, as I know they wil, ≈øaying thou arte a foole and an vnlearned a≈ø≈øeheade, and arte able to make aun≈øwer to nothing &c: care not you for it, but ≈øtil coÃÑmmit your cau≈øe vnto god, who will make aun≈øwer for you, and tell them that they haue bene an≈øwered again & again of diuers godly and learned men: but al wil not helpe, for you haue one ≈øolution for all maner of que≈øtions, euen a faire fyre and fagots, this will be the ende of your di≈øputations. Therfore I pray you to trouble me no more, but do that which you are apointed, wheÃÑ god ≈øhal permitte the time. I am no better theÃÑ Chri≈øt, his Apo≈øtels, and other of my good bretherne that are gone before me. This kind of an≈øwer wil cut their combes mo≈øt, and edify the people that ≈øtand by, ≈øo that the ≈øame bee done coldly with ≈øobrietie, mekenes, and patience: as I heard ≈øay out ≈øwete bretherne Thomas HarlaÃÑd & Iohn O≈øward did at Lewes in Suffex, to the great reioycing of ye childreÃÑ of god yt were in tho≈øe parties: & I heare ≈øay, yt they were di≈ø≈øolued from this earthly tabernacle at Leawes on Saterday la≈øt, & wer condeÃÑned but ye wedni≈øday before: ≈øo that we may perteine ye papi≈øtes haue quicke worke in hand, that they make ≈øuch ha≈øte to haue vs home to our heauenly father. Therfore let vs make our ≈øelues redy to ride in the fiery chariot,4. Reg. 2. leauing the≈øe ≈øory mantels and old clokes behinde vs for a little time which god ≈øhal re≈øtore vnto vs againe in a more glorious wi≈øe. My good brother Harry, you ≈øhal vnder≈øtaÃÑd ye bragging Iohn. T. hath begilde his kepers (who tru≈øted him to wel) and is runne away from them, & hath broughte the poore men into great daunger by the ≈øame. The one of them is ca≈øt by the Councels commaundemeÃÑt, into the gate hou≈øe at We≈øtmin≈øter, the other is ≈øted forth of the countrey for feare. Thus you may ≈øee the fruites of our freewil men, that made ≈øo much boa≈øt of their owne ≈øtrength. But that hou≈øe whiche is not builded ≈øurelye vppon the vnmoueable rocke, wil not long ≈øtand again≈øt the boi≈øtrous windes and ≈øtormes, that blow ≈øo ≈øtrongly in the≈øe dais of trouble. But my derely beloued brother, ble≈ø≈øed be god for you and ≈øuche as you be, which haue plaied ye partes of wi≈øe builders. You haue dygged downe pa≈øte the ≈øande of your owne naturall
≈øtrength, & beneath the earth of your own worldly wi≈ødom, & are nowe come to the harde ≈øtone and vnmoueable rocke Chri≈øt, who is your only keper: and vppon him alone you haue builded your faith mo≈øt firmly, without doubting, mi≈øtru≈øt, or waueryng. Therfore neither the ≈øtormes nor tempe≈øtes, wyndes nor weathers that Sathan and all his wily workemen can bryng again≈øt you, wyth the verye gates of hel to helpe theÃÑ, ≈øhal euer be able once to moue your hou≈øe, much le≈ø≈øe to ouerthrowe it: for the lord god him≈øelfe (and no man) is the builder thereof, & hath promi≈øed to pre≈øerue and kepe the ≈øame ≈øafe for euer. Vnto hys mo≈øt merciful defence therfore, I do hartely commit you and all your good comapany, de≈øiring him for his ≈øwete ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øtes ≈øake, to confirme and ≈øtrengthen you all, that you maye bee con≈øtant vnto the very ende: that after the finall victorye is once gotten, you maye receiue the inmerce≈ø≈øible crowne of glory, of gods free gift through hys greate mercy in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt our alone Sauiour. To whome wyth the father and the holy gho≈øt be all honour, glory, pray≈øe, thankes, power, rule and dominion for euer and euermore, AmeÃÑ. The ble≈ø≈øyng of God be wyth you all.

div.head: ¬∂To my faythfull and louyng brother VVilliam Ayl≈øebury.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the continual aide, ≈øtrength & comfortes of his mo≈øt pure, holye & mighty ≈øpirite, with the encrea≈øe of faith and liuely feelyng othys mercye: be wyth you my deare and faythfull louyng brother W. Ail≈øebury, to the increa≈øe of hys good gyftes in you and the full fini≈øhyng of that which the Lorde hath ≈øo gratiou≈ølye begonne in you, that the ≈øame maye bee to the ≈øetting forth of his glory the commoditye of hys poore afflicted churche, and to your owne euerla≈øtyng comforte in hym. Amen.

Albeit, my dere harte in the lord, that at this very pre≈øent, my ≈øorye ≈ølowe hande is ≈øomething pe≈øtered with writyng, to plea≈øe my frendes which daily cal vpon me for the performance of my promi≈øe and duety towardes them, by
the meanes wherof I cannot now wryte vnto you in ≈øo ample maner as I fayne would: yet le≈øt by my to long ≈øilence, my great ingratitude for your loue and godly letters, ≈øhuld to muche appeare, I haue here in ha≈øte ≈øcribled the≈øe fewe wordes vnto you, de≈øiring you to accepte the ≈øame in good parte, vntyl the Lorde ≈øhall ≈øende me a more conueniente tyme to expre≈ø≈øe my good will and bounden dutye more largely vnto you, promi≈øyng you in ye meane ≈øpace, that my poore praier ≈øhal ≈øupply yt which wanteth otherwi≈øe: as I tru≈øt you do not forget me in yours, for verely I haue great nede of it. My deare brother. I thanke you mo≈øt hartely for your godlye, louing, and mo≈øte comfortable letters, in the which I do euidently perceiue the precious gyftes of God wherwith you are plentifully endued: the Lorde be prai≈øed for you, and from the bottome of my harte I do reuerence his ≈øpirite in you. Wherfore my good brother, bee not negligent in the talent that God hath deliuered vnto you: but diligently applye the ≈øame, as I knowe well you doe, that the Lorde may receiue his owne wyth vauntage, and you the rewarde of a faythfull ≈øeruaunt at the tyme of hys mo≈øt ioyefull returne. Truely I wyl not ≈øpeake it to flatter you, neither would I prouoke you to vaine glory, but I wyll ≈øaye as I ≈øee iu≈øte cau≈øe, that god hathe aboundantly ble≈ø≈øed you with the ≈øwete knowledge and pure vnder≈øtandyng of his holy worde. Be alwaies thankefull vnto god I charge you, and humble and meke in your owne ≈øight, that GOD onely may haue al the glory from the bottome of your hart: And loke that you be very circum≈øpect in al your life & conuer≈øation, that ye light of your good workes may ≈øo ≈øhine before men, that they may be occa≈øioned to glorify your heaueÃÑ ly father on your behalfe, Be diligent in your doings, and quick & tru≈øty in al your Mai≈øters bu≈øines yt you go about, that by al meanes you maye do honour to ye doctrine of our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. RemeÃÑber that Sathan nowe wyll haue greater ≈øpite at you, then at many other, becau≈øe you are ≈øuch a mortall enemy to his kingdome on enerye ≈øyde. Therefore bee you ≈øure he will nowe lie bitynge at your heele, to ≈øee if he can geue you a fall anye manner of waye. that he myght make the truth of that godly doctrine, which you con≈øtantly confe≈ø≈øe, to be ≈ølaundered by ye meanes therof.
I knowe well that Sathans thoughtes are not hidde from you.2. Cor. 2. I doubt not but you will be more circuÃÑ≈øpecte theÃÑ I can declare: notwith≈øtanding I thought it my bounden duty to warne you, as one whom I loue as myne owne ≈øoule, wy≈øhing you all the good I can po≈ø≈øible. Commend me vnto my deare frend Iohn Manning and thanke him for his manifold kindnes. I am much to blame for him: but if the lord do ≈øpare my lyfe a litle longer, I wil write ≈øomthing to him for a remembraunce when I am gone. De≈øire hym to praye for me, as I do not forget hym. I haue ≈øente you your writinges agayne wyth thankes. I pray you write me a copye of that, coÃÑcerning the Trinitie: for I lyke it meruelous wel, it is ≈øo briefe & pithy. I haue no lei≈øure to write it, yet wold I fayne haue it: as knoweth the lord GOD, to who≈øe mo≈øte merciful defence I do hartely committe you, wyth my good brother Iohn Manning: that he with his grace and ≈øpirit, wil guide you both, with al ye re≈øt of his deare children vnto the ende, Amen. The ble≈ø≈øing of God be with you nowe and euermore, Amen.

div.head: To my most faythefull and deare brother. T. V.
div.p: THe euerla≈øting peace of god in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the continuall comfortes of his mo≈øte pure & holy ≈øpirit, be with you my deare and faythfull brother. V. and in all thinges make you ioyfull throughe the liuelye feeling of hys fatherly mercy and godly prouideÃÑce for you: that you hauing daily more and more ye ≈øure ≈øence of ye ≈øame, may be able of your owne good experience, perfectly to comfort me and all other with the ≈øame comfort which you haue, and further ≈øhal receiue of god: who ble≈ø≈øe and kepe you now and euer, Amen.

‚Ä¢ . & happy ≈øhal you be for euermore, becau≈øe you haue beleued. The mo≈øt ≈øwete & faithful promi≈øes of your redemer Ie≈øus chri≈øt

‚Ä¢ 03. he hath remoued them from you as farre as the Ea≈øt is froÃÑ the We≈øt, & hath geuen you for an euerla≈øting po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion his iu≈øtification and holines: ≈øo that now no creature neither in heauen nor in earth ≈øhalbe able to accu≈øe you before the throne of the heauenly kyng. The Lord encrea≈øe thy fayth, & geue thee a liuelye feeling of all his mercyes: whereof thou arte warranted and a≈ø≈øured by the te≈øtimonye of the holy gho≈øte, who confirme in thy con≈øcience (to the vtter ouerthrowing of Sathan and tho≈øe his mo≈øt hurtful dubitations, wherby he is accu≈øtomed to mole≈øt and vexe the true childreÃÑ of god) all that I haue ≈øayd: and by gods grace I will, as a witnes therof, confirme & ≈øeale the ≈øame wt my blood, for a mo≈øt certaine truth. To this bil I did in dede ≈øet to my haÃÑd, being much de≈øired & couÃÑ≈øelled ≈øo to do, & the fle≈øh being alwais de≈øirous to haue liberty, I coÃÑ≈øidered not throughly the incoÃÑuenieÃÑce yt myght come therupoÃÑ: & re≈øpite I de≈øired to haue had, but earne≈øtly they required me to ≈øub≈øcribe. For by & by my mind & con≈øcieÃÑce told me by gods word yt I had done euil by ≈øuch a ≈øleight to ≈øhake of the ≈øwete cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt: and yet it was not my ≈øeeking, as god he knoweth, but altogether came of theÃÑ. Through manye tribulations in earth, is he ≈øtill purged: with ioye vn≈øpeakeable in heauen, is he made pure for euer. Here he dyeth euerye houre: there he liueth continualy. Here is ≈øynne: there is righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. Here is tyme: there is eternitie. Here is hatred: there is loue. Here is payne: there is plea≈øure. Here is my≈øerye: there is felicitie. div.p:

I praye you prouide for me a longe ≈øhirt again≈øt the day of our deliueraÃÑce: for the ≈øhirt you gaue me la≈øt, I haue geueÃÑ it to one of my coÃÑpanioÃÑs, who had more neede then I: and as for the money and meate you ≈øent vs, the bi≈øhops ≈øeruantes deliuered none to vs, neither he whoÃÑ you had ≈øo great tru≈øt in. The two fir≈øt be Scholers in the Vniuer≈øitie. The thirde is as poore as either of the other twayne. Nowe, there is fallen a Prebende in Paules called Cantrelles, by the death of one Layton. Thys Prebend is an hone≈øt mans liuing of .xxxiiij. poundes, and better in the Kings bookes. I woulde with all my harte geue it vnto M. Grindall, and ≈øo I ≈øhould haue hym continuallye with me and in my dioce≈ø≈øe, to preache.

But Alas Syr, I am letted by the meanes (I feare me)
of ≈øuche as do not feare God. One M. William Thomas, one of the Clarkes to the Coun≈øell, hath in tymes pa≈øt ≈øette the Coun≈øaile vpon me, to haue me to graunte that Layton mighte haue alienated the ≈øayde Prebend vnto him and his heires for euer. God was mine ayde and defendour, that I dyd not con≈øent vnto his vngodly enterpri≈øe. Yet I was ≈øo then handled before the Coun≈øel, that I grauÃÑted that wheÃÑ ≈øoeuer it ≈øhould fall, I ≈øhoulde not geue it, before I ≈øhoulde make the Kinges Maie≈øtie preuye vnto it and of acknowledge, before ye collation of it. Now Layton is departed, and the Prebend is fallen, & certaine of the Coun≈øell (no doubt, by this vngodly mans meanes) haue writteÃÑ vnto me, to ≈øtay the collatioÃÑ. And where as he di≈øpaireth, that euer I would a≈ø≈øent that a preachers liuing ≈øhoulde be be≈øtowed on hym: he hath procured letters vnto me, ≈øub≈øcribed wt certaine of the Coun≈øelles hands, that now ye Kings Maie≈øtie hath determined it vnto ye furniture of his highnes ≈øtable. Alas Syr, this is a heauy hearing. When papi≈øtrye was taught, there was nothing too litle for the teachers. When ye Bi≈øhop gaue his benefices vnto idiotes, vnlearned, vngodlye, for kindred, for plea≈øure, for ≈øeruice, & other worldly re≈øpectes, all was then wel allowed. Now, where a poore liuing is to be geuen vnto an excellent Clarke, a maÃÑ knowen & tryed to haue both di≈øcretioÃÑ & al≈øo vertue, & ≈øuch a one as before god, I do not know a man yet vnplaced & vnprouided for, more meete to ≈øet forth gods word in al Englande: when a poore liuing (I ≈øay) which is founded for a preacher, is to be geueÃÑ vnto ≈øuch a man, that then an vngodly per≈øoÃÑ ≈øhal procure in this ≈øorte letters to ≈øtoppe & lette the ≈øame, alas M. Cheke, this ≈øeemeth vnto me to be a ryght heauy hearing. Is thys the fruite of the go≈øpel? Speake M. Cheke, ≈øpeake for gods ≈øake, in gods cau≈øe, vnto whom ≈øoeuer you thinke you may do any good withall. And if you will not ≈øpeake, then I be≈øech you, let the≈øe my letters ≈øpeake vnto M. Gates, to M. Wrothe, to M. Cicill, whom all I doe take for men that doe feare God.

It was ≈øayd here con≈øtantly, my Lord Chamberlaine to haue bene departed. Syr, though the day be delayed, yet he hath no pardon of long life, & therfore I do be≈øech his good Lord≈øhip, & ≈øo many as ≈øhall read the≈øe letters, if they feare
God, to helpe that neither hor≈øe, neither yet dogge be ≈øuffered to deuour ye poore liuings appointed & founded by godly ordinance, to the mini≈øters of gods worde. The cau≈øes of con≈øcieÃÑce, which do moue me to ≈øpeake & write thus, are not only tho≈øe whiche I declared once in the cau≈øe of this Prebend, before ye Kings Maie≈øties Coun≈øell, which now I let pa≈ø≈øe: but al≈øo now ye man M. Grindal, vnto whoÃÑ I would geue this Prebend, doth moue me verye muche: for he is a man knowen to be both of vertue, hone≈øtie, di≈øcretion, wi≈øedome, & learning. And be≈øides al this, I haue a better opinion of ye Kings Maie≈øties‚ñ™ honourable Coun≈øel, theÃÑ (although ≈øome of them haue ≈øub≈øcribed at this their Clarkes craf ‚Ä¢ ie & vngodly ≈øute, to ≈øuch a letter) then (I ≈øay) they wil let, & not ≈øuffer, after reque≈øt made vnto them, the liuing appoynted & founded for a preacher, to bee be≈øtowed vppon ≈øo hone≈øt and well a learned man.

Wherfore for gods ≈øake, I be≈øech you al, helpe that with the fauour of the Coun≈øel, I may haue knowledge of the kings maie≈øties good plea≈øure, to geue thys preachers liuing vnto M. Grindall. Of late, there haue bene letters directed from the Kinges Maie≈øtie and his honourable Coun≈øell, vnto all the bi≈øhops, wherby we be charged & commauÃÑded, both in our own per≈øons, and al≈øo to cau≈øe our preachers & mini≈øters, e≈øpecially to crie out again≈øt the in≈øatiable ≈øerpeÃÑt of couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, whereby is ≈øayd to be ≈øuche a gredynes amonges the people, that eche one goeth about to deuour other: and to threaten theÃÑ with Gods greuous plagues, both now pre≈øently throweÃÑ vpon them, and that ≈øhalbe likewi≈øe in the worlde to come. Syr, what preachers ≈øhall I gette to open and ≈øet forth ≈øuche matters, and ≈øo as the Kings Maie≈øtie and the Coun≈øel do commaunde them to be ≈øet forth, if either vngodlye men, or vnrea≈øonable bea≈øtes bee ≈øuffered to pull awaye & deuoure the good and godlye learned preachers liuings? Thus I wy≈øhe you in god, euer wel to fare, & to helpe Chri≈øtes cau≈øe, as you would haue helpe of him at your mo≈øt nede. From Fulham this pre≈øent, the 23. of Iulie. 1551.

div.head: A letter of Cutbert Sym≈øon, to certayne of hys frendes concernyng hys Rackyng and other cruell tormentes which he ≈øuffred in the Tower.
div.p:
THe .13. daye of December, I was ≈øente to the Tower, and on the Thur≈ødaye after, I was called into the warehou≈øe before the Con≈øtable of the Tower and the Recorder of London, Mai≈øter Cholmeley. They commaunded me to tel them whom I dyd wil to come to the Engly≈øhe ≈øeruice. I aun≈øwered, I woulde declare nothyng.Thys Engine is called Skenyngtons Giues, wherin the body ≈øtandeth double, the head being draweÃÑ towardes the ≈øeete. The forme & maner of the≈øe Gyues, and of his Rackyng, you may ≈øee in the booke of Martyrs. Folio. 1631. Then was I ≈øet in an engine of Yron for the ≈øpace of .iij. houres as I iudged. After that they a≈øked me if I woulde tell them. I aun≈øweared as before. Then was I lo≈øed and caryed to my lodging agayne. On the Sundaye after, I was broughte into the ≈øame place agayne before the Lieutenant being al≈øo Con≈øtable, and the Recorder of London, and they examined me. As before I hadde ≈øayd, I aun≈øweared. Then the Lieutenaunt ≈øware by god, I ≈øhoulde tell. Then dyd they bynde my two forefyngers together, and putte a ≈ømall arrowe betwixt them, and drew it through ≈øo fa≈øte that the bloode followed, and the arrowe brake. Then they racked me twy≈øe. After that was I caryed to my lodging agayne, and tenne dayes after, the Lieuetenaunt a≈øked me if I woulde not confe≈ø≈øe that whi ‚Ä¢ he before they had a≈øked me. I ≈øayde, I had ≈øayde as muche as I woulde. Then fyue weekes after he ≈øent me vnto the hyghe prie≈øt, where I was greatlye a≈ø≈øaulted, and at who≈øe hande I receaued the Popes cur≈øe, for hearyng witne≈ø≈øe of the re≈øurrection of Ie≈øus Chri≈øte. And thus I commend you vnto God, and to the woorde of his grace, with all them that vnfaynedly call vppon the name of Ie≈øus, de≈øiring GOD of his endles mercy through the merites of hys deare ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, to bryng vs al to his euerla≈øtyng kingdome, Amen. I pray≈øe God for hys great mercy ≈øhewed vpon vs. Syng O≈øanna vnto the hyghe≈øt, with me Cutbert Sym≈øoÃÑ.
God forgeue me my ≈øinnes. I a≈øke al the world forgeuenes & I do forgeue al the world: and thus I leaue this worlde, in hope of a ioyfull re≈øurrection.

Cor. 2 becau≈øe the cro≈ø≈øe doth alwais accompany it: ≈øo that if you wil be a ≈øtudent hereof, you mu≈øt nedes prepare your ≈øelf to ye cro≈ø≈øe, which you began to learne before you learned your Alphabet: and Chri≈øt requireth it of euery one that wyll be his di≈øciple, therin not ≈øwaruing from the common trade of callings or vocations: for no profe≈ø≈øion or kind of life wanteth hys cro≈ø≈øe. div.head: A letter of Mai≈øter Thomas Leauer beyng then in exile for the testimonye of gods go≈øpell, to M. Bradford pri≈øoner in the tower of London.
div.p: THe grace of god be vnto you, wyth my harty commendations.

I haue ≈øene the places, noted the doctrine and di≈øcipline, and talked wyth the learned men of Argentine, Ba≈øyll, Zurich, Berne, Lau≈øan, and Geneua, and I haue had experience in all the≈øe places, of ≈øyncere doctryne, godly order, and great learnyng, and e≈øpecially of ≈øuche vertuous learning, diligence, and charitie in Bullinger at Zurich, and in Caluine at Geneua, as doth much aduaunce gods glory, vnto the edifying of Chri≈øtes church with the ≈øame religioÃÑ for the which you be now in pri≈øon. And as I dout not but you in readyng of their bookes, haue fouÃÑd much godly and comfortable knowledge, ≈øo I am ≈øure that they in hearyng of your con≈øtancy & patieÃÑce, take occa≈øioÃÑ greatly to reioyce, wyth thankes geuing vnto God, whiche doth te≈øtifye his truth vnto the worlde, not onely by their writyng, but al≈øo by your ≈øuffering. The lord therefore, which v≈øeth thys your ≈øuffering ioyned wyth godly learnyng, to ≈øet forth his glory, not onely vnto the comfort of ≈øimple ≈øoules in England, but al≈øo vnto the great reioycing & encouraging of ye mo≈øt godly learned men in al couÃÑtreis: wil (as I de≈øire and tru≈øt) geue you ≈øuche comforte in con≈øcience, as ≈øhall ea≈øely beare ye paines of your impri≈øonmeÃÑt. If you de≈øire to ≈øuffer or do that thing whiche mighte te≈øtifye the truth, aduaunce the glory, & edifye the church of Chri≈øt, truly you haue your de≈øire: yea and I en≈øure you, very many godlye men in diuers places, geue daily thankes vnto god in praier for you.

You know your cau≈øe is good: your frendes be in fauour, & your aduer≈øaries in di≈øplea≈øure wyth the almightye god, your heaueÃÑly father: your ≈øufferyng for the truth, ≈øhall not be vnrewarded: your hope in Chri≈øt ≈øhall neuer be confounded. For although your bodies bee kepte within pry≈øons,
yet your te≈øtimony vnto the truth, ≈øhyneth farre abroad in the world, and your faythfull prayers in charitable vnitie, ioyned wyth many others, be continually pre≈øented afore the throne of god. God graunt you grace to finde & v≈øe comfortable meditation of his worde, in diligent obedience vnto hys wyl. Chri≈øt be your keper in comfort, Amen.
